HEADLINE: HOCKEY;
Hockey's Owners Decide to Postpone Opening of Season

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
On what was scheduled to be the first day of the hockey season and next-to-last day of the baseball season, professional sports will rest today. Baseball is still shut down by a players' strike that today becomes the longest work stoppage in professional sports history, and yesterday the National Hockey League, against the wishes of its players, postponed the start of its season for at least two weeks.
Commissioner Gary Bettman of the N.H.L. announced yesterday that the season, scheduled to begin with 12 games tonight, would be delayed so the league and the players could continue negotiating a collective bargaining agreement. 
 Mr. Bettman said the league still hoped to play a full schedule of games, and targeted Oct. 15 as a new potential starting date. The commissioner denied that the league's action short-circuiting the new season constituted a lockout; he said he was simply postponing the start of the season.
But the head of the players' union, Bob Goodenow, said it was a "lockout, pure and simple." With the players ready to play and the owners not letting them, and the players not getting paid, the action has all the classic characteristics of a lockout.
This is the first time two major professional sports have been shut down at the same time. As if that trauma were not enough for fans in two countries, the National Basketball Association and its players do not have a new collective bargaining agreement, are waging their own dispute in the Federal court system and face a potential work-stopping confrontation when their season begins next month.
With only the National Football League operating, mainly on Sundays, following a labor dispute of its own that lasted six years, this promises to be an empty October for sports fans.
Innocent victims of a sports world consumed by fierce fights over player salaries, the fans won't see the World Series for the first time in 90 years, and they won't see the timely start of the hockey season only three and a half months after the New York Rangers' scintillating Stanley Cup championship climaxed what was probably the most successful season in N.H.L. history.
At a news conference at the New York Hilton, Mr. Bettman said: "I reject the notion that it is a lockout. It is a postponement because we could have our full season starting Oct. 15."
But the 75 games scheduled for tonight through Oct. 14 will not be played as scheduled, and the players will not begin earning their salaries tonight.
Further, players on four Canadian teams, those in the provinces of Ontario and Alberta, received lockout notices from their teams as is required under the provincial labor laws. However, the word "postponement" also appeared in the notices.
"It's an owners' lockout, pure and simple," Mr. Goodenow, the players' union leader, said in Toronto. Mr. Goodenow, however, said the players had agreed to continue negotiations. He said he would consult with union representatives today in Toronto before resuming the bargaining.
Mr. Bettman said the players were free to continue working out, but they said they would not.
"We're saying fine if the season is postponed, surely you can't expect us to come in and skate as if nothing happened," said Toronto's Mike Gartner, who is president of the players' association. "Something has happened. We've been locked out. That's a pretty serious thing to play under."
The action taken by Mr. Bettman and the owners of the league's 26 teams came in response to a union proposal made 24 hours earlier that the season proceed with a no-strike pledge from the players and a no-lockout pledge from the owners, while negotiations for a new labor agreement continued.
Mr. Bettman said the union's proposal was "particularly seductive." But he quickly explained that the league was deferring its decision on the idea because the owners are concerned "about the willingness of the players' association to negotiate."
In other words, the owners suspect that the players, who would be happy to play under the expired agreement, could plod along in the talks, and the two sides could reach the season's end without a new contract.
"Unless the players are prepared to negotiate a settlement," Mr. Bettman said, "simply agreeing to the no-strike pledge and playing for the year will only defer the inevitable and exacerbate the problem."
The commissioner, who in an impressive showing was supported by 28 owners and executives representing 20 teams, said the decision to open the season Oct. 15 would be based on the way talks proceed in the next two weeks. "We hope to be in a better position prior to Oct. 15, either to have a deal or know that there is substantial good-faith negotiations going on so that a deal is possible," Mr. Bettman said.
This is only the second work stoppage in N.H.L. history, but also the second in two-and-a-half years. The players struck for the first 10 days of April in 1992, though the missed games were made up.
The baseball strike, the eighth shutdown in that sport in 23 seasons, reached day No. 50 yesterday, matching the 50-day strike of 1981. Today it becomes the longest shutdown in professional sports history.
Mr. Bettman said yesterday the league planned to reschedule the missed 75 games throughout the remainder of the season and after the schedule is completed. Last season's playoffs ended June 14, and it's not likely that the league would want to stretch the post-season into July.
But Mr. Bettman also acknowledged that if the season doesn't start on Oct. 15, some games may be missed.
Because baseball has forsaken October, the N.H.L. had been expected to capitalize on the elimination of competing post-season games.
"We're very cognizant of a unique opportunity," Mr. Bettman said. "It's not just because baseball is not playing. It has to do with opportunities the sport has before it."
He referred to the increased interest in hockey, attested to by a five-year, $155 million television deal with the Fox network and soaring revenue from licensed merchandise. Mr. Bettman said the league's owners had to make "gut-wrenching decisions" after "these considerations were given a great deal of weight."
The Board of Governors, he said, concluded that "if this sport is to grow at all, it has to be on a solid foundation."
Although the owners talk of the need to create a revenue sharing pool for lower-revenue clubs -- which they say include 9 to 11 of the 26 franchises -- their primary concern is the escalation of player salaries. Mr. Bettman said salaries have tripled over the past four years, and over the past three years, "a collective profit has turned to a substantial collective loss."
To halt the escalation, the owners have proposed a tax system that would force teams to pay as much as a 20 percent tax on their payroll, depending on how far it goes beyond the league's average payroll. Under that system, the Rangers would have had to pay a levy of $3,965,000 on a payroll of $20,172,000 last season. That would have been the second highest levy in the league, behind Detroit's $4 million.
Pittsburgh, Los Angeles, St. Louis and Buffalo would also have been assessed steep taxes, and the union contends that the proposal is intended to force those six teams and perhaps others to reduce their payrolls, thus limiting the salaries their players can receive.
Addressing the owners' stated revenue-sharing concerns, the union has proposed a 5.5 percent tax on the payrolls and gate receipts of the 16 clubs with the highest revenues. That system, the union projects, would produce about $40 million to be shared by the low-revenue teams.
But the owners don't want to share gate receipts, and they say the tax rate would not place enough "drag" on salaries.
Several of the owners who accompanied Mr. Bettman at the news conference spoke of what they saw as the importance of creating a new economic system.

HEADLINE: Saudis and 5 Other Gulf Nations Will Ease Their Boycott of Israel

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to the New York Times 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 30

 BODY:
Saudi Arabia and its five Persian Gulf partners announced today that they were lifting parts of the 46-year-old Arab boycott of Israel and pledged to urge the rest of the Arab world to drop all trade restrictions involving the Jewish state.
Today's announcement reflects the dramatic changes in Arab attitudes toward Israel since the Palestinians made peace with it a year ago. It also is another concrete signal to the Israelis that making peace has its rewards. 
 In practical terms, the six members of the Gulf Cooperation Council will formally end the blacklisting of American and other foreign companies that trade with Israel. Even though a number of Arab countries have increasingly ignored the blacklist in the last year, some Western companies for either legal or psychological reasons have been reluctant to move ahead with investment and trade projects.
The move by the gulf nations does not affect the ban on Arab countries against trading directly with Israel.
However, the six gulf countries are expected to make other smaller but symbolically important gestures soon, senior Administration officials said. These include permitting tourists and business executives to enter their countries using passports that reflect travel to Israel, overflights by foreign airlines landing in Israel, transshipment of postal shipments through and to Israel and calls by foreign flagships that stop in Israeli ports as part of their itineraries.
The decision is a personal achievement for Secretary of State Warren Christopher, who has made the issue of opening up Arab markets to all American companies the centerpiece of Washington's policy toward the gulf nations. He characterized it as an important step toward lifting the Arab boycott in its entirety, which he said was "a key objective for the United States as we work to advance peace in the region."
In Jerusalem, Foreign Minister Shimon Peres welcomed the initiative as "an additional move in dismantling the walls of hatred and separation and boycott." Speaking to reporters, Mr. Peres added that those who applied the boycott "hurt themselves."
"The boycott has had a negative effect on the Arab countries as well because today markets are more important than countries and if you put limits to trade you limit your own capacity to trade in a changing world," he said.
The decision also brought quick praise from strong supporters of Israel on Capitol Hill. "For the first time I have some real hope that there are Arab states serious about ending the boycott against Israel," said Charles E. Schumer, the Brooklyn Democrat who is co-chairman of the Congressional Task Force to end the Arab boycott.
In their announcement today, the six countries -- Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, Oman, Bahrain, Qatar and the United Arab Emirates -- said that they would support an initiative in the Arab League to consider ending the boycott entirely. The announcement, read by Foreign Minister Prince Saud al-Faisal of Saudi Arabia after a meeting with Mr. Christopher, said that the six gulf countries recognized "the importance of a review of the provisions of the Arab boycott of Israel so as to take into consideration progress achieved and substantive future requirements of the peace process."
At its meeting of foreign ministers in Cairo in August, the Arab League refused to even put the boycott issue on the agenda. Ending the Arab boycott is "linked to assurances of progress on the Syrian and Lebanese tracks" and in "ending Israeli occupation of Arab lands occupied in 1967," said Esmat Abdel Meguid, the Egyptian who currently heads the Arab League.
The United States protested strongly, and in the aftermath went back to the six gulf countries and urged them to use their annual meeting with Mr. Christopher at the United Nations to take a bold step.
Administration officials credit the intense lobbying of Prince Bandar bin Sultan, the Saudi Ambassador to Washington, for bringing about today's decision. "Bandar was the key in unlocking it," one official said.
The Arabs have boycotted Israel since its creation in 1948 as a way to isolate the country and strangle its economy. The Arab League, which now has 21 members, imposed "secondary" and "tertiary" boycotts in 1951 on companies that did business in Israel and on companies that dealt with those on the blacklist.
The boycott has stood as a relic of history since the Israeli-Palestinian peace agreement last year. But both Syria and Lebanon want to preserve it as a means to win concessions from Israel in their own peace negotiations.
Acknowledging its irrelevance, a senior Arab gulf official told reporters today, "It is very hard to reconcile Palestinians signing economic agreements with Israel while we are also boycotting American companies or British or Japanese companies." He added, "You can't be more royalist than the king."
A senior Administration official described the decision as an initiative taken by the gulf states "not in coordination with the Syrians."
Today's move also helps insure the success of the Middle East/ North Africa economic summit meeting to be held in Casablanca at the end of October. It will bring together Israeli and Arab officials and foreign business executives in a major initiative to generate private trade and investment in the Middle East.
In the past year, a number of Arab countries have increasingly ignored the lesser boycott of companies that do business with Israel and of companies that do business with companies on the blacklist.
Kuwait, for example, announced its own decision to end the enforcement of those lesser boycotts last year. And in a tacit violation of the boycott, Jordan announced last month that it would sign a $55 million joint project with Motorola to operate the country's first cellular phone system, even though Motorola is a major trading partner of Israel.
Still, the bureaucratic tangles associated even with the lesser boycotts have frustrated American companies. Even though Oman, for example, has quietly taken steps to ignore the blacklist of companies trading with Israel, its bureaucrats have often decided otherwise. In the last year, Manhattan Shirt Company and Johnson & Murphy Shoes, both exporters to Israel, have had to seek the intercession of the State Department to get their products into Oman.
The Commerce Department still gets complaints from American companies against the Egyptians, even though Egypt officially ended its boycott of Israel when the two countries signed a peace treaty in 1979.
But today's decision will have an important economic impact on those foreign companies that want to do business with both Israel and the gulf countries. Bechtel, one of the world's largest investors in the Arab world, has traditionally avoided doing business in Israel. But the company is eager to invest in the $1 billion development project for the Jordan Rift Valley, and with today's decision, the risk of doing that has largely evaporated.
It may have less of an immediate economic impact on Israel. Now that Israel has relations with China and India, the world's two biggest emerging markets, the fact that it may soon be able to sell its products to a country like Saudi Arabia is not crucial to its economy. But the partial lifting of the boycott is expected to spur investment in Israel by Japanese companies, which have been reluctant to do so because of the boycott.

HEADLINE: Business Digest

 BODY:

The Economy
 
The Fed's policy decision on Aug. 16 to raise short-term interest rates by half a percentage point was unanimous and based partly on concerns that a smaller move would disappoint financial markets, a new summary of the meeting disclosed. [41.]
 
Consumer spending surged 0.9 percent in August, rising more than twice as fast as income, which gained 0.4 percent, as Americans flocked to auto showrooms. [51.]
 
 
International
 
Japanese and American negotiators swapped proposals late into the night in an 11th-hour push to agree on opening Japanese markets after 15 months of difficult talks. Partial agreements and partial American sanctions are expected. [41.]
 
MIL-Davie, the last big shipyard in Quebec, faces an uncertain future, despite an illustrious past. The yard, which is owned by the Province of Quebec, has been desperately trying to convert from military to civilian operations. [41.]
 
Mitsubishi Bank is taking a loss of more than $1 billion because of bad debts at two affiliated finance companies. [41.]
 
 
Companies
 
Woolworth's vice chairman and chief executive, William K. Lavin, resigned because of differences with the board over the retailer's direction. John W. Adams, the company's chairman, will assume Mr. Lavin's responsibilities on an interim basis. [41.]
 
G.M. and the U.A.W. tentatively settled a three-day-old strike at the Buick City complex in Flint, Mich., that had threatened to shut the company's production throughout North America. [7.]
 
Philip Morris confirmed that it was negotiating the possible sale of its Kraft food service business, which analysts valued at $600 million, to a party that it did not identify. [43.]
 
New Valley's creditors will consider the company's plan for reorganization alone, Bankruptcy Judge Novalyn Winfield ruled, tabling a shareholder plan to oust management. [43.]
 
ITT-Cablevision's $1 billion purchase of the Madison Square Garden properties from Viacom ran into an obstacle: Alan G. Hevesi, New York City's Comptroller, who indicated he might block the deal until Cablevision froze subscription rates. [43.]
 
Delays in interactive cable television experiments by U S West and Bell Atlantic caused by technological bottlenecks have led other telephone companies to hope they could get a competitive edge. But they, too, have hit snags. [43.]
 
 
Markets
 
Stocks closed mixed after computer-guided sell orders buffeted the Dow industrials. The Dow closed at 3,843.19, down 11.44 points for the day, the same amount it gained for the week. [42.]
 
Prices of Treasury securities rose, buoyed by investors' optimism that the United States and Japan would reach a trade pact. [49.]
 
The dollar surged against the yen only to fall back from its highs when no trade pact was reached. It ended up at 99.15 yen. [40.]
 
Wheat futures prices topped $4 a bushel for the first time in 18 months. The Agriculture Department reported low stocks. [40.]
 
 
Your Money
 
Money market mutual funds are charging investors fees for some expenses that they had absorbed during recent years when interest rates were low. [38.]
 
Lehman Brothers nosed ahead of Smith Barney in its top 10 stock picks for the third quarter. Both well outpaced the 4.15 percent advance of the S.& P. 500. [38.]
 
A New York law that is intended to protect surviving spouses may have the unintended effect of making it difficult to pass on a family business. [39.]

HEADLINE: Fed August Rate Rise Based In Part on Market Concerns

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30

 BODY:
The decision by the Federal Reserve's top interest-rate policy committee on Aug. 16 to raise short-term interest rates by half a percentage point was unanimous and based partly on concerns that a smaller move would disappoint financial markets, according to a summary of the meeting issued today.
 "Consideration was given to a lesser adjustment in reserve conditions," said the summary, which is written in central bank and financial market jargon. "Reserve conditions" and "further monetary tightening" both can be read as interest-rate increases.
 
 "But the members concluded that a smaller step was unlikely to be adequate," the Fed's official report on the Aug. 16 meeting said, "and on perceiving this, financial markets would quickly build in further monetary tightening, the unknown size and timing of which would add to market uncertainty and volatility."
 Bond traders and analysts had said at the time that a smaller increase might make the central bank look soft on inflation and send long-term interest rates higher as investors worried that inflation would erode their returns.
 Marc W. Wanshel, an economist at J. P. Morgan in New York, said this evening that this concern at the Fed was significant because it meant that the Fed might continue its apparent pattern since May of raising interest rates in half-point increments every two months. By contrast, the Fed raised rates by a quarter-point in February, March and April this year.
 "It would seem to suggest that when they move again, they'd go half a point," he said, predicting that the next move could come in October or, at the latest, at the policy committee's next meeting on Nov. 15.
 The panel, officially known as the Federal Open Market Committee, met on Tuesday but adjourned without changing interest rates at all.
 On Aug. 16, the committee raised its target for the Federal funds rate to 4.75 percent from 4.25 percent. Banks pay the Federal funds rate for overnight loans from other banks, and the Federal Reserve indirectly controls this rate by buying and selling Government bonds, thereby adding or subtracting from banks' reserves of lendable cash.
 The Fed had previously raised the Federal funds rate by half a percentage point on May 17 and by a quarter percentage point each on Feb. 4, March 22 and April 18.
 The Federal Reserve board of governors also raised the discount rate, which banks pay for overnight loans from the Fed, to 4 percent from 3.5 percent on Aug. 16. The only other increase in the discount rate this year, also a half-point move, came on May 18.
 The Fed's concern about financial markets' reaction to a possible small increase on Aug. 16 irked Democratic members of Congress who have already been critical of higher interest rates. "I think this just bears out and is confirmation of the view that the Fed is overly concerned about Wall Street's reaction and not concerned enough about what's happening on Main Street," said Senator Jim Sasser, the Tennessee Democrat who is the chairman of the Budget Committee.
 Sung W. Sohn, the chief economist at the Norwest Corporation, a bank holding company in Minneapolis, said that the Federal Open Market Committee's unanimity on the final vote probably reflected its members' desire to show a united front.
The committee's members are the seven governors of the Federal Reserve Board and the presidents of the 12 Federal Reserve regional banks. All of the governors and five of the presidents vote at each meeting, with the presidents taking turns in holding the power to vote.
 The decision to raise rates reflected a concern among many members of the committee that the economy was operating at full capacity, today's summary said, so that any further increase in consumer and business spending might result in bidding up the price of a limited supply of goods without actually bringing about any further increases in production. "In their assessment of the outlook for inflation, many members focused on the prospects for further growth in output in the context of diminishing margins of unemployed production resources," the summary said.
 The Fed reduces the spending power of Americans by raising interest rates, which makes everything from credit cards to home mortgages more expensive and leaves people with less disposable cash.
 The committee also concluded that most of the nation's sharp increase in business inventories during the second quarter mainly reflected voluntary decisions by companies to offer more goods for sale. Some private economists had speculated that the rise in inventories resulted from an unwanted accumulation of unsold goods.
 The Fed released its report after the close of trading on financial markets today.

HEADLINE: Late Computer Orders Lower the Dow by 11.44

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Stocks closed mixed yesterday after computer-guided sell orders buffeted the Dow Jones industrial average in the session's final half-hour, causing the Dow to register its second straight decline.
 "With the quarter ending, people unload some of the losers just to get them off their books," Jeffrey Rubin, an analyst at Birinyi Associates Inc. in Greenwich, Conn., said.
 
 The computer orders shaved 17 points off the average, undercutting a rally by the Philip Morris Companies that led the Dow to gain nearly 21 points earlier in the session. The average closed at 3,843.19, down 11.44 points for the day, the same amount it gained for the week. For the third quarter, the Dow rose 218.23 points, or 6 percent.
 Stocks took direction yesterday from developments in trade talks aimed at narrowing Japan's $60 billion trade surplus with the United States, traders said. Preliminary reports that a partial agreement had been reached that would avert sanctions on Japan helped the dollar and bonds rally, bolstering stocks for much of the session. No official announcement on the results of the talks is scheduled until today.
 The speculation of progress in the talks helped offset a Commerce Department report that showed consumer spending increased in August by a larger-than-expected nine-tenths of 1 percent, amid strong demand for autos. The rise could encourage the Federal Reserve to raise short-term interest rates again during the next few weeks.
 Among broader market measures, the Standard & Poor's 500 index rose 0.48 point, to 462.71. The Nasdaq composite index jumped 4.95 points, to 764.29. The American Stock Exchange Market Value Index climbed 2.34 points, to 458.81.
 Advancing issues on the New York Stock Exchange outnumbered decliners, 1,303 to 850. Big Board trading was active, with about 295.8 million shares changing hands.
 The Anheuser-Busch Companies fell 1 1/8, to 50 7/8. The maker of beer and snack foods was dropped from Goldman, Sachs's recommended-for-purchase list by an analyst, Marc Cohen, on concern about beer sales.
 The Allegheny & Western Energy Corporation surged 1 7/8, to 10 5/8. The oil and gas company said it had received a merger offer from an undisclosed suitor worth $12 a share.
 Appliance Recycling Centers of America Inc. fell 2 3/4, to 5 3/4. The provider of recycling services for household appliances said a proposed change in tax laws could have a "significant adverse impact" on operating results beginning in 1995.
 C-Cor Electronics Inc. jumped 4, to 39 1/4. The maker of electronic equipment for use in cable television expects first-quarter earnings at or above analysts' estimates.
 In Tokyo, the Nikkei index of 225 issues fell 51.31 points, or 0.26 percent, to 19,563.81.

HEADLINE: U.S.-Japan Talks Head To the Wire

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30

 BODY:
Japanese and American negotiators swapped proposals late into the night in an 11th-hour push to reach agreements on opening Japanese markets after 15 months of acrimonious talks. Both sides said the most likely result would be partial agreements and partial American sanctions on Japan.
 A deal opening Japan's closed insurance market, officials said, is virtually certain, as well as an agreement on opening Japanese Government purchases of telecommunications and medical equipment. The latter became possible when Japanese negotiators arrived late today with new language on how the two sides would measure whether Japan was following through on its promises to open these markets.
 
 As negotiators worked into the night they said there was a slim chance they could strike a deal opening the closed Japanese glass market, but there seemed little hope for an agreement that would induce Japanese companies to purchase more American autos and auto parts.
 The Administration has said it will initiate proceedings to impose economic sanctions on Japan if there is no progress on glass and autos. But it has stressed that any sanctions would have a specific target, would take some time to go into effect and should not undermine the overall economic relationship between the world's two biggest economies.
 The Japanese have almost 100 trade negotiators, experts and aides in Washington for the talks -- almost equal to the entire staff of the United States trade representative's office.
 Financial markets in New York and Tokyo watched nervously as the United States trade representative, Mickey Kantor, and Foreign Minister Yohei Kono and Trade Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto of Japan engaged in their marathon, all-night negotiating session to determine what was possible and what was not. They are not expected to adjourn until noon Saturday, when Mr. Kantor will announce the results and any American sanctions.
 Billions of dollars have been bet in the currency and bond markets on hunches as to where these talks will end up. Any deal, even one that involved limited, focused sanctions on Japan, would probably help to strengthen the dollar, as traders conclude that the Americans will not have to rely solely on a weak dollar and strong yen to bring down Japan's $60 billion trade surplus. If there are no agreements, the dollar may be hammered, and the yen may soar.
 The dollar was up against the yen today in New York, reflecting anticipation that slightly more good news than bad will come out of the talks. Several big money managers are believed to have hedged their dollar bets by going short in the bond market -- meaning that if the talks fail and the bond market goes down, as it did last time, they will not lose as much by betting on the dollar.
 When the Administration initiated the idea of these framework negotiations with Japan in July 1993, it hoped to be able to announce a package deal of market-opening measures. Such a package was to include Japanese purchases of American autos and auto parts, insurance, telecommunications equipment and medical technology.
 After 15 months of frustrating negotiations, the Administration has resigned itself to a different strategy -- one of basically cutting whatever deals it can in these different areas, and initiating sanctions in areas where no satisfaction is forthcoming from Tokyo.
 The main problem has been Japanese refusal to accede to an American demand that any market-opening deals they agree to include specific yardsticks, known as "objective criteria," to measure whether Japan is really living up to the agreement. The Japanese say this amounts to setting import targets.
 The most likely deal in the area of insurance would involve a Japanese agreement to eliminate rules requiring American companies to consult with Japanese competitors before introducing products. There also would be some way to measure the approval rate for foreign companies wanting to sell insurance in the highly regulated Japanese market.
 In the area of Japanese Government procurement, the American side has been asking Tokyo to increase, from what is now a very low level, the amount of American medical equipment and telecommunications equipment it purchases. This is entirely in the hands of the Japanese Government to do. The Japanese have indicated a general willingness to comply and the two sides have basically been arguing over what should be the minimum level of purchases against which they can measure whether Japan is buying more each year.
 The areas that pose the biggest problem, though, are autos and auto parts, which make up two-thirds of Japan's $60 billion trade surplus with the United States. Here, there are three issues. First, the United States wants the Japanese Government to reduce regulations and inspection requirements, which Tokyo has used to limit imports of replacement auto parts. This is a multibillion-dollar market, of which the Americans have only a tiny share. There has been some progress on this issue, but Tokyo has been hesitant to make concessions, since it could mean fewer Japanese jobs.
 The Americans' other automotive demands are greater purchases by Japanese companies of original auto parts for Japanese cars made in Japan and the United States, as well as more access for American car makers to Japan's dealer showrooms.
 These are areas that are basically in the hands of private Japanese auto companies, which in the past have tended to work together to restrict American access to their markets. But these companies have also had complaints about the quality of American parts and the willingness of American manufacturers to make cars with steering wheels on the right side, since the Japanese drive on the left side of the road. The Americans have been seeking the Japanese Government's help in dealing with Japanese auto makers.

HEADLINE: Artist Returns to His Beloved Mural

BYLINE: By N. R. KLEINFIELD 

 BODY:
He had been exquisitely reliable about it, turning up like an apparition every 13 or 14 years to inspect and, if necessary, retouch his cherished mural of mirthful children parading across the school walls. But he would be old now, if he were even still alive. Was there a chance he would return again?
In 1939, Herman Simms, a 29-year-old artist kept off the bread lines by the Works Progress Administration, painted a mural in the entranceway of Public School 216 in Gravesend, Brooklyn. It was his first mural, and he did only two more. It took him eight months. He was paid $20 a week. 
 Even after he settled in California, his affection for the mural nudged him to return to see how it was doing. It mattered that it was his first big work, and it mattered that the boy playing the violin was his nephew and the woman in the hat reading a story was his first wife.
The last visit occurred in 1980, the year before Richard Breyer became principal of the elementary school, which is named the Arturo Toscanini School. As years passed, aware of the custom and intensely proud of the mural, the spirited Mr. Breyer wondered if Mr. Simms might return one more time. He began to search for him. He enlisted his youngest daughter, Elizabeth, an art history expert who worked for the Mellon Foundation. Nobody knew where Herman Simms was.
"For all I knew, he was dead," Mr. Breyer said. "He had been like Halley's Comet, but humans don't live as long as comets." He doubted he would return.
On Thursday afternoon, it was the usual mad bustle around the principal's office. "At about 1:30, I hear my assistant principal on the phone," Mr. Breyer said. "He turns to me and says: 'Do you know a Herman Simms? He's asking for you.' I practically leapt at him and said, 'Give me that phone.' I told him I'd been looking for him, and he said, that's O.K., he'd be at the school at 10 the next morning. He wanted to know how the mural looked. I said, 'Like the day you put it up.' "
Herman Simms was decidedly robust for 84, coming through the door yesterday in a light jacket and soft loafers. He was a small man with luminous eyes. Smiling shyly, he peered at his 55-year-old work, "Children in Vocational Activities and Children in Directed and Undirected Play," and gave an approving nod. "I'm amazed," he said. "It still looks good."
"Yes," Mr. Breyer said, "we flog any student who touches it."
Mr. Breyer had to ask him a question: was the rumor true that Hannah Nash, a much-beloved music instructor at the school to whom the mural was dedicated, was in fact the music teacher portrayed in the mural?
"No, she was no one in particular," Mr. Simms said, quickly scotching that, but revealing the likenesses of his nephew and now-deceased first wife, who were actually not a student or teacher at P.S. 216.
Mr. Simms said he hadn't painted in a year, after a crowded life of fashion illustration and portrait painting. Portraits were his meal ticket. He was a fixture at malls near his Newport Beach, Calif., home. For several years, he produced portraits at Disneyland, productively enough that he said he was marked down for inclusion in the "Guinness Book of World Records" when he dashed off more than 9,000 faces in 1975. That fame evaporated after two years, when another strong arm finished 46 more, and eventually the record no longer even made it into the book of oddities.
"This is great for him," beamed Marcella, his wife, as she watched him dutifully slide his hand over the mural. "He's been a little sad on the trip. Things have been getting on his nerves. But look at him there."
One piece of the mural dealt with classroom activities -- music instruction, home economics and wood shop. The companion piece depicted recreation -- baseball, marbles, tug-of-war. When he stopped by in 1980, Mr. Simms found that the shop teacher's hand and the ear of a boy were messed up. He spent four days touching up those blemishes and darkening some faded colors.
This time, he decided that the colors had held up well. "I could always find something," he said. "It seems like some areas are a little lighter than they should be. But I'll leave it alone for now."
He rewound time to sum up his past. As he sharpened his art skills during the Depression, he worked as a bellhop at the New Yorker Hotel, making $2 a day. He quit after two years and used his savings, and then some, to finance a trip to Europe. When he returned, owing $100, he became one of thousands of unemployed artists hired by the W.P.A.
His first assignment was P.S. 216, and he followed that with a mural of chemists at work for a bank in Wilmington, Del., and a scene of canal workers that hangs in a post office in Tipp City, Ohio. He has not been back to retouch either of them, but was going to see if he could find the Wilmington mural this weekend.
After the Depression lifted, he did fashion and portrait work in New York -- he had a stand at the Orange County State Fair -- before moving to Newport Beach, where he still lives.
Mr. Simms shook hands with some admiring teachers and students, basking in the aura of appreciation. Before the painter left, the principal had some parting words. "I expect to see you the next cycle," he said, "when you're about 97 or 98."
"All right," Mr. Simms said, evincing no doubt, and he disappeared out the door.

GRAPHIC: Photos: The allure of a first love is seldom forgotten. So too with an artist's first work. After an absence of nearly 14 years, he returned yesterday to the school, now the Arturo Toscanini School, and stood next to his work. "I'm amazed," he said, approvingly, "It still looks good."; A plaque dedicates the mural to Hannah Nash. ((Ruby Washington/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: 0.9% Increase In Spending In August

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30

 BODY:
Americans flocked to auto showrooms in August, and overall spending rose faster than it had in six months. The surge was more than twice the increase in income, the Government reported today.
 The Commerce Department said income rose four-tenths of a percent, a seventh straight increase, while spending jumped nine-tenths of a percent -- the largest gain since 1.3 percent in February.
 
 Consumer spending, the largest force driving economic expansion, was up for the fourth straight month. While the latest rise was more than many analysts expected, they noted that it was in line with recent data suggesting that there was considerable strength in the economy.
 The income and spending figures followed reports on Thursday that pointed to continued expansion.
 The Commerce Department also reported that disposable income -- income after taxes -- rose five-tenths of a percent in August. In July, personal income increased five-tenths of a percent while spending rose three-tenths of a percent, revised upward from a previous estimate of two-tenths.
 The combination of incomes and spending put the savings rate -- savings as a percentage of disposable income -- at 3.8 percent in August down from 4.2 percent in July.
 Wages and salaries, the most closely watched component of income, increased $7.9 billion in August after rising $14.4 billion in July. Government wages and salaries rose $100 million in August, on top of a $900 million gain in July.
 Spending for long-lasting items like cars and appliances rose 4.2 percent in August to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $601 billion. Spending for nondurable goods like food and fuel rose five-tenths of a percent, to $1.405 trillion, and spending for services was up four-tenths of a percent, to $2.661 trillion.

HEADLINE: Bonds Rise As Trade Pact Is Seen

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities rose yesterday, buoyed by investors' optimism that the trade talks between the United States and Japan could produce an agreement.
 A report, later denied, of an agreement on Japanese Government procurement contracts bolstered the dollar in the world currency markets, making dollar-denominated assets like bonds more attractive.
 
 In addition, the Commodity Research Bureau index of 21 commodity futures, considered a leading indicator of inflation, fell 0.82 point, to 229.85, easing investor concern about rising prices for basic goods.
 The price of the 30-year bond rose 11/32 , to 9614/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, fell to 7.81 percent, from 7.84 percent on Thursday. Shorter-maturity issues were mixed.
 The bond market responded positively to several economic reports released yesterday. The Commerce Department said personal incomes rose four-tenths of 1 percent in August, compared with an increase of five-tenths of 1 percent in July, while consumer spending jumped nine-tenths of 1 percent. The numbers were in line with the market's expectations.
 The Chicago purchasing managers' index for September, released yesterday, indicated continued growth for that region's economy, but with the price component of the index declining significantly for the month.
 The purchasing managers' report included a healthy rise in the employment component, to 54.5 points, from 50.2. Production fell 9.3 points, to a still strong 65.9, while new orders edged up to 66. The order backlog eased 1.5 points, to 54.4, but vendor delivery time continued a troublesome climb, to 62.9, up 3.1 points from last month. The high vendor delivery time suggests developing bottlenecks that are potentially inflationary, analysts said.
 Even though the overall price index retreated this month, analysts still noted that its reading of 72.1 points was the second highest since the Persian Gulf war.
 There was little of significance in yesterday's numbers, said Herbert L. Davidson, senior vice president of Meyers, Pollock, Robbins Inc. in Tysons Corner, Va. "As a result, people are now hoping that the Fed will wait until November before hiking rates, giving the market a little relief until then," he said.
 Mr. Davidson said that yesterday's trading included substantial short-covering -- purchases by traders who had sold bonds that they had borrowed in expectations of a drop in price and were now buying to cover their positions.

HEADLINE: Shipyard Full of Worry in Quebec

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: LAUZON, Quebec

 BODY:
Wooden sailing ships, steel steamships, destroyers, frigates, icebreakers, ferries, freighters and tankers have been launched at the MIL-Davie shipyard here since Allison Davie founded the company in 1829. But now the future is uncertain for the last big shipyard in Quebec.
 A Canadian Navy destroyer, the Huron, is getting an electronic overhaul, one of the yard's last big contracts. When the Huron sails for sea trials at the end of November, employment will plummet to 300 from the current 1,200, already well below the 2,250 workers employed at the end of last year and the 3,200 at the end of 1992. Without new work, shipbuilding here could go the way of buggy whip making.
 
 Like many shipyards in North America, MIL-Davie, which is owned by the Province of Quebec, has been desperately trying to convert from military to civilian operations. It has drawn up plans to fill a niche market of 40,000- to 70,000-ton bulk carriers and tankers. Two American yards, Newport News in Virginia and Avondale in Louisiana, are working on similar concepts.
 But while military orders have dried up, the commercial shipbuilding industry has yet to see any sharp pickup in demand.
 And compounding the competitive pressure is an increase in civilian shipbuilding capacity in South Korea, Russia, other former Soviet republics and Poland.
Guy C. Veronneau, MIL-Davie's president and chief executive, readily acknowledges that he is uneasy about the yard's future -- though if it can just survive the next few years, he said, better times are ahead, as the many old tankers and freighters now in service finally give out.
 In the meantime, his workers feel the pressure in this town just half a dozen miles down the St. Lawrence River from the provincial capital, Quebec.
 Henri Pelletier, a 40-year-old who has worked here for 24 years as a marine mechanic, seemed oblivious to the surrounding hills blazing with autumn colors. Among his co-workers there is "much fear," he said, adding that he and his wife worry about what kind of Christmas their children will enjoy, if new business is not found for the shipyard.
 Enter the newly elected provincial government under the separatist Parti Quebecois.
 Many Quebecers who voted for the Parti Quebecois see MIL-Davie, with its nearly blank order book and looming layoffs, as a symbol of a failed federalism.
 "The federal Government could have done something earlier," said Jean Garon, who represents Lauzon in the Quebec Assembly, to which he was recently re-elected with 83 percent of the vote. "But it gave orders to New Brunswick and Newfoundland, even as two other shipbuilders in Quebec had to shut down."
 The new provincial government, he pledged, "will maintain this shipyard as a going concern." The party's leader and Quebec's new Premier, Jacques Parizeau, said something similar when he campaigned a few weeks ago.
 Yet in this era of rocketing government debt and tight budgets, the question is just how much government can do.
 Mr. Garon wants Ottawa to spend $100 million (United States) on a new ferry from Prince Edward Island to Magdalen Island in the Gulf of St. Lawrence. The existing ferry is 30 years old.
 In addition, he said, the federal Government should order a prototype for a new fleet of Navy supply vessels known as Smart ships (for strategic multi-role aid replenishment transport), which cost about $150 million each. Such a fleet could swiftly deploy a battalion of peacekeepers to a foreign crisis spot and provide takeoff and landing sites for helicopters, he said.
 And if the federal Government in Ottawa balks, Mr. Garon said Quebec itself should order a ferry and use it to open a new provincial service from the tip of the Gaspe Peninsula to Magdalen.
 Both Gaspe and Magdalen are part of Quebec. Because the existing Prince Edward Island-Magdalen service is inter-provincial, it comes under federal jurisdiction.
 With MIL-Davie's high visibility in Quebec, many analysts expect the Parti Quebecois to stick by its campaign pledge to save the yard. Pierre Fortin, an economist at the University of Quebec at Montreal, said that the spending on a Gaspe-Magdalen ferry could be easily defended as an investment.
 There is still a possibility that the federal Government could order a replacement ferry from Lauzon because of the age of the existing ship. Ottawa faces a difficult choice, however, because another big shipyard, Saint John Shipbuilding Ltd., owned by the Irving family of New Brunswick, would also like to get the business. Saint John now has more navy contracts than Lauzon does.
 Mr. Veronneau, the head of MIL-Davie, insists that the yard is proposing valid projects, not white elephants. The Smart ships and the ferry, he said, would be "useful for the federal Government."
 Even though MIL-Davie is government-owned, Mr. Veronneau said, his mandate is to run it "as a private and profitable company." Indeed, he said, should the shipbuilding industry recover, the government would sell the company to investors. "The Quebec government," he asserted, "has no business in shipbuilding."
For now, projects like the ferry and naval transports are needed to carry MIL-Davie until the expected surge of new commercial orders to replace aging cargo vessels and tankers.
 Nearly half the tankers on the high seas are at least 15 years old, and of tankers exceeding 200,000 tons, 70 percent are in that category. The useful life of a ship is 22 years. In the next 10 years, many analysts say, half the world fleet of tankers may have to be replaced. Freighters have a similar age profile.
 "People are surprised that so many ships have stayed operational for so long," said Stuart Nicoll, deputy editor of Lloyd's Shipping Economist of London, a monthly magazine covering the shipping market. "A phenomenal amount of shipbuilding will be needed. The debate is over when the surge will take place. Some say two to three years, others say four to five."
 Will the Quebec yard be competitive? Yes, insists Mr. Veronneau, a 57-year-old former international marketing vice president for the transport conglomerate Bombardier Inc., which is based in Montreal.
 Ten years ago, he noted, Japan and Germany were paying lower wages. Today Germany's wages are higher than Canada's, and Japan's are about the same. South Korea still has an advantage, but the gap is closing, with South Korea's wages only about 25 percent below Quebec's. At MIL-Davie, average pay is about $13.30 (United States) an hour.
 "There should be a lot of room for a lot of people," he commented in an office looking out on huge dockside cranes that stand mostly idle. "You don't have to be No. 1. There are 300 shipyards in the world, and you only need to be in the first third."

Henri Pelletier, a marine mechanic, right, says there is "much fear" of unemployment among his co-workers, who include, from left, Jacques Goupil and Richard Croteau. (Patrice LaRoche for The New York Times)(pg.41)

HEADLINE: THE 1994 CAMPAIGN: STORM WARNINGS;
Whitman May Face Rough Weather After Extending Tax-Cut Timetable

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TRENTON, Sept. 30

 BODY:
Gov. Christine Todd Whitman will probably weather the stormlet that followed her admission on Thursday that she would not be able to deliver her hallmark income-tax cut on time, both Democrats and Republicans conceded today. The far tougher test will be how she handles the state's budget problems that are now beginning to surface because of those same tax-cut pledges.
 When it comes to popularity, the feeling around the State House, and in the offices of academics and political consultants, is that Mrs. Whitman has more going for her among the voters than just her dramatic promise to cut income taxes by 30 percent over three years. Her popularity also rests on an artfully conveyed image as a reformer and an outsider.
 
 "She's managed not to become an incumbent," Steven Salmore, a professor of political science at Rutgers, said. With such a reputation, an admission that reforming New Jersey's tax system proved harder than expected is probably a forgivable sin.
 But the Democrats believe that voters will be less forgiving of the fallout from reductions in state aid to schools and municipalities.
 For the region's Democrats, who have often been on the defensive on the tax issue lately, Mrs. Whitman's shift was also a chance to score some easy points. At a ground-breaking ceremony in Brooklyn today, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo worked the news of Mrs. Whitman's altered tax timetable into his campaign against George E. Pataki, his Republican rival.
 "They thought they had a good thing in Jersey, right?" said the Governor, who has dismissed Mr. Pataki's own tax-cut pledge as unworkable. "Keep reading the papers over there."
 There are some who feel that Mrs. Whitman's concession -- that it may take her four years to complete the second half of a 30 percent income-tax reduction she had frequently and unshakably promised to accomplish in three -- may actually work to her advantage.
 "Ironically, Whitman may come out of this looking less like a strident fiscal conservative and more like a pragmatic public servant," said David Rebovich, a political science professor at Rider University in Lawrenceville. "She could easily be seen as someone who tries to help the public with a tax cut when she can, but who is also candid enough to level with folks when the state fiscal situation prevents a tax giveback."
 Republicans, for their part, showed no sign of being worried about the aftermath of the Governor's admission.
 "So she didn't deliver her tax cut on the year and the day and minute? No sweat," said David Murray, a Republican media consultant in Trenton. "Is she going back on her promise? Technically, yes. Does it matter? No."
 Governor Whitman's tax-cut pledge, coupled with a broad promise to attack government waste and restore New Jersey's economic competitiveness, has set a pattern in the campaigns of other Republicans in the region who have also taken up the tax-cut theme.
 At an appearance by Mr. Pataki in Rochester today, Democratic Party workers who have been dogging the Republican's campaign handed out copies of newspaper stories about the Whitman admission.
 But gloating over a tax-cut setback is hardly a commanding campaign theme to take to a public that is rooting for the Governor to succeed. With the passage of a day, New Jersey Democrats refocused their arguments away from the tax-cut schedule and back to their overarching theme: that Mrs. Whitman cannot pay for her tax cuts without driving up property taxes and disrupting public education and state services.
 The tax cut stretch-out is not fatal in itself, the Democrats said. But it is one of many inconsistencies they see in Mrs. Whitman's first term.
 Brendan T. Byrne Jr., chairman of the state Democratic party, said that Mrs. Whitman had also backed down in what seemed like an ironclad pledge not to allow public college tuitions to increase more than 3.6 percent. She has also recently raised the possibility of increasing motor fuel taxes and highway tolls to replenish the state's transportation trust fund.
 Even something as trivial as Governor Whitman's recent use of the state helicopter, which she criticized her predecessor, Jim Florio, for doing in office, formed part of the Democrats' response.
 Mrs. Whitman must close a gap of more than $2 billion in the budget that will begin next July before even factoring in $700 million in state income, which will have been lost to tax cuts that are already on the books by the end of the 1996 budget year.
 The coming fight over apportioning the pain of the necessary cuts will make any arguments over the timing of her tax cut look small, Democrats said today.
 William J. Pascrell Jr., an Assembly Democrat who is also Mayor of Paterson, said: "I look at the commitments she's made, and I think the worst is yet to come. The state of New Jersey under Whitman is going to do to the towns of this state what the Reagan Administration did to the states, and it's going to be World War III."

HEADLINE: Pataki's Rockefeller Lesson: Smile Makes a Better Point

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ROCHESTER, Sept. 30

 BODY:
The candidate saw the placard-bristling protesters waiting in the parking lot and immediately thought back two decades to his boss, Vice President Nelson A. Rockefeller, and what came to be known infamously as The Gesture.
"He made a gesture that in retrospect he shouldn't have," said State Senator George E. Pataki, recalling Mr. Rockefeller's single-digit dismissal of a group of hecklers that was caught on camera as his young advance man, Mr. Pataki, memorized a frightening lesson in how not to behave in his Republican campaign for Governor. 
 "I saw the protesters and I was thinking back to Binghamton and that gesture," Mr. Pataki explained later of his instant decision to bound directly from his car and offer a friendly smile and flat open palm of welcome this morning to each of the 18 Democrats waiting to question and denounce his new campaign promise to enact broad, deep income tax cuts.
The so-called truth squad was out in behalf of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, and Mr. Pataki was trying some gesture-free adaptation.
"I learned it doesn't have to be that confrontational," he said after completing his barnstorming news conference here in which, indeed, the Democrats stood mutely and politely to the rear with their protest signs while the old Republican advance man had the microphone and campaigned hard, with nothing more graphic than a fist of exhortation to get out the Pataki vote.
"Let people know you're human and you care about them even if they disagree with you," the Senator said afterward, taking care to wave a smiling goodbye to the silent Democratic campaign group, one of many being deputized as he races these days across a chain of snapshot appearances in northern New York.
Mr. Pataki has something of a mixed reputation as a campaigner who can deliver a set speech with a wooden tone and little talent for ad-libbing. His partisans held their breath in Manhattan on Wednesday when the Senator twice lost his place in the speech unveiling his keystone campaign stratagem, the tax-cut promise, before the Citizens Budget Commission. Nervous silence and tittering ensued in the hall as the Senator fell silent, groping to resume.
At the other extreme, aides say his natural strength is in relating simply to people along the campaign way. He obviously likes mixing with them for handshakes and greetings, as here. But he can linger in ways that leave his managers anxious that the candidate not veer controversially from the current tight format of being perceived thus far in opinion polls as a fast moving, relatively mistake-free front-runner.
Then, too, Mr. Pataki, ever his own best advance man, can visibly step up the travel pace when behind schedule as on Thursday in Syracuse. The candidate gave a hurried rendition of his tax-cut promise then shook each hand at departure in a high-speed blur-cum-mantra: "With your help. With your help. With your help . . . ."
The Democratic organization devoted to Mr. Cuomo's re-election bid was up early here in Monroe County this morning, marshaling a dozen union protesters with signs ("The Pataki Plan: Increase LOCAL Taxes"). They distributed freshly faxed handbills of the latest State House news stories from Trenton that Gov. Christine Todd Whitman had begun stepping away from her own tax-cut pledge that is a model for the Pataki plan.
After shaking the protesters' hands and clapping Republican workers on the back, Mr. Pataki briskly summarized his "dramatic and real" tax-cut promise, using no text, playing up the working class tax burden and repeatedly denying that, in reining in state spending and taxes, he would force localities to take up the slack in services and spending. "I was a Mayor and I know it doesn't help one bit if we cut state taxes and shift the burden to the county government and the school districts," he said, rebutting one of Mr. Cuomo's main criticisms.
"We have a cushion in there," he insisted at a similar 20-minute stop today in Buffalo. He contended his proposal for a four-year income tax cut of $5.6 billion was little more than half of the $11 billion he estimated would be available in state revenue growth.
At each stop in a long campaign day, Mr. Pataki was flourishing his new summary applause line: "Mario Cuomo says he can't cut taxes. He's right. He can't, but we can. And we will."
Sandra White, one of the Democrats sent to intercept the Senator here as he used an abandoned corporate headquarters for tele-visual effect, listened carefully after receiving Mr. Pataki's disarming welcome and handshake. "My initial feeling from listening to him is if he could do what he promised, then I'd say it doesn't matter who my candidate is," allowed Ms. White, an economically pressed highway worker and member of laborers Local 435.
She picked up her tiny dog, Kiki, when it started yapping during the candidate's speech. "It's time for the lies to stop just to be elected, you know," she said, echoing the demonstrators' common theme. "But his speech was good."
Others in the protest group insisted that the Pataki tax-cut vow was transparently unworkable with fictitious revenue estimates and Draconian service cuts, and that Governor Cuomo was the only proven tax-cutter in the race.
For all the electronic-media dependency of modern campaigning, a candidate still flits across the upstate hustings like an old-fashioned drummer, in town just long enough to proffer the latest notions from his sample case and deny the competition's charge that he is another peddler of nostrums and placebos.
"I like the give and take," Mr. Pataki said. He smiled and shepherded his entourage off to the next stop through the day's autumnal nip and mellowing foliage, a timeless reminder of gubernatorial campaigning across the state. "This is all very familiar," said the old advance man.

HEADLINE: ON HOCKEY;
Trust Is a Stranger as the Season Comes Apart

BYLINE: By Joe Lapointe 

 BODY:
Trust us, the hockey bosses told the players, the news media, the fans and the whole wide world yesterday afternoon.
 Believe us when we tell you we're losing money, they said, as they sat on the dais at the New York Hilton.
 
 We're not trying to break a union or take your money, they said, as they announced the postponement of the National Hockey League season.
 And who could doubt their sincerity?
 Sitting right there, speaking in two languages, was Marcel Aubut of the Quebec Nordiques. Near him were Neil Smith of the Rangers and Ed Snider of the Philadelphia Flyers.
 Two years ago, Aubut traded one player, Eric Lindros, to the Flyers and the Rangers on the same day. It took two weeks and a roomful of lawyers to settle that one.
 Sitting behind Smith was Mike ("I'm-not-going-anywhere") Keenan, the former Flyers-Blackhawks-Rangers coach, now representing the St. Louis Blues. No knife marks were visible in the back of Smith's stylish suit coat.
 It's been, oh, weeks since these two statesmen exchanged obfuscations and half-truths after Keenan left the Rangers in a bitter power struggle with Smith. It took a commissioner and more lawyers to sort that mess out.
 But what this event really needed was Bruce McNall, part-owner of the Los Angeles Kings. Until last summer, McNall was the chairman of the Board of Governors. But he's much too busy these days. He's negotiating a plea bargain and facing a possible jail term following an investigation of financial fraud.
 This media event was a counterpunch to one held the day before in Toronto by the players association, when the workers called the bluff of Commissioner Gary Bettman. Postponement of the season was necessary, Bettman had said, because he couldn't risk a midseason strike, like the one in baseball.
 O.K., the players countered, why not continue bargaining with a no-strike/no-lockout pledge? This won the players a public-relations coup, so Bettman responded with his slick show of solidarity yesterday, just down the street from Radio City Music Hall, home of the Rockettes.
 Perhaps those dancers could have taught these executives to kick in a chorus line. That footage would make the evening news! No, scratch that. They'd probably put steel toes in their wing-tips and go for each other's shins, with all those cameras and reporters around. It shows hockey's growth to see that even its labor troubles are now big news.
 The glib commissioner smoothly changed gears yesterday, explaining that the player offer was "seductive" and that he would think about it, but that he couldn't risk being in the same position next fall, with no contract, so why not talk, talk, talk for two more weeks to see how sincere the players are?
 It is a transparent effort to buy time and circle the wagons and figure out what to do next. For the first time since this showdown began, after slashing player benefits and strutting his power and backing the players into a corner, Bettman was on the defensive.
 The two-week delay "is like sending Jimmy Carter to Haiti," said Jeff Pash, Bettman's bright, young counsel and co-negotiator.
 Perhaps Carter should intervene in the hockey talks, using the language of diplomacy, because the players don't believe the words of Bettman, who uses Orwellian flourishes to call a "lockout" a "postponement" and a "salary cap" a "luxury tax."
 His attempt to restructure the economic relationship is a wolf in sheep's clothing, a plan to hold wages in check while revenues soar in a period of arena-building, increased television exposure and $1 billion per year in souvenir sales.
 When the players hold another infomercial today in Toronto, they probably won't invite Chris Chelios, the undiplomatic Chicago defenseman who issued vague, menacing comments about Bettman's safety the other day.
 The folks at the league office were aghast at this crude attempt to intimidate, but they shouldn't be. Employees sometimes react emotionally and irresponsibly when someone messes with their medical insurance and threatens to shut down their place of business. This is a profession that rewards some employees for fist-fighting skills. Do they think Chelios is the only one talking this way behind the closed doors of the locker room?
 During formal, polite dialogue, the players keep asking the wealthier owners to show sincerity by taxing their gate receipts and sharing them with their less-fortunate brethren. What fun it would be to let them run their fingers through each other's books. Forget it, say many owners, but Bettman hints they might consider it as part of a larger compromise.
 For this union, this sort of stuff is revolutionary. A few short years ago, there was none of this sophistication, none of this confrontation. The players were led by Alan Eagleson, a union boss who had more in common with management than with labor. His sweetheart contracts were part of the reasons the players dumped him.
 He had so much in common, in fact, that he is under indictment for racketeering. Eagleson couldn't be part of yesterday's show. He's in Canada, battling the American feds, who want him here to face charges. If he shows up in the United States, he might get arrested.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Cliff Fletcher of Toronto, left, and Boston's Jeremy Jacobs flank Commissioner Gary Bettman yesterday as the N.H.L. delivers its message at a news conference. (Marilynn K. Yee/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THE 1994 CAMPAIGN: POLITICAL MEMO;
Clinton Shakes the Money Tree

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30

 BODY:
President Clinton's stock speech on the campaign trail this autumn, in ballrooms and meeting halls, always includes a long recitation of his achievements. But it omits a striking one: in 20 months, he has personally raised $40 million in Democratic political donations -- nearly half the national party's reported total.
He has done it mostly by taking a leaf from the voluminous fund-raising manual of the Republicans before him, and using the prestige and power of the White House for Democratic financial gain. 
 Like George Bush and Ronald Reagan, Bill Clinton has flattered big-money donors with private White House parties and seats at state dinners and momentous events. He has freed Cabinet officers, their aides and White House officials to give private briefings on business and politics to especially generous supporters. As his party has begun to court traditionally Republican business leaders, his Administration has consistently invited big-business donors on trade missions -- just as his predecessors did.
And he has blanketed the Democratic tuxedo-dinner circuit with Administration stars. This year alone, the President, his wife, the Gore family and top White House and Cabinet officials will appear at nearly 300 fund-raising events.
"The time before we were in the White House and now just makes a world of difference," waxed Hugh Westbrook, a Methodist minister from Miami who is finance chairman of the Democratic Party's Senatorial committee. "It's night and day."
It is also, chapter and verse, the sort of thing that Mr. Clinton condemned during his 1992 campaign for the White House. At that time, he wrote that American politics was being held "hostage" to monied interests, and complained that "political action committees, industry lobbies and cliques of $100,000 donors buy access to Congress and the White House."
The turnabout distresses those who expected Mr. Clinton to clean up what they view as a political sewer. "The President's aggression on the fund-raising circuit continues to shock and amaze, given his pledges to change the role of money in politics," said Ellen Miller, who heads the Center for Responsive Politics, a Washington group that monitors the flow of money in national politics.
Democratic officials admit things have not changed. But they argue that Mr. Clinton had proposed legislation to control some practices, including a bar on unlimited "soft money" donations to national party treasuries, only to watch it die today in a Senate filibuster.
"He tried his best," Donald Sweitzer, the political director of the Democratic National Committee, said in an interview this week. "In the interim, this is the real world and we're playing by rules as presently set. If we decided not to, we'd simply get creamed."
Indeed, even though Mr. Clinton has sharply closed the gap, the Democrats still get creamed by Republican money men. Through the first 18 months of Mr. Clinton's term in office, the Democratic National Committee and its fund-raising organs in the House and Senate raised $83 million, as against $162 million raised by the Republicans.
Still, the figures are deceptive. In "soft money," the big donations from companies and wealthy individuals that go to party coffers rather than specific candidates, the Democrats outraised the Republicans during that period by 2 to 1. And overall donations to the Democrats were up by one-third, while Republican contributions rose by a mere 3 percent.
While Mr. Clinton could voluntarily temper his party's fund-raising -- Michael S. Dukakis refused corporate and labor money and individual gifts of more than $100,000 during his 1988 Presidential primary race -- ecstatic Democrats seem to have no stomach for it. Mr. Clinton is the best money draw that his party has enjoyed in decades.
Much of what the White House elicits from Democratic donors rolls in at the $1 million-plus chicken dinners at which Mr. Clinton and Vice President Al Gore, in particular, are frequent stars. As befits his office, Mr. Clinton speaks only at national party functions or on behalf of statewide candidates; Mr. Gore and other underlings, from Cabinet officers to aides like Leon E. Panetta, the White House chief of staff, stump for House members and others. (George Stephanopoulos, Mr. Panetta's aide de camp, has done about a half-dozen, many at Greek-American functions.)
But before the dinners, less visible political operations in the party and the White House work to insure that donors feel that their money has done some good, either for candidates or for themselves.
E. William Crotty, a veteran Democratic fund raiser, lives 900 miles from the White House, in Daytona Beach, Fla. But each week his fax faithfully spits out a schedule of briefings by top Administration officials, in hotel rooms and offices around Washington, held expressly for the benefit of contributors and money men and women like himself.
"Say you're interested in growing oranges and you want to go to hear an assistant agriculture secretary, or Mike Espy's policy on the United States' exporting or importing oranges," Mr. Crotty said in a telephone interview this week. "Whoever's having a briefing, sub-Cabinet people, the White House, there are three or four a day. You can go to one if you want."
And people do; before Mr. Clinton spoke nine days ago at a Senatorial campaign dinner in Washington, for example, donors at the million-dollar event met with Administration officials for briefings on issues. The Business Leadership Forum, a party organization catering to corporate donors, plans to shepherd 100 people to Vienna and Budapest next month for "business breakfast briefings and luncheons" and nighttime entertainment, a solicitation states. (Donors pay $6,000 to offset expenses, the party notes.)
The White House and party officials say that such meetings are strictly on the up-and-up. "What you do is facilitate," said Maria Elena Torano, a Miami businesswoman and party fund raiser whom Mr. Clinton invited to his Little Rock economic summit in December 1992, and later named to a Federal advisory post. "If somebody wants to know what the Administration is doing on this regulation, you don't bring him to the secretary's office; you see if there's a briefing on it that they can go to."
Indeed, much of what donors receive for their money amounts to good feeling. For instance, Mr. Clinton invited California donors to the White House for a reception this summer, said Philip A. Schaefer, a San Francisco pension-fund consultant and fund raiser.
Mr. Schaefer, who is organizing a pension investment conference in South Africa, said he was recently invited to a State Department luncheon and White House reception for that country's new President, Nelson Mandela. "I don't know how I got on that list," he said, adding that in a flock of monied donors, he is "a thin-cat, not a fat-cat."
Not that fat-cats are shunned. A spate of news accounts in such publications as The Wall Street Journal and Business Week have noted that big corporate donors to Democratic soft-money accounts are frequently seated on Commerce Department trade missions to places like China. Further, some big donors, like the grain marketer Archer Daniels Midland Corporation and the Boeing Corporation, have subsequently benefited from Federal decisions that increased production of corn-based ethanol or spurred aircraft sales abroad.
Boeing and U.S. West, the Denver-based communications firm, both gained special audiences with Russia's President, Boris N. Yeltsin, during his visit this week. Both firms were big Republican Party donors until Mr. Clinton's election, but since have given the bulk of their money to Democrats, according to Federal Election Commission filings.
But there is no clear evidence of impropriety in those or other cases, any more than in similar instances during Republican administrations. Other corporations with Republican leanings saw Mr. Yeltsin, too.
