HEADLINE: Merging on The Information Superhighway The New Comfort Zone Where Public Meets Private

BYLINE: By Phil Patton; By JULIE V. IOVINE Phil Patton is a contributing editor at Esquire magazine. His latest book is "Made in USA: The Secret Histories of the Things That Made America" (Penguin).

 BODY:
CONVERGENCE: IT'S THE buzzword of the digital age, the mantra of the infobahn, invoked to explain all the alliances and takeovers we see announced daily in the newspapers. These unions recall the shifting ententes of 19th-century European powers: telephone companies linking up with computer companies; software producers allying with television networks; film studios bonding with video game makers. Everywhere, media are converging, and not just at the corporate level: soon computers and televisions will be almost interchangeable devices for pumping information and entertainment into our homes.
Already, the devices around us have begun to converge. From the clock radio to the computer, they have accomplished liaisons far stranger than any corporate union. One result of the process is that there is no longer a simple answer to the question, "What is this machine?" "It's not just a radio, it's an integrated audio system with CD, dual four-headed tape decks, quartz lock tuner and graphic equalizer."
Like upstairs and downstairs, public and private used to be well defined. One acted, dressed, thought and furnished in ways deemed appropriate for one or the other realm. No more. In today's world, the line between public and private, once absolute, is not only shifting but dissolving. In its place is the possibility of a comfort zone where public and private overlap, share the same elements and create a new sense of community.
The convergence of public and private is already under way in politics, the media and business. Its impact on home design affects us dramatically by altering the place we know best. Now, home offices and home theaters -- even kitchens -- are integrating the technology and the styles associated with professional life. On a more literal level, using architectural artifacts -- often salvaged pieces of buildings -- as room decor is more popular than ever. 
 "Multimedia appliances" is the term their makers like to use for the most ambitious of these devices, but "hybrid media" might be a better name. As if responding to the ministrations of some Luther Burbank of electronics, all sorts of recording and playing devices are being crossbred.
As with all hybrids, the quality of the resulting offspring is mixed. Some, like nectarines, are sweet and happy unions, such as the combination of camcorder and four-inch, flat-panel viewing screen available in Sharp's Hi 8 ViewCam ($2,199) or Sony's Snap! Handycam ($899). (All prices are list.) Others, like videophones, seem to be ugly fruit no one quite knows what to do with.
Some combinations seem obvious, but years passed before television sets with built-in videocassette recorders were widely available. And sometimes, the cachet of high technology has delayed convergence. For instance, not long ago, no self-respecting stereophile would have displayed a stack of components from a single manufacturer. The thing was to mix and match the best preamplifier, amplifier, receiver and speakers. But today, even the most technically demanding listeners can find these elements in one unit, such as Bang & Olufsen's BeoSound 2000 ($1,599), which combines them in a single, flat, wall-mountable assembly whose design is worthy of the Museum of Modern Art.
For successful convergence, like successful baking, the proportions and mix of the ingredients must also be right. A new class of products called personal digital assistants now combines computers with communications devices. But in what proportions? A.T.& T. recently stopped selling its EO -- too much computer, not enough telephone (the hand set was extra) -- while Motorola is introducing its $1,500 Envoy, which offers a computer plus modem (it includes wireless connections and easy-to-use software). Meanwhile, Simon ($1,099), the result of a collaboration between BellSouth Cellular Corporation and I.B.M., is described as the first fully integrated cellular phone, wireless fax, pager, calculator and pen-based notepad computer.
Among the more successful hybrid media are those that not only link electronic components, but also help produce another sort of convergence: between public and private. Watching tapes of films in your "home theater" makes private the space we once shared at the local Bijou. Public drama becomes almost sordidly personal: in "The JFK Assassination" CD-ROM ($59.95), Medio Multimedia provides assassination conspiracy buffs with the complete Zapruder film to be computer-analyzed frame by frame. Other CD-ROMs offer "karaoke Shakespeare," such as the I.B.M. Multimedia Publishing Studio's "Macbeth" ($32.95). You can simply watch the play like a film on your screen, or, through a computer microphone, you can soliloquize along with the voices of the repertory cast, or invite friends to play all the parts on the computer stage.
Home theater possibilities are even being boosted by the movie studios, which are seeking a new way to fight the videotape rental industry, now worth an estimated $15 billion (three times Hollywood's annual box-office total). The studios' dream is to deliver movies directly to the home, on demand, via fiber-optic telephone cable, a prospect that remains years away. But while studios continue to dicker with telephone companies and cable television over the details, a glimpse of how this system would work is available today in many hotels, where a "menu" appears on the television screen. On your remote control, you push a number to call up a list of "action films," then another number to pick, say, "Demolition Man." (Unlike pay-per-view, the current cable television system that allows the viewer to telephone and choose from a small selection of movies with predetermined starting times, this plan would permit the consumer to tune in to a wide array of films, any time he or she desires.)
But until such systems pipe films like water or electricity into the home, home theater will depend on videotapes or laserdisks, as well as a formidable array of components: a large-screen television set; audio equipment with sound systems that create room-filling sound, such as Dolby Surround or THX; a high-fidelity VCR or laserdisk player, and a set of at least five speakers, dispersed about the room. Such systems surround the viewer with sound of a quality that surpasses that of the average mall omniplex. Demonstration models almost invariably feature "Top Gun" as their test case, so you can appreciate the surround-sound effect of jet after-burners seeming to emerge from the ficus in the corner.
These systems, however, are intimidating to many buyers. They mix and match a television set from one manufacturer, an audio/video receiver and VCR from another and a set of speakers from a third. Most are still sold through electronics dealers, such as Circuit City or Harvey Sound. But the industry is trying more and more to package the whole system together.
Some audio manufacturers, such as Cambridge SoundWorks, offer home theater packages beginning at around $750. Bose's sleek Lifestyle 12 ($2,200) gives you a receiver, six speakers, a CD player, a radio tuner and remote control -- everything but the television set.
The next convergence may be that of CD-ROM and VCR. A new format called Video CD -- featured, for example, in the Technics model SC-VC10 ($1,199.95) -- plays films on disks that look like the familiar audio CD. The player hooks up to a television set. But since each disk holds only 74 minutes of video, two are required for most movies.
Soon, the great debate over whether the television set or the home computer will be the main on-ramp to the information superhighway system may even become moot. This fall, a critical turning point has been reached with the introduction of the first combinations of television and computer. These are the latest evolution in a process that has seen the computer add a CD player (in the form of CD-ROM), speakers, a fax, a radio and an answering machine. At the forefront of this trend are companies like Compaq, Packard Bell and Apple, which are now offering computers incorporating television, all aimed at the home market.
Packard Bell, for instance, touts its new one-piece Spectria machine ($1,000 to $2,500) as "the first all-in-one multimedia appliance." In addition to computer, CD-ROM, fax modem and speakers, the system includes an answering machine, radio and television. The Spectria is even designed to coexist happily with the Cuisinart in your kitchen or the compact stereo in your den: an optional set of interchangeable colored front panels helps the machine blend with your decor.
Compaq's latest version of its Presario line is another "one-box" home machine, with a stereo, large Bose speakers and built-in television receivers ($1,699). Now you can watch "Wheel of Fortune" in one window on the computer screen while studying your finances in Quicken in another -- and simultaneously talk on the machine's built-in speaker phone. You can even hook a VCR to the Presario and create a computer still picture from your favorite Hepburn-Tracy movie. Apple's Performa 630, when equipped with a card enabling television reception ($1,499 to $1,549 for the Performa; $249 additional for the Apple Video/TV System card), provides the same functions and allows even more elaborate video editing of tapes made on a camcorder.
The melding of media has also made new demands on remote-control units, with their ranks of rubberized buttons. Since many television sets have little computers in them to produce such effects as "picture in picture" (keep up with the Giants in the corner of the screen while watching the Jets), it's no wonder that television remote controls have become more like computer controls.
Sony's egg-shaped controller plus receiver, for example, called Vision Touch (model STR G1ES, $1,700), directs a set of "virtual" buttons on the television screen, like a computer interface, to control a whole audio and video system. Meanwhile, Compaq's new Presario computers feature the "MiniPilot," which puts an image of a television remote control on the screen, controlled by a mouse.
Ultimately, the fate of convergence lies in how people take to these devices. While media moguls like Bill Gates and Gerry Levin debate the electronic landscape of the future, they would do well to remember that natural selection in the world of converging technology lies with the user. It's all about the survival of the designs that fit best in our lives, in our homes and in our hands.
 At the same time, the outside world is defining itself increasingly in terms of the homelike comforts it can provide. For instance, the New York City architects Shelton, Mindel & Associates recently designed the Metedeconk National Golf Club in Jackson, N.J., to recall a weekend getaway. According to Lee Mindel, a principal in the firm, "Using home furnishings in public places looks like someone -- a real person -- cared."
PREVIOUSLY, THE LOOK OF WHERE WE LIVED -- ITS STYLE, materials and aura of comfort -- was easily distinguishable from anything that might be seen outside the house. Theaters had a decor suited to their own particular business, as did restaurants, stores and offices. Today, the language of the home -- couches, ambient lighting, intimate scale -- has been increasingly put to use in both expected and surprising ways, inviting people to feel more at ease in public.
Of course, the idea of the communal living room is not new. Throughout history, societies have always seemed to flourish or atrophy in relation to the quality of their public amenities, including their town squares, neighborhood restaurants and central greens. The ancient watering well was a cafe before there was leisure time. In fact, before the shiny image of the postwar suburbs -- with a car for every garage -- enticed an eager middle class into believing that success meant economic and social independence, gathering in public was as much an American as a European tradition. The interesting development today is that whereas civic organizations and local governments once created public places, such as libraries, town squares and youth centers, it is now the retailers and restaurants that are providing locations for lounging and conversing. It began on a local level with small businesses trying to compete in a tough market. Adding a comfortable armchair to a boutique showed that the shop provided more than just another buying experience.
Barnes & Noble has taken the idea to the national level. There are now over 250 of its superstores, in Manhattan and around the country. Some fill entire city blocks. But their gigantic size is tempered by interiors that suggest living rooms, complete with couches, armchairs and desks. There is often a cafe as well. Indeed, the coffee-bar revolution has fueled the start-up of innumerable coffee shops furnished shabby-chic style with pieces that look as if they came from Grandma's attic. The message: Sink in and stay awhile.
Laura Esquivel, the author of the novel "Like Water for Chocolate," writes, for example, in the bedroom of her Manhattan loft, but seeks the company of the outside world at a neighborhood cafe that has an interior ambiance very similar to her home's. In Atlanta, the upscale Perimeter Mall was recently renovated to include several seating areas with Arts and Crafts-style sofas and armchairs, lamps and coffee tables. In a probable first for any United States mall, customers have been so inspired as to ask where they might buy the same furnishings. ABC Carpet and Home, a home furnishings and antiques store in Manhattan, is even installing a pool table to encourage customers to treat the store as a place to be as much as a place to buy.
"We did a lot of analysis on what people enjoy in a communal environment," says C. Lawrence Whitman, associate director, design, at The Rouse Company in Columbia, Md., and a key player in the Perimeter Mall's redesign. "We found that they react against the sterile and much prefer the familiarity of someplace homelike."
WITHIN THE HOME ITSELF, IMAGINATIVE WAYS TO FUR- nish are as likely to cross over from urban architecture and technology as from historical decorating styles. Elliott Rosenblum, an architect who has given his shop designs for J. Crew and Barneys New York a distinctly homey look, uses pieces of public architecture in his Manhattan apartment. Urban pioneering, a trend that gained momentum in the early 1980's, also redefines expectations of what can be a house by converting defiantly nonresidential properties into homes. Michael Smith, who turned a beauty parlor into a weekend cottage, was so proud of its former identity that he got a permit to preserve the original tile work announcing it as "Edward's Beauty Salon."
The new home office -- a far cry from a desk and computer set up in the guest bedroom -- also signals the general trend toward aligning our professional and private lives. Here, convenience is the key to comfort. In Santa Monica, Calif., the architects Kim Coleman and Mark Cigolle, a husband-and-wife team, designed their house on separate levels: the top for their studio, below for their living space.
In the electronically driven world of the near future, the merging of public and private will only pick up speed. It's reassuring to know that comfort promises to remain an essential factor in the shape of things to come.
When we get off at the ground floor, Angelos finds that all the stadium doors have been locked. He shouts, "I own the damned joint and I can't get out!"
MIKE ILITCH TENDS TO dress in mismatched jackets and slacks from different suits -- steel-blue jacket, gray-green slacks, with white stripes at cross purposes. A pudgy little man, he resembles the comedians Jackie Mason and Harpo Marx, but he has neither the former's cockiness nor the latter's mischievousness. Ilitch, 65, is so timid that it is hard to believe he founded Little Caesars Pizza, which last year did $2.15 billion in sales. He purchased the Detroit Red Wings hockey team in 1982, and the Detroit Tigers baseball team in 1992 for a reported $85 million. His reported net worth is over $300 million. Yet he acts less like a Caesar and more like a low-level employee who is terrified of his boss.
Ilitch smiles when he talks about his beginnings making pizzas. "I was fascinated by flour and water," he says. "You knead it into dough, put it in the oven and it comes out baked. Wow!" But as for being a baseball owner, he says nervously, "I gotta be part of the team, like it or not,"
Ilitch is sitting in his box in Tiger Stadium, looking over the field where his Tigers are playing the Oakland A's. Two of his grandchildren are playing on the floor behind him. His daughter, Lisa Ilitch Murray, and her husband, Glenn, are sitting off to the side. Ilitch is not comfortable with strangers, which is why he surrounds himself with employees and family members whenever he is forced to talk, on the record, about baseball. Lisa, one of his media advisers, is watching her father intently, with great affection -- and worry. After her father turned down an initial request for an interview, Lisa interceded. She asked her father to grant the interview for her, and so he did. Ilitch has trouble refusing his children anything. In fact, his seven children, ages 24 to 36, and his wife, Marian, are partners in all his business enterprises.
Al Sebastian, a staff member, scribbles furiously in a tiny notebook while Ilitch talks, but it is not clear whether he is recording his boss's words for a corporate biography or to insure that his boss will be quoted accurately.
"We need a commissioner who's entertainment-oriented, with sports experience," says Ilitch. "I'm not so sure how important the antitrust exemption is to baseball." He stops, groans. "Aw, I'll get in trouble for that." He looks, pleadingly, toward Lisa. She smiles, nods.
"Owners have been lazy all these years," he says. "They thought they could just talk tradition, open the doors and the stadiums would be filled. Those old stadiums served baseball well in the past. But we need new stadiums that make it exciting for fans prior to the game."
Ilitch wants the kind of entertainment zone that has made Angelos's Baltimore Orioles a financial success. H. Wayne Huizenga, owner of the Florida Marlins, plans to build a new complex that will be home to his baseball team, his football team, the Miami Dolphins, his hockey team, the Florida Panthers, and, quite possibly, the Miami Heat basketball team, which his brother-in-law, Harris W. Hudson, just purchased.
"Wayne's buying everything," says Ilitch. "They gave him 2,500 acres. I'm not in a class with Wayne, but I had the idea first."
In 1987, Ilitch purchased the rundown Fox Theatre in the center of a blighted area in Detroit, along with other nearby buildings, and spent $200 million renovating them. He moved Little Caesars Pizza corporate offices there, added a few restaurants and the Second City Comedy Club. But there were problems with his plans for a new ball park.
Old Tiger Stadium, built in 1902, has been given a coat of white paint, but still looks like a dowager trying to recapture her youth. Yet some people in Detroit think the stadium should be designated a historic landmark. And then there is the question of who would own the stadium and the land under it. Ilitch's opponents think the city should not donate 80 acres just so a local millionaire can make more millions. Ilitch has offered to build a new stadium with $120 million from his own pocket.
"My problem," he says, "is that I'm not politically astute. I have no chits to call in from politicians. I never needed anything from them. I just made my pizzas." He sighs.
"I resent being tabbed as greedy," Ilitch says. "I could handle dumb."
Tiger Stadium is located in a dangerous section of Detroit, which is one reason the Tigers are close to last in attendance in the American League. Also, the team is in last place in the American League East, despite the fact that Ilitch almost doubled the team's payroll this year. He signed Travis Fryman for $25 million over five years, Cecil Fielder for $35 million over five years, and Tim Belcher for $3.4 million for one year. "I got a very poor return on my investment," Ilitch says.
Ilitch could have played baseball professionally. The Tigers offered him a $5,000 bonus when he finished high school, but he demanded $10,000. When the Tigers balked, he joined the Marines for four years during the Korean War. He served his time mostly playing baseball.
After Ilitch left the Marines in the early 1950's, he signed with the Tigers for their original offer. He played four years in the club's minor league system
Ilitch was talented enough, and cocky enough in those days to call the Tigers' owner and insist he be brought up to the majors. Before he made the move, however, Ilitch broke his leg, which ended his career. Without a trade or a college degree, Ilitch took a job making pizzas. He loved it, and in 1959 opened his own pizza restaurant.
Today, he has 4,700 of them throughout the United States and Europe. The success of his chain allowed Ilitch to fulfill a lifelong fantasy, buying the Tigers.
The Tigers were losing money when Ilitch bought them in 1992, but he thought that "with my background I could do better marketing the team." (Better than who? The previous Tigers owner, Thomas Monaghan, who owned Domino's Pizza? You can almost hear Jackie Autry's voice in the background chanting "Dread Owners' Disease.") Ilitch also thought that because he had a baseball background, he'd be more successful than Monaghan.
Ilitch discovered he had little impact on his own baseball people. When he wanted to make an offer for Jimmy Key, a free-agent pitcher, his general manager talked him out of it. Key eventually signed with the Yankees, for whom he has won 17 games this season.
Ilitch agrees with Autry that today's owners are often held captive by their baseball people, who are operating under principles that don't work today. Ticket sales are no longer the game's sole revenue. Many more millions are made through television revenue, marketing -- caps and T-shirts -- and food and entertainment. He says, "You know, the Tigers offices "-- he points overhead -- "are so quiet. They don't want anyone up there but baseball people. When I tell them I want to have a concert or fireworks at the stadium, they say I can't do it. I told them, "I'm gonna lose $10 million this year." (Financial World claims the Tigers lost $5.4 million last year.)
Ilitch's experience with the Tigers has so soured him on the game he has always loved that he admits, if he had to do it over again, he wouldn't. "I should have done more research," he says, "But I got excited."
Ilitch recently appointed a president for Little Caesars so he could spend more time running the Tigers. "Most of the owners didn't run their teams full time," he says. "Players got away from them. These owners would never have let these guys get away from them in their normal business."
When told that a lot of baseball fans and press think that once the owners get the concessions they want, they'll abandon talk about "partnership," Ilitch fidgets. He takes off his tie, sticks his finger in his shirt collar and tugs. "What do you want me to say ?"he asks. "That the Tigers' success really just depends on my ability to run the team properly, which has nothing to do with a salary cap or revenue sharing?" He looks to his daughter, Lisa, for help. Finally, he smiles, a weak smile, and says: "I can't say that! I have partners now!"
As an owner, Ilitch must long for those days when owners ruled their clubs like Genghis Khan. There was no players union, no Senate committees threatening to take away owners' antitrust exemption. One former owner, Calvin Griffith, remembers those days fondly.
"Baseball has its own way of doing things, and the fans don't want it disturbed," Calvin says. By "baseball" Calvin means "the owners."
I'LL BE WEARING A Minnesota Twins hat," he said. And he is. A jowly old man with a big belly, slumped down in a seat at the Helena, Mont., airport.
He grumbles, "Hello," struggles to his feet and waddles out of the airport, past buffalo and moose heads on the wall, to his jeep outside. He drives toward town, past the flat plains with the mountains in the distance.
"The other day I saw snow on the mountains," he says. "Lorda mercy, it was so beautiful I had to stop and stare."
In the 1800's, Helena was a gold-mining town, he says. "There's the ovens where they melted the ore. There's my bank." Money figures a lot in his conversation, and it could be said that Calvin tossed around his nickles as if they were manhole covers. In the 1980's, when he owned the Minnesota Twins, he paid himself $150,000 a year at a time when he was paying half his team considerably more. When his players started demanding salaries in the millions, Calvin told them to go for another team, and they did. The franchise went from a money-maker, which made the playoffs in 1969 and 1970, to losing close to a million dollars in its worst year. He had 13 rookies on that 1982 team, out of 26 players, and their average salary was $65,000, compared with the league average of more than $200,000. Calvin sold the Twins for $32 million in 1984 and retired to his farmhouse in Helena in the summer, and to his condo in Florida in the winter. Bud Selig called him, "the last of his breed," and George Steinbrenner told him, "We'll miss guys like you in baseball." Calvin Griffith, now 82, was the last baseball owner who was raised from childhood to own a team.
Calvin, and that's how everyone still refers to him, despite his years, was named after John Calvin, who preached that a man's earthly success was proof that he was one of God's elect. At 12, his father died, and Calvin went to live with his uncle, Clark Griffith. Clark had been a major league pitcher, and then managed and finally owned his own team, the Washington Senators. He groomed his foster son in baseball from his earliest years, beginning as a batboy.
"Mr. Griffith gave me knowledge," says Calvin. "He told me to be honest. And still he made money 25 years in a row, sometimes never more than $15,000. He gave me every damned thing I ever asked for."
Clark sent Calvin to Staunton Military Academy in Staunton, Va., then on to George Washington University ,where he fashioned a 6-0 record as a pitcher. He harbored fantasies of playing for Clark until his foster father told him there's more "assurance" in the front office, perhaps a kindly way of saying Calvin didn't have big-league talent. At 23, Calvin began his career for $250 a month as the vice president and treasurer of the Chattanooga minor league team. His duties included keeping the books and checking the turnstiles with the ticket receipts for away games. ("He told me to watch the other owners because they cheat," Calvin says.)
Three years later Calvin became the president and field manager of Charlotte's minor league team in North Carolina.
Calvin and his sister, Thelma, inherited the Senators when Clark died in 1955. In 1961, after losing seasons on the field and at the gate, Calvin petitioned the American League president, Joe Cronin, whom Calvin's sister had married, to let him move the team to Minnesota. The other owners turned Calvin down by one vote. Cronin held a second vote when one of the dissenting owners was out of the room. Calvin had just won when that owner returned and said, "I didn't vote." Cronin banged his gavel, and said, "Too late."
"It pays to have a brother-in-law who's the league president," Calvin says.
He pulls into the parking lot of the Hofbrau Restaurant, enters and sits at a table surrounded by people playing poker machines and Keno. The waitress says: "Hi ya, Calvin. What'll it be today?" He orders a ham sandwich and a beer. Then he says, "My days in baseball were the greatest days in my life."
The game is a tough habit for Calvin to break. When there is no strike, he wakes each morning at 10 and reads last night's box scores in the newspaper. Then he watches ESPN. He sometimes golfs or fishes in the afternoon. After a nap and then dinner, he'll drive out to Kindrick Legion Field to watch the Class A Helena Brewers play baseball. When his wife had him build another farmhouse on the outskirts of Helena, so she could have a place to graze her herd of llamas ("They cost up to $15,000 each," Calvin says. "She wants to rent them out as pack animals"), Calvin preferred to live in town, because he was afraid he'd get lost navigating the rutted dirt roads after Brewers games. So he will return to their home, alone, to watch more baseball games on television late into the night.
Calvin knew most of the legends of the game, including Babe Ruth and Judge Kenesaw Mountain Landis, baseball's autocratic first commissioner. Since Landis, Calvin says, the owners have watered down the commissioners' role. "One year I wouldn't vote for a commissioner," he says. "The owners said it had to be unanimous. But I didn't know the guy. One owner said, 'Hell, Calvin, we can always fire him.' I said, 'If that's the case, I'll vote for him.' I didn't like to vote for commissioners, but I saved one. The owners wanted to fire Happy Chandler" -- the former Governor of Kentucky -- "and they wanted it to be unanimous. When I voted against it, the owners threw their papers all over the room."
The owners of Calvin's generation and before were sometimes unsavory characters who fought like cats and dogs -- usually against each other -- to protect what was, for most of them, their only revenue.
"Horace Stoneham" -- the San Francisco Giants' former president -- "was the toughest owner I ever met," says Calvin, putting one half of his sandwich on my plate. ("Shouldn't waste it," he says.) "At a meeting in Chicago, Stoneham got into a fight with Commissioner Ford Frick. They'd had a couple belts, ya know, and their emotions got hot. It was a helluva fight. I just laughed." Calvin remembers that some owners had shady backgrounds. Fred Saight, of the St. Louis Cardinals, pleaded guilty to tax evasion. And Del Webb of the Yankees "had connections in Las Vegas," Calvin says.
We leave the restaurant and Calvin drives toward Kindrick field for his regular Brewers game. He takes off his Twins hat and puts on a Brewers hat. "You know, I see Florida Marlin hats all the way up here," he says, shaking his head. "In my day nobody bought souvenirs." The only advertising revenue he remembers his foster father getting in Washington came from Chesterfield cigarettes. "They paid Mr. Griffith $100,000," he says, "but we were so lousy that at the end of the season he gave back $35,000. He felt guilty. In my day, you had to make your money on ticket sales. I refused to borrow money to pay big salaries. It drove me out of baseball. You just can't pay more than you take in."
He says that today's owners aren't afraid of a players' strike because they have other income. "In my day, owners couldn't afford a strike," he says. "I felt responsible to the fans. I was accessible. I went to church functions. Today's owners send their emissaries 'cause they're busy with their other businesses. They don't watch the games. I saw every damned game."
It's twilight. Kindrick Legion Field is a dilapidated, wood-frame skeleton, painted a gaudy green, on a dusty plain. Calvin waddles up the ramp, takes his seat, a metal folding chair behind home plate. There is a little plaque in front of it with his name on it. As the Brewers take infield practice, Calvin says he feels baseball is America's game because it is played in sunshine at a leisurely pace.
"What they're paid is unbelievable. It takes away their incentive, their team loyalty." Yet, Calvin admits that players' high salaries today are not their fault. "The owners want the players to regulate the owners because the owners can't stop themselves from paying big salaries."
Two teen-age girls walk out to home plate to sing the national anthem. Calvin stands, takes off his hat and puts his hand across his heart. When they finish, Calvin sits down.
A cannon is fired to start the game. Calvin jumps in his seat. "God awmighty!" The KFC mascot chicken throws out the first ball. Calvin loses himself in the game. He talks about the action on the field ("A squeeze bunt! That's an [expletive ]play") and players he's known ("Did you see Ryne Sandberg retired 'cause he said he'd lost his enthusiasm for the game. I give him credit"). Turning around in his seat, he tries to count the house, an old habit. "Aw, I can't do it anymore."
Between innings, the Brewers have promotions: a bike race around the bases; a horse race around the back of the outfield fence. Calvin is fascinated.
"The only promotions we use to have were ladies' days," he says. "Then this guy sued. He wanted a men's day. Isn't that the damnedest thing?" But his eyes never leave the field, the game. "Look at that," he says. "The third baseman tried to throw the goddamned ball before he caught it." Calvin still knows the game, always has. As an owner he was famous for spotting talent, and for making sharp deals. One summer he saw Kent Hrbek playing in a sandlot game around the Twin Cities. He told his scout, "Give him anything he wants," which amounted to a $35,000 bonus. Hrbek, about to retire after 14 years in the majors ,has starred for the Twins ever since.
"The best deal I ever made was at 3 A.M. in a bar in Palm Beach," Calvin says. "I was on the phone all night with Bill Veeck, owner of the White Sox. I got Earl Battey and $150,000 for Roy Sievers" -- an aging player. "Today's owners and general managers don't make deals like that anymore. They never put on a jockstrap. They were just somebody's friends, or a millionaire who bought a club. They don't want to work to make money. That's why they want revenue sharing, so poor clubs can live off rich clubs. The only way a small-market team can compete is to win and draw fans. They'd rather make money through revenue sharing and merchandise sales."
It is still light at 10 P.M., after the game, as Calvin walks toward his jeep in the dusty parking lot. "Who the hell would want to be the baseball commissioner?" Calvin is saying, "He'd have to deal with all the owners. And the owners don't even want a commissioner. Did ya see where this new American League President, Gene Buddig, said he's delighted with his new job because he has so many new ideas for baseball?" Calvin chuckles as he hoists himself up, with great effort, into his jeep. "I'll bet the owners loved to hear that!"
The next morning after breakfast at Gilleys Casino, Calvin drives me to his in-town farmhouse. It is simple -- hardwood floors, plaster walls -- not the house of a man who sold his baseball team for a reported $32 million. There are no mementos of his baseball career. "Not a damned one," he says, and leaves it at that.
Back in his jeep, Calvin drives out toward the farmhouse where his wife keeps her llamas. He refers to her always as "she," or "her" or "my wife," but never by her name, which is B. J. (Belva Jane). He crosses railroad tracks and heads out into deserted country on a brilliant Big Sky afternoon.
He stops at his farmhouse on the deserted hill so I can pet the llamas. "Blow in their nose," Calvin says. "They like that."
When it's time to drive to the airport, Calvin goes quiet. Finally he says: "I got no regrets. I spoke my piece in baseball. I didn't care what people thought. I was respected more than I was loved. I'll take that." He passes some boys playing softball in a field on this sunny summer's day. Without turning his head, with only a quick shift of his eyes, a reflex, out of a habit he can not break, he notices the boys. "Now that boy," he says, "has a good swing."

 CORRECTION:
A picture credit on Sunday with a sports photograph showing Dwight Clark catching a pass from Joe Montana in a retrospective of historical moments in the National Football League identified the source of the picture incompletely. The photograph, from the book "75 Seasons," was taken by Walter Iooss for Sports Illustrated.
An article in The Times Magazine on Sept. 18 about the major league baseball owners misspelled the surnames of a Baltimore Orioles first baseman, of a former owner of the St. Louis Cardinals and of the American League president. The first baseman is Rafael Palmeiro, not Palmiero. The former owner is Fred Saigh Jr., not Saight. The league president is Gene Budig, not Buddig. The article also misstated the opening year of the Detroit ball park now known as Tiger Stadium. It was 1912, not 1902.

The New York Times

SECTION: Section 7; Page 3; Column 1; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 2802 words

HEADLINE: 'I Can't Go On Criticizing'

BYLINE: By Michael Upchurch; Michael Upchurch's new novel, "Passive Intruder," will be published next year.

 BODY:

CHRISTINA STEAD
A Biography.
By Hazel Rowley.
Illustrated. 646 pp. New York:
Henry Holt & Company. $37.50. 
A STARK summary of the global wanderings of the Australian writer Christina Stead makes clear that her life was an unusual one.
Born near Sydney in 1902, she left Australia for London in 1928 and was working in a Paris bank by the early 1930's. After a sojourn in America, she reached Spain just in time for civil war to break out in 1936, then soon fled back to New York where, with her American lover, the Marxist economist William Blake, she spent the early 1940's away from the battlefields of Europe.
As soon as World War II ended, the Red Scare of the late 1940's and early 1950's drove Stead, Blake and many of their fellow leftists to cold-war Britain and Europe. There the couple led a hand-to-mouth existence, alleviated only by the reissue of Stead's best-known novel, "The Man Who Loved Children" (originally published in 1940), which produced some much-needed income in the mid-1960's. Following Blake's death in 1968, Stead made a difficult move back to Australia, where she died at the age of 80 in 1983.
What this hectic itinerary fails to suggest is the extraordinary degree to which Stead, in her fiction, inhabited each of her places of residence. As Hazel Rowley says in the prologue to "Christina Stead," her superb new biography, "No major writer of any nationality has been more truly cosmopolitan than Christina Stead." While the fiction of James Joyce or D. H. Lawrence tended to become all the more deeply steeped in their Irishness or Englishness the farther from home they went, Stead used her mimic's ability to immerse herself in whatever place she happened to be.
She invented a strangely Francophone English to evoke the jittery speech of fly-by-night Paris bankers in "House of All Nations" (1938), and later captured the manic staccato of sleazy New York war profiteers in "A Little Tea, a Little Chat" (1948) and the more genial maunderings of Manhattan's artistic types in "The People With the Dogs" (1952). Her final phase found her perfecting her impersonation of the harsh lilt of Tyneside leftists in "Dark Places of the Heart" (1966) and the comically glib palaver of London literary hacks in "Miss Herbert (The Suburban Housewife)" (1976).
Any one of these novels would be enough to establish Stead as a major European or American or British novelist if questions of actual citizenship were set aside. But the startling variety of her books seems to have confused readers' perceptions of her and obscured the scale of her accomplishments. Like the blind men trying to describe the elephant by touch, readers and critics can describe almost as many Christina Steads as there are books in her canon. It all depends on which ones you've read.
Feminists can stake a claim to her on the strength of her autobiographical fiction: "For Love Alone" (1944), about a young Australian woman leaving her home on a search for self-fulfillment in England, and "The Man Who Loved Children" (1940), as searing a portrait of female domestic entrapment as has ever been written. Other Stead fans, turning to "House of All Nations" and "A Little Tea, a Little Chat," can make a case for her as the century's greatest novelist of the workplace and a psychological writer par excellence, with her devastating portraits of ruthless charlatans and misguided idealists.
New Yorkers might want to recognize her as one of their own. She spent her happiest years in the city, and as late as 1982 still identified herself as "a Manhattanite." "A Little Tea, a Little Chat," greeted with hostility upon publication, now reads like the "Bonfire of the Vanities" of its day. "The People With the Dogs," with its top-to-bottom portrait of an amiably eccentric postwar Manhattan, makes you feel the city's very sidewalks beneath your feet. Stead's best short fiction -- the title novella in "The Puzzleheaded Girl" (1967), and "A Harmless Affair" and "My Friend, Lafe Tilly" from the posthumous collection "Ocean of Story" (1985) -- also offers as wry and knowing a take on the town as one could wish.
The challenge for any would-be biographer is to establish the books' importance and relation to one another; to give a sense of the historical backgrounds and personalities from which Stead drew her inspiration; and to portray the woman herself, a task complicated by the fact that Stead burned many of her personal papers late in her life.
Hazel Rowley, who was born in England and educated in Australia and is now a resident scholar at the University of Texas, meets the challenge splendidly on all three counts. Juggling a vast amount of detail, her biography of Christina Stead is a model of clarity. Ms. Rowley's shrewd selectivity and handling of anecdote make the book compellingly readable. She always has a salient line from Stead's correspondence on hand, allowing readers to enjoy, for example, the writer's own pithy descriptions of "The Man Who Loved Children" ("A Strindberg Family Robinson") or New York during its wartime dimout (when the city "looked like the primeval Manhatto swamp").
Ms. Rowley's interpretation of the novels and their creator is, for the most part, thoroughly persuasive. Her tracing of what she calls "Stead's shadow self" from her unhappy childhood through the crucible of her fiction to the final shambles of her later years (in many ways, this writer's life is a writer's nightmare) gives the biography a vigorous and unnerving momentum, reminiscent of Stead's own fiction.
Central to the story, as readers of "The Man Who Loved Children" will guess, is Stead's problematic relationship with her father, David Stead, a naturalist. (Her mother, Ellen, died of appendicitis when Christina was 2 1/2 years old.) "That his eldest daughter was not endowed with good looks," Ms. Rowley says of Stead's handsome, charismatic father, "was a source of chagrin he made no attempt to conceal." In an era when being an "old maid" was a fate to be dreaded, David Stead made it clear to his daughter that marriage, in all likelihood, was not in her future.
The father-daughter conflict was made all the more tense by her father's reluctance to see Stead as anything but an extension of himself. Ironically, in spite of their differences, they shared strong similarities of temperament and intellect, as Stead in her later years liked to point out, seeing herself as a naturalist like her father, though in her own field, identifying personalities by type with the intention of observing rather than judging them. But, if anything, these father-daughter similarities simply meant that David and Christina Stead knew how to hurt each other most effectively.
Rescue came in the form of William Blake (born Blech), a "German Jew of American upbringing," as Stead described him, whom she met during her first week in London. An autodidact blessed with the vitality of a "small Vesuvius" (again, Stead's words), Blake had a life that followed an intriguing arc of its own. His friendships with shady right-wing bankers and fervent Marxists and Stalinists sent the couple fleeing across the Atlantic not once but twice -- the first time from England to the United States to avoid prosecution in connection with a banking scandal (the folding of the Paris-based bank that became the Banque Mercure in Stead's "House of All Nations"); the second time from New York back to London to avoid the inquiries of the F.B.I. and the House Un-American Activities Committee. Their situation with residence permits was complicated by Blake's marriage to an American woman unwilling to give him a divorce. Stead and Blake lived together for 23 years before marrying.
THE involuntary moves were a mixed blessing, giving Stead much of the material she used in her best books, but often disrupting her writing efforts and preventing her from establishing the network of friends and professional connections that might have made writing a more viable livelihood. But chances are she would have had difficulty finding a sizable reading public even if she had enjoyed more stable circumstances. Ms. Rowley cannily illuminates the challenging originality of Stead's handling of the "many-charactered novel," involving an immersion technique that forces the reader, as Stead explained in a 1939 lecture, to "draw his own conclusions from the diverse material, as from life itself." The results could be harrowing as a character's mesmeric voice, in silky or savage repetition, penetrated the reader's mind, taking full possession of it.
This ability to get under the reader's skin seems to have put some critics off. What too few reviewers picked up on was the sinister vein of humor that ran through even the most ghastly scenes, making the books as exhilarating as they were oppressive. It may not have helped that Stead was reminding readers of disgraces they'd rather forget: war profiteering, bankers going for bust, manipulative utopians bamboozling those around them. One critic remarked of the womanizing scoundrel behind the black market dealings in "A Little Tea, a Little Chat": "There are some individuals in whose company one can remain only to a point. Miss Stead takes the reader far beyond that point." Stead reacted to this with dry insistence on the validity of her vision. Of New York City in wartime, she remarked to a friend, "everyone was not rolling bandages."
If Stead's fiction was problematic to her contemporary audience, it was even more so to the friends and enemies from whom she liked to draw her characters. After the books were written, Ms. Rowley reveals, Stead often referred to real people by the fictional names she had given them. And unlike many writers, she liked to insist the books were absolutely true to life, regardless of any liberties she might have taken with her "models." As Ms. Rowley points out, "Stead tried to have things both ways: she wanted the liberty of invention and the authority of nonfiction."
AS scathingly as she treated her characters, Stead also, Ms. Rowley duly notes, endowed them with "brilliant verbal pyrotechnics" that were well beyond the abilities of most of their real-life counterparts. It's an indication of just how preposterous a man David Stead was that many of those who knew him agree that no exaggeration was necessary in transforming him into Sam Pollit, the villain of "The Man Who Loved Children."
Ms. Rowley gently debunks some of the myths the author constructed around herself in her later years. Stead once said she had written "House of All Nations" in six weeks. Ms. Rowley's investigations indicate that it was more like a year, with much research preceding the actual composition -- still an extraordinary accomplishment, given that the book is 800 pages of snappy entertainment about intricate financial transactions.
Ms. Rowley also reveals that Stead's greatest dissatisfaction with her work was her inability to come up with positive characters. She longed to write "an innocent book about something or other," and after "A Little Tea, a Little Chat," she confessed to a friend, "I can't go on criticizing."
Stead wasn't as ferociously independent as her novels might lead one to believe. In her book reviews and essays, she remained under the sway of her husband's leftist rhetoric, deciding that Pasternak's "Dr. Zhivago" was "true old-fashioned, dyed-in-the-wool anti-socialist propaganda," despite her admiration of the writing. Her own novels, with their maverick views on all political causes, were bound by no such dogma. And on occasions when activists' demands on her time came into conflict with her writing efforts, as happened during the Spanish Civil War, she was capable of putting supplicants off with "I feel it is my duty not to do my duty."
Ms. Rowley makes it clear that Stead's dismal experiences with publishers were as much an obstacle to her finding an audience as the challenging content of the books themselves. In the United States, Stead went through three publishers in eight years and, at various points, was urged to write more like John Steinbeck or Margaret Mitchell. Simon & Schuster insisted that she give "The Man Who Loved Children" an American setting, rather than its natural Australian background (a weakness of the book: Stead couldn't quite eliminate the Aussie accent from her Maryland protagonists). William Blake, a historical novelist as well as an economist, was offered still more dispiriting editorial advice about his fiction. What it needed, he was told, was "some really luscious" sex.
As for income from books, even in the early 1940's, when titles by Stead and Blake were being published with some regularity, the couple were drawing conclusions that writing was "another word for slow starvation," a situation that led to Stead's brief stint as a scriptwriter with MGM. Always trying to come up with salable ideas, they made proposals that suggest they were years ahead of their time. In 1942 Stead failed to get a Guggenheim fellowship to collect ethnic folk tales from across the United States, while Blake's book proposal for a "Woman's Encyclopedia" found no takers in the early 1960's.
For Stead, the years of being stranded without income or a publisher took their toll. (Angus Cameron, her last editor before her long publishing silence, was forced to resign from Little, Brown in 1951 because of his leftist connections.) The reissue of "The Man Who Loved Children" in 1965 looked like it might turn things around for a while, but then Blake grew ill, and with his death Stead lost her bearings. Her drinking -- always heavy -- got out of hand, she wasn't able to write fiction or essays (she spent four months working on a review of Quentin Bell's biography of Virginia Woolf before giving it up), and she made increasingly cranky statements that couldn't have endeared her to anyone. "I detest lesbians," she told Ron Geering, her literary executor, in their correspondence about "Dark Places of the Heart," which features a savage portrait of a women's group home in working-class London. She insisted that her benefactor, Patrick White, wasn't a homosexual, despite White's own candor on the matter, and she told one interviewer, "While there is a man left on earth, I'll never be a feminist."
Starved for affection, she turned to male friends, who had difficulty handling her. For the first time, she had become one of the impossible characters she had portrayed so well, blind to the unreasonableness of the demands she made on those around her.
Ms. Rowley doesn't flinch from showing Stead at her worst, but she doesn't lose sympathy with her either. Far from being a reductive portrait of the writer, "Christina Stead" has the fullness of tragedy, with its glorious peaks and dismal abysses. Ms. Rowley's reading of each passage in Stead's life is deftly enhanced with well-chosen excerpts from Stead's fiction and private papers.
With so much to praise, it feels petty to criticize Ms. Rowley on minor points, but there are a few errors and omissions in the book that need pointing out. The John Ford film Stead worked on at MGM is "They Were Expendable," not "We Were Expendable," as Ms. Rowley has it, and a reference late in the book to a "revised" edition of "The Man Who Loved Children" is surely meant to read "reissued." No mention is made of the 1966 hard-cover reissue of "House of All Nations" or the degree to which it boosted Stead's later reputation. The critical reception of Stead's intriguing novella collection, "The Puzzleheaded Girl," is also missing.
Ms. Rowley's emphasis in her last chapter on "heightened feelings of anger" as the engine that powered Stead's writing seems exaggerated. She attributes Stead's failure to write during her final years to an inability to muster sufficient rage at the world, but by all accounts that rage was on the loose and unbridled. It seems more likely that Stead's writing spirit was broken by the death of Blake (Stead's own explanation) coming after almost two decades of hard times. Working drafts of all her publications of the 1960's and 70's -- "Dark Places of the Heart," "The Puzzleheaded Girl," "The Little Hotel," "Miss Herbert (The Suburban Housewife)" -- had been written during the 1950's. The same is true of her posthumous novel, "I'm Dying Laughing" (1987).
Whatever the cause of Stead's writer's block, it is the fiction itself that matters, and Hazel Rowley's most important achievement is in sending readers straight back to it with a greater appreciation of the persistence and strength of mind that was necessary to write it, and with an increased appetite for the difficult truths Stead was determined to portray. In this regard, "Christina Stead" is everything a literary biography should be.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 7; Column 1; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1979 words

HEADLINE: An American Promise

BYLINE: By A. M. Rosenthal; A. M. Rosenthal, former executive editor of The New York Times, writes the On My Mind column on the Op-Ed page of the paper. He is a graduate of City College.

 BODY:

CITY ON A HILL
Testing the American Dream at City College.
By James Traub.
371 pp. Reading, Mass.:
A William Patrick Book/
Addison-Wesley Publishing Company. $25. 
 THE City College of New York, the heart of James Traub's important book "City on a Hill," was one of the country's great colleges. It turned out Nobel winners in science, playwrights and poets, politicians of value, pioneers in medicine, judges and generation after generation of teachers. And for hundreds of thousands of New Yorkers with no money, it was the only key to a life of intellectual fulfillment and professional attainment.
The beautiful thing about C.C.N.Y. was that its students believed that it was the most intellectually moral college in the land. Isn't that a fine thing to be able to hold on to through college, and after? Money or pull could not get you in. City students had barely enough money to meet the tuition charged through most of the school's history: none. And their families had the social clout of herrings.
Brain, only brain, got you in. For decades -- although not always -- that meant a high school average in the high 80's. Brain was then put to the real test: surviving the endless examinations, the chronic professorial irritability, the fear of being dropped from class rolls because the teacher did not like your performance or face and, most of all, the terrifying realization that for the first time in your whole brilliant life you were surrounded by young people much smarter than you.
To the City College student, brain was merit and merit was the essence of American morality. Mr. Traub, even though he had to go to Harvard, has perfect pitch about the meaning of the founding of City College, known first as the Free Academy, in 1847:
"What distinguished City from every other college at its level was its transformative mission. City did not reproduce privilege. . . . City was the most meritocratic of institutions; and because the idea that a man should get ahead according to his abilities, rather than the accident of birth or background, was the core principle of America's free-market society, City had a moral status that no elite college could claim. City was . . . a promise that America kept."
Every day, as these students walked from a subway in Harlem up a hill to City, they saw blacks all around them -- but rarely at the top, in the classrooms and laboratories. They did not put much thought into why almost all the poor but smart kids turned out to be white. But in the late 1960's the civil rights movement insisted that City was not a promise kept but a right denied -- the right of minorities of color to a college education even if they had failed to receive, or to achieve, the decent high school education that had always been thought to be the prerequisite for higher education. Otherwise, according to the new doctrine of "open enrollment," minorities would be caught in an educational trap without ever tasting some of the fruit of the Golden Land.
Mr. Traub, the author of "Too Good to Be True: The Outlandish Story of Wedtech," understands the white students and parents for whom City was a promise and a faith, and he also understands black and Hispanic people for whom it was a taunt and a challenge. This is a deeply reported, lucidly written and clearly thought-out book -- a book of merit.
He started his research hoping to find that the drastic experiment of open admissions had worked. After months of attending college classes, examining records, talking endlessly with students, administrators and teachers, Mr. Traub concluded that open enrollment was a failure. That will be a matter of pain to many students, teachers and administrators. But Mr. Traub writes and thinks with such warmth and understanding -- never condescension -- that his book could turn out to be an asset to City and its survival.
In 1969, the college administration bowed to demonstrations and political pressure. Open admissions transformed City. The admission requirement, Mr. Traub explains, was reduced drastically -- to graduation in the top half of the high school class. Given the
quality of education in so many New York City high schools by then, that was simply surrendering to mediocrity, and everybody knew it.
But City also opened itself to students who had achieved far less than mediocrity. For students who had not managed to master basic subjects even at a high school freshman level, or below, but had been handed a certificate and pushed out the high school door, a whole world of remedial classes was invented and set up within the college.
It is an achingly sad story Mr. Traub tells. In three semesters these remedial classes were supposed to transform into City College students people of 18 or older who could barely read. From one of the most respected institutions of higher learning in the country, City quickly became one of the most ridiculed.
The dropout rate at City today, Mr. Traub calculates, is approximately 55 percent. It would be a lot higher if teachers, not students, made the decisions and dropout became throwout. As Mr. Traub shows, students in the remedial classes are often pushed up to regular college-level classes although teachers know they have failed even at the remedial level. This does away with any distinction between achievement and failure, and puts acceptability even below the lowest common academic denominator.
But consider this about the young people in remedial classes, those who manage to climb out of them and even those whom teachers in desperation shove into regular college classes: Mr. Traub reminds us that they have enough willpower and strength of character to go to City after working nights or between classes. Day after day, then, they summon up the gumption to face the inescapable sense of academic inadequacy. They have enough determination to fight for a taste of America's rewards through education, knowing that the world around them, in the college and outside, is convinced that they will never make it.
Many of these gutsy youngsters fail, as Mr. Traub shows, because they have never received the family and social support and the intellectual and civic discipline, or had instilled in them the lust for knowledge, that allow foreign students educated abroad to succeed at City College despite the extra burden of learning in a foreign language.
These youngsters were sucked into a system -- open enrollment -- based not simply on interest in their academic future, but on anger, politics and sentimentality. I think readers will agree with one of Mr. Traub's saddest conclusions: many of these students are the victims of open enrollment, not its beneficiaries.
From the outside, the inevitable attention paid to open enrollment makes the college seem like an educational desert. But another story is intertwined with Mr. Traub's account of the failure of open enrollment, although it is not told quite as fully or vividly, or pulled together as well. Gardens of intellectual endeavor and achievement not only still grow at City College but also are positively luxuriant.
The school continues to attract many first-class students. Some attend because of economics. Although the college was forced in 1976 to abandon the free tuition that was so important a principle, its tuition fees of about $2,450 a year are still relatively low.
Many go to City because of its world-class school of engineering and fine mathematics and science departments. All these subjects have turned out to be as attractive to black and Hispanic students at City as to Jews and non-Hispanic Roman Catholics a generation or two back. Meanwhile, the Graduate School and University Center of the City University of New York (the administrative totality of all the municipal colleges) is becoming more and more of a resource to the city, a garden in its own right.
What does this mixture of garden and desert mean? One thing certainly: scuttling or starving out the present City College would be an outrage to all young men and women who have the right to believe that neither money nor pull nor family status will stand between them and higher education. City is now 39 percent black, 28 percent Hispanic, 18 percent Asian, 14 percent white and, as the college administration also notes, 0.4 percent American Indian.
But from a reading of Mr. Traub's book it is clear that continuing remedial classes would be continuing the basic falsehood of open enrollment at City. It is not a means to opportunity but a passage leading from one trap to another.
In a recent letter to me unconnected with the Traub book, Yolanda T. Moses, the president of the college, indicated that the remedial system is being de-emphasized. She says, for instance, that only 234 out of 15,000 students -- 1.5 percent -- now take remedial writing classes. By the spring of 1994, remedial courses over all had been cut to 6.6 percent of the total classes.
MR. TRAUB'S book has two weak points. One, strangely, is that he does not make clear why his book is important to people outside New York who have no involvement in City College but are interested in the health of American higher education. The reason is that under one name or another remedial education is affecting a variety of colleges around the country. This is by no means just City's problem.
The other is that he skimps on suggestions for meeting the problem. One way he touches on would be to send unqualified high school students to the municipal community colleges. But as he knows and says, these schools do not have the career or educational value of the senior four-year colleges.
Maybe the solution section is relatively weak because the only real solution, to Mr. Traub's mind and to mine, is the hardest -- to make sure the job of preparation for college is done where it should be: in the high schools. That would be a lot more useful than trying to push up average-grade entrance requirements or continuing the sorrow of remedial work in colleges.
But such reforms need not end City's critical role as a reasonable and attainable goal for minority students. As a matter of fact, the Jews and non-Hispanic Catholic youngsters who once made up most of the student body used to think that they were the minorities -- getting not an academic break but certainly an economic one. And, would you believe it, it develops that the old-time City College students were not always exactly brilliant. In "City College and the Jewish Poor," published in 1981, Sherry Gorelick had the nerve to suggest as much after examining historical data.
In 1881, only one out of every 11 entrants graduated; most dropped out. As of 1902, 30,000 students had been admitted but only 2,730 graduated. And although the entrance requirement was a grade average of 88 in 1939, in 1924 it was just 60. Ms. Gorelick quotes a graduate of the class of 1924 as saying that the policy of open admissions started in 1970 was a "reversion" to a tradition of open admissions in effect from 1847 to 1930, and that higher standards for admission were instituted then because the college did not have enough seats.
But no matter how many seats, this from Mr. Traub rings true about the fate of the college on the hill, and all other colleges:
"The university is the one site in our culture where knowledge is valued for its own sake, or rather for the free and enlarged views of human life that it affords. Should it lose that sense of purpose, a college would be just another social-service institution. Its sense of standards, of high purposes, would be mere pretensions. And nobody would care especially whether it lived or died."
That has not yet happened to the college on the hill. If enough parents, students, teachers and city officials read Mr. Traub's book as coolly and wisely as he has written it, perhaps it never will.

HEADLINE: SUNDAY VIEW;
For Horton Foote The Pictures Speak Volumes

BYLINE: By Vincent Canby 

 BODY:
THERE'S A SUBLIMELY FUNNY moment in the second act of the Signature Theater Company production of Horton Foote's "Talking Pictures," now Off Off Broadway at the Kampo Cultural Center. A subsidiary character named Gladys, who ran off with another man five years earlier, has suddenly returned home expecting to pick up her marriage where it left off. Willis, the abandoned husband, declines the offer as gently as he can. She's wounded, then outraged. "You men are all alike," she screams at Willis. "Philanderers!" Yet before the act is out, she has already latched onto a new marital prospect. Like so many characters in Mr. Foote's work, Gladys possesses remarkable resilience and tenacity. Though she's noisy and not at all dependable, the grace she displays under fire is genuine.
The Signature Theater Company, which has devoted each of the last three seasons to the work of a single American playwright (Romulus Linney, Lee Blessing and Edward Albee), is thus beginning its Horton Foote season in a way to create exceptionally high expectations. As directed by Carol Goodheart, with a large, very fine cast headed by Hallie Foote, "Talking Pictures" may well turn out to be one of the most entertaining plays of the new theater year, which has scarcely even begun. 
 The scale is small and the focus short. The time is 1929 and the setting the fictional town of Harrison, Tex., not far from the Gulf coast. In spite of geography, Harrison is not much different from the parched Kansas locale of "Picnic" by William Inge, one of Mr. Foote's contemporaries. Both plays deal with love, longing and compromise, broken marriages, missed opportunities and the apparent stasis in small-town life. Yet there is a vast difference between the playwrights. Inge's recollections of the American heartland are drenched in a kind of wish-fulfilling, erotic romanticism that now seems dated and sort of foolish. The Foote plays are cut so close to the bone of reality, they're so uncompromising and clear-eyed in their quotidian concerns, that there's nothing much to date them except the times in which they are set.
That's only one of the revelations in this impeccable production of "Talking Pictures," which will be playing at the Kampo Cultural Center through Oct. 23.
Mr. Foote has the curious distinction of being possibly the least well-known major American playwright today. In part this is because his most celebrated work has not been in the theater but in films, following his career in the 1950's and early 1960's as one of the most successful writers in television's so-called golden age of live drama. He won his first Oscar in 1962 for his adaptation of "To Kill a Mockingbird" (for which Gregory Peck won his Oscar as best actor), and his second in 1983 for "Tender Mercies," an original screenplay that included an Oscar-winning role for Robert Duvall. There was also an Oscar for Geraldine Page in "The Trip to Bountiful" (1985), which Mr. Foote adapted from his television play and Broadway play (1953), both of which starred Lillian Gish.
Since "Only the Heart," his first Broadway play was produced in 1944, Mr. Foote has always remained a practicing playwright. Now 78, he has never stopped writing plays, even as the economics of first Broadway and then Off Broadway made the production of his work increasingly risky. There was a period in the 1970's and 1980's when about the only places you could find his plays in New York were Herbert Berg hof's HB Studio Theater on Bank Street and the Ensemble Studio Theater on West 52d Street. Meanwhile, he continued to write for what might be called mainstream Hollywood. In 1992 he adapted John Steinbeck's "Of Mice and Men" for the MGM film directed by Gary Sinise. More important were his independent movies: "1918" (1984), "On Valentine's Day" (1986) and "Convicts" (1991). These are the pristine but low-budget adaptations of three of his cycle of nine plays, collectively titled "An Orphan's Home." They all are set in Harrison and deal with four generations of one family.
"Talking Pictures," written in 1987 but only now being given its first New York production, is typical of Mr. Foote's best work, which discovers an America not unlike the one we see in Edward Hopper's paintings. Mr. Foote's world initially looks serene. His characters, being plain, seem idealized. They reveal their defining, eccentric spirits only with time. They profess fundamental Christian beliefs, yet they are threatened less often by Satan than by the temptation to surrender to despair. They can't go on, they won't go on, they go on -- sometimes raffishly, like Gladys, sometimes in quiet triumph, like Myra Tolliver.
Myra (Ms. Foote) is the focus of "Talking Pictures," though, as in Chekhov, there are really no minor characters in the play. Each of the 11 roles is so vividly realized, first by the author and then the actor, that you get a sense of community, which becomes an important aspect of the play's total effect.
Myra, who is divorced, plays the piano at the Harrison movie theater (which is still holding out against talkies), earning barely enough to support herself and her teen-age son, Pete (Eddie Kaye Thomas). The two share a cramped rented room in the house of the Jackson family, whose finances also are in trouble. Mr. Jackson (Frank Girardeau), a railroad engineer, has just been "bumped," meaning that he's about to be transferred to another town. Though Myra has a suitor, Willis (Seth Jones), a decent, clean-living construction worker, there's a problem: he's still married to Gladys (Susan Wands) and can't afford to divorce her.
IN ADDITION TO MRS. JACKSON (Alice McLane), the play's community includes the Jacksons' teen-age daughters, Katie Bell (Samantha Reynolds) and Vesta (Sarah Paulson); a sweet, gabby, incredibly cheerful Mexican teen-ager named Estaquio (Isaiah G. Cazares), a would-be Baptist preacher, who has come to Harrison to convert the town's Mexican Roman Catholics; Ashenback (Ed Hodson), the gun-toting paramour Gladys wants to dump, and Gerard Anderson (Kenneth Cavett), Myra's ex-husband, whose hard drinking is responsible for the collapse of his second marriage.
At first "Talking Pictures" unfolds so leisurely, in a series of sometimes short scenes separated by blackouts, that it takes awhile to find its rhythm. This is often the case with Mr. Foote's plays, but that unwillingness to italicize emotions, or to underscore the important moments in any obvious way, is also why the play has the impact it does. It creeps up and dazzles you with moments of extraordinary pathos that alternate with those of uproarious comedy, including a suicide that goes wildly wrong. As the play's first-act curtain must be one of the funniest things Mr. Foote has ever written, the end must be one of the most moving.
In his preface to the printed text of "Talking Pictures," in the volume "Four New Plays," Mr. Foote suggests that "the theater is, or should be (my italics), a collaborative medium." He goes on to say that a theater dominated by the actor, the director, the writer or the producer "is finally a lopsided theater." What is most apparent about the Signature Theater Company production is the teamwork. As the writer and the director serve the actors, the members of this remarkable cast serve them, with the entire group serving the play as a living organism.
The method of the production seems summed up by the beautiful performance of Ms. Foote (the playwright's daughter). Her Myra is simultaneously reserved and outgoing, strong and fragile. The actress is gifted with large, luminous eyes made for stage lighting. There's not a moment in which, without actively taking over the scene, her presence is not felt. In her you see how volatile life in Harrison is beneath its placid surface. Myra faces the loss of her son to her former husband, the loss of the new man she has come to love, and redundancy, 1929-style, when the Queen Theater finally changes over to sound.
Though we all have second thoughts about progress when we reach a certain age, "Talking Pictures" doesn't traffic in easy sentiment or nostalgia. The play is strong, if sometimes wonderfully circular in the way its characters reveal themselves. Mr. Foote's seemingly plain, realistic (but highly condensed) dialogue is responsible for this. In a foreword to the Dramatists Play Service edition of "The Traveling Lady" (1954), Stark Young, the critic, playwright and novelist, wrote:
"As for Horton Foote's dialogue, there is everywhere present a kind of elusive and glowing accuracy. And there is never any sense of arch intention or any sign of the playwright's coquetting with quaintness."
His dialogue requires only that you listen, something that this Signature production makes irresistible.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
'Mother And Child'
 Matthew Lombardo's "Mother and Child," now at the McGinn/Cazale Theater on Broadway at 76th Street, is a harrowing but really quite bad play about AIDS, faith and mysticism. The time is Christmas Eve. When the lights come up on a room at St. Vincent's Hospital in Greenwich Village, a woman (Helen Harrelson), identified only as Mother in the program, has just arrived from Mississippi to celebrate Christmas with her dying son (Anthony M. Brown), identified as Child. Christmas is also his birthday.
It's snowing. The mother's feet are wet and sore. Her son, with tubes connected to his arm and nose, moves about on the bed in restless sleep. She looks at him sorrowfully. "Imagine," she says at the start of a long monologue, "33 -- my Lord!" Mother talks Mississippi redneck dialogue, makes some jokes about the odd-looking people outside the hospital, tells us about a trip she once took to the Grand Canyon, in this way to establish the milieu from which this Mother and Child sprang, as well as their current situation.
When the son wakes up, it develops that his mother has never acknowledged his homosexuality or the existence of his lover, now dead, who, he says, saved him from a life as a male hustler making between $2,000 and $3,000 a week. "Imagine me," the son says to his mother, "a modern-day Mary Magdalene," which confuses the analogies suggested earlier. "Mother and Child," which was directed by the playwright, is about the need for speaking the truth and for being honest with those you love. Guilt is rampant. The son admits having infected his lover with AIDS. The mother confesses she lied about the circumstances surrounding the son's birth. There is also talk about an immaculate conception, apparently in the belief that it was Jesus and not Mary who was so conceived.
The performances are adequate, meaning that they are far better than the material.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
'Down by The Ocean'
 The York Theater Company's "Down by the Ocean," written and directed by P. J. Barry ("The Octette Bridge Club") and now playing at St. Peter's Church, is something seldom seen these days: a comedy in three acts. Four middle-aged men, brothers-in-law, convene every six or eight years on the porch of a Rhode Island summer house while their wives are having a reunion, dealing with children and grandchildren down on the beach. The play's catalyst is the pretty, sexually aggressive young woman who lives next door. Over the course of the three acts (set in 1946, 1952 and 1960), she manages to seduce each of the men for better and for worse.
Though Mr. Barry has command over the craft of playwriting, "Down by the Ocean" isn't that much fun to watch. The play is well made, that is, plotted with some ingenuity, but the characters and the jokes are sitcom thin. Sam Groom, Dennis Parlato, Ross Bickell and John Newton play the often battling brothers-in-law with spirit. Melina Kanakaredes appears as the siren who bewitches them, and Pamela Burrell is the only one of the sisters who ever comes back to the house.
If I had a choice, I'd rather have a month in the country.

HEADLINE: Reminiscences On the 15th St.'Y'

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your article about the Y.W.C.A. at 7 East 15th Street is historically accurate with respect to this gem of Romanesque architecture and its sale by the "Y" in 1917.But the following quotation is hardly adequate: "Since then 7 East 15th Street has been used as office space, and carelessly altered, although the facade has survived miraculously intact." 
 I believe that the purchaser of the building in 1917 was the woman activist-philantropist Carrie Rand. She called it "The People's House" and it became known as the "Rand School of Social Science." It was the citadel of the American Socialist Party movement and contained some significant associations. Besides the S.P. headed by its frequent Presidential candidate, Eugene V. Debs, there was its youth organization the Young Peoples Socialist League (Yipsels), the editorial offices of "The New Leader" and the top two floors were used by the Jewish labor fraternal order, The Workmen's Circle/Arbeter Ring as its weekend high school -- mittlshul.
I attended this school from 1929 through 1932. Kids from dense Jewish neighborhoods -- Lower East Side, Harlem, Williamsburgh -- came to classes via subway on Saturdays and Sundays absorbing lessons conducted in Yiddish on literature, history and political economy.
In the 20's, Attorney General Mitchell Palmer conducted raids at the Rand School, rifling files and hurling desks, etc. to ferret out the antiwar Socialists suspected of being "Bolshevik subversives."
 
ISRAEL KUGLER
 
The writer is professor emeritus in social science at City University of New York.
