HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Flushing's Chinatown;
A Chinatown With a Polyglot Accent

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
SAY "meet me in Chinatown" to most New Yorkers and they start moving toward Canal Street. Most Cantonese-speaking Chinese in town would probably head the same way.
But Mandarin-speakers from Taiwan, or the growing number of Koreans and Asian Indians who have moved to Queens, are as likely to go to Flushing, around Roosevelt Avenue and Main Street, as to Mott or Canal Streets. 
 "Flushing has definitely become the city's second Chinatown," said Roger Lo, a real estate broker from Taiwan who works at A. O. Realty, which specializes in Chinatown properties in New York and on the West Coast.
"It may not be so well known here, but in Taiwan they refer to Flushing as Little Taipei," said Kathleen Petrus, the director of sales and marketing for the Sheraton La Guardia East, a two-year-old hotel on 39th Avenue off Roosevelt Avenue.
Indeed, in less than 15 years, Flushing has turned into a bustling Asian enclave that rivals its much older Manhattan counterpart, if not in size, then certainly in ethnic intensity. Signs on its restaurants and stores are in Chinese as well as English. Its banks, its hardware stores, the Sheraton hotel -- all have Chinese-speaking personnel.
The area, less than four square miles and bounded loosely by Northern Boulevard to the north, Sanford Avenue to the south, College Point Boulevard to the west and Union Street to the east, has attracted other Asian groups as well. Koreatown, as the Chinatown residents call it, is thriving on Union Street between Sanford Avenue and Northern Boulevard and Little India has taken hold on Main Street, south of Franklin Street.
The neighborhood is a transportation hub where bus lines converge on a subway terminus, and the steady flow of middle-income transients through the area has not gone unnoticed by retailers. Caldor, Sterns, Payless Shoes and several other American retailers have opened in Flushing Chinatown. And rents have gotten high. Stores at the intersection of Main Street and Roosevelt Avenue, the neighborhood's hub, fetch as much as $80 a square foot at those rare times when one is vacant. And lately, rents are inching up on Main Street, on Prince Street and on other nearby streets.
"The same tenants who would take stores on, say, 34th Street are looking to rent in Flushing," said Barry Fields, a retail broker with the Queens-based Greiner-Maltz real estate firm.
Like its Manhattan counterpart, Flushing Chinatown gets plenty of non-Asians coming through. Manhattan Chinatown attracts a great many tourists on weekends and, during the week, a goodly New York lunch and dinner crowd from the nearby courthouses and Wall Street. It also has a sizable jewelry business, albeit one that was hurt by the recession.
FLUSHING Chinatown has a narrower focus and reach, but it attracts hordes of outsiders nonetheless. Within it is the first -- or last, depending on how one looks at it -- stop on the No. 7 train, whose other terminus is Times Square; commuters from all over Queens and Long Islanduse it for their daily trek to Manhattan. The Long Island Rail Road is just a few blocks away and more than a dozen bus lines have stops within Chinatown's boundaries.
Not surprisingly, in the afterwork hours and on weekends the area's many greengrocers and fish stores are thronged with nonresidents -- Asians who live elsewhere, as well as Caucasians -- picking up that night's dinner fare.
"Those Asians who live in Westchester, or on Long Island, or in other parts of suburbia, they still do their socializing and shopping in Flushing," said Paul Ho, senior vice president in charge of Hong Kong & Shanghai Bank's retail branches.
Still, it is the Taiwanese who gave the area its ambiance and its name, and it is Taiwanese immigration that continues to fuel its growth. In the late 70's and early 80's, many Taiwanese college graduates came to the United States seeking advanced degrees. Some returned to Taiwan, many others chose to stay. They married, had children and sought an area where their children could get a sound American schooling while still remaining conversant with their Chinese culture.
Flushing by then had fallen on hard times. Many of the ethnic groups that had passed through the neighborhood -- Italians, Irish and others -- had put down roots elsewhere. Many of the buildings were rundown, the stores boarded up, the streets deserted. But the schools had a reputation for excellence.
"Where many of the original Cantonese settlers chose Manhattan to be near the harbor, the Taiwanese chose Flushing to be near what they thought were good schools," Mr. Lo said.
Most of those original settlers worked outside the area, taking jobs with Manhattan corporations. But as the neighborhood's Chinese population grew, businesses catering to that population sprang up as well.
Restaurants, bakeries, hair salons and doctors' and lawyers' offices soon dotted the landscape. Warehouses that had been abandoned by American companies or foreclosed on by banks were snapped up by wealthy Taiwanese and used to store food, shoes, garments, luggage -- all sorts of items that could be sold in the area.
"Northern Boulevard used to be dotted with service stations, with a Chevrolet dealership, with a Bond store," said Kaye Min, manager of Chemical Bank's Flushing branch. "Now it's all small, Asian-owned businesses. And on Prince Street, on 41st Road, on Union Street, on all of the nearby back streets, it is the small stores that are making this area boom."
Success has not come easily to them, though. When Mark Lii, a Taiwanese who migrated to the United States in 1980, decided to open a tea shop in 1984, he automatically chose Manhattan's Chinatown.
"We felt we could get customers from all over the country, that Canal and Mott Street were the areas to be," he said. Mr. Lii's Ten Ren Tea and Ginseng Company did quite well on Mott Street almost from the start.
It was rougher with the branch he opened in Flushing in 1988. "I thought the Chinese community in Flushing had really developed, but I have to admit my first two years were hard," he said. "But now, enough people know about us, and business is good."
LOCAL condominiums and homes and commercial buildings also have sold well. Although New York housing prices, even in Queens, are high compared with those in most of the rest of the country, they seem eminently reasonable to many Asians, who are accustomed to the huge housing costs in Hong Kong, Taiwan, Japan or Singapore. Moreover, several bankers noted, wealthy investors from Hong Kong and Taiwan have been attracted by the perceived political stability of the American Government and prefer investing -- if not necessarily living -- here to investing in Asia.
A result is that in the last eight years or so huge pockets of the neighborhood have been revitalized. On 38th Avenue, rental houses and stores have sprung up on the site of old warehouses. Nearly a decade ago a Chinese investor bought the parcel of land that then housed the RKO movie theater on Main Street near Kissena Boulevard and has since built stores and offices on the site. A former parking lot on 41st Road off Main Street now houses a Chinese-owned apartment building. The old World Journal newspaper building is now the site of the 173-room Sheraton La Guardia, which, while managed by Sheraton, is owned by Taiwanese businessmen.
A group of Taiwanese investors recently paid $10 million for property on 39th Avenue and Prince Street, currently the site of an auto repair shop, and will probably build stores and offices there.
"Ten years ago Flushing was going down the tubes," said Charles Yang, a local insurance broker who emigrated to the United States in 1970 but did not move to Flushing until 1986. "The Indians, the Koreans, the Chinese, they saved this area."
ALTHOUGH the recent recession -- coupled with a diversion of some Chinese immigrants to an even younger Chinatown that is rapidly expanding in Brooklyn's Sunset Park district -- has slowed Flushing Chinatown's growth somewhat, it has not had nearly the impact on the area that it has had elsewhere in the city. According to Mr. Lo, rents have dropped somewhat, but not precipitously. Three-bedroom apartments that might have rented for $1,300 five years ago now go for $1,100; store rents that ranged from $80 to $100 a square foot now range from $50 to $80, while office space that used to command $28 to $30 now can be had for $20 to $25.
"Flushing rents remain high because Oriental people keep moving in," Mr. Lo says. "Even in the recession, few stores or restaurants went out of business, and those that did were bought by other local people."
Local bankers have noticed the same stability. "People in our Flushing branches are not opening and closing accounts every six months," said John Aleffi, Chemical Bank's district manager for North Queens.
PART of the reason, Chinese business people say, is the heavy cultural emphasis the Chinese place on savings. Many Chinese businesses lost money during the latest recession. But instead of going out of business, owners often dipped into their savings to keep themselves afloat.
"Many of our local businesses owners did not make money in the last few years, but their savings let them stay in business," said Mr. Lii, who is president of the Flushing Chinese Business Association.
Even Chinese people who have moved out of the area see Flushing Chinatown's dynamism as a business opportunity. In the early 1980's Zenia Yuan, like many young women, came here from Taiwan to study. She got married, and stayed here. She lives in Forest Hills and has made her living in real estate and finance.
"Along about 1985 or so, I noticed more and more stores and buildings renting and selling to Chinese people in Flushing," Ms. Yuan said. So she bought a building on Main Street and rented it to a clothing store. When that store moved out this year, Ms. Yuan did not seek another tenant. Instead, about seven months ago, she opened her own business, the Mayflower Cafe and Bakery, a Western-style coffee and pastry house. She says she is doing just fine.
Mr. Yang said his insurance business had also taken off. "My business grows because the community grows," he said. "As more Chinese buy property or open businesses, they need more insurance, and they need it from a broker who can explain the policies to them in their language."
Flushing's dozen or so local bank branches have thrived for similar reasons. Well-known American banks like Greenpoint Savings or Chemical Bank coexist with Asian ones like China Trust Bank or Great Eastern Bank. Several local residents say Asian banks generally give higher interest for certificates of deposit, while American banks give better loan rates.
Actually, running a bank in Chinatown is a good-news/bad-news situation. The typically cavalier attitude that many Americans take toward debt -- leverage is synonymous with growth opportunity, credit cards are a means to buy something now that you could not otherwise afford -- is anathema in Chinese culture.
"Chinese people do not feel comfortable borrowing, they consider debt a big weight on their shoulders," said Ms. Min of Chemical Bank. Moreover, added Mr. Ho of Shanghai Bank, there are many alternative sources of funds in Chinatown. "Often, Chinese business owners can get money from wealthy individuals coming from abroad, or from relatives," he said. "And they are usually quite willing to pool their money and open, say, a new restaurant as partners."
But while loan business may be sparse, savings deposits are ample. And since Chinese people are unlikely to take chances with money, what loan business there is, is generally lucrative. Asian culture is such that family members, friends, even acquaintances, will often chip in to help someone in financial trouble, rather than let them renege on their debts. And Chinese people are more likely to assume debt to expand a business that has already been successful, making the loan a better risk for both the borrower and the bank.
"Nonperforming loans are almost nonexistent here," said Mr. Aleffi of Chemical Bank. "The credit character of the Asian market is exceptionally strong."
For all these reasons, banks clearly pursue Asian business. Most Flushing branches, whether American- or Asian-owned, have automatic teller machines that offer transactions in Mandarin as well as English.
CITIBANK has a special Asian Banking Center where Korean, Mandarin and Cantonese are spoken. And most of the banks are open on weekends to accommodate local people who may work in Manhattan but prefer to do their banking in a Chinese-speaking bank.
Local institutions that ignore the demand for Chinese-oriented services do so at their peril. Look at the history of the Sheraton, a now thriving hotel that has become not only the place for visiting Asians, but also the place for local events.
When it opened in February 1992 it marketed itself as an airport hotel with proximity to La Guardia, to Shea Stadium, to the National Tennis Center in Flushing Meadow-Corona Park and to transportation to Manhattan rather than its location in the heart of a bustling Chinatown. Floundering is a euphemism for how it fared.
So the hotel changed its approach. It subscribed to Chinese cable television stations for its rooms, provided Chinese newspapers and put together tour packages aimed at Asian travelers. And it sent an Asian salesperson to Beijing, to Shanghai, to Taipei, all over Asia, to call on government offices and persuade them to send delegations to New York. "That opened the floodgates," Ms. Petrus said.
Today the hotel's occupancy is about 50 percent Asian. It is finally also gettting spillover LaGuardia traffic too. It reaped a bonanza from the U.S. Open tennis tournament in Flushing Meadow last month. And it has become a popular spot for local weddings and banquets.
"We advertise in Spanish, Chinese and Korean newspapers," Ms. Petrus said. "We've learned that marketing to the ethnic community really works."

HEADLINE: Reveille for New Rochelle's Abandoned Army Fort?

BYLINE: By TESSA MELVIN 

DATELINE: NEW ROCHELLE

 BODY:
FOR 27 years, Davids Island, lying unoccupied in Long Island Sound just off this Westchester County city, has enticed developers. Many consider its 78 level acres the best undeveloped real estate left along the New York State coastline.
But since 1987, when the city bought the former military base 18 miles north of Manhattan, potential buyers have found city officials eager for tax revenue but divided by political squabbles. They have also found that the island's fragile environment is fiercely defended by environmentalists and strict state and county regulations. 
 During the Civil War, New Rochelle residents were grateful for the quarter-mile of water separating them from the 3,000 soldiers, mostly Confederate, hospitalized on the island. In later years, they enjoyed the smell of fresh bread wafting over from the Army cooking school and the stirring music of the Fort Slocum band.
Access has been the main impediment to developing the island. Two years ago, the City Council rejected a vision by Xanadu Properties Associates, a group headed by Bruce Stark, a Hawaii-based developer. First proposed 11 years earlier, the $1 billion residential housing plan called for 1,750 condominium units with access to the mainland by a 3,465-foot bridge. The Council, certain that the project, especially the bridge, would never get state and county approvals, turned it down.
Now, with a new pro-development city administration intent on breathing new life into this economically battered "Queen City of the Sound," officials here hope that renewed interest in the island can be a catalyst for reviving the downtown.
In the last two months suitors have been lining up for the right to develop the island. Among them is Donald Trump, the Manhattan developer and casino owner, who sketched an initial proposal before the City Council in July. It called for 2,000 residential units, the number already approved under the city's urban renewal plan for the island.
Last Tuesday Mr. Trump presented a more detailed residential-retail development plan at a City Council meeting. It calls for 2,000 one-, two- and three-bedroom condominiums in three 22-story buildings and 200 one-, two- and three-bedroom condominiums in a 45-story tower. It also includes a 1,000-slip marina, a small retail complex and parking for 3,500 cars. Ferry service would provide transportation to the island and the public would be able to use the marina, the shops and park and beach sites.
In his presentation, Mr. Trump said his proposal was "conceptual" and promised to work with the City Council, residents and skeptical environmentalists to reach agreement on a detailed plan that would meet Federal and state regulations.
Although the Trump organization wants exclusive rights to redevelop the island, Mr. Trump said he would consider a partnership with Westchester County, which would like the island converted to parkland.
Westchester County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke has proposed buying the island for a park facing the county-owned Glen Island Park and connected to it by a ferry. The idea has generated little support among the city's 67,000 residents, except from environmental groups. Many residents are equally skeptical about a proposal by the Davids Island Development Company, a consortium of smaller developers formed to create a family entertainment park with a water park, amphitheater, health club and earth science center and a magnetic monorail to get people to it.
Mayor Timothy C. Idoni said he was pleased by Mr. Trump's readiness to negotiate with a variety of groups and avoid the bitter fights that characterized the last attempt to develop Davids Island. The Council is expected to decide on a developer before the end of October.
Not everyone was as sanguine as the Mayor.
"THE buildings around the perimeter will look like a medieval fortress multiplied by 10," said Robert G. Tritsch, a member of the board of Federated Conservationists of Westchester County, a coalition of environmental groups.
And Jeffery Rogg, a member of the board of the New Rochelle Economic Development Council, said: "We need far more detail. Davids Island must be part of the overall development of the city."
The Davids Island initiative is, in fact, part of Mayor Idoni's plans to increase the tax base in a city that has suffered a 30 percent loss in ratables in the last decade. The downtown's major retail tenants, including Arnold Constable, Bloomingdale's and Macy's, have left, following their customers to more prosperous places farther north.
The vacant storefronts have contributed to a stable crime rate, Mayor Idoni said, because "there have to be people to rob." The loss of ratables, however, has more than doubled the school district tax rate, which went from $97.034 per $1,000 in 1985-86 to the current $201.78.
Last year, shortly after New Rochelle beat out 72 other applicants as the preferred site for a new Unicef headquarters, the United Nations agency decided to stay in New York City. But Unicef's interest, city officials say, gave the city international visibility, increased developer inquiries and gave elected leaders a determination to redevelop their downtown.
"The Unicef deal we offered in New Rochelle made economic sense and expansion sense," said the city's development director, Joseph G. Madonna. "Unicef's interest proved we're not just bumblers up here."
After Unicef's decision, New Rochelle hired Arthur Anderson Consultants to develop a blueprint for downtown redevelopment focused on a four-block area of mostly vacant storefronts. As a result of the report's recommendations, the City Council recently voted funds to widen streets, plant trees and improve signage. They have also hired two people to oversee the downtown redevelopment and guide citywide economic development.
In September the city issued requests for a plan to develop a large-scale mixed-use project on a 4.5-acre city-owned site in the Lawton Street Urban Renewal Area, part of the Unicef site.
The city has been buoyed by the arrival of two new "big-box" retail stores downtown. Three months ago, Price Club, a discount retail chain, opened a 100,000-square-foot outlet on the former Joyce Beverage site. Business has been brisk and city officials expect it to generate $1 million in annual sales tax revenue.
At the other end of the city, another discount retailer, Home Depot, has bought a $1 million option on 12 acres of city-owned land, a former incinerator site. Negotiations have been opened with a third discount retailer, B.J.'s, to occupy an additional 12 acres at that site.
The property, in the midst of an abandoned industrial area lining Weyman Avenue, is just 200 yards from Exit 15 of the New England Thruway. "Our location is superb," Mr. Madonna said. "We're in the middle of an excellent road system and we are strategically situated in southern Westchester."
The City Council is currently considering a proposal by the RoBach Development Company of Ardsley to convert 10 acres of shoreline from its current use as a storage area for the city's garbage trucks to a luxury sports and leisure club with tennis and squash courts, a health club and dock.
FOUR weeks ago, representatives of the Equitable Life Assurance Society visited New Rochelle to discuss using the city-owned Unicef site, slightly more than 4 acres, for its headquarters.
The property is near the proposed $30 million Intermodal Transportation Center downtown, which will combine Amtrak and commuter rail service with local and long-distance bus service. Momentum on the project has picked up since Amtrak agreed earlier this year not to move its station from the downtown area.
Sydney P. Mudd, president of the Joyce Beverage Company until it was sold 10 years ago, has chaired the city's Economic Development Council and its committee to bring Unicef to New Rochelle. A city resident for 53 years, Mr. Mudd has watched the city prosper and decline.
"It's a dream to expect New Rochelle to be what it once was," Mr. Mudd said, "but we'll always be a good place. Now, we are emerging as a city that wants to do well."

LENGTH: 1488 words

HEADLINE: Parochial Schools on the Comeback Trail

BYLINE: By JULIE MILLER 

 BODY:
PATRICIA FINCH scrubbed decades of dirt off the desks at St. John's School in Old Saybrook in preparation for classes. St. John's, in the Roman Catholic Diocese of Norwich, was reopened this fall after being closed for 20 years. Mrs. Finch, one of many volunteers to cleaned and painted the school building, remembered sitting at the same desks when she was a pupil at St. John's. The thought that she was helping to refurbish them for her two children, whom she enrolled this year, made the work easier, she said. "Those desks are antiques, mind you," she said. "If it weren't for the Formica tops, my initials might have been there. I might have been scraping my bubblegum from one of those desks."
The reopening of St. John's and St. Bridget Catholic Elementary School in Cheshire, part of the Archdiocese of Hartford, marks a reversal in a decade of Catholic school closings due to rising costs and a shortage of nuns and priests. The Norwich diocese, which includes Windham, Tolland, Middlesex and New London counties and Fishers Island, N.Y., plans to open regional middle schools in the Montville and Putnam areas in the next 18 months and at least three day care centers in the New London, Willimantic and Putnam areas, the superintendent of schools for the diocese, Howard B. Bennett, said. 
 Catholic schools are popular once again with parents who want education for their children that emphasizes discipline and values, Mr. Bennett said. Mrs. Finch and other parents in Old Saybrook, many of whom attended Catholic schools themselves, said they want an environment free of the violence that has invaded urban and suburban public schools. And they welcome the sight of a principal wearing a long, black habit instead of street clothes.
"The more technologically advanced we become, the more people want to go back to the way people used to be," said Mary Anne Knight of Old Saybrook, whose son is in first grade at St. John's. "You can do as much as you can at home, but when children are away the majority of the day, it's very hard to maintain what you want to instill in them." Mrs. Knight's two daughters, who were in public school through the eighth grade, attend a Catholic high school in Middletown. "I'm very concerned about the lack of discipline in public schools," Mrs. Knight said. "The good children end up suffering. They have to sit and listen while others are disciplined."
School officials, facing difficult economic times, kept schools going in the Norwich and Bridgeport dioceses and the Archdiocese of Hartford by either combining them or establishing schools that serve a region instead of a single church community. St. John's is serving nine parishes, including Clinton, Essex, Old Lyme and East Lyme, Mr. Bennett said. Families in those towns and in Old Saybrook who want to send their children to Catholic schools have had to send them to Groton, New London or Middletown.
The Hartford archdiocese, which covers Hartford, New Haven and Litchfield counties, has closed 20 schools in the past 10 years. "We're struggling to keep the inner city schools going," the superintendent of schools for the archdiocese, the Rev. Zigford J. Kriss, said. "We're starting to consolidate, or merge, schools." As people leave the cities to live in the suburbs, Father Kriss said, urban schools are closing their doors and schools like St. Bridget are reopening. The archdiocese, which had not opened a school in 10 years, reopened St. Bridget, formerly a junior high school, for pre-kindergarten through first grade.
The Bridgeport diocese, which includes Stamford, Norwalk, Bridgeport and some suburban areas, began reorganizing its schools three years ago. Schools formerly owned and operated by church parishes were merged and the diocese was divided into 10 regions, each managed by a board of education and a board of directors, the superintendent of schools, Armand Fabbri, said. In a region with four schools and 10 churches, for example, all 10 parishes share responsibility for the schools. "We made a better financial base for their support," Mr. Fabbri said, "and it's working very well."
The reopening of the schools in Old Saybrook and Cheshire comes after a 10-year decline in Catholic school population throughout the state. Enrollment in the Norwich diocese dropped 22 percent over the last decade to 5,998 from 7,668, according to the diocesan school office. About 6,300 students are expected this year, Mr. Bennett said. The Hartford archdiocese, which had 32,000 students 10 years ago, expects an enrollment of about 24,500 for the 1994-95 school year, Father Kriss said. And the number of students in the Bridgeport diocese this year increased about 3 percent over last year to 11,500 from 11,200, Mr. Fabbri said.
A solid majority of the members of St. John's Church who responded to a survey last June supported reopening the school. But 58 percent of those surveyed said they did not believe St. John's should support the school financially. And members of the parish council, which conducted the survey, expressed concern that since 34 percent opposed the reopening, parish unity might be weakened.
The president of the council, Robert Breault of Deep River, said he realized that change takes place slowly. "I think it's fair to say that in any endeavor, there are always people on all sides of the issue. Change takes some stretching, learning and adapting," Mr. Breault said. "That will be true of this process as well."
Parishioners' children attending St. John's receive $500 toward their tuition from the parishes. Tuition costs $1,650 a year, Mr. Bennett said. Anticipating an increasing interest in Catholic education, the diocese expects to raise $10 million to $15 million over the next five years to support its schools, the bishop of the diocese, Daniel P. Reilly, said.
"We haven't closed a school in the diocese in the last 20 years. We don't close schools here," Bishop Reilly added. "I was convinced something good would happen and the trend would turn around. Schools have always been the backbone of our mission in this country. So we held on."
Mr. Bennett, who was a public school superintendent for 28 years, said he anticipates the resurgence in Catholic schools throughout the United States will continue into the 21st century. "Some of the factors causing this resurgence relate to violence, drugs and crime in general that have infiltrated our public schools in rural, suburban, as well as urban areas throughout the United States," Mr. Bennett said in a speech he gave last February at a meeting of the Federation of Catholic School Parents.
A voucher system, which would allow parents to choose schools for their children, is being considered in 19 states, including Connecticut. "I for one do not think that the voucher system, or 'choice in education,' will come any time soon to this state," Mr. Bennett said. "I am convinced, however, that it will come. This is why the Norwich diocesan schools, 21 elementary and 6 secondary, are preparing for that eventuality."
A spokesman for the state Department of Education, Thomas W. Murphy, defended the public schools. "Violence is really a function of the neighborhoods, suburban or urban. In a violent culture, it can happen anywhere," Mr. Murphy said. "Schools are becoming more violent as a result of the culture. But on a balance, they are among the safest places."
With fewer nuns and priests available to teach, the Norwich diocese plans to raise the salaries of lay teachers, Mr. Bennett said. Starting salaries for lay teachers in Catholic schools range from $15,000 to $18,000 a year, the principal of St. John's, Sister Marie-Alberta, said. By contrast, the starting salary for a public school teacher in Connecticut is about $30,000.
Despite this gap in pay, 100 people applied for eight teaching positions at St. Joseph's, said Sister Marie-Alberta. "There's a different kind of atmosphere here and a different approach to discipline. If they are very religious, the teachers want to be able to talk about that, and they can't do that in public schools," she said.
Parents facing their children's college tuition costs used to think the Catholic elementary and secondary schools were too expensive, Bishop Reilly said. "I can understand that. In the late 1970's, mid-80's and into the 90's, our enrollments were falling because of that," the Bishop said. "But now there's a certain chaotic element that has touched public schools in a dramatic way, neutralizing the teaching of moral values. And parents are saying, 'We want something more for our children.' "
Everyone in the Norwich diocese knows the schools are a priority, Bishop Reilly said, but convincing those who resist the idea of opening schools takes patience. "They'll see those kids and what they bring into the community, and they'll say, 'How did the parish exist without the schools?' " he said.

HEADLINE: Q and A

 BODY:

Neighbor Is No Fan of a Ceiling Fan
 
Q I live in a condominium unit in Westchester County. The owner of the apartment below me installed a ceiling fan in his bedroom, which is below my bedroom. When the fan is turned on I can hear the cyclical sound of what I believe is the fan's motor. The sound is loud and annoying enough to prevent me from getting an adequate amount of sleep. 
 When I have spoken to the unit owner he has been sympathetic and willing to make arrangements to investigate and cure the problem. He said an electrician looked at the fan, but the fan noise still penetrates into my bedroom. I had a good quality wall-to-wall carpet installed, but to no avail. Now the owner does not even return my phone calls anymore. The property manager says the problem should be resolved between the unit owners involved.
I have spoken with the tenant in the unit and he avoids using the fan often or keeps it at the slowest speed, which is still very audible. I have offered to defray any costs necessary to eliminate the fan noise.
The condominium plan states that "no nuisances shall be allowed upon the property nor shall any use or practice be allowed which is a source of annoyance to occupants or which intereferes with the peaceful possession and proper use of the property by its residents." Can noise from a ceiling fan be considered a nuisance? If so, can I prove it? I prefer to avoid litigation. What options do I have? . . . Anthony Rossitto, Harrison, N.Y.
 
A According to Ronald A. Sher, a White Plains lawyer, Mr. Rossitto may possibly seek recourse against the unit owner or the condominium, "if the condition from the fan vibration or excessive noise constitutes an unreasonable interference with quiet enjoyment or otherwise violates the warranty of habitability."
Mr. Sher suggests that the writer first review the condominium's declaration and bylaws to determine if board permission was required for the installation and that Mr. Rossitto ask the board to ascertain if the installation was performed by a licensed electrician in conformance with the building code. He said a qualified engineer or contractor should conduct an inspection of the equipment to recommend ways of alleviating the condition.
"Assuming a proper installation, the settlement of subjective quality-of-life issues, specifically involving excessive-noise complaints, is difficult," he said. "The board may attempt to mediate a resolution or consider a formal referral to impartial arbitration."
Failing that, he said, the writer may consider litigation against the board and the unit owner. "The writer will be required to submit proof from an expert establishing that the fan vibration and noise level constitutes an unreasonable interference with quiet enjoyment or otherwise violates the warranty of habitability," Mr. Sher said.
 
Seeking Exemption From Rent Rises
 
Q I am 66 years old. I lost my job on Sept. 1. I have lived in a rent-stabilized apartment since 1964. If I do not find a new job my only income will be Social Security. Am I eligible for a Senior Citizen Rent Increase Exemption? . . . Marie Tafaro, Brooklyn.
 
A Possibly, said Lou Ganim, a spokesman for the New York State Division of Housing and Community Renewal, which oversees rent administration in New York City. In the city, if a tenant or a tenant's spouse is 62 or older and lives in a rent-regulated apartment; if the combined household disposable income is $16,500 a year or less, and if they are paying at least one-third of their disposable income for rent, the person who is 62 or older may apply for the exemption.
If the tenant qualifies, he or she is exempt from future rent-guidelines increases, maximum base rent increases, fuel-cost adjustments and increases based on the owner's economic hardship and major capital improvements.
The program is administered in the city by the Department for the Aging. Applications should be filed with the Department for the Aging, SCRIE Division, 150 William Street, Fourth Floor, New York N.Y. 10038. Telephone: (212) 240-7000.

HEADLINE: If You're Thinking of Living In/Saugatuck;
An Immigrant Haven, a Sailor's Delight

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES 

 BODY:
WITH its toe protruding into Long Island Sound, the Saugatuck neighborhood at the southwestern corner of Westport resembles the boot of Italy, facing east toward its mate across the sea. It lends credence to the commonly held belief that European immigrants settle in areas of America that remind them of home.
"In the mid-1800's Westport farmers, the railroad, and anyone else who needed cheap labor would meet the shiploads of immigrants at the docks in New York, promising them jobs and homes," said Margaret Lebedis, a guide at the Westport Historical Society. 
 "That's how many Italians wound up here. Sometimes it took 20 years to pay off their debt as indentured laborers. It was common practice in those days."
Saugatuck's Italian laborers founded what has become something of an ethnic aberration in wealthy, cosmopolitan, suburban Westport. The enclave is now a working-class neighborhood of one- and two-family houses and businesses clustered around the Saugatuck railroad station, a hub of shops, food markets, restaurants, marinas and service companies that supply the entire peninsula with most of its needs.
Its houses, owned by such families as the Lucianos, DeMatteos, Nisticos and Valiantes, have been passed on from generation to generation and when they are for sale, usually under $200,000, it is by word of mouth or a small ad in The Westport News.
Beginning in the 50's the population of Saugatuck swelled with people from many ethnic and economic backgrounds, and the Italian sons and daughters moved up into the professions and business ownership, fueling a homogenization of Saugatuck that went largely unnoticed except by some oldtimers. "Now you hardly know anybody," complained Lillian Bottone, a lifelong resident. "Everybody used to be so close."
Saugatuck residents are passionate about their neighborhoods, whether they live in the crowded Italian section, in the spacious tree-shaded homes down Saugatuck Avenue, or the water-oriented properties at the foot of the boot.
Saugatuck Island, at the very toe southeast of Canal Road, is inhabited by about 100 families and joined to the mainland along the Saugatuck River side by a 60-foot-long, single-lane bridge reinforced with crude wooden planks, and on the Long Island Sound side by a causeway that occasionally floods under very high tides. But that's part of the charm.
"We moved here seven years ago because it's the most beautiful place we had ever seen," said Lynne Del Monte, an island resident out for a recent morning stroll.
All island householders belong to The Saugatuck Island Owners Association, to which they pay dues of $150 a year for road repairs and snow plowing. The association also maintains a private boat launch and two small beaches, and when the "clamming is open" sign is posted islanders can count on shellfish for dinner.
SAUGATUCK SHORES, northwesterly and just above Saugatuck Island, and the island itself are dense with homes -- everything from rebuilt fishing shacks to waterfront mansions. They sell from the mid-$300,000's to $2 million or more, and increase in value as the supply of waterfront dwindles.
Properties range in size from a rare acre or two down to a quarter-acre and the proverbial postage-stamp size, tucked behind other houses along gravel-covered lanes. So little land is available that new homes are built by buying old ones and razing them.
"Celebrities and privacy-seekers tend to buy in northern Westport," said Marta Flavin, a broker with Riverside-Shavell Realty. "Saugatuck houses are too close together for their taste." But Saugatuck summer rentals to celebrities are common, priced up to $30,000 for two months.
Joseph P. Arcudi, Westport's First Selectman and the son of an immigrant, is concerned about the revaluation of all town property, required by the state every 10 years, and due to be completed and in force by Oct. 1, 1995. "More than 250 people came to a meeting last month to discuss the ramifications," he said. "Most of them were waterfront property owners. Their value has gone up more than any others."
The decline in value of commercial property, which accounts for 20 percent of Westport's $3 billion worth of real estate, will shift an additional tax burden onto householders. Currently, Westport's tax rate is in the lower third statewide and houses are selling well, thus increasing their value and tax liability, said Mr. Arcudi.
"It seems like every other couple that comes into the office has a baby, or the wife is pregnant," said Sarita Solomon, a broker with William Raveis Realty on Riverside Avenue. "Saugatuck is attractive to young people because of the wide range of house styles and prices. It's possible to find a house under $300,000."
A principle reason for choosing Westport is its public schools: three elementary and two middle schools and one high school, which consistently produces S.A.T. scores that exceed state and national averages by 50 to 80 points.
The current baby boom required an addition of six classrooms and a library-media center to the King's Highway Elementary School, which Saugatuck children attend. Another addition will soon be necessary at the Bedford Middle School, but Staples High School will not be affected.
Westport's reputation for academic excellence is enhanced by award-winning programs in music, art, drama and sports, extended kindergarten hours from 8:30 A.M. to 1:15 P.M., the first FM radio station in the Northeast operated by high school students, a regional program for handicapped children, foreign languages from grade 5 on, and a predominance of teachers with master's degrees and doctorates whose average salary is $60,000.
In addition, there are 13 privately operated preschools and day-care centers, where child-care services for infants as young as 6 weeks, from 7:30 A.M. to 6 P.M. five days a week, cost around $200. Detailed information is available through the Pupil Personnel Department at Staples High School.
Westport's only private school is Greens Farms Academy, a day school where tuition for kindergarten to Grade 12 ranges from $10,700 to $13,600.
Recreation for the people of Saugatuck focuses on the water. Those who do not have a private dock can join the Cedar Point Yacht Club, with 150 slips, or Saugatuck Harbor Yacht Club. Cedar Point charges an initiation fee of $1,000 and $1,000 a year dues, with slip fees of $16 to $25 a foot per season. Saugatuck Harbor, with 160 slips at fees of $35 to $45 a foot, charges $1,000 in dues. But E. Don Smith, the club's commodore, would not disclose the initiation fee.
Both clubs are for serious sailors and neither has a restaurant or a bar, but their kitchens are at the disposal of members or caterers.
THE municipal Longshore Country Club on the east shore of the Saugatuck River, has a waiting list for its two marinas, which have a total of 245 slips (with fees of $13 to $20 a foot per season) and 183 moorings, but the golf course and 9 tennis courts are available to residents for $20 a season.
Greens fees are $7 to $13 daily, or $75 for the season. Tennis fees are $2 to $6 for an hour and a half, or $70 for the season and the fees apply to three other municipal locations with a total of 17 courts elsewhere in Westport.
Nearly a dozen restaurants of many ethnicities, but mostly Italian, thrive in Saugatuck. They include DeRosa's, specializing in northern Italian cuisine. A 10-ounce loin veal chop stuffed with fontanella cheese is $14.95. The Mansion Clam House features 1-pound lobsters with corn on the cob and salad for $18.95.
Cultural amenities in Westport proper include the Westport Country Playhouse, founded as a straw-hat theater in the 1930's by the Theater Guild of New York; the Westport Arts Center, where exhibitions, music, dance, lectures and art classes are scheduled all year; and the Nature Center for Environmental Activities.
Resident permits for three Westport beaches cost $20 a season, and admission to the 234-acre Sherwood Island Beach State Park off Exit 18 of I-95 is $5 weekdays, $7 weekends for residents, $8 and $12 for out-of-staters.
Shops on Main Street in downtown Westport include Barney's, The Gap, Coach leather goods, Williams-Sonoma, Joan & David and dozens of one-of-a-kind boutiqes. A new public library is off Route 1 near the Levitt Pavilion, where free summer concerts are held on the riverbank.
A Saugatuck relic of the early 1800's, when farmers sent their onions to New York by boat, the Bridge Street bridge over the Saugatuck River swings sideways to let vessels pass. David Haehl's great-grandfather was one of six men who operated the hand crank before the bridge was motorized. He also built the house that the family still lives in.
Descended from early Dutch, Irish and Scottish stock, Mr. Haehl is a dedicated Saugatucker. "We consider ourselves different from Westporters," said Mr. Haehl. "We've been here longer, and we stay here."

 ITALIAN FESTIVAL: Before the mid-50's, when the Connecticut Turnpike fragmented the old Italian neighborhood, a modest Feast of St. Anthony was held each July on Franklin Street. A parade was led by men carrying the St. Anthony statue, and homemade Italian foods were dispensed from booths on the street. Today the event goes on for four days and has grown so large, with food, entertainment, merchandise for sale, and a huge parade, that it is held in the parking lot of the railroad station and attracts around 110,000 visitors from Connecticut, New York and New Jersey. Saugatuck's old-timers still pin money on the statue in the old way, and linger at the booth that displays pictures of their immigrant forebears.

HEADLINE: Indian Point and the Bottom Line

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD 

DATELINE: CROTON-ON-HUDSON

 BODY:
THE Indian Point 3 nuclear plant in Buchanan is either a dinosaur, unable to compete economically against younger technologies in a changing environment, or it is a valuable asset that is getting much-needed changes in management and worker training so it can resume saving money for its customers.
The New York Power Authority, the country's largest state-owned utility, which owns the plant and takes the second view, squared off last week against critics of the plant -- proponents of the dinosaur theory -- in a legislative hearing here that is likely to be only the first of a series of debates that will take a 30-year dispute about nuclear power in Westchester into a new phase: economics. 
 The discussions will boil down to a giant, complex game of "what if."
The factors involved are stunning in their variety. There is the cost of competing fuels, especially natural gas; the level of industrial demand for electricity, the success of future campaigns to increase energy efficiency and the life expectancies of other generating stations around the state, nuclear and non-nuclear.
There is also the question of how much money can be safely cut from the plant's budget, and whether some unforeseen event, at Indian Point 2 or 3 or at any of 107 other reactors nationwide -- or several hundred around the world -- will create the need for changes at the plant.
When it produces power at all -- which it has not done in 19 months because of safety problems and will not do before next spring at the earliest -- Indian Point 3's electricity costs more than power from the open market, about 4.4 cents a kilowatt-hour, opposed to about 3 cents for electricity available on an hour-by-hour basis through the power grid.
At the heart of the problem is high operating costs and a statewide surplus of more than 4,000 megawatts. (The peak demand for power in the state is about 26,000 megawatts.) Not counted in that surplus is the cushion of 22 percent that the state's utilities like to have on hand in case of breakdown or maintenance shutdown.
Opponents believe surplus opens up the best opportunity to close Indian Point 3 since the early 1980's, the years immediately after the 1979 accident at the Three Mile Island plant near Harrisburg, Pa., when the Nuclear Regulatory Commission insisted on better emergency plans, and the reactors at Indian Point, with nearly 300,000 people within 10 miles, had difficulty complying. The hearings in the 1980's on the adequacy of emergency plans for the site in Buchanan were the longest in the history of the commission.
Now, some people want to try again.
"You'd have to have a relatively significant savings to justify the public-health risk, and the data is, it's more expensive," said Assemblyman Richard L. Brodsky, Democrat of Greenburgh and chairman of the State Assembly's Environmental Conservation Committee, who held a hearing on the plant's economics in Croton last week.
Here, though, all estimates rely on "what ifs." What, for example, would the surplus look like if every plant were subjected to a hardheaded cost analysis?
S. David Freeman, the president of the Power Authority, testified that for now his agency "could probably purchase power at a price lower than the total embedded capital and operating costs of Indian Point 3. However, if every plant that is high cost in the short-term wholesale market in New York State were shut down, we'd be very short of power."
And in that case, utilities would be forced to run their most expensive plants, the ones that burn the most expensive fuels or burn them the least efficiently, and the result would be higher costs. At that point, experts say, Indian Point 3's power might look cheap again.
Another "what if" is what happens if the plant runs no better in future than it did in the past.
"Today the plant is uneconomic," Mr. Freeman said in an interview. "It's had a bad run the last year and a half; it's dead in the water." But new management and new attitudes will make it run better, he said; besides, most of the work required for reopening the plant has already been done.
If the plant is retired now, he said, it would be on the basis of imperfect information. "I don't know the future, and I don't think anybody else does," he said. "One can have lots of projections for future natural gas prices, and somebody in all of this world is going to be right, but if you look at the past, there haven't been many of them."
On the other hand, Charles Komanoff, an energy analyst, said in testimony that if the plant is kept running, it would also be on the basis of uncertain assumptions.
Mr. Freeman, who was instrumental in canceling several nuclear construction projects when he was the chairman of the Tennessee Valley Authority, said that he would not hesitate to pull the plug if it did not appear that the plant could run well. Before coming to the Power Authority in March, he was the general manager of the Sacramento, Calif., Municipal Utility District, an agency he joined shortly after voters there decided to shut their nuclear plant, Rancho Seco.
The error there, Mr. Freeman said, was spending hundreds of millions of dollars to fix up the plant and then finding out that it still would not run reliably. But Indian Point 3 deserves another chance, he said, and some cost-saving measures have not been explored, like merging security forces and spare-parts inventories with Indian Point 2, Con Edison's reactor, which is adjacent. Some people want to close Indian Point 2 also, but it runs more reliably so its power is cheaper, and closing it would be more complicated because the state does not own it. Indian Point 1, also operated by Con Edison, ran from 1962 to 1974.
Mr. Freeman did not offer a detailed analysis but said he would confer with Mr. Komanoff to see why their assessments differed. Despite the fact that the two appeared in conflict at the hearing last week, the two are longtime allies, proponents of investing in conservation.
But another state official, Francis J. Murray Jr., the State Energy Commissioner, did present an analysis that favored the plant. He sketched out four possibilities, each with a different combination of retirement dates: nuclear plants 30 to 40 years old and fossil plants 45 to 60 years old. He also threw into the mix varying levels of demand-side management, meaning utility subsidies to customers to invest in motors, lamps, air-conditioners and other equipment that uses less electricity.
Under certain assumptions, he demonstrated, retiring the plant now would mean requiring new generating capacity as early as 2003, which is so close in utility terms that a company that thought it would need a new generator then would be actively planning it now. With a different set of assumptions, no new capacity is needed before 2009.
The electric system currently allows expensive plants to operate, a situation that economists describe as inefficient, because most customers are not free to shop for cheaper supplies elsewhere. The Power Authority's single largest customer, New York City and its various governmental agencies, would like to shop that way and anticipates that in a few years, with changing Federal and state laws, it will be able to, paying Con Edison to deliver the power over its lines.
Already, the threat of a free market in electricity has helped prompt the Power Authority to offer the city a long-term contract, making the authority's pain over the reactor more acute. Thus Kent Miller, the city's director of energy policy, said the city did not care what happened to the reactor, because it expects a contract that will insulate it from the cost increases that come when the plant is shut.
But if the market opens up to allow users to negotiate with producers without the utility as a middleman -- a practice known as retail wheeling -- selling expensive electricity from Indian Point could become even more difficult.
Illustrating the degree to which the problems of energy are interconnected with other problems, Mr. Miller said, New York City would not favor closing the plant if the Power Authority planned to make up the lost production by burning more oil and natural gas at the Polletti generating station in Queens. That would add to the city's air pollution problems, he said.
Looming over the plant is another possibility, that expenses will rise instead of fall. In Albany, the Department of Environmental Conservation is considering requiring power plants on the Hudson to build cooling towers so they can use their cooling water over and over, drawing only small amounts to make up for evaporation rather than running water through the cooling system only once, as they do now. The current system pulls small fish into the plant and kills them.
The cost of a cooling tower has been variously estimated. Mr. Freeman said it might be $200 million, probably too much to justify continuing to operate the plant.

HEADLINE: A Building to Love, but Not to Buy

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM 

 BODY:
THE most expensive item on display these days at Ralph Lauren's flagship store on Madison Avenue is not the tartan socks ($21), or the mohair skirts ($365) or even the leopard-accented throws ($2,165). It's the building it's all housed in.
Called the Rhinelander mansion after the grande dame who built it 96 years ago, the little architectural gem can be had for a cool $46 million -- cash and carry. 
 The building's owner, an Irish real-estate concern that acquired several trophy properties before falling on hard times, quietly put the mansion on the block more than two years ago and has yet to find a buyer at the asking price.
The green, bound, confidential sales memorandum, shows why the building is hard to unload. Like many one-of-a-kind assets from the Star of India to London Bridge, the bauble may be lovely to own, but don't count on it to pay the bills.
"It's easy to fall in love with this building, but from an economic point of view, I just don't see how it works," said Therese Byrne, publisher of Retail Maxim, a newsletter analyzing retail real estate.
Yet it's also easy to understand why many acquisitive types might at least toy with the idea. The four-story, faux French chateau is one of the city's best-known and beloved structures. Sitting primly on the southeast corner of Madison Avenue and 72d Street, it serves as a gatekeeper to one of the world's toniest shopping streets and is itself the home of one of the country's most chronicled emporiums, officially the highest-grossing store of the Polo Ralph Lauren Corporation.
"Every part of this building exudes personality," coos the American Institute of Architects' Guide to New York City.
But the Rhinelander has often been a building shunned. Even Gertrude Rhinelander Waldo, the wealthy blue blood who commissioned the building in 1895 for $500,000, preferred to stay in her old digs across Madison Avenue when it was completed in 1898.
The Dime Savings Bank foreclosed on the property in 1912, and it changed hands eight more times by 1989, when the current owners arrived on the scene. They paid a then astronomical $43 million -- a record $1,500 a square foot.
Even Mark T. De Riemer, the broker who was hired six months ago to market the property, acknowledged, "with a unique asset like this, you have to cast a pretty wide net to find an investor who's willing to buy the most exquisite real estate property in New York."
The property offers an extremely low return on investment, given current market norms. It relies entirely on one tenant who has considerable leverage when it comes time to renegotiate the rent. And the rent is already high by Madison Avenue standards.
"I would say this isn't a prudent investment," said Edward A. Friedman, president of Newmark Real Estate Services and a specialist in Manhattan's high-rent retail districts. "But I won't say no one would buy it. Look at what was paid for the Empire State building."
Assuming a buyer paid for the Rhinelander all in cash, his annual return would be only 6.2 percent, according to the sales document. "Anyone sitting around with $46 million in cash is going to be looking for a much better return," said C. Bradley Mendelson, senior managing director at the Edward S. Gordon company, a Manhattan brokerage.
The rent is up for renegotiation on Jan. 1, and real estate analysts estimate that annual payments could jump from $2.83 million to $3.33 million, a 17 percent increase at a time when rents along the rest of the avenue have stabilized.
Ralph Lauren, who owns 64.8 percent of Polo Ralph Lauren, has never minded paying up to showcase his designs in a luxurious setting.
A customer laden with packages, leaving the building on Thursday night, said he believes Mr. Lauren was getting his money's worth. "When you enter this building, you step into another world and leave New York behind," said Peter John, a 30-year-old photographer. "I was just in Brooks Brothers' on Madison Avenue, and I didn't feel the same." Another customer appeared thoroughly drawn to the Lauren mystique: Mike Philipps, a 30-year-old stockbroker, said everything he was wearing, down to his boxer shorts, was made by Ralph Lauren.
But the analysts bet that overpaying is a luxury that Mr. Lauren may no longer be able to afford. They expect him either to fight the rent increase or try to renegotiate the lease. His company is already paying a big chunk of its sales -- 8.3 percent to be precise -- to rent the mansion, and sales at the flagship store have been flat to down. With depreciation on the $20 million renovation of the mansion, and other outlays, Polo's occupancy costs approach 20 percent of revenues.
More problematically, the current owners have yet to discuss the rent increase with Polo, which under the lease has to agree to a fair market value for the property before the rent can be recalculated.
The landlord, the Power Corporation P.L.C., has been preoccupied with its own financial problems. It is also possible that it is holding back so as not to agitate its sole tenant before it sells the property.
Real estate experts had a hard time coming up with names of likely buyers. The offering memorandum is clearly pitched to foreign investors, including information that American investors would find redundant, like how many airports service New York City, maps of the Upper East Side and a full-blown description of Mr. Lauren's many achievements, including a list of magazines that have featured him on their covers.
But many of the foreign investors who spent astronomical amounts of money to snap up New York trophy properties in the 1980's are out of commission. Japanese investors are beset by economic woes at home. Arab investors were among those who sold the mansion to Power, turning a 583 percent profit on their original $6.3 million investment in just five years.
And the Chinese and Koreans who are busily scooping up prime Manhattan real estate, are too budget-minded. "When the Japanese bought property, they wanted the equivalent of a Chanel bag," Ms. Byrne said. "The Chinese, they want a good knockoff."
Mr. De Riemer said European investors are the likeliest prospects. Why doesn't Mr. Lauren buy the fabled jewel himself? It appears that he is equally value-oriented when it comes to his own purchases. "It's a wonderful building," said Peter Strom, vice chairman of Polo Ralph Lauren. "We'd love to own it at the right time and at the right price."

HEADLINE: Wall Street;
Copper Linings for Wall St. Clouds?

BYLINE: By Susan Antilla 

 BODY:
COPPER, that great catalyst of scintillating conversation at gatherings of metallurgists, is making for interesting talk in stock market circles.
September-delivery copper closed at a four-year high of $1.278 a pound on Monday, the peak of a recent rally that caught the attention of Wall Street's tea-leaf readers. 
 Never at a loss for a market rule of thumb, some Wall Street types dredged up this gem: "Every bull market has a copper roof." Or, if copper rallies, the stock market falls.
Indeed, in the most recent history of copper prices, an all-out rally in copper prices that started in November 1986 took off in advance of the 1987 stock market crash. And the copper rally from December 1989 to August 1990 got going before the 21 percent decline in the Dow Jones industrial average between July and October of 1990.
For the most part, though, copper rallies portend stock market slumps with about the reliability of a coin toss, said Jeff Rubin of Birinyi Associates, a research firm in Greenwich, Conn. "We've also had plenty of rallies that were not coincident with a big market dropoff," he said.
In the 15 copper rallies of 20 percent or more since 1948, the Dow followed with a bear market only eight times, said Mr. Rubin. Not nearly as reliable as the Super Bowl theory, the hemline indicator, or the position of Venus in the darkening Wall Street skies.
The belief that euphoria over copper is bad for stocks derives from peculiarities of the economic cycle, explained Steve Leuthold of the Leuthold Group, a securities research firm in Minneapolis. "Big copper rallies like this one take place when shortages take place in an expansion," he said. A copper rally could be a signal that the economic expansion is getting long in the tooth, Mr. Leuthold explained. And since conventional wisdom has it that the stock market turns down 6 to 12 months before the nation's recovery goes kaput, the copper rally could be bad news.
This go-round, however, investors trying to make sense of copper's rise had better take a broader look at economies internationally, the pros say, because the big demand for copper isn't coming from the United States. "Our economic expansion is 44 months old," said Mr. Leuthold. "But the European one is only about a year old, and the Japanese expansion is even less."
Ditto the importance of growth in India and China, said Jim Williams of Williams Inference Service, a business consultant in Longmeadow, Mass. "You've got exploding middle classes in India and China that need new refrigerators, new TV sets, new cars -- things that use commodities like copper," he said. Add to the worldwide demand for commodities the fact that copper is the speculator's metal of choice, and you wind up with more demand than supply, explained Michael Metz, market strategist at Oppenheimer & Company. "Copper is the commodity with the largest speculative following," he explained.
All that demand has led to what commodities traders call backwardization -- a fancy word that's used when spot prices of a metal today are higher than those of the same metal in the futures market.
Stay with us now, and you can amaze your friends at otherwise dull cocktail parties. Metals prices in a bull market would seem naturally to be higher in the futures market, which reflects price expectations months ahead, than the current spot price. But when there are shortages, the so-called "nearby" spot price can wind up higher than that of the futures -- a "backwards" way for things to be.
It causes refiners and extractors of copper to gear up to produce more copper, explained Mr. Leuthold. "So four or five months from now, there will be more production onstream after producers decide they can make money even on more expensive refining processes," he said. But for now, the actual metal available for delivery is in short supply, making spot prices unusually high.
Copper's popularity may derive from international considerations that have no direct effect on American stocks, said Mr. Williams. But the same international expansions that are goosing copper's price might have their own effects on our domestic financial markets, he added. Mr. Williams's guess is that third-world expansions will be funded largely by borrowing from developed countries, and that, of course, means "the price of money goes up." And everybody knows how well the stock market likes higher rates.
But that doesn't support a theory that directly ties the action in copper to the action in the Dow, say analysts. "Correlation doesn't necessarily imply causation," said Steve Hanke, professor of applied economics at Johns Hopkins University, who said he remembers hearing the "copper rallies lead to Dow declines" theory after the 1987 stock market crash.
"Storks do land on houses in Europe that have newborns in the house, but that doesn't mean they delivered the babies," Mr. Hanke said. More likely the storks like the warm chimneys of families trying to keep the house toasty.
"It is really true," he insisted. "You always find storks on chimneys of houses with newborns." Which may be a tidbit even more useful to investors than that of the copper-leads-to-Dow declines theory.

HEADLINE: Business Diary: September 25-30

BYLINE: By Hubert B. Herring 

 BODY:

COMPANIES
 
At the Epic Battle of Virginia, Historians Rout Disney
In this sprawling circus tent that is America, there's certainly room for many things -- a bit of history here, a bit of slicked-up entertainment there. But what bothered some people about Disney's grand idea for a theme park in northern Virginia was that with authentic history so close by -- Civil War battle sites galore -- the glitz could drown out the real stuff. Most Virginians supported the park -- the Governor, after all, had visions of 19,000 jobs and $47 million in annual revenues for the state. But opponents -- including some vocal historians and environmentalists -- made enough noise to get their way, and last week Disney dropped plans to build Disney's America at its chosen site. It vowed to seek another site in Virginia, but given all the regulatory hoops it must jump through, it'll be years after 1998 -- the original target -- before it opens. 

The $600 Million Man
Five years ago, you would have thought Peter Guber laid golden eggs by the case. It's one thing to shell out a few dollars to snag a prize executive, but Sony's staggering cost to get Mr. Guber's services left Hollywood wondering if the decimal points were remotely in the right place. So badly did Sony want him to oversee its newly acquired studios, Columbia and Tri-Star, that it paid roughly $200 million to buy out the production company owned by Mr. Guber and Jon Peters, and perhaps $400 million more to buy out the team's Warner Brothers contract. After that, Mr. Guber's $2.75 million salary seemed like a paltry tip. Granted, the Guber-Peters team did lay golden film eggs -- "Rain Man," "Batman." But at Sony, the flops, like "Last Action Hero," piled up. Last week, having cost Sony over $100 million a year, Mr. Guber resigned -- "to follow my dreams."
 
G.M.'s Balancing Act
General Motors is trying to take the long view, but that instinct can crash head-on into short-term realities. It's selling cars now, so it's got to make cars. But it balks at hiring more workers unless it knows it can keep them busy. What this added up to last week was that workers at one plant, weary of endless overtime, endless assembly-line pressure, went on strike demanding relief. And they didn't mean temporary workers, G.M.'s preferred solution. The strike quickly rippled across the auto-making landscape, disrupting numerous assembly plants.
 
You Think You're Organized?
The gadget factories -- O.K., O.K., "consumer electronics companies" -- keep telling us we need "personal digital assistants." These portable devices, one gathers, allow you to do practically anything but beam yourself to the office -- send e-mail, make plane reservations, check stock quotes. Thus far mankind has muddled through without them -- AT&T stopped making its EO, and Apple's Newton has had slim sales. But here comes the Magic Link PIC 1000, on sale last week at $995, and everyone seems to be involved -- Apple, Sony, Motorola, AT&T, you name it. You can tell it to page you if you get mail from the boss. If that's what you want.
 
USAir, Feeling the Pinch
USAir has problems, and they go a lot deeper than its string of crashes. It's lost $1.8 billion since 1988, and is trying to get its unions to cut back -- so far, with no success. So last week, trying a time-honored solution, it stopped paying some bills. To be precise, it deferred payments on its preferred stock. Representatives of two big investors, Berkshire Hathaway and British Airways, voted with other directors to halt the payments -- "sending a signal," as an analyst put it, that USAir is "sharing the pain." Investors were in no mood for pain, though, and sent USAir stock plunging.
 
ECONOMY
 
A Man, a Plan, a Root Canal (Well, the Political Equivalent)
This, alas, is the way the American system works. People agree something's a mess, a presidential candidate vows to fix it, he gets elected, he makes it his top priority -- and then the politicians and the lobbyists and the armchair experts get hold of it and everything goes kerflooey. And so it was that another bold crusade sputtered to a halt last week as George Mitchell played taps for national health insurance. Who did it? Did President Clinton aim too high? Did Republicans conspire against him? Did special interests dynamite the process? All the above, and more. But there's always next year. "I will never give up the fight," said Teddy Kennedy (assuming he gets reelected).
 
Defining Mutual Fund Risk
Most investors have probably never heard of derivatives -- or if they have, think of them merely as something they wouldn't want to meet in a dark Wall Street alley. The S.E.C. wants to keep it that way. Reasoning, correctly, that investors in mutual funds, especially bond and money market funds, want nothing to do with these high-octane concoctions, the S.E.C. last week recommended that for the first time fund sponsors be forced to tell shareholders just what gambles are being made with their money. The next hurdle: how, exactly, to put a statistical face on something as elusive as risk.
 
If in Doubt, Promise Tax Cuts
Well, it certainly worked for Christine Todd Whitman. George Pataki knows that a lot of voters, even those who profess a deep and abiding concern for the common good, care most deeply about one thing. So last week, after critics said he had no economic plan, he came up with a novel one: cut taxes. To be specific, cut the top income tax rate by 25 percent, and have fewer people paying that rate. The dent in state revenues by 1998: $5.6 billion. And where, specifically, would this come from? Basically, slash the state work force, sell a plane and a couple of helicopters, and pray like crazy for a flourishing economy. To be fair, of course, Governor Cuomo -- who called the Pataki plan a "magic act" -- is playing this game too, with vague promises of $1.5 billion in cuts in income and business taxes. Read their minds: "I want to be Governor."
 
Inflation Bells Are Ringing
Once again, economic news took a roller-coaster ride. On Tuesday, as the markets held their breath, the Federal Reserve panel that handles such matters met but announced no interest-rate increase. But just two days later came a flood of reports suggesting that the economy was charging ahead. Second-quarter growth was put at a strong 4.1 percent rate, while jobless claims fell to the year's lowest level and new-home sales surged. Good news, of course, for job-seekers and builders -- but the inflation alarms started ringing like crazy.
 
INTERNATIONAL
 
A Leaky Investment
Back in 1986, it must have seemed a glamorous investment -- and perhaps one with a big payoff, too. But anyone who put money in the Channel Tunnel is probably looking longingly at simpler inventions. Like tugboats. With delay after delay, costs have risen to twice the original budget. And those dividends promised for next year? Try 2004. Then last week, in what investors fervently hoped was the final blow, there were reports -- possibly exaggerated -- that the tunnel was leaking. Sure enough, those battered Eurotunnel shares hit a record low. And passenger service doesn't even start til next month.
 
Brazil, Meet the World
Brazil elects a President tomorrow, and if, as expected, it is Fernando Henrique Cardoso, the nation could finally move toward a far bigger role in the world economy. Brazil, with Latin America's largest economy, is the only big South American country still clinging to barriers to foreign investment, but last week Mr. Cardoso said he'd change all that. "Nafta doesn't frighten us," he said, vowing to break up state monopolies and allow foreign investment in many areas. As Finance Minister, Mr. Cardoso managed to wrestle Brazil's inflation down to a livable level, a strong sign that if he promises something, he'll probably deliver. If, of course, he's elected.
 
Mr. Yeltsin's Neighborhood
Boris Yeltsin knows which side of this country to butter up. What he needs, he keeps saying, is not a handout, but investment and trade. And since trade is greased by proximity, he looks longingly at the Northwest. Not counting Alaska, Seattle is the mainland American city closest to Russia, and Washington is the state with the largest concentration of companies doing business with Russia. In five years, in fact, Russian trade with the Northwest has grown sixfold, to nearly $200 million a year. So it was only natural last week that Mr. Yeltsin would stop off in Seattle to pay his respects.

HEADLINE: Wall Street;
Why Fund Investors Just Aren't Buying American

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris 

 BODY:
AS interest rates have risen this year, the great love affair between mutual fund investors and Government bond funds has soured. At the end of August, such funds had seen 23 percent of their assets disappear from their peak in the summer of 1993. And the closely related mortgage-backed funds had done even worse, with assets off 24 percent. 
 Fortunately for the mutual fund industry, much of that money has gone into other kinds of funds -- primarily stock funds. There is now more money in funds that invest solely in foreign stocks than there is in United States Government bond funds. Between them, mortgage-backed and Government bond funds had almost 28 percent of all long-term fund assets just after the 1987 crash, and more than 17 percent as recently as late 1992. But now that market share has fallen below 10 percent for the first time since 1985, when the boom in bond funds was just beginning. FLOYD NORRIS
