HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends;
Who's for More Inflation and Who Isn't

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
EVER since the 1970's, when the nation really got hit with inflation, Americans have been telling themselves that a rising inflation rate is villainous. But now some powerful people are stepping forth and saying that maybe a little more inflation is not so bad. Or maybe the alternative is worse.
They don't put it that way. The ghost of the 70's, when the inflation rate almost tripled in the blink of three years, is still powerful enough so that almost no one dares to offer three cheers for rising inflation. But the ghost is losing its spookiness. There have been too many months in which sharply rising inflation has been expected, feared, spotted down the block -- but never in the house. 
 And now an increasingly vocal constituency is saying that maybe the world has changed. Maybe the annual inflation rate can get as high as 4 percent -- it is 2.8 percent today -- and still not shoot up, as it did in the 70's. They are manufacturers, retailers and some bankers, among others. All are prospering. And they argue that their newfound prosperity might not last without a little tolerance of rising inflation.
Their campaigning is directed today at a single institution, the Federal Reserve, and a single possible act: whether the Federal Reserve should raise interest rates another notch in 1994. In the eyes of the inflationists, that extra notch, the sixth increase this year, could finally discourage borrowing in a nation that requires abundant credit to thrive.
The National Retail Federation, not given to openly lobbying the Federal Reserve, did so last Tuesday, when the Fed met to consider another rate increase. That would "lead to a dampening of consumer confidence and spending" just as Christmas approaches, said Tracy Mullin, the Federation president, in a letter to the central bank.
The Federal Reserve, perhaps taking into account this appeal and others, did not act. And Ms. Mullin did not describe her federation as pro-inflation. Her case is that less borrowing means less economic growth. But in America today, economic growth and inflation are intertwined, so that favoring brisk economic growth means tolerating a rising inflation rate, and conversely fighting inflation means favoring slower economic growth.
A new uncertainty feeds the debate. Economists used to know, more or less accurately, the level of economic growth that might set off spiraling inflation. But changing times may have altered the dynamics. "In these uncertain circumstances, people say what is in their interest," said Herbert Stein, chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers in the Nixon Administration. In their interest, a huge and diverse group of anti-inflationists -- a coalition grouped together loosely as The Bond Market -- is campaigning for higher interest rates and less economic growth to keep a lid on the inflation rate.
Although they may not think of themselves as members, millions of Americans who have accumulated trillions of dollars in savings in recent decades belong to the coalition. They have lent out their savings, most often to the Government through the purchase of Treasury bonds, but also by investing in mutual funds or in pension funds that, in turn, buy bonds. Mainly these Americans are wealthy, but anyone with savings can have a stake in the fight against inflation. Their stake is this: Their money should not lose value while it is out on loan. The money should buy as much in the future, when the loans are repaid or retirement comes, as it does today. And that means no erosion from inflation.
Foreigners who lend money in the United States, usually by buying Treasury securities, also belong to the coalition. So does anyone who imports foreign goods and parts, another big contingent. Their concern is not loans, but the likelihood that inflation will drive down the dollar's value, making imports more expensive. And then there are bankers, but their long-standing membership in the anti-inflation coalition is wavering.
Banks lend out deposits as car loans and mortgages, for example. Once, they worried that inflation would erode the value of this money before it was repaid. But now the banks sell the loans to others, at a profit, letting these others worry. Rather than inflation, the banks' concern has increasingly become making as many loans as possible. And that requires brisk economic growth.
Understandably, then, the American Bankers Association is not so quick to join the anti-inflationists. "The thought of inflation is frightening to bankers," said James Chessen, the association's chief economist. "But they don't want to see lending dry up either."
The nation's manufacturers aren't afflicted with such ambivalence. They have begun a full-court press against another rate increase by the Federal Reserve this year. To hear the National Association of Manufacturers tell it, slowing the economy, just when their goods are selling briskly, would be an insult. After all, they say, their efficiency and flexibility are so much greater than in the 80's. They can keep the marketplace stocked well beyond the old boiling point, when rising demand created shortages that drove up prices and with it the inflation rate.
"American manufacturing is at the beginning of a competitive comeback that we don't want to see derailed by an unnecessary economic slowdown," said Jerry Jasinowski, the association's president. "We want more growth, and we are willing to accept some inflation with it." Not incidentally, a little more inflation might help the manufacturers make price increases stick.
Nodding in agreement with the manufacturers and the retailers are just about anyone in the housing and auto industries, where rising interest rates for car loans and mortgages could dissipate the current good times. Labor is also a standard proponent of strong economic growth, but now more than usual. "We are right at the point that employers might hire more permanent, full-time workers" said John Zalusky, an A.F.L.-C.I.O. economist.
And then there are the fence-straddlers, chief among them the Clinton Administration. It boasts of the rising economy and the gains in employment. But concern is also expressed that inflation might get out of hand. And there is no overt lobbying of the Federal Reserve.
The approaching Congressional elections are also producing some fence-straddlers. Neither Democrats nor Republicans are eager to campaign on a platform of less inflation if it means less growth.

LENGTH: 2057 words

HEADLINE: The Tyrant Mao, as Told by His Doctor

BYLINE: By RICHARD BERNSTEIN, Special to The New York Times 

 BODY:
Mao Zedong, China's "Great Helmsman" whose brilliance, the official doctrine insists, led a vast nation to restored greatness, was actually an irritable, manipulative egotist incapable of human feeling who surrounded himself with sycophants and refused even to be treated for a sexually transmitted disease, though he knew he was spreading it to the numerous young women who shared his bed.
Those are among the elements of an extraordinarily intimate portrait of Mao drawn by Li Zhisui, who was his private physician from 1955 until Mao's death in 1976 at the age of 82. 
 Dr. Li, who has lived in the United States since 1988, has written "The Private Life of Chairman Mao," a 663-page memoir of the imperial court of Mao that, in absolute contrast with the official image, portrays it as a place of boundless decadence, licentiousness, selfishness, relentless toadying and cutthroat political intrigue. Excerpts from the book, which will be published soon by Random House, will appear in the coming week's issue of U.S. News and World Report.
"In outer appearance, Mao was very easygoing, easy to contact," Dr. Li said in an interview at his home in suburban Chicago. "But when you stayed longer with him, you found that he was a merciless tyrant who crushed anybody who disobeyed him."
Dr. Li's memoir contains very little in the way of major revelations about the political or diplomatic history of the Maoist epoch. No new light, for example, is shed on the most mysterious event of the period, the abortive coup engineered by Mao's supposed hand-picked successor, Defense Minister Lin Biao, in 1971, or on such matters as Mao's role in the Korean War or the diplomatic opening to the United States.
But Dr. Li's book, even in focusing on the private side of Mao, contains numerous new details about the nature of his rule, including his associations with other major figures. Jiang Qing, Mao's third wife and later the head of the radical faction known as the Gang of Four, is portrayed as a flatterer and a hypochondriac who, by the time Dr. Li arrived on the scene, no longer had conjugal relations with Mao. Other major figures of the time are seen as reliably sycophantic toward Mao. Those very few who were not were purged as a result.
 
Zhou, Like Others, 'Was Really a Slave'
 "Mao was a man who had no friends," Dr. Li said. "He saw everybody as a subject, a slave. The mistake of those who got purged was to see themselves as equal to him. He wanted everybody to be subservient."
"Zhou Enlai was really a slave of Mao," Dr. Li said, speaking of the Chinese Prime Minister, whose reputation in the West was for sophistication and finesse. "He was absolutely obedient. Whenever I saw him with Mao he acted like a servant with his master. A lot of people think that Zhou protected people, that he was such a good man. But actually everything he did he did under Mao's orders. Mao was on the sedan chair and Zhou was one of his bearers."
Dr. Li, who is now 74, comes originally from Beijing but studied medicine during World War II at the West Union University Medical School in Sichuan Province in south-central China. The school was founded by American missionaries, so Dr. Li's training was mostly in English, which he speaks well.
He went to work as a ship's doctor in Australia but, when the Communists took power in China in 1949, he returned home at the behest of his older brother, also a doctor, who had been a Communist since the mid-1930's.
Through his well-connected brother, Dr. Li was assigned to be a physician at a special clinic set up to treat China's new top leaders. In 1955, he was named Mao's personal doctor. He lived with his wife, Lillian Wu, and their two sons in a home in the Zhongnanhai Compound, a closely guarded part of China's imperial-era Forbidden City where Mao and other senior leaders lived and worked.
From then until Mao's long illness and death in 1976 (after which Dr. Li presided over the efforts to preserve his body), he remained very close to Mao, according to his account. He not merely treated Mao's various illnesses, most of them very minor, but also accompanied him on his trips around the country, serving as his tutor in English and visiting him in response to his extremely frequent summonses, which often came in the early hours of the morning.
 
How Real Is Memoir? Photos Offer a Clue

Is Dr. Li's account authentic? Can future historians rely on this memoir? One important piece of evidence that Dr. Li is indeed who he says he is comes from the numerous photographs of himself with Mao taken at various periods throughout Dr. Li's stretch of service to the Chairman. Many of the photographs are included in the book.
In fact, there may never be any rock solid corroboration for many of the details that Dr. Li gives, or for the many anecdotes that he tells. But Chinese living in this country have no doubt that Dr. Li was Mao's doctor, while American specialists on China have been impressed by the consistency between Dr. Li's accounts of events and what was already known.
Dr. Li immigrated to the United States in 1988 to seek medical treatment for his wife, who died later that year. He now lives with one of his two sons and his family in a suburb of Chicago.
"It boils down to the fact that the person who worked with him on the book did a tremendous amount of checking," said Andrew J. Nathan, a specialist on Chinese politics at Columbia University said in an interview. Professor Nathan was referring to Anne F. Thurston, another expert on China, who worked as Dr. Li's editorial assistant.
"In helping to create the book for an American audience, she needed him to explain a lot of the material and he was able to do so in a way that checked out," he said.
Some of the descriptions in the book, minus the numerous details on Mao's very active sex life, have appeared in other memoirs, especially those concerning Mao's imperial way of life, his residence and swimming pool in Zhongnanhai, his chronic insomnia and the very odd hours that he kept, as well as the atmosphere of sycophancy that surrounded him. But nobody before has provided anything like the full, elaborately detailed portrait that Dr. Li presents in his book.
"Here's a picture of the daily life of a man who has absolute power, and the fascinating thing is how absolute power sort of deranges the possessor of it, so that the boundary between fantasy and reality is obliterated because there's nothing to check his will," Professor Nathan said. "He was insulated in his own cocoon while everybody danced to his whims, and that has a lot to do with the tremendous disasters Mao wrought on the country as a whole because he was insulated from reality. His fantasies became reality."
Indeed, in Dr. Li's voluminous description, Mao emerges as a kind of Chinese Caligula, whose bohemian and decadent life contrasted utterly with the images of it so carefully fashioned by Chinese propaganda.
 
In a Land of Denial, Vast Sexual Excess

The most salacious elements of Mao's career, in Dr. Li's portrait, certainly involve Mao's sexual life, which reached openly lascivious proportions in a country where sexual license was rigorously prohibited for almost everybody else.
Along the way, Dr. Li provides some medical details, including the fact that Mao had an undescended testicle and that he suffered from bouts of impotency. Mao was married three times and had several children but, Dr. Li writes, sometime in midlife, and for undetermined reasons, he became infertile.
"So, I've become a eunuch, haven't I," Dr. Li remembers Mao saying after hearing the news.
Mao, Dr. Li says, used women for three purposes, the first and most important having to do with his pleasure. At Zhongnanhai, and wherever Mao traveled, Dr. Li writes, there were dance parties -- this at a time when ballroom dancing in China was deemed bourgeois and actively discouraged. Young women from cultural troupes or from the Communist Party secretariat, women who Dr. Li says were "selected for their looks, their talent and their political reliability," came to the dances and Mao commonly chose one or more of them to be entertained in his room, or in his special train, or in the guesthouses where he stayed when on one of his many "national inspection tours."
The second reason was political. Dr. Li reports that the husband of one of Mao's girlfriends, for example, was a subordinate of Lin Biao, and that she reported back to Mao on Lin's plot against him.
Finally, Dr. Li says, Mao believed in the Daoist lore that sexual activity leads to longevity, or, at least, the Daoist lore "gave him an excuse to pursue sex not only for pleasure but to extend his life."
"By the early 1960's, as his power rose to new heights, he rarely complained about impotence," Dr. Li writes. "At the height of the Cultural Revolution in the 1960's, he and Jiang Qing were sexually estranged, but Mao had no problems with the young women he brought to his bed -- their numbers increasing and their average ages declining as Mao attempted to add years to his life according to the imperial formula."
Once, Dr. Li recalls, Mao sent him one of his sexual partners, a young woman who had come down with trichomonas vaginalis, which is sexually transmitted. Dr. Li treated her and several others who got the disease.
"The young women were proud to be infected," he writes. "The illness, transmitted by Mao, was a badge of honor, testimony to their close relations with the Chairman."
Mao himself showed no symptoms of the disease, though he was clearly a carrier of it, Dr. Li said. When Dr. Li suggested that he take some antibiotic to protect his sexual partners, Mao told Dr. Li: "If it's not hurting me, then it doesn't matter. Why are you getting so excited about it?"
Many of Mao's personal habits, as described by Dr. Li, seemed related to his godlike status. He lived virtually without regard to the clock, often sleeping during the day and, even when not sleeping, staying in his bed, remaining in his bathrobe for weeks at a time. He lived in rooms built near a swimming pool in Zhongnanhai and would often summon his closest advisers to see him well after midnight.
Mao never bathed or even washed his hands or face. Dr. Li says that during the day his bodyguards went into the room and wiped his body, his hands and his face with hot towels. He never brushed his teeth, which Dr. Li says were coated with a green patina. Mao's habit, shared by many peasants in China, was to wash his mouth in the morning with tea and then to eat the tea leaves. When, once, Dr. Li suggested to him that he should use a toothbrush, Mao's reply was, "A tiger never brushes his teeth."
Mao, in Dr. Li's portrait, became utterly convinced by the power of his own fantasies. If, for example, provincial party leaders transplanted rice near railroad tracks to impress Mao when he went by on his special train, he never seemed to want to notice that it was a fake. He appeared to be utterly indifferent to the immense suffering and even the death on a large scale that some of his utopian fantasies produced, whether through vast purges of intellectuals or policies like the Great Leap Forward.
"Mao never said a word about the suffering of people to me," Dr. Li said, "The word regret was not in his dictionary."
How did Dr. Li survive for so long so close to Mao when so many others were purged, or killed?
"He once told me," Dr. Li said, "that you can play with a dragon, but you have to be very careful not to touch a single spot on the dragon's neck where it is very sensitive. If you touch it, you're done for. He told me that he is that sort of dragon."
"I never said anything roughly or straightforwardly," Dr. Li continued. "In other words, if you worked for Mao, you had to disobey your own conscience. You can never say anything as you think it. You have, first of all, to think what Mao will say."
Dr. Li acknowledges that for his first few years with Mao, he was held in his spell, and admired him as China's savior. As the years passed, however, Mao's cruelty and selfishness filled him with loathing.
"If I had known what I was getting myself into in 1949, I would have stayed in Australia," Dr. Li said. "For so many years, I did yes-man work, just to survive."

HEADLINE: THE 1994 CAMPAIGN: THE DEMOCRATS;
Democrats See Only Negative Numbers

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1

 BODY:
With little more than five weeks until Election Day, the Democratic Party seems to be headed for one of its worst midterm drubbings since World War II, which would present President Clinton with enormous legislative problems in the last two years of his term.
It would also alter the shape of the 1996 Presidential campaign. 
 Though most professional politicians remain reluctant to make firm predictions, a month of episodic campaigning since Labor Day has persuaded leaders in both parties that the Republicans have a genuine chance of making the net gain of seven seats that they would need to seize control of the Senate for the first time since 1986.
They have led the Senate for only 10 of the 62 years since the election of Franklin D. Roosevelt.
"It's bleak, very, very bleak," a leading Democratic campaign consultant in the Midwest said recently, and a senior White House official commented, "We're in the soup up to our neck, and it's hot."
Roger Stone, a Republican consultant, who was understandably much more willing to be quoted by name than his Democratic brethren, said, "It's hard not to be optimistic," adding, "I think we're riding a 1974-style tide, the kind the Democrats rode after Watergate."
So ebullient are some Republicans that they dream of pulling off a startling political hat-trick by taking control of the Senate, the House of Representatives -- which they have not controlled for 40 years -- and the governorships of the nation's half-dozen most populous states.
But many races are dead heats, many more remain in doubt and the lengthy session of Congress means that many incumbents have not yet hit their stride, either on the stump or on television. Some Democratic strategists think they can still cut their party's losses by emphasizing Republican obstruction of President Clinton's proposals and by ridiculing the lack of financing details in Republican proposals put forth in a midterm platform this week.
"So far, they have made us the issue," said Robert Shrum, who is advising a number of Democratic candidates, including Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts. "We need to put the onus back on them -- their behavior, their negativism. In 1946, their slogan was 'Had Enough?' and they're trying the same thing this time. We can't let them get away with that."
But so far, all the momentum has been running one way. Democrats who were expected to win easily are hard-pressed, and supposedly vulnerable Republicans are doing well.
Republicans threaten the Democrats in a dozen Senate seats: open seats in Arizona, Maine, Michigan, Ohio, Oklahoma and Tennessee; and those now held by Senators Dianne Feinstein in California, Mr. Kennedy in Massachusetts, Frank R. Lautenberg in New Jersey, Harris Wofford in Pennsylvania, Jim Sasser in Tennessee, where there are two contests, and Charles S. Robb in Virginia.
It is the rule of American politics, not the exception, that the party holding the White House loses Congressional seats in midterm elections. It has held true in every such election since 1938 in the House and in all but three in the Senate. But the losses have been truly punishing only when the President was deeply unpopular with voters.
For the Democrats, the years of misery have been 1946, which produced a pair of Republican-led houses that Harry S. Truman derided as the "good-for-nothing, do-nothing 80th Congress," and 1966, when rising impatience with the grinding war in Vietnam, with the economy and with Lyndon B. Johnson himself cost the Democrats 47 seats in the House and 7 in the Senate.
There is little doubt that Mr. Clinton constitutes a major problem for the Democrats this year, with his approval rating hovering around 40 percent in the polls, although he has raised several million dollars for their races. Many Republicans, like Guy Millner of Georgia, who is trying to oust Gov. Zell Miller, seek to tie their opponents to the President; Democrats, like Representative Dave McCurdy of Oklahoma, who wants to succeed retiring Senator David L. Boren, also a Democrat, tend to stress their independence.
But there are other problems as well, many of them beyond Mr. Clinton's control or only marginally affected by his Presidency:
*A nagging sense of economic discomfort, evident despite the strong business turnaround that has marked Mr. Clinton's Presidency, is costing the Democrats the credit they might normally expect for good times. Real family income has been declining in the United States since 1972, according to Government statistics, and that has engendered pervasive worry about the future.
*The rebellion against incumbency, which has been gathering speed for a decade and helped elect Mr. Clinton in 1992, seems to be cutting more deeply into the Democrats this year because they control the House, the Senate and the Presidency. They are incumbent all over town.
*Many more Democratic senatorial seats are up this year, which gives the Republicans that many more chances to score breakthroughs.
The President has had to scramble hard for most of his legislative victories in the last two years, forming and reforming coalitions. The almost inevitable Republican gains in the House and Senate mean that doing so will be harder starting in January. Anything more than modest health care legislation, for example, seems unlikely, and welfare reform will be an uphill fight.
In the House, in particular, conservatives appear sure to have a stronger voice in 1995. Republican candidates are poised to pick up about a dozen Democratic-held seats in the South, for example. There, though both parties are more conservative than their counterparts elsewhere, the Republicans are clearly the more conservative of the two.
The picture would be more sharply altered if the Republicans took voting control of Congress.
In that event, Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, a hard-nosed partisan who has led his party's charge against Mr. Clinton, would probably be Speaker of the House; 93-year-old Strom Thurmond of South Carolina would be in line for the chairmanship of the Senate Armed Services Committee, and Jesse Helms of North Carolina, perhaps the most tenacious and quarrelsome conservative in the Senate, could demand the chair of the Foreign Relations Committee if he wanted it.
Almost certainly, that would mean gridlock with a vengeance.
Some members of Mr. Clinton's circle argue that it may help him two years from now, by giving him a stone on which to strike his flint. He could challenge the Republicans, newly saddled with authority, to devise a legislative program, which would give him a target for 1996. President Truman used that strategy in 1948.
Other top Democratic strategists think that the loss of either house would cripple the President.
If the Republicans took control of the Senate, Bob Dole of Kansas would be expected to become the majority leader. That might convince him not to run for President; some Republicans consider it doubtful that the party caucus would let him do both things at once if he wanted to.
A Republican Presidential primary contest without a Dole candidacy could produce a wide-open nominating race, though if Gov. Pete Wilson of California is re-elected, as now seems far more likely than it did a year ago, he could quickly emerge as a strong contender.
If the Republicans take eight Senate seats now held by Democrats, which seems quite conceivable, they could afford to lose one of the seats they now hold and still take control. They seem to be in the most trouble in Minnesota, where the Democratic candidate, Ann Wynia, a former state legislator, is running a strong campaign for the seat now held by Senator Dave Durenberger, a retiring Republican.
The Delaware race, where a 73-year-old Republican, William V. Roth Jr., is trying for fifth term, could produce an upset, Democrats think.
Republican House targets are concentrated in the South, but they crop up in all parts of the country. There are a half dozen in Ohio, four in Michigan, another half dozen in Washington State, five in California.
"There are still weeks to go," said Linda Divall, a Republican pollster. "But the close races tend to go to the party with the surge, and that's us, so far. I think we're sure to go from 178 seats now to more than 200, and it could be 210 or even 215."
It takes 218 to control the House.
But it is the battle for the statehouses that most excites the Republicans, who are thinking ahead to the 1996 general election campaign.
Traditionally, big-state governorships are considered good organizational bases, particularly for a party that does not hold the White House. Of the six biggest states, the Republicans are ahead in the polls in California, slightly ahead or dead even in New York, even in Texas (where their candidate is George W. Bush, a son of George Bush), slightly ahead in Florida (another Bush, George W.'s brother, Jeb, is the candidate here), slightly behind in Pennsylvania and well ahead in Illinois.

HEADLINE: Behind a Boom in Blooms: Safety, Drama and TV

BYLINE: By ANNE RAVER 

 BODY:
In the beginning, after everyone got kicked out of Eden, some hunters and gatherers stuck a few seeds in the ground, and the first gardeners were born.
Now, about 10,000 years later, the QVC shopping network has discovered gardening. And so have the baby boomers -- 60 million potential consumers of trowels, perennials, shrubs, trees, lily ponds and worm boxes. 
 In 1993, according to the National Gardening Survey, conducted by the Gallup Organization, 68 million American gardeners spent $22 billion on plants and equipment, up $6 billion from 1989.
The people who are spending the most -- an average of $400 a year -- are 30 to 49 years old, college educated, with annual incomes of more than $50,000. Those making $100,000 are spending twice as much.
"What's really hot now is the home as sanctuary," said Bruce Butterfield, who has been tracking trends for the National Gardening Association for 16 years, "and that includes making a space outdoors that renews you. In the 80's, the cocktail chatter was, 'How are your tomatoes?' Now it's, 'My perennial garden looks like hell.' "
Gardening has been America's No. 1 hobby for 15 years. So why now is it hotter than compost?
Television, for one thing. When Martha Stewart talks about hydrangeas on her syndicated television show, they sell out all over the country. The shopping networks are selling plants, cheap, and not just daffodils but peonies, bleeding hearts and butterfly bushes.
The Scripps Howard Broadcasting Company, which owns nine television stations, is setting up a 24-hour cable Home and Garden Television Network in Knoxville, Tenn., and plans to begin its live shows in November. Ken Lowe, the president of the new network, said it hoped to reach 30 million to 40 million homes in five years. Programs will include everything from how to design a rose garden to features on community gardens and the gardens of celebrities.
Newsstands are flooded with garden magazines like Fine Gardening, Organic Gardening, Gardens Illustrated, Horticulture Magazine, Sunset and Southern Living. The Meredith Corporation, which publishes Better Homes & Gardens, now offers its 7.6 million readers an eight-page insert devoted entirely to gardening and puts out seven special issues a year full of ideas for the home landscaper. And next year, it hopes to draw another million new readers to a glossier, more upscale gardening magazine, Home Garden and Landscape, designed for baby boomers.
"It's clear to us from the research we've done that the greatest increase in interest is among people with relatively higher income and more education," said Christopher Little, the president of Meredith's magazine group.
"They're being more thoughtful and conservative and investing their time and energy to making home a sanctuary," he said. (There's that word again.)
Lawns are passe.
"They want a patio with pretty plantings," Mr. Little said. "Or a pretty place under a tree where they can have coffee in the morning."
They do not want to wait 15 years to have a mature perennial garden or trees that give them shade. "They are not trying to re-create Versailles," he said. They want bulbs and annuals, pretty planter pots. Low-maintenance stuff with a quick return of satisfaction.
There is a breathless air about some of these boomer gardeners that comes from discovering Pompeii and Perovskia, an unruly old perennial that is suddenly hot, in one fell swoop.
"I can't believe you put this seed, this dry little thing in the ground, and it turns into this beautiful ---- " Dorothy Kalins, the editor in chief of Garden Design magazine, said, stopping herself short, because she knew she was rhapsodizing.
"There's something spiritual about it," she continued. "It connects you to the old order. And rituals. Yet it's leavened by such common sense and humor. And yet there's a sense of awe about the complexity of it all. The garden has everything. Sex, drama. Life and death."
Of course, Virgil and Pliny were saying the same things 2,000 years ago, but they did not have a glossy $5 magazine stuffed with $6,000 full-page ads from Ralph Lauren, Hathaway, Jaguar, Godiva, Rolex and Stolichnaya to pay for their thoughts on plants.
Garden Design, a well-respected but rather dry magazine published for 13 years by the American Society of Landscape Architects for professionals and gardeners who can talk about Beatrix Farrand and Chamaecyparis without missing a beat, was retooled and showed up in subscribers' mailboxes in April like some phoenix.
The magazine, now published by Meigher Communications, says its circulation has doubled, to 150,000, in six months.
Even the old guard has noticed an upswing in readers as well as blue-chip advertising. Horticulture Magazine, the 90-year-old workhorse for serious gardeners interested in perennials, unusual shrubs and landscape design, has a circulation of 330,000, up 50 percent in four years, it says.
Meanwhile, in the homes of Del Rio, Tex., and Phoenixville, Pa., gardeners are shopping by television.
On Sept. 14, a Wednesday, at 11 A.M. in the small city of West Chester, Pa., QVC cameras were trained on two people sitting on a stage surrounded by flowers. Calls were coming in from all over the country. QVC is plugged into 50 million homes.
QVC's gardening expert is Derek Fell, a photographer who bills himself as the author of 50 garden books (well, 15 of them were calendars, he admits). His co-host is Donna Harfenist, whose role is to testify readily and often how little she knows about gardening. Both are smiling, a bit tensely. They have to talk fast to sell as many plants as possible in one hour, while still communicating the sheer joy of digging in the dirt.
"I love my garden because it just fills my heart," Ms. Harfenist said, "but I'm the gal who throws herself on the dirt and hopes something will come up."
But when she orders with Spring Hill Nurseries, the mail-order company selling the plants on QVC, "I'm perfectly confident," she said. And she feels the same way about Mr. Fell: "Derek," she said, "I could listen to you forever. You even make soil interesting."
The two were discussing the "Sun Starter Bulb and Perennial Garden" for $19.99, one of a handful of step-by-step gardening kits sold by Spring Hill Nurseries of Tipp City, Ohio.
That is 59 bulbs and perennials for 72 square feet of space, plus instructions, all for $19.99. And don't forget the 10 free hybrid lilies that come with any purchase.
"Now, Derek," Ms. Harfenist said, holding up a big daffodil bulb, "which way does the bulb go? Does that little pointy thing go up or down?"
So it goes, as the two race on through the Lifetime Peony Collection ($19.50), the Butterfly and Hummingbird Garden ($39.99) and Mr. Fell's latest book, "550 Home Landscape Ideas," published by Simon & Schuster.
The peony collection (1,700 kits) sold out in 10 minutes. The hummingbird garden (604 kits) in eight and one-half minutes. At the end of the hour, Mr. Fell and Ms. Harfenist had sold $100,000 worth of plants. The three previous shows sold $500,000 worth. And Mr. Fell's book has gone into a third printing, with 60,000 copies now in print. Though the show is still in its test stages, QVC is planning more installments in the spring.
But the queen of selling plants with style is Martha Stewart. When she talked about hydrangeas in her magazine, Martha Stewart Living, and then featured them on her syndicated show, seen in New York on WCBS (Channel 2) on Sunday at 8:30 A.M., nurseries could not keep them in stock.
"Within 10 days of the magazine hitting the East Coast, about every wholesale hydrangea grower sold out for the whole year," said Jerry Bolduan, a California nurseryman who grows 4,000 hydrangea bushes for his cut-flower business.
Gardening on television is, of course, not new. Thalassa Cruso, the doyenne of dirt who was one of the first gardeners to wield a trowel on television, taught Johnny Carson how to compost eggshells in his closet about 20 years ago. And there is "The Victory Garden," which originated on WGBH-TV in Boston in 1975 with James Crockett, the grandfatherly don of vegetables.
The show, which now features a number of solid practitioners, like Roger Swain, a biologist who is the science editor of Horticulture Magazine, draws three million viewers, WGBH says.
Experienced gardeners have been watching the frenzy with a mixture of pleasure and skepticism.
"There's always room for more garden shows," Mr. Swain said, "and I'm happy to have seed companies and nurseries and all those things."
But in his view, gardeners should be encouraged to consume less, not more. "You can almost measure the quality of your gardening by how little you purchase," he said, "because the better it's growing, the less you need of anything."
Perhaps it is a good thing Mr. Swain is on public television.
Ms. Stewart is talking empires. She wants her own channel. After she gets out her own CD-ROM, which is now being designed by two students at Indiana University, and after she goes on line. You can't get much more than a taste of hydrangeas in a six-minute segment on television. So you digest a little more in an eight-page article in her magazine.
And if you want to know more than that, you turn on your computer. "You can ask me a question, and I'll give you options," Ms. Stewart said. "Everything I'm trying to develop now is geared toward the ultimate Internet for Martha."
There is plenty of talk about the information highway at Garden Design, too. But for now, its creators are just reveling in the subject matter and the glorious advertisements, which have always followed the boomers.
And now they are in the garden.
"The super achievers are now buying their ultimate home, or they have the money to buy their own weekend home," said Joe Armstrong, a partner in Meigher Communications and one of those baby boomers who have built their careers on catering to their own generation.
"Twenty years ago, we were going to discos and rock concerts," he said. "Now we've left Madison Square Garden for the real garden."
And when asked how much money is to be made there, he shouts gleefully, "Billions!"

HEADLINE: U.S. GAINS ACCESS TO MORE MARKETS IN JAPANESE DEAL

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1

 BODY:
In a significant advance for the United States, Japanese and American negotiators reached agreements today to open Japan's markets in insurance, glass and medical and telecommunications equipment in ways that should increase American exports to the world's second-largest economy.
But the all-night negotiations to meet an American deadline failed to produce a deal to increase Japanese purchases of American cars and car parts, which account for two-thirds of Japan's $60 billion trade surplus with the United States. President Clinton responded by immediately carrying out his threat to initiate limited trade sanctions against Japan for failing to open more of its market for auto parts, even as he expressed satisfaction with those deals that were struck. 
 The sanctions process, though, requires a 12- to 18-month period of investigations and further consultations before punitive tariffs are imposed on Japanese exports to the United States. As a result, the proposed sanctions are not expected to disrupt relations between the two countries or to rattle the financial markets.
Indeed, the value of the American dollar, which has slid steadily against the Japanese yen since the beginning of 1993, is expected to strengthen as a result of the package agreed upon today, which should reduce a lot of the trade tension between Washington and Tokyo.
Opening four lucrative sectors of the relatively closed Japanese marketplace, the deal culminates 15 months of often bitter negotiations between Washington and Tokyo. If the agreements work out as written, they may constitute one of the most important breakthroughs in American-Japanese trade relations since World War II.
The deal with Japan should also make it easier for President Clinton to win Congressional approval for a global trade agreement, the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, which is now before Congress. The agreement would lower tariff barriers around the world.
Many trade analysts and industry representatives said they thought the package was a bargain for the United States in general and for American companies in particular. But they were assuming that the Japanese would carry through on their promises today to help foster progress "in access and sales" in the areas of insurance, glass and Government purchases of medical and telecommunications equipment.
The Clinton Administration can finally point to some tangible results from its get-tough strategy with Japan.
"This is certainly a plus for U.S. trade policy," said Clyde V. Prestowitz Jr., president of the Economic Strategy Institute, a research group financed in part by American corporations and car companies, which have long advocated a hard-nosed trade policy with Japan.
"The deal establishes two things," said Mr. Prestowitz, a former United States trade negotiator. "One is a recognition on all sides that the Japanese market has certain structural barriers that need special attention. Second, there is an implicit commitment by Japan to deal with those barriers in ways that can be measured."
He added, "It is unfortunate that they did not get anything on autos, but at least Clinton did not back down, which is what so often happened in the past."
The failure, though, to reach an agreement on autos is a big hole in the package. It is true that American officials are increasingly less concerned with the sales of American autos and original auto parts to Japan, because those have been rising in recent years thanks to greater efforts by American manufacturers to sell to the Japanese -- although the sales numbers remain very low.
But American car makers are still largely frozen out of the Japanese market for replacement auto parts. The actions toward sanctions that Mr. Clinton announced today will be directed at opening that sector, which is tightly controlled by Japanese Government regulations.
The fact that the President carried through with his vow to begin the process immediately of imposing trade sanctions on Japan, for its failure to move on replacement car parts, keeps pressure on Tokyo to make concessions in future talks planned on this issue.
Still, the ultimate value of the entire package can only be assessed after several years. Senator Max Baucus, Democrat of Montana and chairman of the Senate subcommittee on international trade, said he was "disappointed that Japan failed to eliminate its pernicious trade barriers in the auto and auto parts sectors."
He added, "I will be watching their implementation carefully" in the other sectors.
This final round of negotiations began at 3 P.M. Friday in the conference room next to the office of the United States trade representative, Mickey Kantor. For the next 20 hours Trade Minister Ryutaro Hash imoto and Foreign Minister Yohei Kono were like tag-team wrestlers taking turns shuttling from the conference room to Mr. Kantor's office with proposals, counterproposals and different language.
Mr. Kantor was closeted with his top deputies, Charlene Barshefsky and Ira Wolf.
Finally, just after 11 A.M., a bleary-eyed Mr. Kantor sealed the deal with Mr. Kono and Mr. Hashimoto with a handshake and expressions of good will translated by an exhausted United States Government translator, officials said.
The key breakthrough came with a Japanese agreement to accept indicators that would measure "progress" in their opening of markets, without promises to the Americans of any specific market shares.
Asked if the deals would work, Mr. Kantor said, "They are results-oriented and they can be enforced."
Looking at the fine print of the deals, it is clear that the agreement opening the tightly controlled $320 billion Japanese insurance market is the most sweeping. Penetration by foreign companies of that market is about 3 percent, compared with more than 10 percent in the United States.
 The accord provides for both Governments to track the foreign share of the Japanese market with several quantitative indicators and to try to make the American share increase.
Maurice R. Greenberg, chairman of the American International Group, which is based in New York and is one of the largest insurance companies in the world, said his company had not been allowed to bring its most creative insurance products and methods of distribution to Japan because of restrictive Government regulations, even though the company had been in Japan since 1946 and was by far the largest foreign insurer there.
"I think this deal shows great wisdom on the part of Japan," Mr. Greenberg said. "It will benefit the Japanese consumer in the long run and makes for a more level playing field because it now allows us more freedom to introduce products. The detail of this agreement leaves little room for ambiguity."
In purchases of telecommunications equipment by the Japanese Government and the largely state-owned Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corporation, the agreement calls for extensive changes in the previously secretive and biased rules by which the Japanese Government allots contracts in telecommunications, an area that is now 95 percent controlled by Japanese companies.
But it does not guarantee the United States any specific market shares. The same applied to Japanese Government purchases of medical equipment, where the United States had 23 percent of the market, compared with 40 percent it holds in Europe.
The glass agreement consists of an accord on a set of "principles" that will be made final in the next 30 days. American companies have had less than 1 percent of the $4.5 billion Japanese flat glass market.
"We are very pleased after long and difficult negotiations that U.S. negotiators have achieved agreement on the key principles that will finally open the Japanese glass market to real competition," said Ralph Gerson, president of the Guardian International glass company.
Generally speaking, the Japanese goal had been to avoid anything that constituted hard, market-share targets for American imports. They appear to have succeeded, but at a price of allowing regulatory changes in all of the deals that should make it easier for American companies to gain market share and reduce the traditional advantages of Japanese companies.
The Japanese agreed in each area to some sort of quantitative measures that the two sides will be able to use to track whether the Japanese markets are becoming more open.
"Agreement was reached on objective criteria, which do not include the so-called numerical targets," Foreign Minister Kono told reporters later. He said the agreement would not only benefit bilateral trade relations between the United States and Japan but would apply to all foreign countries trying to break into the Japanese market.
The one sour note was sounded by Andrew H. Card Jr., president of the American Automobile Association, who said, "No agreement with Japan can be meaningful without addressing the auto and auto parts sector."
The potential sanctions initiated by the Administration today come under section 301 of the Trade Act, which calls on the trade representative's office to identify and address priority foreign practices that discriminate against American exporters.
The process begins each March 30, when the Administration lists major trade barriers around the world. It then has until Sept. 30 to see if it can get some satisfaction in addressing these problems. If not, as in the case of Japan, the trade representative narrows the list to the worst offenders. Once the 301 list is released, negotiations begin and sanctions may be imposed within a year to 18 months.

HEADLINE: 7 Industrial Nations Deliver a Rosy Economic Forecast

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MADRID, Oct. 1

 BODY:
Finance Ministers from the seven major industrial powers proclaimed today that the world economy looked firmly set for a period of sustained growth coupled with low inflation and announced a series of measures to support this.
Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen, who served as chairman of the meeting, said the industrial nations faced "an excellent economic outlook," with prospects for growth "improving significantly" and trade set to rise "at a faster rate than at any point in the last five years" while inflation remains "subdued." 
 "Clearly, our growth strategy, deficit reduction in the United States, lower interest rates in Europe and encouraging consumer demand in Japan are making a demonstrable difference," Mr. Bentsen said at a news conference after daylong talks with Finance Ministers from Britain, Canada, France, Germany, Italy and Japan.
To help sustain the upswing, the ministers from the so-called Group of Seven nations agreed to a number of new measures that include an allocation of $20 billion worth of extra monetary reserves as well as fresh credits to help former Communist countries and the poorest developing countries take part in the recovery.
They asked the International Monetary Fund to "take a more aggressive role" in surveying their economic policies to identify emerging threats to the recovery and make suggestions for dealing with them.
They also asked the United States Federal Reserve and the Central Banks of the other Group of Seven countries to become more closely involved in efforts to supervise the recovery.
American and European monetary officials said this did not mean that Central Banks were planning to intervene more frequently in financial markets to manage currency values. Rather, they said it signified that central bankers, with their expert knowledge of these markets and their responsibility for interest rate policy, are to be more closely involved in preparing Group of Seven meetings, which are expected to be more frequent in future.
As expected, the Group of Seven ministers reaffirmed their belief that reducing the very high rates of unemployment in many, mainly European, industrial economies, would require more than just sustained economic expansion.
They pledge themselves once more, as they did in Detroit last March and again in Naples in the summer, to make their economies more flexible and open to free market forces by removing regulations that stifle entrepreneurial endeavor.
The only concern they expressed in the final statement read out by Mr. Bentsen was concerning the recent increase in long-term interest rates around the world.
While this might reflect fears of renewed inflation, the ministers said that "to some extent" it reflected a worldwide shortage of capital caused by "an increasing gap" between what people are saving and the growing demand for investment funds in many areas, particularly Asia.

HEADLINE: At Odds in Bosnia

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SARAJEVO, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Oct. 1

 BODY:
Through 30 months of the Bosnian war, and the loss of 200,000 lives, NATO and the United Nations have had extraordinary difficulty working together to end the suffering.
But seldom have the two organizations been so obviously at odds or so clearly out of touch with the feelings of most people living in this country as over the past week. 
 Just over a week ago, angered by a day of shooting incidents in which two peacekeepers were wounded, United Nations military commanders here called in a NATO air strike that succeeded in hitting an old, empty Serbian tank. This, it was announced by the United Nations commanders in Sarajevo, was an example of tough peacekeeping.
But the air raid failed to impress the Clinton Administration and clearly left NATO, whose solitary target was selected by United Nations commanders, feeling dissatisfied. On Thursday, at a NATO defense ministers' meeting in Spain, the British Defense Minister, Malcolm Rifkind, announced that "there will be no more pinprick air strikes."
The United States Defense Secretary, William J. Perry, sharply criticized the approach favored by United Nations officials and commanders here.
"When we go in," he said, "I want to go in with compelling force. Force not necessarily just proportionate to the act at stake, but enough to make it clear that there is a heavy price to pay for violating the rules that NATO has established." The attack on the tank "was not robust, not strong enough," he added.
In other words, the Clinton Administration believes that substantial use of NATO air power could change the attitude of the Bosnian Serbs. Instead of constantly engaging in brinkmanship -- leaving tanks in a zone around Sarajevo that is supposed to be free of heavy weapons, or shutting off water and electricity to the city to gain other concessions -- the Serbs would think twice about such provocation and perhaps move closer to accepting an American-backed peace plan, the thinking goes.
This theory -- that Serbs could be bombed into a change of attitude -- has never been tested over the course of the war, so it remains unproven. The Serbs might react in a different way, by killing United Nations soldiers, for example. It is this prospect that worries the United Nations force here, and it seems to have led its British and French commanders in Sarajevo to adopt a different approach from that now officially supported by British and French defense ministers within NATO.
Take the events of the past week. After the NATO air strike, the Serbs got predictably cross. A Serbian liaison officer delivered a note saying that any United Nations aircraft attempting to land at the airfield would be targets for reprisals. The threat closed the airport, leaving a single way into and out of the city, the Mount Igman Road, which is constantly targeted by Serbian guns.
At the same time, most United Nations aid convoys passing through Serbian-held territory in Bosnia were held up by the Serbs. A week later they remain immobilized, though the United Nations secured a pledge from the Serbs today to let them resume next week. Food supplies are running low in the eastern Muslim enclave of Srebrenica, and stocks in Sarajevo that should be growing in preparation for the winter are shrinking instead.
"You can't escalate the situation by using force and then continuing to use it," Lieut. Col. Tim Spicer, a spokesman for the United Nations force, said this week. "You have to use force in a proportionate, precise and relevant way, and then you must negotiate patiently."
In other words, tough peacekeeping must be followed by conciliatory peacekeeping to keep the United Nations mission alive. But this approach begs the question: What exactly did last week's NATO strike achieve? Would it be better to be consistently hard-nosed or consistently accommodating?
By promising tougher and wider action against the Bosnian Serbs today, NATO defense ministers appear to be trying to respond to these questions.
The response is belated. Ever since the Clinton Administration first proposed lifting the arms embargo against Bosnia and using air strikes more than a year ago, it has been obvious that NATO and the United Nations had a problem. The dilemma lies in the irreconcilability of the wide air strikes publicly favored by Mr. Clinton and the presence of thousands of United Nations troops here. To pretend otherwise appears disingenuous at best, but the problem has never been resolved.
And so, while defense ministers have vowed that NATO will be more robust, United Nations officers here have spent the last nine days negotiating with the Serbs over the airport closing and whether they might be allowed to inspect some tank and artillery positions violating the weapons exclusion zone encircling Sarajevo. The Serbs said no, and the inspections have been postponed.
Such incongruities are not lost on the people of Sarajevo, who live in a cage that is no longer littered with carnage but is a cage nonetheless.
They know that United Nations food helps keep them alive. They know that NATO and the United Nations did work together last February to stop the Bosnian Serbs' shelling of the city. But that does not prevent them from glancing up with disdain at the NATO fighters constantly droning overhead.
"I feel increasingly that what NATO and the United Nations conspire to offer me are 15 more years of vegetation," said Dzenan Kapteanovic, an economist serving in the Bosnian Government Army. "I'd trade that for a good fight -- win or lose in a year or two but get it over."
Such sentiment is increasingly widespread, though apparently not shared by the Bosnian Government, which seems to be anticipating a long war of attrition. It reflects a sense of living in a limbo, with neither peace nor all-out war -- a product of the enormous financial and political outlay by NATO and the United Nations since the Bosnian war began in April 1992.

A Danish peacekeeper ran to take cover yesterday during a firefight between Bosnian Government forces and Serbs on the edge of Sarajevo. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: THE 1994 CAMPAIGN: TAXES;
New Jersey Forum for New York Message

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: FORT LEE, N.J., Oct. 1

 BODY:
After months of hopscotching from one end of the state to the other, the New York gubernatorial campaign moved today to perhaps its oddest venue so far: a rain-soaked cliff in New Jersey overlooking the George Washington Bridge.
Three mayors assembled by the campaign of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo attacked a new plan to reduce income taxes put forth by the Republican candidate, George E. Pataki. That the mayors were from New Jersey, not New York, was another sign that the budget-cutting policies of Gov. Christine Todd Whitman would remain a focus of the New York campaign. 
 Mr. Pataki appears to be seeking to capitalize on the popularity of Mrs. Whitman, who has attained national stature for her antitax efforts. But today Mr. Cuomo, in turn, tried to harness criticism of Mrs. Whitman in her own state to diminish her marquee value in the New York campaign.
The mayors said Mrs. Whitman's much-publicized proposal to cut taxes by 30 percent was forcing municipalities to raise property taxes sharply and reduce services for poor people. The 15-percent cut already in place had only served to shift the tax burden from the state to municipalities, the mayors said.
"The grave concern that we have is that the Republican gubernatorial candidate, Mr. Pataki, is attempting to suggest to New Yorkers to follow the same dismal economic plan," said Mayor James E. McGreevey of Woodbridge, a Democrat who also serves in the State Senate.
Mr. McGreevey said state aid to his school district was cut by $789,000 this year. Mayor Jack Alter of Fort Lee, a Democrat, said municipal aid to his borough dropped $975,000. And Mayor John F. Zisa of Hackensack, a Republican, said property taxes there rose about 9 percent.
Such complaints brought a warning from Mrs. Whitman that just as state government is tightening its belt, localities must also reduce expenditures to avoid increasing property taxes. Mrs. Whitman's own difficulties with the state budget this week prompted her to announce that her tax cut plan would require four years to carry out, not three.
That development was jumped on by the Cuomo campaign, which said it was evidence that Mr. Pataki's inspiration for his proposals was flawed. But the Pataki campaign stressed today that its plan would not hurt municipalities in New York because Mr. Pataki would work to reduce mandated spending.
"Obviously, this is a partisan attack," Zenia Mucha, a campaign spokeswoman for Mr. Pataki, said of the news conference held by the mayors. "Mario Cuomo's unfunded state mandates have caused property taxes to soar. George Pataki will cut mandates and will cut property taxes."

McGreevey of Woodbridge, N.J., center, one of three New Jersey mayors assembled by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's campaign. With Mr. McGreevey in Fort Lee was the town's mayor, Jack Alter, left. (Frank C. HEADLINE: THE 1994 CAMPAIGN;
Candidates See Distinct States, Each New York

BYLINE: By TOM REDBURN 

 BODY:
Anyone listening to Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and State Senator George E. Pataki, his Republican challenger, talk about New York's economy would think they were describing two different states.
"Happy days are near again," Governor Cuomo declares. "I took you through two recessions. And at the same time laid a foundation for a powerful new economy. More powerful than any you've ever had in the state." 
 In the almost 12 years since he became Governor, Mr. Cuomo says, "We gave you 500,000 new jobs and 50,000 new businesses. And we gave you a whole new high-tech economy."
But Mr. Pataki, surveying the same landscape, sees not the peaks but the valleys. "New York lost almost half a million private sector jobs," he says, "at a time when the other 49 states created more than four million jobs."
Mr. Pataki says the reason that New York has done so poorly, ranking 47th among the states in new jobs since 1982, "is because we tax too much, we spend too much, we regulate too severely.
"And the inevitable result is that we have missed out on the economic turnabout that began nationally in 1991," he said.
From those starkly different diagnoses of New York's economic condition come equally divergent prescriptions to improve the state's health.
Both candidates are proposing to cut state taxes to create a more hospitable environment for business: Mr. Pataki with a 25 percent cut in personal income taxes; Mr. Cuomo with a more modest lowering of income taxes and utility taxes along with property tax relief. Each, however, envisions Albany performing quite different operations: to Governor Cuomo, state government needs to do more; to Mr. Pataki, it must do less.
Biggest Challenge:
Local Tax Burden
But neither candidate has yet to outline a program to confront fully the state's central economic and fiscal problem, experts say. The biggest challenge facing the next governor, they argue, is that much of the tax burden in New York is imposed by cities, towns and counties, whose finances are interwowen with Albany's in a tangle of money and politics.
As a result, simply cutting state taxes alone could backfire by pushing more of the tax burden onto localities, analysts say. Instead, they say, state and local finances need to be fundamentally rearranged so that the stiffest tax levies, which fall hardest on New York City and certain other localities, can be reduced where they are doing the most economic harm. Meanwhile, most analysts agree, public spending should be brought under control to conform with more realistic prospects for long-term growth in the state's economy.
"Taxes in New York are so far out of line with those in the rest of the country that they are a serious drag on economic development," said Steven D. Gold, director of the Center for the Study of States in Albany, summing up a view held by many analysts across a wide ideological spectrum.
"But while cutting taxes is necessary," Mr. Gold said, "it is not sufficient."
The difficulty arises, he said, because of New York's unusually heavy reliance on local taxes to pay for government services like education, welfare and health care for the poor and disabled.
Although the pattern varies across the state, on average more than half the taxes on New Yorkers are levied locally. Measured as a share of personal income, New York ranks 22d among states in business and individual taxes collected by the state alone, 8.5 percent above the national average. But it ranks first, 78.4 percent above average, in local tax burden.
Mr. Cuomo, defending his record, says the state has tightened its belt more than local governments. "The local taxes are high because the local government made them high," the Governor said in an extensive interview with The New York Times last week. "So if we were to say, 'Don't worry about all that, guys, we'll pick up your burden,' what incentive is there for them to do anything like what we've done?"
Inefficient and overlapping local governments certainly share responsibility for the exceptionally high costs of providing public services in New York, analysts say. Still, Michael Wasylenko, an economist and state tax expert at Syracuse University, said, "Local taxes and spending are completely out of line with other states largely because of policies emanating from Albany."
 
The Mandate Factor: Costly Impositions
 Over the last decade, New York State doubled aid to local schools. Yet Albany still provides a smaller share of school budgets than most other states while continuing to impose costly mandates on local districts. More critically, no other state imposes as heavy a burden on local governments to pay for Medicaid and welfare as New York does.
While Albany has assumed a greater share of nursing home expenses, lifting a total of $7 billion in extra Medicaid bills from cities and counties since 1984, it fell far short of keeping up with the fast-rising expenses of the program. And New York is one of only 14 states that require localities to contribute to Medicaid, the health care program for the poor.
Both candidates say they want to help ease the Medicaid load on local governments.
Yet Mr. Cuomo, who has proposed a complete takeover of local Medicaid expenses, could not persuade the Legislature to assume more than a small extra amount. Meanwhile, Mr. Pataki said he would like to ease the Medicaid burden on localities, but has yet to offer a specific plan.
The local tax burden grew substantially under Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller, who served 14 years from 1959 to 1973. He built up state government, but found the soaring costs so expensive to finance that Albany quietly began to transfer many obligations to local governments and a myriad of quasi-independent state authorities.
Now, any efforts to reduce state taxes on businesses and individuals run the risk of doing little more than shifting an even greater burden to local taxpayers. And any effort to realign state and local finances, particularly by relieving New York City and other local governments of their share of Medicaid costs, exposes fault lines that have long divided cities and suburbs, Republicans and Democrats, upstate and downstate.
For New York City, the issue is critical. But the entire state is affected.
"The New York metropolitan area is the business center and engine of the state's economy," said Cynthia Green, deputy research director of the Citizens Budget Commission. "If we're truly concerned about economic development, we have to recognize that the heavy local tax burden here is a serious problem for everybody in the state, not just the residents of New York City."
Officials in New York City and elsewhere are worried that Mr. Pataki's plans to lower state income taxes might force local taxes to rise and, in even the best case, would spell the end of any hope for a state pickup of the Medicaid bill.
Mr. Pataki's plans call for cutting the state's top income tax rate from the current 7.875 to 5.9 by 1998. He said that he thought the state work force could be cut by one-third and state agencies could be consolidated without reducing services.
Those cuts in spending would raise only $300 million of the $5.6 billion drop in revenues caused by the tax cuts, but Mr. Pataki said he counts on a vibrantly growing economy to increase state revenues by 6 percent a year -- growth the Cuomo campaign says would be almost impossible to achieve.
 
Cuomo Prescription: High-Tech Future
 To be sure, many of New York's economic difficulties arise from forces apart from the high levels of state and local taxation. Improvements in telecommunications, ocean shipping and air transportation spurred the trend toward the globalization of industry and undermined the traditional roles of older cities like New York, Syracuse, Troy and Buffalo as manufacturing hubs.
Governor Cuomo, telling the State Business Council last month that the state's economic future rests with "high-tech, high-tech, high-tech," said his administration is helping to bring New York into the 21st century. New Yorkers, Mr. Cuomo proudly pointed out, went from 9.5 percent above the national average in per capita income in 1982 to 19 percent above last year.
The Governor cited the creation of 13 Centers for Advanced Technology at state universities and the planned state investment of another $32 billion on top of $50 billion in spending on highways, mass transit and other public works. New York also pours lots of money into an economic development program to recruit and retain business by offering targeted tax breaks, cut-rate energy and low-cost financing.
"New York's economic strategy is based on our producing the highest quality goods and services and selling them to the rest of the world," Governor Cuomo said. "This requires high-tech capacity, sophisticated higher education and skills training, extensive infrastructure development, access to markets and aggressive hospitality to business."
 
The Pataki Plan: Reduce the Burden

To Mr. Pataki, however, the state economy would be sounder if Albany stopped trying so hard to help New York companies find ways around higher taxes and more regulations and simply lowered the costs of doing business for everyone.
"What's reducing New York to the ranks of the also-rans is the presumption that whatever we need, government should provide," he said in a speech last week to the Citizens Budget Commission. "Governor Cuomo keeps protesting that we can't cut taxes unless the economy grows. I say we can't have a growing economy unless we cut taxes."
On the campaign trail, Mr. Pataki often repeats as a mantra: "Mario Cuomo says he can't cut taxes. He's right. He can't, but we can. And we will."
Despite the state's reputation, not all businesses in New York face exceptionally high taxes.
Two recent studies by economists, by Robert Tannenwald of the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston and by the accounting firm KPMG Peat Marwick, found that the combined impact of corporate, property and sales taxes on manufacturing outside New York City is actually lower than in other major states, including Pennsylvania, Massachusetts, Michigan and North Carolina.
"In comparison with the 10 states included in the study," the Peat Marwick group concluded, "upstate New York has the lowest overall tax burden on investment."
But the studies looked only at manufacturing companies, which benefit from a generous state investment tax credit, and did not include the hidden taxes, like those on utility bills, that affect all businesses.
Moreover, Manhattan is one of the most costly business sites in the country. Vertex Inc., a research company in Berwyn, Pa., found that taxes on a typical $15 million service business in New York City were the fourth highest in the nation, behind Philadelphia, Pittsburgh and Seattle.
Regardless of the research, many business executives say high taxes and other costs are continuing to drive them out of the state.
Floyd Maines, president of a $350 million institutional food supplier near Binghamton that employs almost 600 people, says he has been recruited by Pennsylvania state officials to move his business across the nearby border.
"It looks like we could save millions of dollars on taxes, utilities, and workers' compensation just by moving 10 miles," Mr. Maines said. "We're tempted, but I'm waiting to see if the situation is going to turn around here."

HEADLINE: For Taiwan, Asian Games Are Recognition

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Oct. 1

 BODY:
Taiwan's team at the Asian Games, which open on Sunday in Hiroshima, is unlikely to return home with many medals, but the country won a prize this week that, in the arcane twists of East Asian diplomacy, made the trip a success. The head of the committee bidding to bring the 2002 Asian Games to Taiwan received his identification card.
That seemingly routine gesture was at the center of a tense diplomatic dispute that over the last several weeks has threatened relations between China and Japan and underscored China's increasingly overbearing attitude toward its neighbors. 
 The problem is that the head of the Taiwan committee, Hsu Li-teh, is also Deputy Prime Minister. Thus for Taiwan, his visit marks a modest success in its unending efforts to maintain political contacts with the outside world despite the fact that Japan, the United States and most other countries have abandoned formal diplomatic ties with Taiwan in favor of China. Communist China regards Taiwan as a renegade province, not a separate country.
In China, Mr. Hsu's trip to Hiroshima has been received as more of a loss than if their powerful team returned home without a single medal. China has angrily insisted that Japan's willingness to permit Mr. Hsu's entry violates Japan's vow to recognize just one China.
Taiwan has insisted that the visit is about sports and not politics. But the Chinese have grown increasingly shrill and threatening.
"The Japanese Government does not sufficiently understand what grave consequences its approval of Hsu's visit will bring about," The People's Daily, the Communist Party newspaper, said.
The Chinese have hinted that they may block Japan's efforts to become a permanent member of the United Nations Security Council in retaliation for the visit. In addition, several Chinese officials hastily called off visits to Japan over the last week.
The Japanese Government has maintained in public that it is not involved, that the issue involves sports and the governing Olympic Council of Asia. But officials have been deeply perplexed about the situation in which Japan has been placed and the prospect that Japan's deeply important and sensitive relations with China might be harmed.
With China on its way to becoming a dominant regional military power, and with its economy booming, Japan has for several years done everything it could to maintain stable relations.
For instance, Japan followed most other countries in freezing certain economic relations with China after the brutal crackdown in Tiananmen Square in 1989. But it was the first industrialized country to resume economic aid to China and to exchange high-level government visits.
This time, the Japanese have stood their ground, insisting the visit has nothing to do with diplomacy or politics.
Japanese officials also argue that the visit does not technically violate the letter or even the spirit of the 1972 agreement under which Japan and China first established diplomatic relations. The Chinese threats have thus been perceived as signs of emerging imperiousness by Beijing.
What is particularly discouraging for some Japanese officials is that they thought they defused the issue a week ago. Originally, Taiwan had managed to extract an invitation for their President, Lee Teng-hui, to the Games.
Diplomats here say that the invitation, from the current president of the Olympic Council of Asia, Ahmad al-Fahad of Kuwait, was a mistake that resulted from a lack of appreciation of the diplomatic sensitivities.
The Olympic council eventually withdrew the invitation. No sooner had the Chinese halted their threats of "very serious political trouble" over the affair, than the new issue of Mr. Hsu's visit came up.
China continued its attacks against Taiwan and Japan. In fact, the threats grew more tangible, with some Chinese calling off visits to Japan. The moves have caught the Japanese Foreign Ministry by surprise.
If there has been a silver lining to the cloud over the games it is that the Chinese have withdrawn a threat to start a boycott. The Chinese could well provide the most exciting moments at the Games, with the women among their runners expected to challenge some world records.
But the most enduring lessons may come from the diplomatic field, shedding light on China's and Japan's diplomatic principles.

HEADLINE: Italian Government Assures Jews It Rejects Anti-Semitism

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ROME, Oct. 1

 BODY:
The Government of Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi has formally assured American Jews that it has no anti-Semitic bias after a Cabinet minister blamed "New York's Jewish lobby" for Italy's economic problems.
The assurance was given on Friday in a letter to Abraham H. Foxman, national director of the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith, during a visit here that coincided with a series of events highlighting efforts toward reconciliation between Roman Catholics and Jews. 
 "The Italian Government, in its entirety, systematically rejects all forms of anti-Semitic pollution of the civil culture of our country, even if they be merely linguistic," the letter said.
The letter denied that Labor Minister Clemente Mastella had made anti-Semitic remarks in August when he said the presence of the neo-Fascist National Alliance in the coalition Government "worries New York's Jewish lobby" and implied that "Jewish high finance" had contributed to a slide in the Italian lira. Mr. Mastella, a member of a faction allied with Mr. Berlusconi's Forza Italia party, later issued an apology.
Mr. Foxman was to have met Mr. Berlusconi on Friday, but the Prime Minister sent two other Cabinet ministers instead in order to go to Milan on unexplained business.
Mr. Foxman said in an interview that Mr. Berlusconi's rejection of anti-Semitism was "about as clear as we could have hoped."
The National Alliance has five ministers in Mr. Berlusconi's Cabinet, but its leader, Gianfranco Fini, has persistently sought to distance it from its roots in the wartime Fascism of Mussolini.
Mr. Foxman also met Pope John Paul II on Thursday as Israel's first Ambassador to the Vatican, Shmuel Hadas, presented his credentials. The Pope used the encounter with Mr. Hadas to renew a long-standing Vatican proposal that Jerusalem's religious status be internationally guaranteed.
"One hopes that the unique and sacred character of this city will be the object of international guarantees assuring its access to all believers," the Pope said. Israel has rejected such demands in the past, saying Jerusalem's holy sites are open to all believers.
Mr. Foxman said the final step in the formalization of relations between the Vatican and Israel represented "the first day in a new era" that would make it much easier for Jews and Catholics to address divisive issues. These included what he termed the Christianization of Holocaust sites, the question of young Jews baptized as Catholics in World War II and the question of historic blame for the rise of Nazism.
At a news conference after his meeting with the Pope, Mr. Foxman also urged the Vatican to open records from World War II, when an estimated 10,000 Jewish children and infants in Poland and Germany were saved from the Holocaust because local clerics baptized them as Catholics. The Vatican has not formally responded to his appeal.
Mr. Foxman said he had been one of them -- a Catholic nanny persuading a Polish priest to baptize him and alter church records to show that he came from a Catholic family. Mr. Foxman was reunited with his parents after they survived the Nazi death camps.
"We owe those who have a question, those who have a suspicion and are willing to face the answer, the opportunity to go somewhere, to ask the questions, to delve in their past," he said.
