HEADLINE: Rich and Poor Nations Split on Aid Plan

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MADRID, Oct. 2

 BODY:
A serious new political rift between the world's rich and poor nations opened tonight after finance ministers from 21 nations were unable to agree at a meeting here on a plan to create billions of dollars in development aid.
The aid is intended to help Russia, other former Communist countries and the poorest developing nations build up trade and participate in the emerging world economic recovery. 
 After difficult talks all day, the finance ministers, who come from developed and developing countries and who make up the Governing Interim Committee of the International Monetary Fund, could not agree on how much money would be made available.
The United States and the six other industrial powers in the Group of Seven -- Japan, Germany, Britain, France, Italy and Canada -- said yesterday that they would agree to creating no more than $23 billion in aid, and they insisted that it all be allocated in a way that favored the former Communist world and the poorest nations. But developing countries, backed by the managing director of the I.M.F., Michel Camdessus of France, pressed for an allocation of $52 billion. The Group of Seven considered the higher figure inflationary.
The Camdessus camp also wanted at least some aid to be distributed in a broader fashion, so that all poorer countries would get an immediate injection of monetary reserves.
The aid under discussion takes the form of Special Drawing Rights, an international credit unit developed in the 1970's as a substitute for the dollar and sometimes called "paper gold." The rights are held by countries in their monetary reserves and entitle them to draw foreign currencies from the I.M.F., thus strengthening their creditworthiness and enabling them to buy more foreign goods.
But only about $28 billion of the rights have ever been created, and they have conspicuously failed to replace the dollar as an international reserve currency.
American and other European officials appeared deeply angry tonight with Mr. Camdessus, whom they blamed in part for the impasse, saying he had encouraged the developing world to press for a much bigger allocation than the Group of Seven agreed to yesterday.
"Camdessus miscalculated, whipping up third world expectations," said Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer, Kenneth Clark, after the meeting.
The finance ministers did agree to allow former Communist and certain developing countries greater access to I.M.F. credit in the future but left the details to be worked out. And they failed to agree on a way to extend and enlarge the special lending program the I.M.F. set up to help Russia and other former Communist nations develop market-based economies.
The negotiations could resume at the finance ministers next meeting in April, but several ministers were cautious tonight. One European said, "We are in no hurry" and insisted the Group of Seven would want assurances in advance that developing countries were ready to accept the group's point of view.
France also angered the United States during today's difficult negotiations by adopting a somewhat ambiguous position in the dispute, officials said.
While Finance Minister Edmond Alphandery of France gave nominal backing to the Group of Seven stand, he did not conceal from other ministers that France had favored a larger sum.
In the view of the United States and a majority of the Group of Seven countries, the expansion of international capital markets already provides adequate credit for developing nations, and the creation of too many Special Drawing Rights would only stoke the fires of world inflation.
Because the former Communist countries and some poorer developing nations did not participate in earlier special rights allocations, and because they are short of reserves, the United States and its allis proposed that the aid under discussion be skewed in their direction.
But such a special distribution would have taken a year or so to arrange because it requires a change in I.M.F. rules subject to ratification by parliaments of member nations.
While much of the dispute focused on the arcane world of Special Drawing Rights, it also represented an attempt by Mr. Camdessus and the I.M.F., which manages the Special Drawing Rights plan, to increase their importance in the international monetary system by raising the quantity of new reserve units held by the world's central banks.

HEADLINE: George L. Bach, 79, Business Educator

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: PORTOLA VALLEY, Calif., Oct. 2

 BODY:
George Leland Bach, the first dean of the business school at Carnegie-Mellon University, died on Thursday. He was 79.
The cause was Parkinson's disease, said the business school of Stanford University, where Dr. Bach was a professor until he retired in 1983. 
 The dean of the Carnegie-Mellon business school from its founding in 1946, Dr. Bach resigned in 1962 and became a visiting scholar at Stanford. After becoming a professor at Stanford, he received the university's highest award for teaching in 1979.
He wrote a textbook, "Economics: An Introduction to Analysis and Policy," which was published in 1954. It has gone through 11 editions and been printed in four languages.
A fellow of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences, he was a native of Victor, Iowa. He majored in economics at Grinnell College and earned a doctorate at the University of Chicago in 1940.
He is survived by his wife, Ruth Jacqueline Bach, four children and eight grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Volume of New Issues Plummeted in Quarter

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE 

 BODY:
The total volume of new securities issues in the United States plummeted 51.5 percent in the third quarter and 29 percent in the first nine months of the year as rising interest rates and fears of inflation led investors to take a more cautious approach.
Because of such a sharp drop in almost all classifications of new stock and bond issues, underwriting fees continued to plunge, with securities firms suffering a 56.6 percent decline in the third quarter and a 32.7 percent fall in the nine-month period. 
 "It certainly was the weakest quarter so far this year," Grant Kvalheim, a managing director of Merrill Lynch, said. "The best thing we can say about it is that the activity level picked up in the last half of September and we expect that to continue in the fourth quarter."
According to the Securities Data Company, a leading research firm, the volume of all domestic new issues dropped to $143.5 billion in the July-September quarter from $296.1 billion a year earlier. For the first three quarters, the volume fell to $588.9 billion from $829.1 billion in the corresponding period of 1993.
Since the Federal Reserve began raising short-term rates in February, total issuance has declined more than 50 percent on a monthly basis.
Bonds represent the bulk of the new issues and investment-grade bonds represent the largest percentage of the bonds that were issued. All debt securities fell 50.2 percent, to $130.8 billion, from $262.7 billion, in the third quarter, and 30 percent, to $528.8 billion, from $733.4 billion, in the first nine months. The investment-grade market tumbled 36.3 percent, to $41.7 billion, in the latest quarter, and 28.7 percent, to $158.7 billion, in the nine-month period.
The issuance of mortgage-backed securities dropped to its lowest level since the second quarter of 1989. And the volume of new issues of junk bonds was lower than in any three-month period since the third quarter of 1991.
In contrast, asset-backed securities bucked the trend, as many new portfolios were repackaged into loans. Volume in the third quarter jumped 47.9 percent, to $21 billion from $14.2 billion. In the January-September period, volume increased 36.3 percent, to $54.4 billion from $39.9 billion.
"The rise in interest rates obviously put off a lot of potential issuance," Mr. Kvalheim said. He noted that the yield on the bellwether 30-year Treasury bond advanced to 7.81 percent from 7.60 percent in the third quarter and that shorter-term rates increased even more. "The yield curve has flattened," he added.
On the equity side, new issues of common stock, excluding closed-end funds, fell 54.3 percent in the third period, to $9.5 billion from $20.8 billion. The decline was narrower, at 28.6 percent, for the first nine months of the year, to $42.6 billion from $59.7 billion.
"The I.P.O. market had such a dreadful performance that small-cap money managers said, 'I'm not going to buy anymore,' " Robert L. Cooney, a managing director of CS First Boston, said. "It was a self-correcting and cleansing process in which you get rid of marginal issuers and you bring about more realistic pricing."
Donal Orr, a senior vice president of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, said that "portfolio managers have had to be a lot more selective in what they were able to buy."
"We've had a market environment that is fairly fragile and volatile," he said. "Portfolio managers are looking for opportunities in the existing marketplace before they will participate in a more risky I.P.O."
Disclosed underwriting fees declined 56.6 percent, to $999.1 million, from $2.3 billion, in the third quarter of 1994. For the first nine months of the year, disclosed fees fell 32.7 percent, to $4.5 billion, from $6.7 billion.
The Securities Data tally, which gives full credit to the lead underwriter, shows that Goldman, Sachs & Company led in investment-firm fees for the third quarter with $156.4 million, compared with the next highest total, $126.4 million for Merrill Lynch. However, the positions were reversed for the nine-month period, as Merrill Lynch finished with $801.5 million in fees and Goldman, Sachs had $508.3 million.
Merrill Lynch also maintained its title as the leading underwriter of debt and equity, a ranking it has held since the first quarter of 1990, by achieving a market share of 17.3 percent for the third quarter and 16.8 percent for the first nine months.

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS QUARTERLY REVIEW;
Advisers Post Gains In Model Portfolios

BYLINE: By JAN M. ROSEN 

 BODY:
AFTER struggling for a year in a choppy stock market, five investment advisers zipped ahead in the third quarter, with three chalking up gains on par with the previous four quarters combined in their hypothetical retirement portfolios.
Sheldon Jacobs, editor of The No-Load Fund Investor of Irvington, N.Y., widened his lead with a gain of 5.52 percent, bringing his original $50,000 portfolio up to $58,938, an increase of 17.88 percent since the contest began in July 1993. 
 Eric Kobren, president of Insight Management in Wellesley, Mass., held onto second place over all, building his all-Fidelity portfolio to $56,878, but his gain of 3.83 percent put him in fourth place for the quarter.
Harold Evensky, an investment adviser in Coral Gables, Fla., had a 4.97 percent gain, the second best of the quarter, to $54,937; John Rekenthaler, editor of Morningstar Mutual Funds of Chicago, had a 4.03 percent gain, to $54,090, and the portfolio of Jack A. Brill, a San Diego investment adviser who uses only what he considers socially responsible investments, advanced 3.52 percent to $53,196.
But these are 20-year portfolios, so it is too early in the derby to count anyone out. The test of a portfolio manager is how he or she performs in both bull and bear markets.
Perhaps the one discouraging note is that the professionally managed portfolios look less attractive when compared with an unmanaged market average. The "efficient market" theory holds that investors cannot beat market averages over the long term, so they should not even try. In this quarter, only Mr. Jacobs and Mr. Evensky outperformed the Vanguard S.& P. 500 Index Fund, which posted a gain of 4.86 percent.
Both put a portion of their money overseas, and those funds gave them their strongest returns. Markets in Latin America and Asia, excluding Japan, have boomed recently.
The portfolio performance is tracked quarterly by Lipper Analytical Services Inc. in Summit, N.J., and the initial results could change slightly early this week as funds finish their quarterly accounting. It excludes transaction costs, sales charges and taxes. The five experts can shift portfolio holdings each quarter. For the coming quarter, four of the five made changes, with three becoming a bit more aggressive.
Mr. Jacobs is standing pat. "My game plan is basically to stay with a well-diversified portfolio that is not overly risky," he said. "I see a very gradually slowing economy that will be a favorable climate for stocks."
He added, "I prefer an all-equity portfolio" for long-term growth, and the economic climate should be right for that.
Mr. Evensky agreed that the economic fundamentals looked good, but said that "it is not clear sailing." He is cutting his stake in the Meridian Fund to 10 percent and adding a 10 percent stake in Penn Mutual, a value fund that was closed when the race began but is now open to new investors.
"Our clients are not looking to make a killing," he said. "They are looking for risk-adjusted consistent return. We deal with those who have made their money and want to keep it."
Mr. Kobren is dropping the Fidelity Capital and Income Fund, which barely gained in the quarter and is replacing it with the Fidelity Fund, which is managed by Beth F. Terrana, a proven Fidelity manager whom he respects.
"Since this is a long-term growth portfolio for retirement, we can stand a little more firepower in the account," he said. "It's a matter of trying to make the portfolio a little more volatile when the economy and corporate profits are still in very good shape." He is keeping Capital and Income, which did very well over the last three years, in conservative accounts.
Mr. Brill is reducing his position in Calvert Social Investing to 13.3 percent and adding a 5 percent stake in the Calvert Strategic Growth Fund, an aggressive portfolio managed by Cedd Moses, who has enhanced returns by using options, futures and short sales.
"This diversifies the portfolio and adds dimensions not previously available to socially responsible investors," Mr. Brill said, referring to those who avoid stocks of companies involved in tobacco, alcohol, nuclear weapons and firearms.
Mr. Rekenthaler is cutting his stake in the Janus Fund to 10 percent and adding a 10 percent position in the new Fidelity Mid-Cap Stock Fund. With a 2.63 percent advance in the quarter, "Janus was sluggish, and that was my major disappointment," he said.
Although he usually avoids a new fund until it has proved itself, "Fidelity has a track record of grooming up-and-coming portfolio managers," Mr. Rekenthaler said, and Jennifer Uhrig is running Mid-Cap aggressively, having won her spurs on several sector funds.
He is optimistic for the long term. "Some of the stuff I like just got cheaper," he said wryly, mentioning European stocks and energy issues, so he is sticking with his basic game plan.
Again, sticking with a game plan is what has kept all five on track. Nervous investors who trade frequently or bail out the minute a holding dips into negative territory generally lose money. All five contestants have solid gains.

HEADLINE: Treasury to Auction Bills

 BODY:
The Treasury's schedule of financing this week is confined to bills, beginning with today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills.
At the close of the New York cash market on Friday, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 4.64 percent, traders said, while the six-month issue was at 5.20 percent.

HEADLINE: METRO MATTERS;
Core of Tax Cut Debate: New York's Self-Image

BYLINE: By Joyce Purnick 

 BODY:
WITH just over a month to go before New York elects its next governor, it would help to get one thing clear: the tax cut debate between Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and his Republican opponent, State Senator George E. Pataki, is not, at its core, about cutting taxes. It is about New York's definition of itself. Because unless New York is prepared to change dramatically what it is and long has been, it will never have low taxes. Lower? Yes. But low? Not likely.
Put simply, New York has vast obligations and historically high standards. The state is home to a lot of needy people and helps care for them because Federal dollars do not go far enough. But New York does not stop there. It spends more than most other states, and not just on the poor. New Yorkers have always had expensive tastes. Even Republican New Yorkers. 
 For instance, the state spends the largest piece of its budget not -- surprise -- on Medicaid or welfare, but on its schools: Out of a $34 billion budget, nearly $10 billion in state funds (localities contribute, too) goes to the schools, compared with $6 billion for Medicaid and $2 billion for welfare. It so happens that Republicans in the Republican-led State Senate -- where Mr. Pataki works -- hold up the budget every year to win increases for their suburban and rural school districts. And those districts consistently get more than their fair share.
IT is no accident that, statewide, New York maintains one of the best teacher-to-student ratios in the country or that the state contributes to the cost of busing students to and from private and parochial schools.
Such largess is the norm in New York. Federal studies show that combined state and local spending in New York is among the highest in the country in nearly every category, from education to courts to hospitals. It long has been, even when Republicans were in power.
Such traditions are hard to change. Are New Yorkers, whatever their politics or pocketbooks, prepared to do with fewer government services to pay for a large tax cut? Will lobbyists for legions of special interests settle for less? If not, then any large state tax cut would most likely lead to higher local taxes because the state sends $7 of every $10 it collects back to the localities.
Mr. Pataki argues otherwise. He wants to reduce income tax rates significantly -- up to 25 percent over four years -- and says a growing economy and eliminating waste, fraud and abuse -- every campaign's Big Three -- will pay for it. He might, however, keep an eye on New Jersey, where the Republican Governor, Christine Todd Whitman, pledged a 30 percent tax cut over three years, but now says she needs at least another year. Mrs. Whitman is also facing a $2 million budget gap and is hearing complaints that local taxes are going up to pay for her cuts.
MR. CUOMO, no stranger to outbreaks of tax cut fever among the electorate, feels the pressure, too, but is promising what is advertised as a much more modest reduction. The Democratic Governor scorns Mr. Pataki's proposal as "fiction," and predicts it would lead to higher local taxes.
Not that Mr. Cuomo is immune to wishful thinking. Local governments would have to tighten their belts if New Yorkers are to benefit from any state tax cut, he says. But how much can local governments realistically save, given their inescapable costs? Rudolph W. Giuliani, the Republican Mayor, is cutting to the bone to close his budget gap, in large part because Medicaid is costing New York City more than $2 billion a year, and welfare costs $900 million, out of a $31.6 billion budget. Counties and cities around the state are similarly burdened because New York is one of the few states that demand local contributions to Medicaid and welfare.
Mr. Pataki says that like Governor Cuomo, he favors a state takeover of Medicaid, and he emphasizes the need to reduce fraud and administrative costs. But Mr. Pataki's own campaign staff estimates that efficiencies could save only $300 million from Medicaid's annual state cost of $6 billion.
In fact, barring an economic boom, Mr. Pataki's proposals would not only make New York more efficient. They would also force New Yorkers of all parties to make decisions they have not before been willing to consider. Would they refuse to admit an illegal immigrant to a public hospital or school? Would they put time limits on welfare benefits and shelter for the homeless? Would the more affluent be willing to do without publicly subsidized parks and beach clubs, or publicly financed busing to private schools?
Those are the underlying questions implicit in the tax cut debate. Maybe before the campaign is over, New Yorkers will ask those questions of their candidates and of themselves.

HEADLINE: DANCE REVIEW;
Graham on Themes as Old as Time Itself

BYLINE: By ANNA KISSELGOFF 

 BODY:
"Clytemnestra," Martha Graham's three-act dance treatment of the Oresteia, is nothing short of epic drama, and it received an astonishingly integrated performance on Saturday night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. Christine Dakin, magnificent and complex in the title role, and the other members of the Martha Graham Dance Company must not be missed when "Clytemnestra" has its repeat performance on Friday.
Nor should, for different reasons, anyone pass up the sections of "Chronicle" that were revived on Friday night for the first time since the 1930's. If "Clytemnestra," choreographed in 1958, is a brazen panorama imbued with overt sexuality and a fragmented modernist structure, "Chronicle" is a stark social-protest piece from 1936, smoldering in the crucible of its very purity. To see Terese Capucilli rise up as a towering red specter of war is to shudder at the apocalyptic height of Graham's vision. 
 This contrast in repertory is a highlight of the current "Radical Graham" series in the Next Wave Festival at the Academy's Opera House (30 Lafayette Avenue, at Ashland Place, Fort Greene).
Whatever the diversity, Graham's cardinal principles are clear: movement expresses inner emotion and is never diluted into decorative form. More important, her dances are life-affirming. Even the range in the season's second program, the mixed bill on Friday, embodied this concept.
"Appalachian Spring," with its Shaker hymn embedded in Aaron Copland's score, celebrates a frontier roof-raising. But the basic image was actually a metaphor, in 1944, for Graham to reaffirm democratic American values during World War II. In 1946, she shifted ground notoriously with "Dark Meadow," an exploration of Jungian symbols, enhanced by Isamu Noguchi's phallic sculpture, that still leaves viewers uncomfortable or nonplused. Typically, this ritual probing into the mysteries of life and sex ends with an ode to rebirth.
The program, framed by these major pieces, included repeats of the newly reconstructed "Satyric Festival Song" from 1932 and "Deep Song," Graham's antiwar solo of 1937, created during the Spanish Civil War.
The same war was the springboard for "Chronicle." "Sketches From 'Chronicle,' " as the current production is called, conjures a more general desolation. Its second section, "Steps in the Street," was brilliantly revived under Graham's supervision in 1989; it has enough repetitive minimalism to put the current so-called avant-garde to shame. But the two sections just reconstructed, "Specter: 1914" and "Prelude to Action" are more dated, in the best sense. That is, they speak specifically of a 1930's esthetic.
Consistently, however, Graham's most timely pieces have endured through their timelessness.
"Sketches From 'Chronicle' " is, in fact, a study in how potential cliches can be diverted into original expressive purpose. Two sub-sections have not been included in this reconstruction: "Masque," from the first part; "Dances Before Catastrophe," and "Tragic Holiday" from the second part, "Dances After Catastrophe."
But the present sequence -- "Spectre: 1914," "Steps in the Street" and "Prelude to Action" -- tells the story.
The original program note spoke of conquest and "the ugly logic of imperialism," ending with "the taut gathering of new energies and new forces." If this final call to action is militant in its energy, the opening "Specter," subtitled "Drums -- Red Shroud -- Lament," is a lesson in economy.
Ms. Capucilli, in a voluminous skirt with a red lining, remains initially rooted to the platform on which she sits while Wallingford Riegger's score (orchestrated by Stanley Sussman) begins. The movement is concentrated in a tense and mobile torso or crossed fists. After Ms. Capucilli rises tall on the two-tiered platform, there is a typical Graham manipulation of fabric. The skirt becomes a red shroud, draped over the frightening specter of war who sinks and then dissolves from abstract form into a very human woman beating her fists on the floor until she lies back on the platform.
The bloodiness of the central, shattering image (the section was reconstructed by Carole Fried and Ms. Capucilli) is matched perfectly by the stark anonymous patterns of "Steps in the Street" (subtitled "Devastation, Homelessness, Exile"), led by Denise Vale.
"Prelude to Action" (reconstructed chiefly by Sophie Maslow) is a period piece, but a strong one. Ms. Capucilli, now in white, has a leg-swinging solo before the 12 women and Ms. Vale, who supports her, heed her call. They divide into complex overlapping and dynamic units. Energy within form tells this tale.
Elsewhere on the bill, Joyce Herring triumphed as an especially tender bride in "Appalachian Spring." Floyd Flynn was her engaging and youthful husband, Ms. Vale a focused pioneer and Pascal Rioult an impressively fervent preacher. His followers -- Elizabeth Auclair, Sandra Kaufmann, Rika Okamato and Alessandra Prosperi -- danced more than superbly. As for "Dark Meadow," it was led with particular passion by Ms. Capucilli and Donlin Foreman while Kathy Buccellato, as the earth mother and guide, offered an electric performance.
"Dark Meadow" was the prelude to Graham's exploration of Greek myth, which reached its peak with "Clytemnestra." In the latter work Andrea Matthews and Kevin Deas were the fine singers. Halim El-Dabh's score could have been better played.
Ms. Dakin has come a long way since her debut in the role in 1992. The vengeful and sorrowing queen, seeking redemption, became in this performance a creature of sharply shifting moods, with every nuance expressed through movement. A tapestry of brilliant emotional colors was woven by the entire cast, including Graham's wonderfully voracious furies with their twisted mouths.
Outstanding performances came from Mario Camacho, a febrile Messenger of Death arching with special tension and moving with brilliant timing; Mr. Foreman as a powerful Agamemnon; Ms. Capucilli, a dramatic Electra; Mr. Rioult as a carefully thought-out Aegisthus (Clytemnestra's lover); Kenneth Topping, convincing in the difficult role of Orestes; Ms. Vale as a crazed Cassandra; Miki Orihara as a strangely poignent Iphigenia; Mr. Flynn as an agressive Hades, and Ms. Herring as a voluptuous Helen.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Terese Capucilli in "Chronicle," a Martha Graham social-protest dance from 1936. (Sara Krulwich/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: HOCKEY;
N.H.L. and Union to Go Back to Bargaining Table

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
Having each executed a nifty public relations step in the days before the scheduled start of the season, the two sides in the National Hockey League dispute will resume talks tomorrow aimed at getting the season started Oct. 15.
Bob Goodenow, the players' labor leader, spoke with Gary Bettman yesterday and, the league said in a news advisory, told the commissioner he was prepared to meet tomorrow. They will talk again today to set a time and place. 
 The negotiators most likely will meet in New York, though one person from the league has suggested the talks be moved to a neutral site. But it is the substance, not the site, of the talks that will determine whether or not the season starts on its new opening date.
Bettman designated Oct. 15 as opening day on Friday when he countered the union's move of 24 hours earlier.
Faced with a lockout on opening night last Saturday, the players proposed that the season begin on time and be played in its entirety, under the expired collective bargaining agreement, with the players pledging not to strike and the owners pledging not to lock out and restoring the economic benefits Bettman took away before training camp.
Hockey fans, hoping to avoid the misery that befell their baseball counterparts on Aug. 12, welcomed the proposal and eagerly prepared for opening night.
What they didn't understand in the first flush of anticipation, though, was that the owners would be reluctant to play the season under economic terms they were trying to change. Furthermore, the owners were concerned that the players would drag out talks throughout the season and they would reach the end of the playoffs in the same position they are in now.
The Board of Governors was expected to reject the proposal outright but instead developed its own twist. Bettman announced the next day that he was postponing the start of the season to Oct. 15, giving the two sides an additional two weeks to negotiate an agreement before the season might lose games.
Depending on the pace of negotiations, the commissioner said, he would decide in the interim whether or not to open the season on the new target date. He preferred to have a deal in place by then, he said, but he conceivably could accept the players' proposal without one.
With that move, Bettman was not rejecting the players' proposal but instead placing the onus of negotiations on them. If they didn't begin meeting right away or if they stalled when they did meet, they could be made to look responsible for their own lockout.
In an effort to impress upon the players what he saw as the value of the owners' proposal to settle the dispute, Bettman sent each player a three-page letter the same day he announced the Oct. 15 start.
In the letter, a copy of which was obtained by The New York Times, Bettman cited the economic and image gains the league has made in the past two years.
"I share your concern that a delay in the season will undercut much of the progress that our sport has made over the past year," Bettman wrote. But he went on to say that in the last five years, teams have increased player payrolls $1.14 for every new dollar earned.
"We need a player employment system that avoids making this a league of haves and have-nots," he wrote. "Unless we develop that type of system, our recent success will not solve our economic and competitive problems. This situation must be addressed, and addressed now."
Bettman also noted that the union "refused to meet with us" for more than five months. He then outlined the terms of the owners' proposal, including the luxury tax on payrolls, revenue sharing to benefit low-revenue teams, unrestricted free agency and an entry-level salary system.
Bettman told the players they "should feel free to speak to your club owner or general manager if you have any questions about collective bargaining."
Players generally do not react well to letters that bypass their union and are sent directly to them. It was not known if any of them immediately sought out their owners or general managers with questions. But most of them did hold team meetings after their player representatives returned from a meeting Saturday in Toronto.

HEADLINE: HOCKEY;
3 Teams' Players Call Themselves Informed and United

BYLINE: By JASON DIAMOS 

 BODY:
The Rangers rented a room at the Rye Town Hilton yesterday. The Islanders gathered at Troy Loney's place. The Devils were over at Scott Stevens's house.
Three separate meetings. One distinct purpose. 
 "We went over what we went over yesterday," said the Rangers' Adam Graves, referring to the players meeting held Saturday in Toronto. "Basically, we just updated on everything, took it back to all the guys, talked it over, got everyone's view."
Graves, Mike Richter, Glenn Healy and Nick Kypreos represented the Rangers in Toronto. Loney and Brad Dalgarno were there for the Islanders. The Devils, headed by Bruce Driver, sent the largest contingent of any team: 10 players.
Yesterday, Graves, Loney and Driver emphasized that their teammates were all on the same page after the informational meetings.
"We understand the issues," said Loney. "And that makes our resolve that much stronger."
The Devils decided they would go to the team's training facilities at South Mountain Arena in West Orange, N.J., today to remove their equipment.
One of the major issues discussed in all the meetings was whether to continue practicing together while they are essentially locked out by the owners. Each group came up with a decision, but none will reveal what it was until today, after all the player representatives talk by phone with the Players Association in Toronto. The decision will be leaguewide.
"It isn't the Islanders, the Rangers anymore," said Loney.
"It's the N.H.L.P.A.," said Graves.
Most of the other discussion focused on the league's latest proposal.
"When you look at things at face value, some people are saying to us, 'Why aren't you signing that?' " Graves said. "But when you break it down, we don't think it's very fair. Everyone realizes what this entails. In your heart, you know it's morally wrong. It just isn't fair."
Graves added: "It goes without saying that the guys fully understand what the issues are. To say anyone's happy, no. We're hockey players; we want to play hockey. Right now, we're being locked out unless we agree on what Gary Bettman has given us as a proposal. And in no way do we feel we want to accept it. It would be nice to say you could give or take on this issue, give or take on that issue. But their position is take everything as one or don't play. There's been no give or take."
The players say they will definitely not accept a salary cap in any form. Early in training camp, some older veterans suggested they might be willing to give in to a rookie salary cap.
"But once it was explained, you haven't heard anybody else," said Loney, who just turned 31. "I'm as strong against it as anybody else because with it veterans will lose their jobs. You saw the same situation in football. The same exact thing would happen. Under the cap, the rookies' salaries would be down. It would become an economic decision for teams. You have a rookie, maybe he's not ready, but you need to slash costs. So you release a veteran and the rookie takes his place."

SECTION: Section C; Page 2; Column 1; Sports Desk 

LENGTH: 1724 words

HEADLINE: HOCKEY;
Collaboration Or Coincidence?

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
Jim Quinn, a players lawyer who has been involved in landmark litigation in football and basketball, sees it as the ultimate dream. "We could sue them all at once," he said, fantasizing about the idea of mounting a mammoth antitrust case against professional sports.
Shaking himself out of his courtroom reverie, Quinn added, "It may or may not be the seeds of a great lawsuit, but it's interesting that people who purport to be competitors are cooperating." 
 With more professional leagues shut down than operating, players and their lawyers cast a suspicious eye at the officials and some club owners and executives of Major League Baseball, the National Hockey League and the National Basketball Association.
They see, as one lawyer put it, a "cross-fertilization," men who own or operate teams in more than one sport, and they talk of meetings attended by representatives of the three leagues. They do not charge a conspiracy, but some question the propriety of what they suspect is joint planning by officials of leagues that are supposed to be competing for the fans' dollars.
At the same time, members of management talk of joint efforts of the heads of the three unions, pointing to the similarity of player proposals in baseball and hockey in current negotiations as evidence. They don't accuse the union chiefs of illegal acts either, but the suggestions of cross-pollination on both sides add spice to the unique development that has enveloped sports these days.
The National Football League played its full complement of games yesterday, but Major League Baseball neither played its final day of games nor planned for the start of its playoffs tomorrow, and the National Hockey League did not play its two scheduled games. The National Basketball Association doesn't have any games scheduled for another month, but they might not be played either.
Strikes, lockouts, postponements, shutdowns. They have replaced the game of summer, autumn and winter. Even the man who runs Bud Selig's delicatessen in Milwaukee asked the question: Why now? Why are all of these professional sports leagues mired in labor problems at the same time?
One reason is that the collective bargaining agreements in the three sports ended at about the same time. Another is money -- the battle for the billions of dollars in revenue generated by professional sports.
The players want their salaries to be determined in a free market while the owners want to gain control over the escalation of those salaries. Salary cap or luxury tax, the owners' system of choice is aimed at producing less income for labor and more for management. Baseball and hockey owners see the cap at work in the other leagues, and they want their new system.
"It clearly is not by accident," said Selig, baseball's acting commissioner. "It is clearly taken from our experience. This has been coming for a long time. The systems that used to work so well economically don't work anymore. Tragically, I think we were all guilty of not facing up to that. The timing is all too bad, but it should not be misunderstood. No matter what the explanation, it is not a historical accident that the only sport playing has revenue sharing and a salary cap."
As the battle rages, though, the players and their lawyers wonder if the owners said, "Me, too," or if the movement has been orchestrated.
"I don't know if it's a grand conspiracy, but my information is they've been in regular contact and consultation," Donald Fehr, executive director of the Major League Baseball Players Association, said. "They've had some meetings in Bettman's and Stern's offices."
Gary Bettman is the commissioner of the National Hockey League; David Stern, Bettman's former boss, is commissioner of the National Basketball Association. Selig has not been identified as having been a participant in any meetings, but Richard Ravitch, the baseball owners' chief labor executive, has.
Richard Moss, a well-placed players lawyer, said he has heard about "lots of meetings," and another person associated with players, who spoke on the condition he not be identified, said that when Jerry Reinsdorf, principal owner of the White Sox and Bulls of Chicago, was in New York for baseball labor meetings last month, he met with Bettman.
Reports of interleague meetings or telephone conversations come not only from people on the players' side. One owner with friends in more than one league said he is aware that Ravitch has spoken to the others. A baseball owner said he, too, knows that Ravitch has seen Bettman and Stern "on occasion."
Another baseball person said: "I know they talk a lot. I'm sure they've gotten together at lunch or meetings. Dick often says, 'Gary said this; David said this.' "
But none of the principals acknowledges any such widespread communications.
Stern said yesterday that he could recall having had lunch with Bettman and Ravitch once in the last six months. He denied that they have undertaken any joint efforts or bargaining strategies.
"We rail against economic reality and owners," the N.B.A. commissioner said. "Those tend to be a unifying thing."
Bettman said that he could recall only one meeting among the three men "many, many, many months ago."
"It was a status report as to where we each were and what our unions were telling us," he said. "Nothing more than bringing everyone up to date as to where things were and where they were likely to go. There's no ongoing series of meetings or discussions about who is doing what or what we're going to do, at least not between me and the other guys. As a matter of industry knowledge, you may get an occasional inquiry: 'We read this; what does it mean?' "
Bettman said he and Stern "chat on a regular basis about a lot of things," but he added, "I have a league to run and he has a league to run and guess what? We're competitors. It would be counterproductive to be doing anything with other sports because we compete head to head. In the best of all worlds I'd make a deal next week and baseball and basketball would be out."
It would, the N.H.L. commissioner said, "be an unfair and inaccurate aspersion" to say the sports officials meet and work in unison.
Ravitch said he talks with Stern occasionally but added: "I think we're both guarded. We have our own unique responsibilities. He doesn't tell me his strategy and I don't tell him mine." Ravitch said he has talked with Bettman "once or twice."
The way Stan Kasten sees it, talking among officials, owners and executives in various sports is natural. Kasten is president of Ted Turner's teams in Atlanta, the Braves and the Hawks.
"It's an industry and people tend to have their contacts and expertise across the spectrum of that particular industry," he said. "I don't think it's different from any other industry. We all know each other. We talk."
As a member of the owners' negotiating committee in baseball, Kasten was in New York last month trying to help produce a settlement that would end the players strike and salvage the World Series. As a member of the labor committee in basketball, he will be in New York for a meeting tomorrow.
Kasten said he actively speaks with people in both sports and is a close friend of Bettman. But he said: "The problems of each sport are unique and are being handled very individually. Otherwise, we'd have had a cap in baseball years ago."
The N.B.A. talks won't begin until the union's appeal of a Federal court ruling upholding the league's salary cap is decided, perhaps in three or four weeks. Reinsdorf, the Chicago owner, is another who is interested in those developments as well as the muddied future of baseball.
Abe Pollin (Washington Capitals, Washington Bullets) and the Gunds, George 3d and Gordon (San Jose Sharks, Cleveland Cavaliers) own teams in hockey and basketball. So do the owners of the Rangers and Knicks, whoever they are at any given moment.
Mike Ilitch owns the Tigers and Red Wings of Detroit. Wayne Huizenga owns teams in just about every professional league. John McMullen, owner of the New Jersey Devils, also used to own the Houston Astros. David LeFevre, governor of the Tampa Bay Lightning, used to be a minority owner in baseball.
Bettman worked in the N.B.A. for 11 years. Jeffrey Pash, his senior vice president and general counsel, became the National Football League's chief attorney when Paul Tagliabue became commissioner. Management people, generally anonymously, are quick to mention what they say is an intimate relationship between Fehr, the baseball labor leader, and Goodenow, his less experienced hockey counterpart. Some throw in Charles Grantham, the basketball players' union chief.
"My guess is we don't have the same networking intensity that occurs on the players' side," said Stern. "We're not connected the same way historically."
A baseball official said he has been told that "Don and Charlie and Goodenow are in almost daily contact." But, the official added, "We have no problem with that."
Some N.H.L. people believe Fehr and Goodenow consult on a regular basis. "That's how we got the same proposal," one official said.
Another hockey person said, "I think the thing is so dominated by Donald Fehr that Goodenow won't do anything."
A players lawyer said the unions talk "all the time," but he didn't believe Goodenow was constantly looking over his shoulder. Another lawyer close to the baseball union said Fehr offered Goodenow "very little guidance."
Fehr and Goodenow scoffed at the notion that they daily press each other's button on their speed-dial telephones.
"Bob and I talk every so often," Fehr said. "We have some lawyers we both use in varying degrees and for different things." He said the notion that "Bob and the hockey players do what we tell them is silly."
Goodenow said he speaks with Fehr occasionally, "maybe once or twice since their strike started."
"As a new person," Goodenow added, "Don called me and said, 'If you have any questions, call or stop in. They've been in their new offices, I think, since January, and I stopped there in August for the first time."
Asked about the similarity of the unions' proposals -- a tax on player payrolls, a tax on total revenues or gate receipts -- Fehr said, "If you're going to tax something, there's a limited number of things you can tax."

HEADLINE: Business-Friendlier at City Hall

 BODY:
Movie projectors have not used combustible nitrate film for decades, so the safety risk is long gone. But an obsolete city regulation still requires projectionists to obtain a license from New York City's Department of Consumer Affairs. Likewise anyone who holds a masquerade ball, works in a pool hall, or drives a laundry truck.
These are among the 21 license categories that Mayor Rudolph Giuliani now proposes to eliminate as part of his larger effort to "re-engineer" the city's regulatory process and remove unnecessary burdens on businesses. The City Council will have to determine whether any of the licenses on the City Hall hit list, like the one now required for used-car wholesalers, still make sense as a matter of consumer protection or public safety. But in general Mr. Giuliani's approach to cutting the city's daunting, expensive -- and often mindless -- red tape is both welcome and overdue. 
 Too often, as the Mayor's task force on regulatory reform observes, businesses are "crippled by the triple plagues of unnecessary or unduly harsh rules, uncaring or unthinking enforcement and poor business-government communication."
Some positive changes are already under way. For example, a pilot program begun in August in Queens allows "one-stop shopping" for various construction permits or certificates of occupancy, eliminating a lot of the normal traipsing from agency to agency. The administration plans to phase it in citywide, and to extend the one-stop concept to tax, license and inspection matters.
The city's complex regulatory process is deeply entrenched and cannot be transformed overnight. The budget crunch, which provides an impetus for change, may also make necessary new computer equipment unaffordable. Much of what Mr. Giuliani is now proposing, like allowing businesses to pay fees or fines with credit cards, requires approval from the State Legislature. Licensing is one area where quick progress should be possible. But only two years ago, the City Council rejected many of the same suggestions when they were proposed by Mark Green, then the city's Consumer Affairs Commissioner.
There is reason even beyond the budget crisis to hope that this year will be different. Mr. Green, a Democrat who is now the city's Public Advocate, and Mr. Giuliani, the city's first Republican Mayor since John Lindsay, do not seem to agree on much else. But they are together on the need for sensible licensing reform that protects essential consumer safety and health interests without pummeling law-abiding businesses.

HEADLINE: What Would F.D.R. and Einstein Do in Smoke-Free New York?;
Stop the Bidding War

 BODY:
To the Editor:
With all the talk of businesses leaving New York City, the move of the Swiss Bank Corporation, with its 1,500 workers, to Stamford, Conn., was reported as a "blow to the city" (news article, Sept. 22). 
 But it is Stamford that has placed itself in a vulnerable position with a "gain" that will cost the people who live there $120 million over the next 10 years, which comes to $60,000 per employee. The prospect of lowering local taxes becomes more remote.
In New York City, as in Stamford, the way to attract jobs is to reduce everyone's taxes, not just the taxes of those wielding the most influence.
With each bidding war to lure major companies and institutions, the stakes rise until Stamford's gift to Swiss Bank more than doubled what New York City had ever offered. Let's hope this is the beginning of the end of these programs. This extreme exposes just how silly and ultimately unprofitable the game of corporate bluff is.
Both Connecticut and New Jersey must realize that by weakening New York City's economy, they are weakening their own. Without New York City as the country's financial center, future Swiss Banks will opt for new locations that are much less expensive and much farther away.
As the president of a company that owns and manages two million square feet of New York City real estate, I know that to retain tenants you have to improve the quality of life and lower the cost of doing business.
 
H. DALE HEMMERDINGER
New York, Sept. 23, 1994

HEADLINE: THE 1994 CAMPAIGN: WOMEN;
In '94, 'Vote for Woman' Does Not Play So Well

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Oct. 2

 BODY:
When Dawn Clark Netsch pulled an upset and won the Democratic primary for governor of Illinois last March, she seemed well on her way to following the trail blazed here two years ago by Carol Moseley-Braun, who rode the sex card to the United States Senate.
Not only is Ms. Netsch the first woman nominated for governor by either major party in Illinois, she is the first woman in the nation with a female running-mate, Penny Severns, as well. Yet Ms. Netsch rarely talks to voters about the historic nature of her ticket, and her candidacy has generated little enthusiasm among women or men. Unlike Ms. Moseley-Braun, a Democrat who drew support from Republican women, Ms. Netsch is having trouble winning over women in her own party and is stalled as much as 30 points behind Gov. Jim Edgar in local polls. 
 "Nobody is really paying much attention," Ms. Netsch, the 68-year-old State Comptroller, said in an interview at her campaign headquarters here. "Maybe it's our fault for not having made more of it. But if you beat everybody over the head with it constantly, then it sounds as if you're saying people should vote for you just because you're a woman."
While the professorial Ms. Netsch is a far different candidate in many ways than the youthful Ms. Moseley-Braun -- and her sex is but one factor in her campaign -- her conflict over whether to emphasize the fact that she is a woman is emblematic of the conflicts faced by female candidates around the country. The impressive gains by women in 1992 have left a complicated legacy for those running this year; many agree that being a woman is not the advantage it was two years ago and can even be a handicap.
Since the raw anger over the Supreme Court confirmation hearings of Clarence Thomas -- who was accused of sexually harassing a female colleague -- has subsided, many female candidates say they do not think it helps to emphasize their sex. In a turnabout from two years ago, it is the men who now see the benefit of playing up the sex of their female opponents. Crime rather than the economy has become the central issue in many races, leaving women to suffer from a stereotype that they are not as tough as men on crime.
Even women who were elected to the House in record numbers in 1992 are finding the excitement over their victories short-lived. They are now considered insiders, and most of them are Democrats -- not a sure-fire recipe for victory this November. As a result, more than a third of the 48 female House members are considered endangered.
"We're talking about a year where there is less opportunity, where many of the women elected in 1992 are running for re-election in a much tougher political climate," said Harriett Woods, president of the National Women's Political Caucus who lost two Senate races in Missouri in the 1980's. "There has just been an apathy among all the electorate. Women may suffer from it, but I don't think it's people saying, 'Oh, we aren't going to support women.' "
Another dynamic playing against women, pollsters say, is that voters generally find it easier to vote for a woman for a legislative job like senator rather than an executive post like governor. And this year, as opposed to 1992, there are many more contests for governor.
Here in Illinois, Ms. Netsch has not recovered from a barrage of commercials after the primary in which Mr. Edgar attacked her for opposing the death penalty. At the time, her campaign did not have the money to respond to Mr. Edgar, and her standing in the polls plummeted.
Struggling to climb back, Ms. Netsch's senior aides met with worried party leaders last week and decided to redouble efforts to mobilize women and other groups who historically are reliable Democrats. "Women are demoralized for some reason," Kay Clement, a veteran Chicago political organizer and Ms. Netsch's closest friend, said during a women's luncheon here. "They aren't coming out with the support that they did two years ago."
In other states, women have more hopeful stories to tell. Several have fought off aggressive challenges from male opponents to win primaries. The Democrats waging competitive, if not winning, races for governor include Kathleen Brown in California, Bonnie Campbell in Iowa and Myrth York in Rhode Island. At least three woman are favored to win election to the Senate; Senator Kay Bailey Hutchison, Republican of Texas; Olympia Snowe, a Maine Republican, and Ann Wynia, a Minnesota Democrat.
Even so, there are as many examples of women who waged vigorous primary campaigns with help from national women's groups but lost to male rivals who in most cases were better financed.
They include these Democrats who were defeated: State Senator Debbie Stabenow, in Michigan's primary for governor; State Senator Lana Pollack, in Michigan's Senate primary; Mary Boyle, a local county commissioner, in Ohio's Senate primary; State Representative Joan Wagnon, in the Kansas primary for governor, and Marsha Murphy, a local county executive, in the Missouri Senate primary.
Lynn Yeakel, who capitalized on the furor directed at Senator Arlen Specter for voting to confirm Mr. Thomas to the Supreme Court and won the Democratic Senate primary in Pennsylvania in 1992, did not even make it past this year's primary for governor.
On the Republican side, Ronna Romney, a former radio talk show host, was edged out in Michigan's Senate primary. "What you find as a woman is that the normal networks just aren't open," Ms. Romney said in an interview on the eve of her primary. "We literally had to create a whole new universe and a whole new finance universe."
Whatever the degree that sex plays in the elections next month, the results will inevitably be compared to 1992. As Senator Patty Murray, a Washington Democrat who was elected two years ago, declared last week at a Los Angeles fund-raising event for Senator Dianne Feinstein, a California Democrat: "The entire nation is watching California to see if women are up to the job. If the Year of the Women ended in 1992, what does that mean to our daughters?"
If Ms. Feinstein survives a challenge from a well-financed Republican, Representative Michael Huffington, and Ms. Brown manages to defeat Gov. Pete Wilson, California would be the first state where the top three office-holders are women. The second Senator, Barbara Boxer, is also a Democrat.
While Republicans are too savvy to make any sexist appeals that the state is not ready for three women in control, Ms. Feinstein and Ms. Brown are not going out of their way to emphasize their sex. They seem to be trying to preserve their expected support from women without losing male voters. It is a striking contrast to Ms. Feinstein's failed bid for governor in 1990, when she emphasized the historic prospect of becoming the state's first female governor.
Even with diminished voter turnout this year, Mr. Wilson says Ms. Brown's sex gives her an edge. "There are a certain number of women who avowedly say that they will vote for her because she's a woman, purely because of gender," the Governor said in an interview. "There are certain stereotype prejudices that work for and against men and women."
But another stereotype probably works to Mr. Wilson's benefit: crime. Like Mr. Edgar in Illinois, Mr. Wilson has repeatedly castigated Ms. Brown for her stance against the death penalty -- though both women say they would enforce the law on the books. While his attacks would probably work on male opponents, pollsters say they are all the more effective on women.
As part of the subtle effort to characterize her as an indecisive young girl, some of Ms. Brown's detractors derisively refer to her as "Kathy." "They're trying to diminish her, trivialize her," said Celinda Lake, Ms. Brown's pollster.
Don Sipple, the media consultant for Mr. Edgar, Mr. Wilson and George W. Bush, who is running for governor in Texas against Gov. Ann W. Richards, has created look-alike television commercials in all three states that warn viewers that the Democrats are too easy on crime.
"The ads are intended to show rape or assault and to scare the begolly out of people," Ms. Netsch said. "The message they're trying to convey is, obviously, 'This is going to continue if you elect women.' To suggest to women that somehow they are incapable of dealing with or understanding the importance of violence, it really is insulting."
But it works.
Though it may be too late, Ms. Netsch has begun fighting back with a commercial in which she vows to build more prisons if that would keep criminals off the street.
Mr. Sipple insisted that his commercials would be just as effective against men. "Anybody who gets in and thinks they can play a gender card," he said, "they're wrong."
Still, Susan J. Carroll, a political scientist at Rutgers University and an authority on female candidates, said, "When women have positions they believe, like anti-death penalty, it makes it more difficult to counter the stereotype that they're somehow not tough on crime."
Ms. Richards has had an easier time than Ms. Brown and Ms. Netsch in inoculating herself from attacks on the crime issue because she is for the death penalty and has cultivated a tougher persona. "She not only supports the death penalty," Ms. Netsch said, "but she's gung-ho about it."

HEADLINE: NO REST ON TRADE: IN THE TRENCHES;
Foes Line Up To Do Battle Over GATT

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2

 BODY:
An eight-week delay in the Senate vote to ratify a global free trade pact has galvanized a broad range of opponents, who vow an all-out campaign this fall in their uphill fight to stop the 123-nation agreement.
A final vote on the pact, which would cut tariffs around the world and expand the free trade rules of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade to cover farming and services like accounting, has been delayed until after the November elections. This gives the opposition extra time to organize but may also insulate some senators from public pressure. 
 "If we know anything, Congress is never more sensitive to the public than right before an election, and never less sensitive than right after an election," said Ross Perot, who plans to begin condemning the pact in a nationally syndicated weekly radio talk show starting on Oct. 9.
Other opponents are more optimistic, saying Senator Ernest F. Hollings, a South Carolina Democrat, has done them a big favor by using his power as chairman of the Senate Commerce Committee to force a postponement of the Senate vote from next Thursday to Dec. 1.
"We were sure to lose next week -- there is nowhere to go but up," said Ralph Nader, the consumer advocate, who opposes the pact.
While nobody is seriously predicting that the pact will be defeated, and while some on Capitol Hill still predict that Senator Hollings will relent and allow a vote in the coming days, nervousness is spreading.
"As the arguments are made pro and con, GATT will pick up more opposition that it has now, but whether it will pick up enough to be meaningful remains to be seen," Senator Jim Sasser, the Tennessee Democrat who is involved in a tough battle for re-election, said in a telephone interview from Tennessee. Mr. Sasser said he was taking a "wait and see" position on the pact.
The House is scheduled to vote on Wednesday, but some members are calling for a postponement until after the elections.
The same unusual coalition of labor unions, environmentalists, consumer advocates, populist farmers, conservative Republicans including Bob Dole, the Senate minority leader, and liberal religious groups that unsuccessfully fought the North American Free Trade Agreement has reunited against the GATT pact. Their three main objections are that the pact will widen the Federal budget deficit, undermine American sovereignty and weaken American laws intended to protect workers, consumers and the environment.
The pact would eliminate $11 billion in Federal tariff revenues over the next five years, and more after that. The Clinton Administration plans to offset the first five years of losses with a combination of cuts in farm subsidies and various extra fees on businesses.
Mr. Nader and other critics describe the tariff cuts as a giveaway to international corporations. But Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen has contended for several weeks that the trade pact will stimulate the American economy, and that the taxes on the extra economic output will more than offset the lost tariffs.
The critics also contend that the World Trade Organization to be established under the pact will be too powerful. Its secret tribunals of trade experts will have the power to authorize countries to impose trade sanctions on nations that raise trade barriers, including environmental, consumer and worker safety laws that may act like trade barriers.
A similar trade tribunal ruled three years ago that the United States could not bar the importation of tuna caught in huge nets that also killed many dolphins. The United States was able to block that tribunal's decision from taking effect because until now GATT has required unanimity among its 123 members to impose sanctions.
But the World Trade Organization will operate under the principle of one country, one vote, with a two-thirds majority able to impose sanctions on any country.
The Clinton Administration has contended that the tribunals should be trusted not to challenge American laws. The Administration won a surprise victory on Friday when a GATT tribunal ruled that the American law requiring certain minimum fuel-efficiency standards for cars was not a trade barrier.
A group of 51 journalists joined the ranks of critics on Sept. 14, sending a letter to President Clinton condemning the trade panels as undemocratic and excessively secretive.
Many critics of the pact accuse the television networks and major newspapers of systematically ignoring them, paying attention now only because President Clinton has begun speaking out in favor of it. "Now we have the opportunity to have this public debate -- we've been hollering a long time," said Larry W. Mitchell, the vice president for government relations at the Denver-based National Farmers Union, a populist group of 253,000.
As politicians try to weigh the costs and benefits of opposing the trade pact, public opinion is hard to judge. Recent polls have shown that more than half the people know nothing about it.
Opposition to the current trade pact suffers from the same fissure that divided the movement against the North American Free Trade Agreement: there are those who are totally opposed to free trade agreements and those who collaborate with the Clinton Administration to make trade pacts less harmful to their constituencies.
The most hard-line opponents are consumer advocates like Mr. Nader and labor unions like the International Union of Electronic Workers that would be hit hardest by import competition. In contrast, the national leadership of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., including Lane Kirkland, the president, and Tom Donahue, the secretary-treasurer, has worked with the Administration and won many concessions.
For instance, the legislation proposed by President Clinton to put the pact into American law would protect some American textile and apparel workers from foreign competition; make fewer tariff reductions than initially planned for imports from poor countries, particularly in the Caribbean, and make it impossible for the Administration to negotiate future free trade agreements unless it received separate permission from Congress.
The labor split was apparent when about 75 men and women, mostly from the International Union of Electronic Workers, protested the pact on Friday in Lafayette Park, across from the White House. In introducing another speaker, Mr. Nader said, "Following him surely will be Lane Kirkland or Tom Donahue from the A.F.L.-C.I.O. They're not here? Oh."
By contrast, business backing for the trade pact is monolithic. The Administration has even won over some industries that have suffered from foreign competition and might be expected to suffer from the pact, like textile producers. The White House wrote into the legislation various side deals to grease the way for passage.
The only noticeable exception is the Washington-based United States Business and Industrial Council, a conservative group of 1,500 mostly family-owned businesses in the Midwest that fear competition from multinational corporations based in New York and abroad. The group plans a series of local radio and television advertisements critical of the pact.
"Our members live in the community," said Kevin L. Kearns, the group's president. "It's not like living in Scarsdale and commuting down to Manhattan and laying off 10,000 people."

HEADLINE: The Year's First Winning Quarter

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
Is it time for American investors to pay the piper yet? Not according to the summer's stock market, where results for the third quarter show that comeuppance will have to wait.
Despite only moderate overall gains, the leading stock exchanges provided an even richer field of lucrative stocks from which to pick and choose gingerly. For the first time this year, according to figures compiled by Media General Financial Services, there were more winners than losers, and by a wide margin. 
 Of stocks selling for more than $5 a share on the New York Stock Exchange, American Stock Exchange and on the Nasdaq market, almost three rose in price for every two that fell. That is, out of almost 6,000 stocks, 3,324 advanced, 2,364 declined and 228 remained unchanged.
An elite 2.5 percent of this group were especially sweet. The top 50 gainers on the three leading exchanges appreciated in price between 40 percent and more than 80 percent on the Big Board, between 25 percent and 250 percent on the Amex and between 70 percent and more than 180 percent on Nasdaq.
That compares to an improving record for the overall averages. Despite some jarring bumps along the way, caused mainly by market anxieties about inflation, interest rates and the declining value of the dollar, the Dow Jones industrial average during the period was up about 6 percent, the Standard & Poor's 500 up 4 percent, and the Nasdaq composite index up 8 percent.
By contrast, the first and second quarters were clear losers, battered by the increases in interest rates by the Federal Reserve Board and the resultant plummeting of the bond market. In the first quarter, only four stocks rose for every seven that fell. The second quarter was not much better: Five stocks rose for every seven that fell.
What will happen in the fourth quarter? Wall Street, as elsewhere, is divided in its outlook. But those with sporting blood have their own predilections.
"The cyclicals were the darlings and the interest-rate-sensitive stocks were the laggards in the quarter," said Bill Allyn, director of listed equity trading at Jefferies & Company, who is optimistic about inflation and interest rates. "The easy money has been made on the cyclicals. I'd like to bet on the laggards for the fourth quarter."
But John Lipsky, chief economist at Salomon Brothers, said: "The near-term news has obviously been good news. But that good news is already sowing the seeds of downward pressure in the near future."
Mr. Lipsky sees a slowing but still strong fourth quarter, with a possibly difficult first quarter of 1995, with companies experiencing a noticeable slowdown in earnings growth.
Since the Fed started raising short-term interest rates in February and forced traders to look over their shoulders at its chairman, Alan Greenspan, before buying or selling stocks, investors have been asking one question: When do higher corporate borrowing costs lead to thinner profits and lower stock valuations?
For more than two years, many companies have been including a boilerplate sentence in their quarterly earnings reports that said, in effect, that some portion of profits were due solely to interest-rate savings. Those savings, mainly from refinancing old high-interest debt, do not lift profits as much anymore now that the Fed is tightening.
And whether companies have spent those savings wisely on new factories, new products or more efficient production processes that yield more profit is still not clear. How much old debt, long-term financing bound by restrictive covenants, remains to be refinanced at relatively attractive rates is also unclear.
As much as half of the price of a stock, economists say, reflects investor expectations about future earnings, so the fate of those interest-rate savings is critical. So are Wall Street expectations about current earnings. Easton Ragsdale, chief quantitative analyst for Kidder, Peabody, notes that many stocks spurt in price when companies report earnings that exceed analysts' expectations.
But in a recent study, Mr. Ragsdale's group at Kidder found that analysts tended to be too low in their estimates as the year begins, making it somewhat easier for companies to beat forecasts. As the year progresses, analysts tend to raise their estimates, making it harder to beat forecasts.
If, in third-quarter reports, which will be released in the next few weeks, companies continue to exceed forecasts, it will show the continuing strength of the economy as well as the continuing success of cost-cutting and efforts at increased productivity, Mr. Ragsdale said.
The third-quarter stock gainers were not crowded among a lucky few, although cyclical stocks -- those associated with a growing economy -- were clearly in favor. Industries in the S.& P. 500 that rose in share price between 10 percent and 22 percent during the period included household products, tobacco, broadcast media, gold mining, paper products and machine tools.
By contrast, the losers did tend to concentrate among a few groups, like banks, oil and gas companies and airlines. And among the unluckiest few were the biotechnology concerns underwritten by a luckless brokerage house, D. Blech & Co., whose financial problems helped drag down the stock of those companies it underwrote. D. Blech merged with a healthier firm last month.
On the nation's largest stock exchange, the New York Stock Exchange, chemical companies and specialized electronics firms were among the top 10 gainers. Four chemical companies, with rising earnings and recommendations by Wall Street analysts, rose sharply. American Cyanamid, whose shares rose on the rumor and then the announcement of a merger into American Home Products, rose 77.7 percent, to $99.50 a share.
But the big gainer on the Big Board was the Whitehall Corporation, whose stock rose 83.1 percent, to $20.38 a share, on a strong 1995 outlook for its mix of specialized electronic gear, like seismic survey and acoustic measurement systems.
Similarly, General Datacomm and Network Equipment rose on expectations that their products would be useful in telecommunications and computer networking. General Datacomm rose 75.1 percent, to $28.25 a share, and Network Equipment rose 68 percent, to $14.50 a share.
Big Board losers tended to be those that reported poor earnings or were associated with the interest-rate-sensitive housing industry. Rhodes Inc. a retailer of home furnishings, fell 39.1 percent, to $9.75 a share. And the biggest decliner was UDC Homes, a builder of retirement homes, which dropped 51.1 percent, to $2.63 a share.
Nasdaq winners tended to be high-technology companies; 6 of the top 10 had something to do with computers. Micrion Inc., for example, makes equipment that tests integrated circuits. Its stock rose 184 percent, to $17.75 a share. Alliance Semiconductor, the 10th-largest gainer, makes random-access-memory chips. Its stock rose 106.8 percent, to $22.75 a share.
Nasdaq losers tended to be high-tech concerns, too. Five of the top 10 were such companies, but 3 of these were associated with D. Blech, the brokerage house. The biggest loser was the NDE Environmental Corporation, a detector of leaks in underground storage systems, which reported continuing losses. It fell 83.3 percent, to $1.25 a share.
The biggest Amex winner was the SFM Corporation, a toy and electric machinery company, whose big earnings rise surprised Wall Street and whose plans for a 4-for-1 stock split pleased investors. SFM rose 250.5 percent, to $32 a share. The biggest Amex loser was Greyhound, whose continuing restructuring did little to revive its stock price. Greyhound fell 70.2 percent, to $1.94 a share.

HEADLINE: Legal Aid Society Plays a Big Role in New York's Courts

BYLINE: By JAN HOFFMAN 

 BODY:
Unlike most American cities, New York relies heavily on the Legal Aid Society to represent the indigent not just in civil matters, but in criminal cases as well.
The strike by the private nonprofit organization will affect the gamut of cases: everything from criminal prosecutions and appeals to tenant disputes, immigration hearings, child abuse and neglect proceedings, prisoners' rights suits, and unemployment and welfare benefits cases. 
 Courts in most major cities like Los Angeles and Chicago, and in states like New Jersey and Connecticut, are not nearly as vulnerable as those in New York to the strain imposed by a strike. They use public defenders to represent the poor in criminal cases; as government employees, public defenders are generally prohibited from striking. Civil cases are handled by a variety of local and Federal legal-services organizations including the Legal Aid Society.
The society was started in 1876, largely to offer services to new German immigrants, including representing them in criminal cases. It rapidly expanded, in large measure because of support from philanthropists like John D. Rockefeller Jr., to take on thousands of civil and criminal cases for the poor. In 1961, acknowledging the importance of the society in the lives of the indigent, New York City contributed about $100,000. Last year it paid the society $79 million just for its work on criminal cases.
By 1966, the society had contracted to become the city's primary defender for the poor. That decision was in response to a 1963 United States Supreme Court ruling, in the case of Gideon v. Wainwright, that insured that indigent defendants were entitled to lawyers.
The society does not handle all cases for indigent defendants, however. In matters involving multiple defendants, conflicts can arise, particularly if defendants want to testify against each other.
So a second tier of representation has sprung up, known as the Assigned Counsel Plan and consisting of private lawyers who charge the city by the hour. They are called upon when such conflicts arise. Considered more experienced than many Legal Aid lawyers, they also handle murder cases.
But after a 1982 strike by Legal Aid Society lawyers that crippled the city's courts for 10 weeks, judges increasingly turned to Assigned Counsel lawyers, who represent defendants in nearly half of the city's felony cases. Their bills were expected to reach $50 million this year.
This summer, in a cost-saving effort, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani proposed to return the bulk of the criminal caseload to the society. That program began scarcely two weeks ago. But with the onset of the strike, Assigned Counsel lawyers will presumably once again pick up thousands of new cases.
During the 1982 Legal Aid strike, the Koch administration commissioned a study of the feasibility of adopting a system of public defenders who would be employed directly by the city and prohibited from striking. The report, written by John F. Keenan, now a Federal judge, found the idea worth considering but advised against switching immediately to such a system from an established organization that the report said was well-qualified to perform its function.

International
South Africa won a long-sought prize from Wall Street: an investment-grade rating from Moody's that is expected to make it easier to raise money to build roads, provide electricity and create jobs. Standard & Poor's rated the debt below investment grade. [Page D1.]
Volvo is facing the stiffest test yet of its ability to survive as an independent company, despite a recent surge in sales and profits driven by economic recovery in its largest markets. [D1.]
Global investors moved toward Asian markets other than Japan in the third quarter. Latin American stocks also did well. [D2.]
 
The Economy
 
Pressure is building on Corporate America to bid up wages to attract machinists, computer specialists and other skilled workers in short supply. But companies are resisting. [D1.]
