HEADLINE: Mandela Thanks U.N. for Apartheid Fight

BYLINE: By RICHARD BERNSTEIN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Oct. 3

 BODY:
Nelson Mandela addressed the General Assembly today as South Africa's first black President, thanked the United Nations for its help in overcoming apartheid and asked it to make a new commitment to fight poverty.
"It surely must be one of the ironies of the age that this august assembly is addressed for the first time in its 49 years by a South African head of state drawn from among the African majority of what is an African country," Mr. Mandela said. 
 Mr. Mandela's speech seemed aimed less at making a policy statement than at ceremonially declaring the end of apartheid before the group of nations that had made dismantling apartheid one of its main official aims.
Mr. Mandela has addressed the General Assembly and other United Nations groups in the past, but today he became the first South African head of state, black or white, to do so. Before him, the highest ranking South African official to speak to the General Assembly was the Foreign Minister; since 1972 no senior South African official had appeared. The General Assembly stripped South Africa of its credentials as a member state in 1974, only restoring them with the formal dismantling of apartheid.
Mr. Mandela's appearance in the vast chamber clearly had an emotional significance for many of the delegates, who rose and applauded as Mr. Mandela was introduced and again when he finished speaking. Mr. Mandela is to go to Washington on Tuesday for meetings with President Clinton and other Administration officials.
"It is indeed a most welcome thing that this august organization will mark its 50th anniversary next year with the apartheid system having been vanquished and consigned to the past," Mr. Mandela said.
"That historic change has come about not least because of the great efforts in which the U.N. engaged to ensure the suppression of the apartheid crime against humanity.
"The millions of our people say thank you, and thank you again, that the respect for your own dignity as human beings inspired you to act to insure the restoration of our dignity as well."
Today's speakers before the General Assembly also included the Cuban Foreign Minister, Roberto Robaina Gonzalez, who denounced the Security Council for sanctioning the invasion of Haiti by American forces, which he characterized as an illegal effort by powerful nations to control the fate of one of the weaker ones.
"The cannons of the invaders and the boots of the foreign occupants were the ones that installed in Haiti the dictatorships of this century and trained and supported those who are still tyrannizing their people," Mr. Robaina Gonzalez said. "How then can we trust that they will encourage democracy in the future?
"The evils of the third world are not resolved through military occupations, which are just used to serve selfish interests."
Mr. Robaina Gonzalez made only a brief reference to recent talks between Cuba and the United States over the flight of Cubans to the United States. He said the talks, held last month in New York, "led to partial solutions to the already age-old dispute between Cuba and the United States."
It what seemed like a conciliatory remark, he described "the spirit of seriousness and respect that prevailed in these negotiations and the will of finding solutions by both sides." That, he said, "made it possible to conclude an agreement satisfactory for both parties that, if totally fulfilled, will lay the foundations for the normalization of migratory relations between the two countries."
The talks have led to a preliminary agreement by which Washington would accept at least 20,000 Cubans a year; in exchange, the Cubans vowed to patrol their waters to encourage would-be emigrants to use official channels.
The two sides plan to meet next month to evaluate the agreement.
Cuba has made it clear it wants future meetings to get into other areas, especially the United States economic embargo, which Mr. Robaina Gonzalez denounced today as "an action without any legal justification, without moral virtues and without ethical principles."
Washington says the talks should be limited to immigration.

HEADLINE: THE 1994 CAMPAIGN;
Incumbency Dogs a Popular Governor of Colorado

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: DENVER, Oct. 3

 BODY:
In an age when more souls are bared on talk shows than in confessional booths, Bruce Benson, the Republican candidate for governor of Colorado, might have been seeking a sort of electoral hug when he surprised an audience during a debate here last month by revealing that he had been arrested twice for drunken driving in the early 1980's.
His opponent, Gov. Roy Romer, in a rather lame effort to join in the spirit of contrition at the debate, said that he, too, had "a confession to make -- I'm worried about world population and I've had seven children." 
 But now Mr. Benson is having to explain some other embarrassing details about his past, a messy divorce that will put the politics of redemption here to a severe test.
The divorce records, made public last month after a lawsuit brought by a Denver television station, disclosed that Mr. Benson had told his son that he was "going to kill" his former wife, Nancy Benson, a remark that the millionaire oil executive has said was simply a figure of speech.
According to an affidavit in the records, Mrs. Benson said that her husband had "harassed, taunted and threatened" her. The records also disclosed that Mr. Benson had been having an affair, which he admits, for two years before he asked for a divorce last year.
Moreover, women's groups in Colorado have criticized Mr. Benson for contributing $1,000 to the legal defense of Senator Bob Packwood, the Oregon Republican who has been accused of sexual harassment by about two dozen women.
In a news conference after the disclosures, Mr. Benson said that he regretted saying he would kill his wife, and that having an affair was a mistake. "I've fully admitted the errors of the ways of my life," he said.
Mr. Benson predicted that voters would respect his honesty. "That's a rare quality in a politician," he said.
Given Mr. Romer's popularity during his eight-year tenure -- he grew up on the Colorado plains, and his centrist approach has seemed to fit the temperament of the state -- together with a booming state economy and the problems haunting Mr. Benson, it would seem that the Governor would be coasting toward victory. In 1990, Mr. Romer was re-elected with 64 percent of the vote.
But political analysts say the contest could be tight. A Denver Post poll taken in July, before Mr. Benson's divorce records became public, showed the Governor with a five-point lead, with a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three points. About 11 percent of voters were undecided.
Governor Romer, analysts say, suffers a stigma that many voters deem worse than drunken driving or marital infidelity: he is an incumbent. He is also a Democrat, and the low popularity ratings of President Clinton have been widely seen as a detriment for Democrats in the Nov. 8 elections.
In a bizarre twist to a campaign that is already unusual, Mr. Romer, riding in an unmarked police car, was pursued by a red Chevrolet at speeds of up to 110 miles per hour on Interstate 25 near Greeley on Saturday. The 20-mile chase, which occurred after the Governor and Mr. Benson took part in a debate at the University of Northern Colorado, ended when the state trooper who was driving the Governor was able to shake the pursuing car. The police are looking for the two occupants of the Chevrolet.
The state police car was assigned to take Mr. Romer to his next stop after the Governor's staff received a suspicious call from someone seeking details of Mr. Romer's schedule, campaign workers said.
Both Mr. Romer and his Republican challenger are seen as centrists, with Mr. Benson a bit more conservative.
In television advertisements, Mr. Benson, a former Republican state chairman, has focused on welfare and crime, and has criticized the Governor for his past support of tax increases. He has also blamed Mr. Romer for his support of the new Denver International Airport, which has been plagued by difficulties and is already more than a year behind schedule.
Mr. Romer has countered that Mr. Benson himself donated money to the campaign to approve the new airport. The Governor has also said he supports changes in the welfare system, but has criticized the Republican plans as Draconian.
On crime, Mr. Romer notes that he called a special session of the Colorado Legislature last year to examine ways to fight crime, and that prison construction during his two terms has been the largest in the state's history.
Rodney Hero, a political scientist at the University of Colorado in Boulder, said the Republicans would have a difficult time portraying Mr. Romer as a liberal.
But he said Mr. Benson, who built a fortune in the oil industry, could benefit from a sense among voters that "can-do business barons" are better suited to solve the problems of government than politicians.
Mr. Romer will be most vulnerable, Mr. Hero said, because he is an incumbent. "After a while in office," he said, "you've made as many enemies as friends."

GRAPHIC: Photos: The incumbent, Roy Romer, in a fist-clenching debate with his challenger at the University of Northern Colorado last Saturday. (Associated Press); The challenger, Bruce Benson, making a point in last Saturday's debate, which was sponsored by United We Stand America of Colorado. (Brian Brainerd for The New York Times)
 
Chart: "THE 1994 CAMPAIGN: Colorado"
 
GOVERNOR'S RACE
 
DEMOCRAT: Roy Romer, 65, two-term incumbent
REPUBLICAN: Bruce Benson, 56, oil executive
 
ANALYSIS
Mr. Romer, a centrist with roots in rural Colorado and a style that has always been successful among working-class voters as well as Denver liberals, could be damaged by an anti-incumbency mood. Mr. Benson, an amiable businessman from the moderate wing of the Republican Party, has been embarrassed by incidents in his past: drunken driving convictions and a bitter divorce.
 
LATEST POLL
A survey by the Denver Post/KCNC TV from July 14 showed Mr. Romer with 47 percent; Mr. Benson with 42 percent; and 11 percent undecided. Margin of sampling error was plus or minus three percentage points.

HEADLINE: Sister Mary Margaret Johanning; Lecturer and Consultant Was 57

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON 

 BODY:
Sister Mary Margaret Johanning, a lecturer and consultant on theological affairs and the former international community leader of the School Sisters of Notre Dame, died on Saturday at St. Marys Health Center in Jefferson City, Mo. She was 57 and lived at St. Peter's Convent in Jefferson City.
The cause was pancreatic cancer, the Roman Catholic Diocese of Jefferson City said. 
 Sister Mary Margaret was elected to the Provincial Council of the School Sisters of Notre Dame in St. Louis in 1971 and served as the international leader in Rome from 1977 to 1987. In that position, she led the community through a revision of its constitution, enabling the nuns to expand on their roles as teachers in Catholic schools to add a variety of activities, including parish ministry. The order has 7,500 women serving in 35 countries.
In 1989, Sister Mary Margaret became Chancellor of the Jefferson City diocese, a position reached by only a few women in the Catholic Church in the United States. As such, she served as Bishop Michael F. McAuliffe's principal administrator for 87 parishes and their 37 parochial schools.
She held the title of Chancellor at her death and was on leave from that position. She also directed the planning commission of the diocese and the office of leadership services. As of the end of 1993, the diocese counted 87,000 parishioners.
Sister Mary Margaret, a native of Glasgow, Mo., was an economics graduate of Notre Dame College in St. Louis. She earned a master's degree in theology and a doctorate in religious studies at Marquette University in Milwaukee.
Beginning in 1962 as an elementary school teacher in a St. Louis parochial school, she was soon lecturing widely at workshops and retreats in the United States and abroad. Before her election to the Provincial Council in St. Louis, she was an instructor in theology at her alma mater, Notre Dame College.
She entered the Congregation of the School Sisters of Notre Dame in 1958 and professed her final vows in 1966.
Sister Mary Margaret is survived by her parents, Bernard and Gertrude Johanning of Glasgow; four brothers, Jerome, of Mound, Minn., Myrl, of Shawnee, Kan., Bob, of Glasgow, and Don, of Sturgeon, Mo., and two sisters, Joetta Jones of Jasper, Ind., and Cindy Monnig of Jefferson City.

HEADLINE: THE 1994 CAMPAIGN: THE AD CAMPAIGN;
Cuomo: Warning of Tax Cuts

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK 

 BODY:

CANDIDATE Mario M. Cuomo
 
 PRODUCER The Garth Group, New York City 
 VISUAL The words spoken by the announcer scroll up the screen in yellow letters, interrupted only by a picture of an editorial from the Buffalo News, titled: "In Season of Big Promises, Beware of Rosy Tax Cut Plans."
 
 SCRIPT Announcer: "Do you think raising local property and school taxes is a good idea? George Pataki does. But Governor Cuomo and local officials across the state don't. Financial experts are calling George Pataki's plan a disaster. Felix Rohatyn, a member of President Reagan's economic commission, said the plan would devastate the state's finances. And mayors are warning about cuts in state aid to schools and higher property taxes. When Republicans named George say read my lips, it's politics as usual all over again."
 
 ACCURACY The Cuomo campaign's assertion that Mr. Pataki thinks raising local property and school taxes is "a good idea" may be the most outrageous claim in any ad in this year's campaign, and that's saying something. Mr. Pataki, of course, has never said such a thing. Instead, Mr. Cuomo has taken one possible effect of Mr. Pataki's proposed income tax cut -- an increase in local property taxes -- and attributed it to the Republican candidate as intent.
 
 It is true that some financial experts believe that Mr. Pataki's tax plan is based on overly optimistic assumptions about economic growth and that Mr. Pataki has not explained how he would compensate for lost revenues. Mr. Rohatyn, however, is hardly objective. He is a longtime Cuomo ally, whom the Governor appointed as chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation. The "read my lips" quip, while clever, is somewhat disingenuous, given that Mr. Cuomo is also promising tax cuts, albeit less ambitious ones.
 
 SCORECARD Mr. Cuomo watched a political novice, Christine Todd Whitman, get elected Governor of New Jersey last year because she promised massive tax cuts, and he is determined to make sure that history is not repeated in New York. The key to success is to attack Mr. Pataki's credibility, to dismiss his plan as pie-in-the-sky that bears little relationship to fiscal reality. It is a sophisticated argument to make to an electorate that does not always examine such issues in depth, but Mr. Pataki has given the Governor an opening by proposing half a plan that trumpets the good news while suppressing the bad.
 Kevin Sack

HEADLINE: A Sound Japanese Trade Pact

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration has negotiated a good trade agreement with the Japanese that should benefit both countries. By opening up Japanese markets for insurance, telecommunications and medical equipment, the accord will bring lower prices to Japan and higher sales to the U.S. The U.S. backed down from benighted demands that numerical targets be set for imports into Japan -- and seems willing to turn down the rhetoric that has needlessly inflamed trade disputes.
The economic impact of the accord will be small -- boosting Japanese imports by less than $2 billion, by one estimate, only some of which will come from U.S. companies. Nor is the agreement novel; in hammering hard at blatantly protectionist rules and regulations in Japan, it mirrors accords that previous Administrations struck on computers and farm goods. 
 The Japanese Government did not, to its credit, agree to numerical targets for imports. Applied to insurance and other markets, numerical targets would require Tokyo to ride herd over private companies, which would run counter to the deregulatory approach the United States advocates for Japan. Japan did agree to a "substantial increase" in government purchases of equipment. But even here, the language is murky. The Japanese will say the pledge is a goal; Washington will call it a commitment. The fudge could lead to endless squabbling.
Left unresolved is a dispute over automobiles and auto parts, which account for two-thirds of the bilateral trade deficit. The U.S. triggered a negotiating process over auto parts that will last perhaps 12 months and could culminate with sanctions. The best U.S. strategy would be continuing to focus on unfair government rules, such as discriminatory safety inspections of American-made parts, and use international dispute panels, not unilateral sanctions, to resolve disagreements.
The Clinton Administration has achieved a useful trade accord by focusing on market barriers. It will help both countries and preserve the U.S. commitment to international rules of fair play.

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
Hunt Them Down

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL 

 BODY:
When a nation sets out to persecute a segment of its population, to hound them down, mark them, deprive them of the human care it gives to others, tells them they cannot work to earn their bread, that nation takes a large step toward persecuting other groups who live within its borders. It follows as blood the wound.
In dictatorships, the first persecution is carried out by command, in full knowledge that other groups are on the list. 
 In democratic countries, the first persecution is usually the result of generalized public anxiety and uncertainty, manipulated and deepened by politicians who scavenge and batten on antagonism within society.
The antagonism becomes a political movement in itself, frightening into silence politicians who are aware of the dangers of the acceptance of any persecution of any group but willing to push that into the back of their minds.
All this is taking place in America -- the anxieties being directed against a small slice of the population, the heightening by political propagandists, the submission of the political center.
The target is the residents of the U.S. who have come to this country in search of work or refuge without securing admission papers -- the 3.2 million people called "illegal aliens" or "undocumented immigrants." Usage depends on whether you despise them or can muster up some memory of America's debt to the paperless.
Americans suffering from jumpy nerves about immigrants should demand that Washington spend more billions of their tax money to make the borders tighter, knowing total tight is impossible. And it is in democratic order for the Government to use its legal powers to deport illegals.
But it is not in democratic order for politicians to spread falsehoods about the the economic "burden" of immigrants, legal and illegal, to use clubs of fear to drive out immigrants, or to saddle the country with immigrant-hunting computer banks and work licenses that will cut away at every American's liberty.
Immigration, legal and illegal figured in, adds up to an economic boon to America. The estimate of the Urban Institute in Washington is that they contribute $25 to $30 billion more money in taxes and jobs than social benefits paid out.
Benefits. On the West Coast, there is lots of political noise about removing them from illegals, to drive them out. Mean-spirited referendum items may pass but they will bring little economic benefit. The truth is that the dreaded benefit-swilling illegals now receive little more than the schooling for children upheld by the Supreme Court and emergency medical help.
And now, an immigration "reform" commission appointed by the Clinton Administration calls for a nationwide computer bank that would grant or withhold the permission to work. Every job applicant, immigrant, naturalized or native-born, would have to be computer-cleared as a legal resident of the U.S. fit for a work license.
Lovely. Tomorrow, the Government could ask the computer to hunt down every person who broke a law, had a bad credit rating or ever had a contagious disease to see whether he should be permitted to work. Will Americans really stand for this?
While we think it over, the "anti-illegals" crowd is moving against its next target: immigration itself, the concept of America as a haven for refugees and a place of economic hope for some of those who stupidly failed to be born in America.
The anti's are so strong that many Republican and Democratic politicians who are opposed to them just keep quiet. As antidote, I give you two quotations.
One is from Mario Cuomo, Governor of New York. "I love immigrants," he said. "Legal, illegal -- they are not to be despised."
And this is from New York City's Mayor, Rudolph Giuliani.
"If you come here and you work hard and you happen to be in an undocumented status, you are one of the people who we want in this city. You are somebody that we want to protect and we want you to get out from under what is often the life of being like a fugitive, which is really unfair."
One of them is a Democrat and the other Republican. But when it comes to understanding America's roots and the dangers to them, you can't tell these fellows apart -- my happy thought for the day.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Neighborhood Grocers, Not Big National Chains, Need Support

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re your Sept. 22 article and Sept. 24 editorial about an effort to build a Pathmark supermarket in East Harlem: A subsidized superstore in East Harlem is neither needed nor wanted by residents and merchants. There are more than 15 supermarkets in this low-income community. They are not "overpriced" or "understocked" bodegas. They occupy the same buildings that were abandoned by the chains that fled with the urban disorders of the 1960's. 
 When the chains abandoned neighborhoods like Harlem, East Harlem, Jamaica and the South Bronx a retail desert was created. Offices closed, bank branches moved elsewhere. The only retailers willing to come into these neglected areas were Dominican supermarket owners and Korean greengrocers.
You repeat the canard that food prices are confiscatory at neighbor
hood markets. The New York City Human Resources Administration publishes a "Diets and Dollars" newsletter that surveys grocery prices in eight city neighborhoods. These surveys demonstrate that independent neighborhood supermarkets compete with (and undersell) the supermarket chains.
The New York Economic Development Corporation found in a marketing study commissioned early in the Pathmark project that 89 percent of community residents surveyed were satisfied with their supermarkets.
This project is disgraceful. Charitable money and municipal tax abatements are being used to subsidize an $8 billion corporation.
There are 1,000 independent supermarkets in New York City, whose owners have invested in our poorest neighborhoods. City officials need to recognize and encourage this kind of organic growth. We should not subsidize out-of-towners to do what local retailers can do very well themselves.
 
ALFREDO RODRIGUEZ
RICHARD LIPSKY
New York, Sept. 29, 1994
 
The writers are, respectively, president and executive director of Neighborhood Small Business Association.

HEADLINE: Long-Term Rates Highest in 2 Years

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
Long-term interest rates rose yesterday to their highest levels in more than two years as fresh evidence of economic strength and rising inflation reverberated through the bond market.
By late in the day, the price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 13/32 , to 95, while its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, rose to 7.85 percent, from 7.81 percent on Friday. It is the highest yield on a 30-year bond since June 1992, when yields were at 7.87 percent. 
 Traders of short-term Treasury securities, betting that the recent spate of strong economic reports will force the Federal Reserve Board to increase the overnight Federal funds rate again soon, also responded by pushing up short-term rates. Rates on new three-month and six-month Treasury bills auctioned yesterday rose to their highest levels in three years.
The rise in rates, which traders said came on low volume, was attributed to the results of a monthly survey on the nation's purchasing managers.
For credit market participants, who dote on data that show the economy is growing at a moderate, noninflationary pace, the numbers in September's survey of the nation's purchasing managers did not make for reassuring reading.
The survey, which is issued the first business day of each month, showed not only that the manufacturing sector was booming last month, but also that factory costs, reflected in the prices purchasing managers paid for their goods, rose to their highest level in six years during September.
"The manufacturing sector is rolling along at a pretty good clip, and is not slowing down to a sustainable rate," despite the efforts of the Federal Reserve so far this year, said Steven A. Wood, director of financial markets research at BA Securities Inc.
Equally sobering, analysts and economists said, was a rise in the employment component of the survey to its highest level since December 1988.
"The employment component left people feeling pretty confident that we are going to get a pretty good increase" when the Labor Department issues its September employment report on Friday, said Dana Johnson, head of capital markets research at First Chicago Capital Markets.
Most Wall Street economists are forecasting that the report will show that payroll employment increased by 250,000 to 275,000 last month.
With the employment report ahead, a number of market participants said results of the purchasing managers' survey convinced them that the Fed would move soon to lift rates. But they said they were equally convinced that the next Fed move would not be the last.
"Securities like two-year and five-year notes are priced to reflect as much as another half-a-point increase in the funds rate," said Dan Callahan, a managing director in charge of Government securities trading at Paine Webber. "But the Fed is going to have to shift from a neutral policy stance to a restrictive one to slow the economy down, and 50 basis points is only the first leg on the way to a restrictive monetary policy." A basis point is one-hundredth of 1 percent.
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 7 1/4 percent 10-year notes were offered at a price of 979/32 late yesterday, down 10/32 , to yield 7.64 percent.
The 7 1/8 percent five-year notes were offered at 99 1/8, down 9/32 , to yield 7.33 percent. And the 6 1/2 percent two-year notes were offered at 9923/32 , down 1/8 of a point, to yield 6.65 percent.
At the Treasury's weekly bill auction, the new three-month bills were sold at an average discount rate of 4.92 percent, up from last week's average of 4.79 percent. It is the bills' highest rate since Oct. 28, 1991, when the average was 4.99 percent. Six-month bills were sold at an average discount rate of 5.38 percent, up from 5.22 percent last week. It is the bills' highest rate since Sept. 3, 1991, when the average was 5.39 percent.
The selloff in the Treasury securities market spilled over into the secondary markets for corporate and tax-exempt municipal bonds.
Traders said prices of some municipal issues were off as much as a quarter to a half point. Actively traded corporate issues fell by a similar amount, traders said.

HEADLINE: Confidence In South Africa Debt

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
South Africa won a long-sought prize from Wall Street yesterday: an investment-grade rating from a major credit-rating agency that is certain to make it less costly for the country to borrow money to build roads, provide electricity and create jobs for millions of poor black citizens.
Moody's Investor's Service, one of the two major firms that judge the ability of corporations and governments to pay back what they owe, awarded South Africa a rating just above subinvestment, or junk bond, status. 
 But the second major rating agency, Standard & Poor's, gave South Africa a rating just below investment grade, in part because the agency said it wanted more time to evaluate the changes in South Africa. Still, the firm indicated that the rating could be raised to investment grade in the next few years.
The rating actions come as President Nelson Mandela of South Africa is in the United States on a visit aimed in part at encouraging investment in his country. Mr. Mandela took office in May, decisively ending the era of apartheid.
Even though South Africa got a split rating from the two agencies, that leaves it in a position comparable to that of several countries that have been struggling politically and economically. Mexico, for example, has a split rating, even after its substantial efforts to open markets.
Under the previous all-white Government, South Africa's debt was unrated, and for years the nation was unable to borrow money at interest rates it could afford. Many international investors, like pension funds and mutual funds, will not buy securities of companies or governments that do not have investment-grade ratings.
Now, South Africa can draw on the vast international capital markets by issuing bonds and other debt, enabling it to borrow more money for longer periods of time than it could get in loans from banks.
South Africa has not put a price tag on its program of reconstruction and development, but during the next decade, the cost may total billions of dollars, analysts say.
Split ratings by Moody's and Standard & Poor's are not unusual. Of 43 countries rated by both firms, 20 have split ratings, including Sweden and New Zealand.
But the split rating will have market consequences by tempting some potential bond buyers to use the lower rating to demand higher interest rates when South Africa issues debt. In the end, the markets will determine which agency was right.
A smaller rating firm, IBCA of London, gave a subinvestment grade rating to South Africa less than two weeks ago. The firm, which did not have access to South African officials or special Government data, cited the nation's challenge of managing "high black expectations of improving living standards even though its own budget deficit is too high."
Moody's gave South Africa its minimum investment-grade rating of Baa3 yesterday, while Standard & Poor's assigned a rating of BB, two notches below investment grade. S.& P.'s rating, however, was accompanied by the notation "with a positive outlook," meaning the rating could be raised in one to three years.
No South African corporation or governmental unit can claim a higher rating than what the firms have assigned to the country.
The ratings should help the nation financially, but South Africa will still have to pay millions of dollars more in interest charges than more creditworthy issuers do. The United States, for example, with the top AAA rating, might pay an interest rate of 7.3 percent for a five-year Treasury note, while South Africa might have to pay 8.8 percent, based on the Moody's rating. Under the S.& P. rating, South Africa might have to pay 9.3 percent or more. Market conditions could force even higher charges.
In South Africa, Chris Liebenberg, the Minister of Finance, said the Government was pleased with what happened. He said both ratings firms had shown confidence in "the coherence of the economic policies and political stability brought to the country by the new Government of national unity."
The Moody's Baa3 rating puts South Africa on a par with Indonesia and Greece and above Hungary, but below Chile. On the S.& P. scale, only South Africa has a BB, which sets it above Argentina and the Philippines but below Uruguay and Mexico.
S.& P.'s "positive outlook" is a hard-won notation for a country. In July 1992, Mexico, one of the fastest-growing countries in Latin America and one praised by Western investors for its market orientation, received a BB+ "with a stable outlook," meaning that S.& P. did not plan to change the rating anytime soon. It was only in November 1993 that Mexico got a "positive outlook," offering the prospect of an eventual change in rating.
For Goldman, Sachs & Company, South Africa's investment adviser, yesterday's ratings bring to a close an extensive process that began in July and involved the preparation of 150 pages of data on economic, political and social trends in the country. Officials of Moody's and S.& P. visited South Africa for a week on separate trips, talking to 25 to 30 prominent South Africans both inside and outside the Government.
Guido E. Cipriani, the senior analyst for S.& P. overseeing the South Africa review, described the process as thorough and hardheaded. "There are no right answers for the questions we ask a country," Mr. Cipriani said. "We essentially want to know how a government would manage in a crisis. O.K., how would you handle an oil shock? What happens if Mandela dies? We want to hear the cogency of their analysis. Whether we buy it or not is another matter."
Richard B. Davis, a former head of corporate ratings at Moody's from 1973 to 1979, helped lead a Goldman, Sachs team of bankers that prepared South African officials for their presentations to the agencies. Mr. Davis, who helped pioneer the rating of "sovereigns," or countries, at Moody's, said the task was aided by the careful record-keeping of officials in South Africa.
Carlos Cordeiro, a Goldman, Sachs partner in London with responsibility for Europe and Africa, described the work as "exhilarating" and inspiring. "A country that did not exist six months ago in its present form," he said, "has won an investment-grade rating only four months into a new administration."

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Mandela Seeks Investors
 Nelson Mandela urged United States investors last night to accelerate their participation in South Africa, saying that a partnership with foreign investors would play a "central and valuable" role in the economic development of his country.
In a speech to the National Foreign Trade Council, a nonprofit organization that promotes international trade and investment by American companies, at the Waldorf Astoria Hotel in Manhattan, Mr. Mandela, the President of South Africa, said it had been three years since investors were encouraged to prepare to enter the democratic South Africa.
"The conditions are now ripe for practical work to start," he said. "We do appreciate that many companies have already taken major steps in this direction, and we urge that this should be accelerated.
"This is not to say that foreign investments on their own will solve our economic problems," he added. "They will, however, play a central and valuable role in our economic development."
Mr. Mandela said the country was not engaging in "special pleading. That is why I speak of a partnership, to signify a relationship of mutual benefit."
Mr. Mandela said he would work to create a stable and predictable policy and regulatory framework that promoted investment, reduced protectionism, and increased investment opportunities for all.

HEADLINE: A G.M. Test of Productivity: Making Parts 24 Hours a Day

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PARIS, Oct. 3

 BODY:
Two General Motors components plants in the Midwest are operating round the clock seven days a week as part of a broad effort to wring greater productivity from the company's high-cost workers, a G.M. executive said today.
The highly unusual pace of production, a one-year experiment, is proving efficient, the executive said, and G.M. may put other plants on similar schedules as it hunts for ways to increase capacity on the cheap. 
 "We're heading in that direction," said J. T. Battenberg 3d, president of G.M.'s parts-making subsidiary, who was here to discuss his worldwide operations at the Paris Auto Show. "We're expecting our facilities to work harder than they ever have before."
Just Friday, G.M. agreed to hire more than 500 workers represented by the United Automobile Workers union at a plant complex in Flint, Mich. But today Mr. Battenberg had harsh words for the union's pay scale, saying his operations had hired no workers represented by the U.A.W. for at least six years, and had no plans to hire any.
"We have not hired U.A.W.," he said. "It just isn't economically feasible." Workers at the two Midwestern plants, operated by G.M.'s Packard Electric division, are represented by the International Union of Electric Workers, which has been more willing to meet G.M.'s wage and scheduling demands.
At the two plants in Warren, Ohio, about 600 people have been working in four crews, putting in 12-hour shifts for three days in a row with three days off. The plants make plastic moldings and copper cable for wiring harnesses. The work schedule has been in place for about nine months.
Mr. Battenberg said his operations had been driving down their labor costs by shifting U.A.W. workers into capital-intensive factories while hiring non-U.A.W. workers for labor-intensive work. In addition, establishing more flexible work arrangements in some U.A.W. plants, like multi-crew operations that keep production going through the weekend, could make them competitive even at high wages, he said.
Mr. Battenberg said that about 38 percent of the parts-making subsidiary's 178,000 hourly workers worldwide were paid top U.A.W.-level wages of about $44 an hour, including benefits. Several years ago, he said, up to 70 percent were. The average wage in the subsidiary, he said, is about $24.50 an hour. But Mr. Battenberg said he was now hiring workers for a new wiring and electronics plant in Alabama at only $8.50 an hour, including benefits.
The lower wages reflect the success that the subsidiary, known as the Automotive Components Group, has had bargaining contracts with unions that represent rubber and electrical workers, rather than with the U.A.W. The trend presents a dilemma for U.A.W. leaders, who would like to shore up their membership roles but would alienate many members if they agreed to reduced wage scales.
Mr. Battenberg also said the components group's business with companies besides G.M. was growing more than 10 percent a year and was on track to reach 30 percent of total sales by 1996. The group had $25.1 billion in revenue in 1993, 25 percent of which came from outside G.M.
The parts-making operations have been trying to increase their outside business to 50 percent by 2002, to insure that they are competitive in costs and technology with other suppliers.
Mr. Battenberg said he had sold $3 billion worth of uncompetitive businesses since 1992, and was negotiating to sell one more operation, Magnequench, which makes magnets. Mr. Battenberg said that his target was to sell $3.5 billion worth of businesses, but that he might sell more.

HEADLINE: Stocks Mostly Lower, but Dow Gains 3.70

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Stocks were mostly lower yesterday after a report by the nation's purchasing managers showed that manufacturing activity in September was stronger than expected. Blue chips showed a gain, but the broader market declined.
The purchasers' report bolstered expectations that the Federal Reserve would act soon to raise interest rates for the sixth time this year to cool inflation. 
 "We've had the view the economy is too strong for the Fed, and this report confirms that view," said Jeffrey Applegate, chief investment strategist at CS First Boston.
Todd Clark, senior director in equity trading at Mabon Securities, said, "We're getting right back to the earnings-versus-rates argument." Stocks didn't fall more because the strength in factory output bodes well for manufacturers' earnings, he said.
That expectation helped the Dow Jones industrial average eke out a gain of 3.70 to close at 3,846.89, after falling as much as 17.16 earlier in the day. Alcoa and Goodyear led the advance. Alcoa gained 1 1/8, to 85 7/8, and Goodyear rose 1 1/8, to 34 1/2.
The National Association of Purchasing Management reported yesterday that its manufacturing index, a barometer of activity in the nation's factories, climbed to 58.2 in September from 56.2 in August. Any reading above 50 indicates expansion in manufacturing.
"This report would be good for names like Alcoa and Goodyear," Mr. Clark of Mabon Securities said. "With the N.A.P.M. index as high as it is, people are thinking the deeper cyclical companies are going to report impressive earnings."
The Standard & Poor's 500 Index fell 0.97 to 461.74. The index gained as much as 0.60 initially, then fell as much as 2.38 after the purchasers' report. The American Stock Exchange Market Value Index fell 0.35, to 458.46. The Nasdaq Composite Index, led by Intel, declined 3.41, to 760.88.
Semiconductors paced today's retreat after a profit warning from Advanced Micro Devices Inc. The stock slid 3 1/4, to 26 1/2, in active trading after the company told analysts that microprocessor price cuts could hurt fourth-quarter earnings. Intel dropped 1 1/4, to 60 1/4; Micron Technology slumped 2 1/8, to 32 3/8, and Texas Instruments Inc. fell 2 1/2, to 65 1/2.
Declining stocks on the New York Stock Exchange totaled 1,351 against 841 gainers. Trading was moderate, with about 278.4 million shares changing hands on the Big Board.
Stock investors may grow more concerned if the strength of the purchasing managers' index, one of several economic reports this week, is echoed by the report scheduled for Friday on September employment. The report is expected by many economists to show that the economy added 250,000 jobs last month, up from 179,000 in August.
Care Network rocketed 13 1/8, to 24, after Humana offered to acquire the company for $123 million, or $25.25 a share.
Healthsource jumped 1 1/2, to 37. The health maintenance organization was rated intermediate-term "above average" and long-term "buy" in new coverage by an analyst at Merrill Lynch, Lucy Olwell.
Oxford Health Plans Inc. rose 1 1/2, to 78 1/2. New York State insurance regulators granted the company's requested 8 percent average rate increase on some contracts.
Purolator Products soared 6 5/8, to 24 5/8. Mark IV Industries, which owns 4.7 percent of the automotive-filter maker, agreed to buy the rest for $25 a share, or $264 million.
Brilliance China Automotive Holdings slumped 3, to 13. The mini-bus maker said first-half profit fell to 22 cents a share from 50 cents a year ago.
Information America vaulted 1 7/8, to 5 3/4. The information services company received a $6-a-share takeover offer from West Publishing.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Lifted by Trade Pact, But Bond Selloff Curbs Rally

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar ended with modest gains against most other leading currencies yesterday as a rally from a trade agreement between the United States and Japan was blunted by a selloff in the American bond market.
The currency market cheered the trade accord between the United States and Japan, which was announced on Saturday. In trading in Asia, the dollar jumped nearly a full yen. In late New York trading, the dollar settled at 99.57 yen, up from 99.15 yen on Friday. 
 While the compromise trade deal is not expected to reduce significantly the trade imbalance between the two countries, a key factor behind the dollar's steady decline, it sets the stage for more talks and removed the immediate threat of United States sanctions against Japan.
But the dollar's advance stalled in early trading in the United States after Treasury bond prices dropped following a National Association of Purchasing Management report indicating a surge in American manufacturing last month and higher inflation at the producer level.
"The inflationary signals irked the bond market," said Stephen Flanagan, a Paine Webber vice president. "The dollar is going to have a tough time rallying no matter what the news is when bond prices are off."
Currency dealers have been following American asset markets to gauge demand from foreign investors for dollars.
Also blunting the dollar's advance beyond the key 100-yen level, market participants said, was heavy selling by Japanese manufacturers, which hold abundant stocks of the dollar generated by their exports.
"They don't care about what's going on in the trade talks," said Koichi Takenaka, a vice president at the Industrial Bank of Japan in New York, adding that these companies have fixed their internal budgets at 100 yen to the dollar. "They think the dollar still faces risks to the downside."
Lisa Finstrom, a currency analyst for Smith Barney, said that many American and European traders had concluded by late last week that there would be a trade agreement and adjusted their positions accordingly.
In other currency trading in New York yesterday, the dollar rose to 1.5543 German marks, from 1.5518 marks on Friday, and rose to 1.2930 Swiss francs, from 1.2880 francs on Friday. The British pound was quoted at $1.5788, up from $1.5765 on Friday.

HEADLINE: Executive Changes

HEADLINE: Smaller Asian Markets Did Well in 3d Quarter

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON 

 BODY:
After favoring Japanese stocks early in the year, international investors moved toward other Asian markets in the third quarter. Markets were tepid in Europe, but strong in Latin America.
"It's sort of a reversal of what happened in the first quarter," said Steven Nagourney, chief global strategist at Lehman Brothers. "We're moving into a new paradigm here." 
 Investors sent Japanese stocks down 5.53 percent, the worst performance on any major market in the quarter. Concern about the yen, together with unusually high stock prices -- the average price-to-earnings ratio hovered between 70 and 80 times earnings -- contributed to the decline, Mr. Nagourney said.
Smaller markets in Asia picked up the slack. Three of them were among the world's five best performers: Malaysian stocks rose 18.49 percent, leading all major markets; Hong Kong stocks increased 9.98 percent, and shares in Singapore were up 9.74 percent.
"Money in Asia is staying there," Mr. Nagourney said. "You're just getting a shift into emerging markets."
Yet other analysts said that Japan's slip might have been inevitable after two strong quarters. The third-quarter decline in Japanese stocks followed a 28 percent rise in the first half of the year when measured in dollar terms, reflecting both stock prices and the increase in the exchange value of the yen.
William Wendler, a vice president at Rowe Price Fleming International, a unit of T. Rowe Price managing international funds, said his company remained bullish on Japan, expecting economic and political stability to spur a new rise in stocks in coming quarters.
"The market is still expensive," Mr. Wendler acknowledged. "But we definitely see the economy in recovery. You see it in private construction, car sales and even in retail sales."
By contrast, European markets were slack in the third quarter, and look as if they may remain so in the last three months of 1994. With the exception of Finland, a tiny market that rose more than 14 percent, most European markets grew marginally.
German stocks dropped 1.23 percent, French issues lost 0.61 percent, and British equities rose 3.28 percent.
"The equity market at the moment looks sort of O.K.," said Tim Brown, British strategist at UBS Phillips & Drew International in London, echoing the ho-hum attitude shared by many analysts. "I don't expect it to look significantly different a year from now."
A brighter picture has emerged in Latin America, where stocks grew strongly. Mexican stocks jumped 18.48 percent.
Geoffrey Dennis, emerging-markets research chief at Bear, Stearns & Company, said that the upswing was built on market gains in the United States, and on favorable economic and political news in much of the region.
"Once investors feel comfortable about the U.S., they tend to quickly look overseas for a growth kicker," Mr. Dennis said. "Forgetting very quickly, of course, what happened earlier this year."
When concern about stocks in the United States led to some drops in February and March, Mr. Dennis recalled, emerging markets fell sharply.
He expressed concern over the assassination in Mexico last Wednesday of Jose Francisco Ruiz Massieu, secretary general of the governing Institutional Revolutionary Party, the second prominent victim of political assassination there this year. But he thought that Mexico's political situation was probably stable enough to support continued market gains in the coming year.
Mexican stocks rose most sharply in August, Mr. Dennis said, after the nation's second-quarter growth was reported at 3.8 percent, well above the expectations of local and international analysts.
"We've lightened up on our forecast in Mexico," said Mr. Dennis, who now predicts a 10 percent gain in stocks there by the end of the year. His favorite Latin American markets are those of Brazil, Chile, Argentina and Mexico, in that order.

HEADLINE: Volvo, on a Rebound, Faces a Survival Test

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: GOTEBORG, Sweden

 BODY:
Given their reputation for durability, the boxy station wagons and sedans rolling off the Volvo Group's production lines here these days may well be shuttling suburban families and other loyal buyers reliably around for many years, even decades to come.
The question now is whether Volvo itself can last as long. 
 Despite a recent surge in sales and profits driven by economic recovery in its three largest markets -- the United States, Britain and its home base of Sweden -- Volvo is facing the stiffest test yet of its ability to survive as an independent company.
As one of the smallest of the major car manufacturers, and as one of the few not to have been snapped up by another auto maker in the frenzy of consolidation that has swept the European industry in recent years, Volvo increasingly risks being run down by giant competitors in Europe, the United States and Asia.
Still, Volvo seems determined to go it alone. Late last year, the company aborted a planned merger of its car and truck operations with Renault S.A. of France, complaining that Volvo's financial and strategic interests would not be well served by the deal. Although it continues to work with the Mitsubishi Motors Corporation of Japan in developing a small car, Volvo is betting that it can muster on its own the efficiency and financial strength it will need to control its destiny.
To help it do so, a new management team under Soren Gyll, who took over as chief executive after leading a successful board-room revolt against the Renault deal, has abandoned the elaborate diversification strategy championed by his predecessor, Pehr Gyllenhammar, and is paring the company back to almost nothing but its car and truck operations.
By selling Volvo's extensive interests in pharmaceuticals, food and other industries, whose proceeds could total $5 billion over three or four years, Mr. Gyll plans to reduce debt and finance development of new vehicles. At the same time, he is pushing to cut costs further, speed up product development and protect the brand's image as a paragon of safety and reliability.
"A lot of people have questioned our ability to survive," Mr. Gyll said. "So people are working very hard. It's the Volvo spirit. We are small but we will show everyone that we are good."
Volvo, however, is far from assured of making it on its own. It sells only two lines of cars worldwide, the big, sturdy 900 series and the slightly sportier 850, plus a line of smaller cars, the 400 series, that is not sold in the United States.
Because Volvo sells relatively few cars -- 311,800 last year, or less than 1 percent of the world market -- it can afford to develop new cars only at widely spaced intervals, meaning that each model must not only be successful, but also be successful for years longer than competing models. Its last entirely new model, the 850, was introduced in 1991.
Despite big improvements, Volvo remains saddled with high costs. It takes about 47 hours of labor to produce a car here, down from around 70 hours in the late 1980's but still behind the 20 hours or so needed by Japanese auto makers. Volvo also produces cars in Ghent, Belgium, where productivity is higher, and in Born, the Netherlands, the site of its small-car venture.
Moreover, Volvo's leadership in automotive safety, reliability and environmental friendliness -- the attributes that have made Volvo so strong in the affluent family market -- is under attack from a wide range of rival auto makers that can make valid claims to improved safety and durability.
While Volvo can make it on its own for the medium term, said John Lindquist, a senior vice president at the Boston Consulting Group in London, "there is an issue for the longer term."
"If they cannot maintain their differentiation in the marketplace, if they cannot maintain cost competitiveness and get much better at development, then they'll be forced into joining up with someone," he said. "If they can do all those things and make careful alliances with producers for key components, then they can probably get by. But it's a tall order."
Volvo executives acknowledged that they could not afford any missteps, especially when it came to developing new cars. The expensive process typically runs into the billions of dollars.
"We are small," Mr. Gyll said. "Each product has to be good. The pressure on the organization is tremendous."
Despite the failed merger with Renault, Volvo is pressing ahead not only with the small-car project with Mitsubishi but also with plans to add to its high-end product lineup, he said. The new small car will replace Volvo's current 400 series.
Although he declined to provide any details about the higher-end cars, Mr. Gyll said Volvo wanted to expand its reach beyond what he called the family market, which generally means buyers between the ages of 35 and 55, and into cars that would appeal to older drivers.
"We want to be stronger in the pre-family and post-family markets," he said.
In the long run, Mr. Gyll said, Volvo cannot rule out alliances or joint ventures with other auto makers and component suppliers, or even an outright merger. But he said he had no doubts about the ability of the company to thrive on its own at least through the end of the decade.
For the first six months of this year, Volvo sold 189,000 cars, 20 percent more than in the corresponding period last year, and its market share increased in most countries. Volvo sold 45,213 cars in the United States in the first six months, or 19.1 percent more than in the corresponding period in 1993.
Its truck business has also been strong, with a new model, the FH series, helping to push deliveries up 37 percent in the first half of the year, to 32,400.
Operating profits for the car group were 1.475 billion Swedish kronor, or about $197 million, in the first half of the year, compared with a loss of 70 million kronor, or $9.4 million, in the period a year earlier. The truck group earned $237 million in the first half, up from $8.2 million.
Helped by divestitures that yielded gains of $550 million in the first half, Volvo reduced its debt by the end of June to about $120 million, from $1.9 billion at the end of 1993.
Volvo is also benefiting from the weakness of the Swedish currency, analysts said. The weak krona makes Volvo's exports less expensive in terms of other currencies and makes earnings in dollars and other foreign currencies worth more when translated back to kronor.
Over the last several years, Volvo has closed two of its three car production plants in Sweden, consolidating its Swedish production in Goteborg. Employment in the car division, which peaked in 1989 at 34,607, has fallen by 22.6 percent, to 26,803.
The company is taking steps to protect itself from competition. This year, for example, it is pioneering an advance in safety with the introduction of side air bags in the front seats of the 850.
It is also seeking growth by pushing into new markets, particularly in Asia.
"We're building on our strengths in the niches where we are strong," Mr. Gyll said.
To a large degree, though, Volvo's prospects will ride on the company's success in slogging through the process of cutting costs and improving efficiency. Volvo's engineers, like those at nearly every other auto maker, are being forced to keep the cost of producing their designs uppermost in their calculations. Increasingly, they are also being asked to save money by using the same components in different models as often as possible.
On the production line, most of the progress to date has come from fairly predictable steps. Volvo has automated the process of bolting together the chassis and the body of its cars. Employees working on a car's underside have been given easier access by turning the chassis on its side during one stage of assembly.
Workers have also been given more authority to stop the production line to rectify problems, saving the time and expense of having a separate team go back later to deal with errors and quality problems. Quality-control teams spot-check the assembly line, and production teams can earn bonuses by avoiding errors.
A big portion of the company's productivity problems over the years have been linked to high rates of worker absenteeism, a chronic problem throughout Sweden. Absenteeism is now running at less than 5 percent a day here, down from 15 percent a few years ago, largely because of new Swedish Government policies, including a reduction in sick-pay benefits.
"We're looking at a whole new degree of competition, in Europe in particular, in terms of trying to match Japanese efficiency," said Nigel Griffiths, an auto industry analyst at DRI/McGraw-Hill in London. "For Volvo, a lot of their future will come down to their own resilience."

HEADLINE: Workers Scarce but So Are Raises

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
Pressure is building on Corporate America to bid up wages to attract machinists, computer specialists and other skilled workers increasingly in short supply. But companies are resisting the pressure with numerous tactics, from turning away business to hiring the unskilled at low wages and then training them.
No one knows how long this effort can keep hourly wages from rising faster than inflation for millions of production workers, especially if the economy continues to grow at a brisk pace. Already wages are rising in a few cities, most spectacularly in Phoenix. But mostly, executives say, companies are holding the line -- an assertion that is backed up by some Labor Department data and Federal Reserve surveys. 
 "There is a certain amount of stubborness, a determination not to pay more," said Tucker Hart Adams, chief economist of Colorado National Bank, who surveyed 60 companies in Denver, where labor shortages have appeared but not wage increases. The resistance, she said, comes in part because employers say they cannot raise prices to cover higher wage costs. "I tell them, 'At some wage, people will answer their help-wanted ads.' And they say they can't go up more than 25 cents an hour or their profits will disappear."
Rather than bid for people already skilled, companies are increasingly training unskilled lower-wage workers, interviews with executives suggest. This may mean that a company's work force is less productive for a while, but the Clinton Administration hails the practice as a way to reopen good jobs to the unskilled.
In another tactic, many companies that once recruited only locally now cast their nets across the nation. Some push existing employees to work more hours. Some also agree among themselves not to hire away one another's skilled people.
And when fat raises are given to keep valued workers, the extra cost is increasingly offset by denying raises to others, according to a survey of big corporations by Towers Perrin, a consulting firm.
In Rochester, Jasco Tools Inc. embraces several of the tactics. Jasco is not planning any increase for the time being in the $10-to-$15-an-hour base pay that most of its 250 machinists receive. Jasco, in fact, needs 20 more machinists to keep up with orders for the auto and aircraft parts, cutting tools and other metal products that the company makes, Gary Rogers, the president, said.
"If you bid for machinists, then your base wage for everyone has to go up," Mr. Rogers said. "And even though our products are in demand now, the market is very competitive and you cannot cover the rising wage cost with higher prices."
So Mr. Rogers is turning away business. But he has hired a full-time instructor to recruit and train high school graduates and people laid off at nearby Eastman Kodak and Xerox plants to be Jasco's new machinists. Fifteen trainees are now on board, earning $5 to $7 an hour.
"It takes three weeks to a year to train them, depending on their level of experience and the machining tasks that we will require of them," Mr. Rogers said. Once trained, their wages rise as they acquire skills. But it will take four years for the most qualified to reach $10 an hour.
"Before Kodak and Xerox had trouble, these giants scooped up people, paying them more and setting the tone for wages," Mr. Rogers said. "That has stopped, of course."
Shawn McDonald, now 19, said he did not even consider seeking a job at Kodak or Xerox when he graduated from high school 18 months ago and joined Jasco as a trainee at $5.50 an hour. He could have made more at those companies, he says.
"I just knew that you learn more at the smaller shops with their one-on-one training," Mr. McDonald said. He is now an apprentice earning $6.75 an hour. And he is already functioning as a novice machinist.
Chase Manhattan Bank in New York is similarly reluctant to bid up wages to hire technicians and programmers who are experts in the networks of desktop computers that are now so popular. Such people are in short supply in many cities. But Chase has a surplus of programmers for big mainframe computers, which have been phased out at the bank, and these extra programmers are being retrained.
"We would have to pay 30 percent more in wages to hire a qualified programmer for desktop computers," Craig Goldman, a Chase senior vice president, said.
But for Mr. Rogers at Jasco, training the inexperienced is a successful tactic only if competitors do not hire away his experienced machinists -- and with them orders that might otherwise have gone to Jasco. As president of the Rochester Tooling and Machining Association, he has helped to engineer an informal agreement among members to provide employee training instead.
Jasco's workers are not unionized. But union contracts sometimes prevent wage bidding. That is the case at General Motors, which has agreed to hire or call back assembly workers in Flint, Mich., at wages established under an existing contract. It is also true among union carpenters in Washington, D.C., where construction is booming.
They are members of the United Brotherhood of Carpenters and Joiners, which limits the wage they can demand to the $17.09 an hour specified in the current contract. Membership in the Washington area had declined since 1990, mostly because there was not enough work, until a recent step-up in Government projects, said Edward E. Shaw, secretary-treasurer of the union's district council for Washington.
The union is trying to rebuild its ranks, and it has signed up 100 immigrants from Mexico, who in hard times had taken jobs from union members by working for less money. They are in enough demand today to receive the union wage.
Still, the union is acting mostly as a brake on wages, helping in effect to contain the pressure for higher wages, Mr. Shaw said. Aside from the recruiting of immigrants, carpenters are being brought in temporarily from Baltimore, where the demand for them is not as great. "We have been able to get just enough people to keep up with the demand without forcing contractors to bid for carpenters," Mr. Shaw said. "We feel we have an obligation to help the contractors, so they will stick with us in bad times."
The tightest labor markets are mostly west of the Mississippi and include Austin, Tex.; Albuquerque, N.M.; Denver; Des Moines; Minneapolis, Phoenix, and Sioux Falls, S.D. In those cities, unemployment rates are less than 4.5 percent, well below the national average of 6.1 percent. And expanding a staff without bidding up wages to lure scarce workers is not always easy.
The Principal Financial Group, a financial services company based in Des Moines, is adding 1,200 people this year to the 8,500 it already employs in Iowa -- without raising wages. The company cannot raise wages without pushing up the entire pay scale, Max Johnson, vice president for human resources, said.
The biggest problem for Principal, he said, has been the recruiting of 150 new college graduates in computer science at a $30,000 starting salary; they can get $36,000 in Chicago, 400 miles away.
Principal has expanded its recruiting to both coasts, particularly aiming at schools with big minority populations. "We are doing this for affirmative-action purposes," Mr. Johnson said. "But we also find that we can recruit them at our wages."
In Phoenix, by comparison, the bidding for construction workers is spectacular. The Intel Corporation and Motorola Inc., among others, are building or expanding factories, and thousands of new homes are going up to accommodate the new arrivals. Plumbers who earned $10 an hour in January get $13 or $14 now, and when one of the 65 plumbers employed at the Gilbert Plumbing Company fails to show up on a job, Ward Gilbert, the vice president, knows right away what happened.
"They are getting calls at home at night from other contractors, and some come in to us and say, 'We got this offer, will you match it?' " he said. "Or they disappear and we find them after a few days and offer to match the increase. Usually it is 50 cents an hour, and we tell them to be quiet about the raise, but it filters out and then we have to raise others."
Trying to avoid this pressure, Mr. Gilbert has 12 people in training at $6 an hour. He is hoping that in six months they will have learned enough to do some of the tasks on a job. Meanwhile, he has given notice of a 6 percent price increase. New-home prices have risen 7 percent this year, according to the Greater Phoenix Economic Council.
That is the sort of inflation connected to rising wages that frightens the bond market and encourages the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates. Some economists and corporate executives argue that the fear is unwarranted, that Phoenix is the exception and that corporate resistance to wage increases is much greater than it was 15 years ago.
Average hourly wages for non-supervisory workers, adjusted for inflation, did spiral upward in the late 1970's as the unemployment rate declined, reaching a low of less than 6 percent. But the next time unemployment got that low, in the late 1980's, there was no such response. Now unemployment is roughly where it was in the late 1980's, and hourly wages adjusted for inflation have not yet popped up.

HEADLINE: Let's Also Think of Biotechnology Safety

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "Biodiversity Pact on the Ropes" (editorial, Sept. 26): More than just "Republican opposition and Democratic lethargy" are combining to put the Convention on Biological Diversity on the ropes. 
 The international agreement is about the protection and maintenance of biological diversity. Other concerns, while important, should be subordinate. Biosafety should not be judged in terms of free flows of biotechnology exports, but rather of effective maintenance of diversity.
Experts agree that there is a wide range of risks associated with genetically engineered organisms. Recently, Prof. Elaine Ingham of Oregon State University and Michael Holmes, a doctoral student there, presented findings of one risk at the annual meeting of the Ecological Society of America.
In testing a bacterium genetically engineered to produce ethanol, they found an unpredicted side effect: the bacterium cut the amount of beneficial mycorrhizal fungi in the soil by more than half. Given the fungi's critical role in the uptake of plant nutrients, Professor Ingham noted:
"If the organism survived readily and spread widely, very likely we would be unable to grow crops without a control mechanism for this organism."
No one denies that biosafety risks are real. These risks, the economically inconvenient byproducts of our scientific creativity, need to be carefully assessed and addressed. Neither our own United States regulatory system nor that of the rest of the world appears to be doing an adequate job. You reported Sept. 20 that gene transplants in salmon have resulted in transgenic fish that grow at much faster rates and may achieve huge changes in body size.
You did not report, however, that if such fish were to escape, they might displace native salmon, with irreversible economic and environmental consequences.
Because fish and other genetically modified organisms are not likely to respect international boundaries, an international biosafety protocol is crucial. Concern about the ecological consequences of the introduction of new species, whether fish, bacteria, weeds or viruses, is legitimate.
When the United States goes as an observer to the first conference of the parties to the biodiversity agreement in the Bahamas, it should offer as evidence of our concern a call for a stringent biosafety protocol, not for greater access to genetic resources.
 
BETH BURROWS
President, Washington
Biotechnology Action Council
Edmonds, Wash., Sept. 29, 1994

HEADLINE: Stairmasters and the Internet Invade a Staid World;
To Attract Younger Alumni, Particularly Women, University Clubs Try to Modernize

BYLINE: By TRIP GABRIEL 

 BODY:
All along Clubhouse Row in midtown Manhattan, university clubs are trying to knock their stuffiness out.
The Princeton Club asked recent graduates if dropping the coat-and-tie requirement in the Tiger Bar and Grill would persuade them to join. The Harvard Club formed a committee to find portraits of female graduates after the overwhelmingly male membership realized that not one of the dark oil paintings lining its dark, wood-paneled walls depicts a woman. And at the Yale Club, members can sign up for an evening class that teaches them "to play the blues instantly." 
 The changes are earnest, if uncertain steps in a fight against eroding memberships and declining use at the tradition-steeped clubs, many of which occupy the blocks of 43d and 44th streets between Vanderbilt Avenue and the Avenue of the Americas.
Steeply falling revenues have been a factor in backing some clubs into bitter labor disputes recently. At the Harvard Club, waiters, cooks and dishwashers have been on strike since April. At the Princeton Club, union members began "informational picketing" two weeks ago, handing out fliers in a prelude to a strike.
Princeton reports that its membership dropped 28 percent, to about 7,000, from 10,000, in the last five years. The 100-year-old Harvard Club, whose membership has dipped to 10,300, from 10,500, since 1992, says revenues from its dining rooms and functions fell 20 percent in six or seven years.
The older Ivy League clubs are all envious of their latest neighbor, the Penn Club, which signed up 10,000 members just three months after opening in June. It is a success that Penn Club officials attribute in large part to aggressively seeking young alumni, especially women.
All the clubs are fighting for new blood, and that has meant that menus conceived during the Hoover Administration, featuring prime rib and popovers, are being replaced by deep-fried skate and beef carpaccio. And oxblood leather armchairs are giving way to Stairmasters.
"The role of the club in society is changing," said Jim Lawler, a club consultant and the acting general manager of the Chemists Club, an association of scientists. "Simply being a nice place to have lunch that features deceased animals and heavy wood is not going to happen anymore."
Not everyone, however, is thrilled. Daniel P. Lieblich, president of the Princeton Club and a member of the class of '38, said that after an experimental loosening of the dress code in the bar this summer, "I had some comments about how terribly informal it is downstairs."
To their most loyal members, university clubs are sanctuaries where, as Holly Golightly described Tiffany's, it feels as though "nothing bad could ever happen to you." Open to all who attended a particular school, they offer familiar faces, generous Scotches, moderately priced rooms for out-of-town members, business and social networking and a clean restroom in midtown. Annual dues range from around $150 for recent graduates to around $900 for senior members, less if they live outside New York City.
Yet, these very icons of an established old-boy culture seem to have lost some appeal, particularly for the young. A 37-year-old independent video producer said he resigned from the Princeton Club several years ago because of its buttoned-down dress code.
"I never wore ties to meetings, and I felt like I was 7 years old if you had to walk in and borrow a tie from them," said the producer, who declined to be identified for fear of offending friends and colleagues.
University club managers cite a variety of reasons for the declines in members and usage: the long regional economic slump, changes in generational attitudes toward clubs and, to a lesser degree, the elimination of the tax deduction for club dues and the lowering of the deduction for business meals from 80 percent to 50 percent. Weaker clubs, like those of Columbia University and New York University, closed their doors in the last decade.
But at the same time, newcomers have eagerly jumped into the game. The Penn Club opened at 30 West 44th Street after a $25 million renovation of a 1900 Beaux-Arts building. It joined the Cornell Club, at 6 East 44th Street, which opened five years ago after adding 4 stories to a 10-story building.
And this summer, the Chemists Club signed up Georgetown University and Polytechnic University of Brooklyn as affiliates, an arrangement that lets the alumni share the club's new building, which opened on West 45th Street last December. Vassar College recently became an affiliate of the Williams Club at 24 East 39th Street, and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology has joined with Princeton.
The spurt of activity reflects the recognition by universities that clubs bind alumni to their alma maters and build endowments. Whereas clubs like Harvard, Yale and Princeton are member-owned, the newer ventures are subsidized by the universities.
Almost all of the older clubs are studying the success of the Penn Club, whose membership is younger and includes more women: 46 percent of members are under 35, and 38 percent are women.
Rachel Spasser, the club's 27-year-old marketing manager, said, "This is an accessible place, not where you feel uncomfortable walking in -- where, as a woman, you feel intimidated."
The club promises career development seminars, an Internet link to the university's job placement office and a Thursday happy hour, when the coat-and-tie dress code is abandoned.
Arthur I. Hirsch, a divorce lawyer who is the chairman of the Harvard Club admissions committee, defended the institution, whose members include Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan and, at one time, Ivan F. Boesky, who did not attend Harvard but was admitted to the club after donating millions to Harvard's School of Public Health.
"This whole stereotype about the stuffiness, it just ain't so," Mr. Hirsch said. "There is a remnant of that, O.K.? It's like Yiddish: my grandmother spoke Yiddish, but we don't speak it anymore. It's dying out. The emphasis at the club is 'lighten up,' basically."
The Harvard Club says 75 percent of its members are over 32 and 15 percent are women, although among those admitted in May and June from the latest graduating classes, women make up 36 percent. There are seven women on the 20-member board of governors.
Trying to let down its hair, the club set up a "recent graduates' room" last summer that was outfitted with a pool table and a wide-screen television. But its popularity was limited. "In our clumsy way, we may not be succeeding, but we are trying," said Michael D. Yamin, a board member.
Thomas Inglis, the general manager of the Cornell Club, cautioned that clubs ought not banish the old boys just yet. "The older, more mature people are farther on in their careers, and they utilize the food and beverage facilities more," he said. "They also pay higher dues and are more likely to bring in out-of-town guests to stay in the rooms."
Indeed, there is the possibility that as clubs attract more women, their all-important income from bars and restaurants will decline.
"Women's expense accounts aren't as lofty, and women are more concerned with health," Mr. Lawler, the club consultant, said. "Men are more likely to feel comfortable about treating themselves, so to speak, at lunch or the cocktail hour."
While many older club members enjoy entertaining guests in a club dining room, younger members often prefer trendy restaurants. Manhattan restaurants are beginning to recover from dire times, but club dining rooms are not bouncing back as fast. One reason seems to be that traditional club cuisine, says Robert Trainor, the chef at the Penn Club, "has become very passe."
To compete with city restaurants, Mr. Trainor serves wild mushroom ravioli and eggplant terrine at the Penn Club.
Despite their troubles, university clubs have one thing going for them, the value of which is probably even higher in shaky times: they offer members many discreet opportunities to advance in the business and social worlds.
Mr. Lawler said that in planning for the future, other clubs might look to the Penn Club, which attracted younger alumni by pitching itself as a halfway house between coddled campus life and the indifferent city. "It's like a warm nest on a rainy day," said Dan Forman, 21, who is hunting for a first job in advertising.
Club officials say they will have a solid future if they can maintain that welcoming feeling. In their own way, they seem to be trying. A few years ago, the Princeton Club demolished the floor of its barroom, on which was inscribed the slogan: "Where women cease from troubling and the wicked are at rest."

CORRECTION-DATE: October 5, 1994, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
An article yesterday about university clubs in Manhattan misstated the closing date of a club for Columbia alumni. It was in 1973, not in the last decade. The article also omitted the Columbia Club's current status. Since 1990, it has been an affiliate of the Williams Club.
