HEADLINE: Man in the News: Fernando Henrique Cardoso;
Brazil's Big Winner

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BRASILIA, Oct. 4

 BODY:
Hooded, handcuffed and listening to friends' cries under torture, a leftist sociology professor facing interrogation one night 25 years ago thought his life might end at the hands of army intelligence agents. Indeed from 1964 to 1985, the years of Brazil's military dictatorship, he suffered exile, imprisonment, blacklisting and the bombing of his social research group.
But today, voting returns and exit polls indicated that Brazilians had elected the professor, Fernando Henrique Cardoso, to be President by the widest popular margin since a retired army general was chosen to lead the nation in 1945. 
 The election of Mr. Cardoso as Brazil's first President in decades with a strong political power base bolstered the strength of civilian democracy in a country that has had its share of political instability. It also signaled to many that Brazil would stay on a firm course of fighting inflation and spurring economic growth through free-market policies after many false starts and promises.
Indeed, there were many predictions that Mr. Cardoso, a former Foreign Minister and Finance Minister, would also push Latin America's largest economy into a new period of rapid economic growth that would draw in huge amounts of foreign investments and imports.
With only 13 percent of votes counted by nightfall, Brazilians relied on three exit polls, which gave Mr. Cardoso victory with about 54 percent of the vote, enough to avoid a runoff against his closest challenger, Luis Inacio Lula da Silva. Until a few weeks ago Mr. da Silva, a trade union leader, was the front-runner.
This evening Mr. da Silva declined to comment on the results, but he in effect acknowledged his defeat by saying his party would not ask for any positions in the new Government.
With a reputation in this capital for cordiality and congeniality, the 63-year-old intellectual chosen to lead Brazil is a complex person who defies easy labeling. He described himself today as a leader of "the viable left," and many in Brazil hailed his victory as a vindication for his decades of dissent.
"The generation of the exiles finally reach power," the daily Jornal do Brasil said today, joining virtually all of Brazil's press in informally annointing Mr. Cardoso as the next President.
In some respects, the optimism over Mr. Cardoso's election recalled the hopeful spirit that existed when Brazil's last elected President, Fernando Collor de Mello, took office in 1990. But Mr. Collor later tried to rule by dictating to Congress, and after being disgraced by a congressional corruption inquiry, he was forced to resign in 1992.
In contrast, Mr. Cardoso has a reputation as a patient conciliator. "He's a coalition builder, naturally more a prime minister than a president," said Alfred Stepan, a lifelong American friend who is now president of Central European University in Budapest.
In a country where two-thirds of the electorate never finished primary school, Mr. Cardoso vowed in the campaign to spend billions of dollars to guarantee education and health care for all. "We are an unjust country," he said. "The great Achilles heel of Brazil is injustice."
On the other hand, a survey of executives of Brazil's top 500 companies found that, of the eight presidential candidates, Mr. Cardoso won the support of 97 percent of those who responded.
"What this guy brings to the table is the power of Sao Paulo," an admiring American banker said, alluding to Mr. Cardoso's legislative constituency in Brazil's financial capital. "For the first time in memory, Brazil has a political leader not only with moral and technical authority, but also with political authority."
He flashes the easy grin of a man born in Rio, but Mr. Cardoso will be Brazil's first elected president in 65 years who came to prominence in Sao Paulo. Propelled by opinion polls indicating that Mr. Cardoso would win, stock prices on the Sao Paulo's exchange have risen about 80 percent since July.
Convinced that Brazil is entering a high growth phase similar to the "miracle" years of the 1970's, business executives cite the free-market track record forged by Mr. Cardoso during his one year as Finance Minister, which ended last April. As a candidate, he promised to maintain a tough anti-inflation fight that has reduced Brazil's monthly inflation from 45 percent in June to 1.5 percent in September.
Although recent economic projections have been encouraging, some skeptics have wondered about the veracity of the numbers. These skeptics pointed out that three days before the vote on Monday, Brazil registered its lowest monthly inflation rate in five years.
Mr. da Silva charged that Mr. Cardoso's business backers were artificially holding back price rises and that the anti-inflation plan would fall apart after the election.
In interviews during the campaign, Mr. Cardoso vowed to open oil, telephone, mining and public works to foreign companies, to gradually privatize state companies, to maintain Brazil's six-month-old foreign debt accord, and to maintain trade policies that have rapidly opened up an economy larger than Russia's.
For the first time in almost a decade of civilian rule, Brazilians say they believe that their president will have the political power to carry out many of his promises. On Monday Mr. Cardoso's three-party coalition apparently won a loose majority in Congress. Centrist candidates also fared well in races for powerful state governorship posts.
On the world stage, Mr. Cardoso is expected to raise Brazil's low-key profile dramatically. Itamar Franco, Brazil's current President, speaks only Portuguese, is visibly uncomfortable around foreigners and often cancels overseas trips on short notice.
With English honed during the 1970's as a visiting lecturer at Berkeley, Oxford, Princeton, Stanford and Yale, Mr. Cardoso also speaks fluent French, the traditional foreign language of Brazil's elite. He is also fluent in Spanish and taught in Chile during one of his periods of exile. Unlike most Brazilians who travel in Latin America, Mr. Cardoso speaks proper Spanish, not a hybrid, improvised "Portunhol."
Arrested and then banned from teaching in Brazilian universities by the military in 1969, Mr. Cardoso founded Cebrap, the Brazilian Analysis and Planning Center. A haven for other blacklisted professors, the Sao Paulo research center was bombed by right-wing terrorists in 1974.
The author of 21 books, Mr. Cardoso is best known abroad as the co-author, with Enzo Faletto, of "Dependency and Development in Latin America."
Fernando Henrique Cardozo was born on June 18, 1931, in Rio de Janiero. Drawn into politics 20 years ago, Mr. Cardoso served as a Sao Paulo senator from 1983 to 1992. In 1988 he helped to found the Brazilian Social Democratic Party, a center-left group that opposed corruption.
Mr. Cardoso's wife, Ruth Correa Leite Cardoso, stayed in Sao Paulo while her husband moved to Brasilia. An anthropologist at Cebrap, she specializes in studying community movements by women and blacks in Sao Paulo shantytowns. Their three children are grown and married, and Mrs. Cardoso said last month that she would move to Brasilia if her husband won the race.
Although Mr. Cardoso's inauguration on Jan. 1 will mark the 10th anniversary of civilian rule, the threat of military intervention is never distant. According to a book issued today, "A Historia Real," Mr. Cardoso helped to defuse an incipient military rebellion against President Franco last February.

HEADLINE: MISSION TO HAITI: AT THE U.N.;
ARISTIDE, AT U.N., EMPHASIZES NEED FOR CONCILIATION

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Oct. 4

 BODY:
Pledging that "in 11 days I will be in Haiti," its exiled President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, told the United Nations General Assembly today that he is committed to a policy of reconciliation and reconstruction under which civil violence will not be tolerated and retribution will be left to the judicial process.
"We will prepare our reconciliation coffee with the filter of justice, so that no traces of violence or vengeance will be found," he said, quoting a Creole saying. He devoted much of his address to outlining a recovery plan, suggesting also that Haiti's Army, which he called a drain on the economy, would be reduced in size. 
 "The first black republic on earth, today torn asunder by the coup of Sept. 30, 1991, is marching resolutely and definitively toward the establishment of a democratic society," he said.
Father Aristide's remarks drew sustained applause at several points in his address.
Later at a news conference, he repeated his belief that a political amnesty, now being discussed by the Haitian Parliament, cannot cover those who have committed criminal acts while in power. He said that he would wait for the Haitian Parliament to complete its amnesty law, but that he would also look to the courts -- which he plans to reform -- for justice.
"When you talk about crimes against humanity, you don't talk of a general amnesty," he said.
President Aristide also said he would like to see the two remaining military leaders, Lieut. Gen. Raoul Cedras and Brig. Gen. Philippe Biamby -- whom he did not mention by name -- follow the example of Lieut. Col. Michel Francois and flee the country.
In response to a question, he said he had hoped that Colonel Francois, who headed the police in Port-au-Prince and had the allegiance of the paramilitary units, would have gone farther away than the Dominican Republic, to which he apparently fled earlier today.
The Dominican Republic, which shares the island of Hispaniola with Haiti, until recently cooperated little with international embargoes intended to deprive the Haitian military of essential supplies. Some Haitian exiles fear that Colonel Francois, with the help of a brother living there, could set up a base of resistance to Father Aristide.
But in general today, President Aristide was optimistic and effusive in his thanks to the world, the United States and the Haitian people for having stuck by him and preparing the way for his return. He said he would be ready to go back to Haiti sooner than Oct. 15 -- the date by which the Haitian military leaders had agreed in talks with former President Jimmy Carter to step down -- if the two generals resigned before then.
President Aristide deflected a question about what agreement he might make with the United States on the role of American forces in Haiti. He said that now, everyone involved in the Haiti issue is working in unison. He said that he had no complaints about how the Americans were carrying out their mission.
Much of Father Aristide's speech today was devoted to a review of Haiti's economic problems and his plans for development of the country, the hemisphere's poorest. Leaving aside the populist, socialist platforms and slogans of his earlier years, he loaded his address with statistics.
"Why is it that we have one soldier for every 1,000 Haitians and 1.8 doctors per 10,000 inhabitants when the industrial countries have on average one doctor per 400 people?" he asked.
"It is time to create a stable environment permitting national reconciliation across this land where we will no longer have 7,000 men absorbing 40 percent of the national budget," he said. He proposed cutting the army over time to 1,500 troops.
For the first time in Haitian history, he said, he will permanently separate the army and the police force.
Father Aristide, looking toward the bicentennial of Haitian independence in 2004, proposed to build schools and introduce an aggressive literacy program. About 1.2 million children are not in school, he said, approaching twice the number of those enrolled. He said Haiti needs between 35,000 and 100,000 new teachers and up to 20,000 schools to meet the demands of 3 million children within 10 years.
In health, he said his goal is to build up to 8,000 infirmaries and rural health centers and increase hospital beds substantially. He wants to see life expectancy raised from 54 to 65 years by 2004.
Father Aristide laid out detailed plans for restructuring local government and the Haitain justice system from the rural areas upward, and for doubling the number of trained lawyers. He also mentioned reforestation and road-building as social priorities for Haiti.
Following economic plans he has devised with the help of the World Bank and International Monetary Fund, Father Aristide spoke warmly today of foreign investment and the need to reduce $81 million in payments due on Haiti's international debt. He said that on resuming office, he would release $13 million to begin to pay the arrears.
When asked at his news conference about his abandonment of earlier economic principles, he replied, in effect, that it was necessary to get in step with those who can help.
In his speech, Father Aristide made a strong appeal to Haitian exiles to return and rebuild the country in the decade before the bicentennial.
Speaking alternately in French and Creole, President Aristide sent this message to what he called the Haitian diaspora, referring to them as the country's 10th department or district. Haiti has nine major political-geographical divisions.
"Bravo for the 10th department!" he said. "Haiti is the biggest wealth of Haitians. Haiti is always our home. Come home. We will brighten it like a rainbow."

HEADLINE: U.S. AND CHINESE RESOLVE DISPUTE ON MISSILE SALES

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4

 BODY:
As a sign of improving relations, the United States today agreed to allow the export of high-technology satellites to China that was frozen after Beijing secretly transferred missile components and technology to Pakistan.
In return, China pledged that once those sanctions are waived, it will not sell or transfer surface-to-surface missiles covered under an international accord controlling the transfer of sensitive missile technology. 
 The agreement, signed by Foreign Minister Qian Qichen of China and Secretary of State Warren Christopher before television cameras in the State Department Treaty Room, also commits the two sides to cooperate in promoting an end to the production of fissionable material for nuclear weapons.
Even though China has promised in the past to abide by the international missile accord, only to break its promises, Mr. Christopher touted today's agreement as "a very important step forward."
Mr. Qian's two-day visit, which included a meeting on Monday with President Clinton, reflected an improvement in relations between the two countries since the United States softened its tough stance on human rights and extended the trade benefits to China in May.
In recent weeks, China signed $6 billion in trade deals with American companies, and on Monday Mr. Qian presented letters from President Jiang Zemin inviting Mr. Clinton and Vice President Al Gore to visit China.
Mr. Jiang is said to be eager, even desperate, for Mr. Clinton to visit Beijing, and more than a month ago the Chinese began asking the Americans what kind of diplomatic breakthrough would be needed to get Mr. Clinton to go. The probings come amid fresh reports that have reached the American Embassy in Beijing that the health of Chinese leader Deng Xiaoping is worsening.
Mr. Clinton has no plans at the moment to visit China, the White House spokeswoman, Dee Dee Myers, said today.
In Mr. Clinton's meeting on Monday, as in other meetings with Mr. Qian and other Chinese officials, the issue of China's deteriorating human rights record was raised. "The President expressed disappointment" about the lack of progress on human rights, a White House statement said on Monday.
Among the Administration's requests were the release of Wei Jingsheng, China's best known dissident, as well as Chinese political prisoners who are ill and Tibetan prisoners, senior officials said.
These officials said they could not confirm a report in a Beijing-backed newspaper in Hong Kong today that Mr. Wei, who has not been seen in public since he was detained last April, has been granted parole and sent to several economically advanced regions to see how China had changed under its reforms.
"We made clear during these discussions that human rights is an important part of our relationship with China," one senior Admninistration official said. "The human rights situation certainly hasn't gotten better."
Under the agreement signed today, China for the first time accepts the internationally recognized definition of what constitutes a violation of the missile accord, known as the Missile Technology Control Regime. In addition, it commits China to ban the export to any country of surface-to-surface missiles with a range of at least 185 miles and a payload of at least 1,100 pounds.
But the Administration has yet to persuade Beijing to follow the lead of Russia and formally adhere to the accord in its entirety, or to become a full member of the accord.
In a recognition that there is still a long way to go on arms-control issues, a State Department statement issued at the ceremony said, "The two countries agreed to work together to promote missile nonproliferation through a step-by-step approach to resolve differences over missile exports."
In August 1993, after American intelligence agencies reported that China had sent technology and parts for M-11 missiles to Pakistan, President Clinton banned the export to China of several high-technology satellite systems for two years.
But the sanctions, which were scheduled to expire in any case in August 1995, hurt American business and were a major irritant in the relationship between Washington and Beijing.
Even with the sanctions, the Administration has permitted the export of satellites that did not include sensitive military technology. In other cases, American companies themselves withdrew their applications for approval because of the sanctions.
Today's agreement paves the way for American companies to begin to sell their satellite technology to China once again. In particular, it will immediately allow three satellite projects worth hundreds of millions of dollars to proceed, if the manufacturers decide to do so.
Senior Administration officials denied that today's decision was driven by commercial considerations.
"This is really not an economic decision," one such official said. "This is a non-proliferation decision. The thrust of the story should not be that to develop American exports we wiggled around non-proliferation concerns."
China has never admitted that it sold components for M-11 missiles to Pakistan in violation of the international agreement intended to curb the spread of such technology.

HEADLINE: THE 1994 CAMPAIGN: NEW YORK GOVERNOR;
Deep Discontent With Cuomo Strengthens Pataki, Poll Shows

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK 

 BODY:
Five weeks before Election Day, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and his Republican rival, State Senator George E. Pataki, are locked in a tight race because many New Yorkers are so disenchanted with the three-term incumbent that they are willing to support a challenger who remains largely unknown, according to a New York Times/WCBS-TV News Poll.
The statewide telephone poll, taken between Sept. 29 and Oct. 2, shows a virtual dead heat, with Mr. Pataki holding a slim lead of 44 percent to 41 percent among registered voters. Twelve percent are undecided. The distance between Mr. Pataki and Mr. Cuomo is within the poll's margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points, meaning that either candidate could actually be ahead. 
 The Governor remains far more popular in New York City, his hometown, than in the rest of the state. The poll shows him leading Mr. Pataki by 66 percent to 25 percent in the city, while Mr. Pataki leads Mr. Cuomo by 47 percent to 36 percent in the New York City suburbs and by 56 percent to 28 percent upstate.
Despite the closeness of the race, the survey reveals deep disillusionment with Mr. Cuomo, and suggests that the burdens of 12 years of incumbency, which Mr. Cuomo refers to as "my albatross," will not be easy to overcome.
Mr. Cuomo won re-election with a record 65 percent eight years ago and was considered a leading Presidential contender for both 1988 and 1992. In the poll, however, more people viewed him unfavorably than favorably, and fully a quarter of those who said they voted for him in 1990 said they now plan to vote for Mr. Pataki.
The poll suggests that New Yorkers believe that at least half of the Pataki campaign slogan that Mr. Cuomo has been "too liberal for too long." Three-fifths of those questioned said he had been Governor for too long, although 54 percent said he was not too liberal.
Despite Mr. Cuomo's campaign pledge to cut taxes, 55 percent said they believed he would raise them if re-elected, compared with 28 percent for Mr. Pataki (few actually believe that either candidate will succeed in lowering taxes). And perhaps most damning, when asked to name the best thing Mr. Cuomo has done as Governor, 57 percent gave no answer.
But the poll does suggest that Mr. Cuomo has one political asset that he has yet to fully exploit: a reservoir of good will from New Yorkers who believe he is a strong, honest and compassionate leader. The poll shows that 71 percent of those questioned believe he has strong qualities of leadership, compared with 32 percent for Mr. Pataki. Sixty-one percent believe he has the honesty and integrity they want in a governor, compared with 43 percent for Mr. Pataki. Fifty-three percent believe he cares about the needs and problems of people like themselves, compared with 44 percent for Mr. Pataki.
And yet, only 29 percent of those questioned have an overall favorable opinion of Mr. Cuomo, while 40 percent view him unfavorably. For Mr. Pataki, 18 percent said they viewed him favorably and 19 percent unfavorably, while 63 percent said they were either undecided or did not know enough to have an opinion. Of those who said they would vote for Mr. Pataki, 30 percent said the main reason was because they did not like Mr. Cuomo, and another 31 percent said they simply wanted a change.
Many respondents were like Margaret Serro, a 53-year-old seamstress from Merrick, L.I., who is not enrolled in a political party. She said in a follow-up interview that she had voted for Mr. Cuomo in the past and knew virtually nothing about Mr. Pataki, but would vote for the Republican anyway.
"I dislike Mario Cuomo that much," she said. "He hasn't done anything for us in the years he's been in office. He's got all this money in New York State and we don't see any return for the working people. Politicians will be politicians and I don't know that Pataki will be any better. But at least you'll see somebody different."
Other respondents said they faced a tough decision. Mary Lou Miller, a 47-year-old school guidance counselor who lives in Avon, 20 miles south of Rochester, said the state needed a change. But Ms. Miller, a self-described "bipartisan Republican," said she disagreed with Mr. Pataki's support for the death penalty and was uncertain whether he strongly supports abortion rights, as she does.
"I'm going to be in a real Catch-22," she said.
The poll depicts a highly volatile race, largely because Mr. Pataki, a freshman Senator from Putnam County, is such an unknown quantity. That leaves Mr. Cuomo, who still has millions of dollars for television advertising, with a chance to portray Mr. Pataki in such an unflattering light that New Yorkers will find him an unacceptable alternative.
That effort, of course, has been under way for weeks. The Cuomo campaign has broadcast a steady volley of ads depicting Mr. Pataki as a dishonest right-wing extremist who is controlled by his patron, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato. Mr. Pataki has countered with ads that deride Mr. Cuomo's policies on taxes, welfare and crime. Thus far, however, there is no evidence that either campaign's advertising has had a decisive effect.
The poll of 1,148 registered voters began last Thursday, the day after Mr. Pataki disclosed his plan for cutting personal income taxes.
In the poll, Mr. Pataki's 3 percentage point lead among all registered voters grew only slightly, to 49 percent to 44 percent, when undecided respondents were asked who they leaned toward, and when the survey was limited to those who said they definitely would vote. The poll did not specifically give respondents a choice of three other candidates -- Robert T. Walsh of the Right-to-Life Party, B. Thomas Golisano of the Independence Fusion Party, and Robert Schulz of the Libertarian Party -- but 1 percent said they would vote for someone other than Mr. Cuomo or Mr. Pataki.
Three other independent polls taken during the last three weeks have shown Mr. Pataki with a lead of between 1 and 10 percentage points, while one showed Mr. Cuomo with a 4 percentage point lead. That poll, by the Quinnipiac College Polling Institute in Hamden, Conn., was weighted so that 37 percent of the respondents lived in New York City.
Both candidates sought yesterday to put the most generous spin on the numbers.
"The momentum is clearly building and heading our way," said Mr. Pataki, after a Manhattan news conference.
Mr. Cuomo, in Albany, saw things differently. "We should be further behind, according to my pollsters," he said. "That probably is going to shake up my people because it threatens my underdog status."
The poll shows that the issues that most concern New Yorkers, in order, are crime, taxes and unemployment, which was 6.7 percent in August. Sixty percent of the New Yorkers questioned said they rated the economy as either fairly bad or very bad, compared with 46 percent in a nationwide poll take by The New York Times and WCBS-TV last month.
Asked about the state's sentencing practices for murderers, 47 percent said they support the death penalty, 36 percent said they support a maximum sentence of life without the possibility of parole, and 6 percent said they favor long sentences with the possibility of parole. The death penalty is a significant issue in the campaign because Mr. Pataki supports it and Mr. Cuomo has vetoed it for 12 consecutive years. The Governor contends that New Yorkers would choose his life-without-parole option in a referendum.
On abortion, 47 percent said it should be available to those who want it, as Mr. Cuomo says, and 35 percent said it should be available under stricter limits, as Mr. Pataki contends. Fifteen percent said it should be illegal.
And in perhaps another foreboding result for Mr. Cuomo, 56 percent said that statewide public officials should be limited to two four-year terms, while 38 percent said they should be allowed to serve as long as they continue to be re-elected.
 
How the Poll Was Conducted
 The latest New York Times/WCBS-TV News Poll of New York State is based on telephone interviews conducted from Thursday to Sunday with 1,552 adults throughout the state. Of these, 1,148 said they were registered to vote.
The random sample of telephone numbers was provided by Survey Sampling of Fairfield, Conn.
Within each household, one adult was randomly designated as the respondent. The results have been weighted to take into account household size and number of telephone lines at the residence, as well as to adjust for variations relating to region, race, sex, age and education.
In addition, results about respondents' intended votes in November have been weighted by the statewide distribution of actual ballots in recent elections from New York City (31 percent), its suburbs (24 percent) and the rest of the state (45 percent).
According to statistical theory, in 19 of 20 cases, the results based on such samples will differ by no more than 3 percentage points in either direction from what would have been obtained by seeking out all registered voters in New York State.
The potential sampling error for smaller subgroups is larger. For example, results based on residents of New York City would be plus or minus 4 percentage points.
In addition to sampling error, the practical difficulties of conducting any opinion survey may introduce error into the poll. Differences in the wording and order of questions, for instance, can lead to somewhat varying results.

HEADLINE: Mandela Bids U.S. Assist In New Fight

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4

 BODY:
In his first visit to the United States since his inauguration, President Nelson Mandela thanked the American people today for helping to overturn the apartheid system and then implored them to join South Afria in its newest struggle: overcoming poverty and building its economy.
At an emotional White House ceremony that included a 21-gun salute and trumpet flourishes, Mr. Mandela said that after coming so far in helping the rebirth of his nation, the United States should not abandon its friend, but must instead invest in a new South Africa. 
 "We have now opened a new battle line, to fight against poverty, against hunger, against joblessness, against homelessness," Mr. Mandela said, standing beside President Clinton on a podium on the South Lawn. "It may prove to be a more difficult battle than the one we fought with arms and other pressures. It needs, first and foremost, resources."
In his weeklong visit to the United States, the 76-year-old South African leader has brought the same message as other prominent foreign leaders, including President Lech Walesa of Poland and President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia -- he no longer wants help for his political struggles, but needs aid for the daunting economic challenges ahead.
"I have come here with a message," he said. "People of the United States of America: Open your markets to us. People of the United States of America: Come and invest in our country."
Mr. Mandela's schedule includes not just a state dinner at the White House tonight, with the singer Whitney Houston entertaining, and an address to a joint meeting of Congress on Thursday, but also many gatherings with chief executives of blue-chip corporations. At those meetings, Mr. Mandela is stressing that it is time to invest in South Africa because the days of violence and instability are over.
For the diplomats, members of Congress, black leaders and others among the 4,500 invited guests at the White House ceremony, it was quite a sight to see Mr. Mandela, who spent 27 years in prison because of his fight against apartheid, walking with his stiff but dignified gait to inspect the honor guard with President Clinton.
Mindful of the civil wars in Rwanda and Bosnia, Mr. Clinton hailed Mr. Mandela for his success at promoting reconciliation in his deeply fractured nation and at spearheading the peaceful liberation of his people.
"Now all over the world there are three words which spoken together express the triumph of freedom, democracy and hope for the future," Mr. Clinton said to thunderous applause. "They are, President Nelson Mandela."
Mr. Clinton promised that the United States would continue to extend a helping hand to South Africa. His Administration plans to increase aid to South Africa during the next three years, to $800 million from $600 million, by, for example, providing more than $100 million in loan guarantees for housing and electrification projects in poor townships.
In addition, the Overseas Private Investment Corporation is to announce on Wednesday two investment funds totaling $150 million that are intended to generate about $1.3 billion in investment in South Africa.
Mr. Mandela's visit has spurred some investor interest. Duracell, the battery company, closed its South Africa operations in 1984 but said today that it would start selling batteries again in that country, aided by $13 million in political risk insurance provided by the Overseas Private Investment Corporation. Then, in a move that is expected to create at least 400 jobs, the Subway Corporation has agreed to open 80 sandwich shops in South Africa.
A group of American blacks, including the actor Danny Glover and the basketball star Shaquille O'Neal, announced this week that they would put up $15 million to invest in a Pepsi-Cola bottling venture.
Mr. Mandela said corporate America "can play a decisive role in insuring that there are enough homes, there are enough jobs, there are enough schools."
The guest list for the White House dinner included many big-city mayors, black leaders, members of Congress and a sprinkling of prominent business executives. Among them were the Rev. Jesse Jackson; Coretta Scott King; ex-Mayor David M. Dinkins; Sidney Sheinberg, president of MCA; Stephen J. Friedman, chairman of Goldman, Sachs; Louis V. Gerstner Jr., chairman of I.B.M.; John H. Johnson, chairman of the Johnson Publishing Company, and Dennis Weatherstone, chairman of J. P. Morgan & Company.

 Utilities complain that a Federal law requiring them to buy energy from independent generators has locked them into paying fees twice the market rate for power they no longer need. [D1.]

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
New G.M. Revamping Focuses on Car Design

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PARIS, Oct. 4

 BODY:
The General Motors Corporation announced its fourth reorganization in 10 years today in an effort to streamline its approach to developing cars. Executives stressed that the latest attempt would not yield cataclysmic change, like the reorganization of 1984, which paralyzed the company.
G.M. said it would merge its four North American car development operations into two, while more closely allying them with its European ones, as a way to achieve economies of scale and to stifle the traditionally fratricidal competition among divisions of the company. 
 Other auto makers are also shaking up their organizations to cut vehicle development costs. But G.M. has the greatest challenge: For decades, different teams designed unique vehicles for the company's rival divisions.
G.M. executives say they have learned that customers generally do not notice if, for example, some Chevrolets and Pontiacs share engines, suspensions and other components, provided the vehicles are styled differently and have other distinctive features.
As a result, the executives say, G.M. can save money by combining the engineering teams to design a basic platform, or car chassis, and then taking advantage of economies of scale in producing more similar parts.
In addition, G.M. said the reorganization should shorten vehicle development time. Many analysts have criticized G.M. for taking more than five years to develop some vehicles, making the cars seem stale when they are introduced.
This reorganization signals that the old G.M. system of internal competition is dead, executives said. "There aren't any kingdoms left," G. Richard Wagoner Jr., president of G.M.'s North American operations, said in a meeting with reporters in Warren, Mich., today. "Like it or not, we've got to work together."
John F. Smith Jr., G.M.'s president and chief executive, said in an interview before the opening of the Paris Auto Show, "It's just another evolution."
"This just gets everyone a little closer," he continued, "particularly the North American unit."
Mr. Smith said he had no estimate of how much would be saved by the reorganization.
Mr. Smith has been consolidating G.M.'s sprawling operations since taking over as chief executive two years ago, and auto industry analysts welcomed the latest changes as a sign that his efforts had not lost momentum, even though the company's profits have been rising.
"After a lot of agonizing, this is the final step to put in place" to streamline car development, said Joseph Phillippi, auto analyst with Lehman Brothers in New York. At G.M. now, he said, "It's taken too long to do a product, as well as consuming a lot of resources."
G.M. is combining its four car development groups into two: a small-car group and a midsize and luxury car group. G.M.'s North American operations also include a truck development group, a powertrain group and a sales service and marketing group.
G.M.'s Saturn subsidiary -- until now an independent company within G.M. -- will be folded into the small- car group. Previously Mr. Smith had said Saturn would have a separate platform. The decision to combine its future development with that of other small cars, like the Chevrolet Cavalier, is risky because Saturn workers and buyers tend to think of Saturn as unique and unrelated to G.M.
But Mr. Smith said the change was needed to cut costs at Saturn. "I don't think they are taking a step backwards," he said of Saturn, because with its different styling, other features and sales system, the car will still seem different from other G.M. products to buyers.
In addition, Saturn's president, Richard G. LeFauve, 59, was promoted today to vice president and group executive in charge of the small car group, suggesting that Saturn's interests will be protected.
Louis R. Hughes, president of G.M.'s international operations, said in an interview here that he expected that platforms in the United States and Europe would increasingly share parts. "We have platforms in the United States and Europe that are within millimeters of each other," he said. "That's a fact, and long term, that makes no sense."
But while the Ford Motor Company is merging its European and American auto operations, Mr. Smith emphasized that he favored keeping G.M.'s operations independent, instead forming alliances between the units to work on specific projects.

HEADLINE: U.S. Index Suggests Growth Into New Year

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4

 BODY:
The Government's chief forecasting index posted its biggest advance in five months in August, a sign that the economy will grow briskly through the holidays and into the new year.
The advance of six-tenths of 1 percent in the Commerce Department's index of leading indicators was the latest in a series of consistently strong reports since last Tuesday, when the Federal Reserve Board decided it was not yet time to increase interest rates again. 
 Today's results were not a surprise, because most of the components of the index had been published. But they seemed to solidify opinion that the economy has not slowed much and may be rebounding from a summer lull.
Combined with yesterday's report from corporate purchasing managers of a robust September in factories, the rise in the leading index "means the Fed has not tightened enough," said Maury N. Harris, chief economist at Paine Webber.
Nine of the 11 index components contributed to the August advance, with the biggest factor being a jump in new factory orders for consumer goods and materials. This was despite a large buildup of inventories in the spring that seemed to imply a pause while stocks were worked off.
The second-biggest contributor to the August rise was more companies' reporting slower deliveries from suppliers, a measure of production bottlenecks that is thought to be a favorite gauge of Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman.
"That is a precursor of inflation," said Paul D. Mastroddi, a managing director at J. P. Morgan in New York.
Separately, the Bureau of Mines said its Primary Metals Index, intended to predict activity in steel and other basic industries, jumped 1.9 percent in August, the biggest increase since November. This index, compiled with the Center for International Business Cycle Research at Columbia University, edged up one-tenth of 1 percent in July.
David B. Bostian Jr., economist at Herzog, Heine, Geduld, a New York brokerage firm, said his own forecasting index rose just three points for the month, to plus 197, warning of what he said would be a "sharply" slowing economy in 1995. The Fed, he predicted, is increasingly likely to raise interest rates this month, not waiting for its first policy meeting after the elections on Nov. 15.
Another private-sector index, from Safian Investment Research in White Plains, rose four-tenths of 1 percent in August, with 17 components up and 7 down. What lies ahead, according to Kenneth Safian, is a "continued though moderating advance in business activity."
But the Commerce Department's index, which broke a streak of four months with little or no increase, seemed to leave little doubt that the economy would remain strong, despite the Fed's repeated attempts this year to force its growth rate back below 3 percent.
Other positive contributors to the August increase were a decline in first-time claims for unemployment benefits, higher stock prices, another rise in the price of materials sensitive to the business cycle, higher consumer expectations, a longer average workweek and more building permits. The only negatives were a decline in the money supply and lower factory backlogs on durable-goods orders.

HEADLINE: MISSION IN HAITI: POLITICS;
Aristide Backers Start to Surface

BYLINE: By CATHERINE S. MANEGOLD, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Oct. 4

 BODY:
Slowly, cautiously, a government-in-waiting is surfacing here.
Evans Paul, Mayor of this gritty, impoverished city by the sea, can now speak openly with politicians, journalists and friends, arriving nattily dressed at City Hall and at luxury hotels to appear on television to discuss Haiti's future.
But when night falls he does not go home. Instead, with memories of his arrest and beatings still in mind, he moves around the capital, seeking refuge in the homes of those who promise shelter. 
 Joseph Fignole, a member of Parliament and a staunch supporter of President Jean-Bertrand Aristide, chooses not to hide. But visits must be carefully arranged.
On Saturday, after a meandering drive up pitted back streets, a stranger was asked to stop and wait for an exchange of passwords before a guide would show the way to the house that has several times sheltered him from gunfire.
Samuel Madistin, the chairman of Parliament's human rights and justice commission, left the country just one day before Guy Malary, the Justice Minister, was assassinated last year. Seventeen days later, Haitian soldiers circled Mr. Madistin's parents' home, riddled it with automatic weapons fire, beat his 60-year-old father and drove the couple from the country.
Mr. Madistin returned to Haiti on April 28. The next day he had to run from an ambush on Carrefour Road.
"The problem is not when you leave," Mr. Madistin said. "It is when you come back."
Now he lives at home for the first time in years. But he is unsettled. "Nothing has changed so far," he said. "We have seen what happened this week. We have seen more killings. It is no time for confidence."
Three years and more than 3,000 deaths after Father Aristide was driven from the country, the civilian Government here is struggling awkwardly into the open beneath a protective shadow cast by American troops.
Though Father Aristide and many in his Cabinet are still safely ensconced in Washington and Montreal, others guided by ambition and ideology are working here for deep changes in a political system long driven by brute force.
Meeting in cars, in embassy residences, in friends' houses and occasionally in public, they have spent months trying to cobble together a transition to civilian rule and democratic principles. But as they do so, they must fight well-founded fears for their own safety, internal rivalries ignited by the promise of elections next year and prevalent doubts about their ability to govern an angry population choked by a crippling economic embargo and embittered by years of desperate poverty.
They also must still hide.
"It is like a game of cat and mouse," Mr. Madistin said.
"They look for us and we elude them," he said of the paramilitary groups that have threatened and harassed political figures opposed to the military's de facto government.
It is a sinister game that affords both sides some natural advantages. Since only two main streets lead through Port-au-Prince, spotters working with the military can easily trace most movements. That has forced the underground to use the back routes and sometimes travel in disguise.
Children have proved an unexpected problem to some of those in hiding. "They know my face," Mayor Paul said.
Staying too long or getting too comfortable in one place can spell trouble, too. "If you stay, the usual things change," Mr. Paul said. "Children cannot have their friends over. The house is quiet. People notice."
And on back streets, money buys betrayal.
Telephones, though preposterously unreliable, have worked to the underground's advantage. Since Haiti's communication system is so primitive, said Micha Gaillard, a socialist politician who serves as chief of staff for the Education Minister, "they can only tap about 25 lines at a time." He laughed, and added, "I was too small for that list."
Still, Mr. Gaillard was hardly out of danger. He left home when someone left a macabre message at his doorstep. One morning before dawn, as he prepared a pot of coffee, he heard a spray of automatic weapons fire just outside the family gate.
A man lay sprawled in blood on his driveway. The killing came after dozens of threats. So Mr. Gaillard disappeared out a back door, taking his wife and children into a place the Haitians call "maronage," a life of hiding.
Now he is back, relaxing over a computer chess game with a son and working 15-hour days to revamp the Government and shore up his political party, Konakom.
For him, the changing tide brought by the arrival of American troops presented an odd dichotomy. He opposed intervention. But now that the troops are here, he cannot help celebrating.
"Today, I receive you with a fan," he said grandly, welcoming a visitor and flicking a switch on a portable fan, though a stiff breeze off the sea was rustling the papers on his desk. "The Americans went to the local power station and they said, 'Give us more power!' So now we have electricity. It is great!"
That relief is not broadly shared yet. Many lawmakers remain in hiding to some degree; others remain in exile. And thousands of others make up a modern diaspora that began under the dictatorship of the Duvaliers and has continued to the present.
"More than 300,000 people were displaced," said Ira Kurzban, a Miami lawyer who represents the Aristide Government. "It is like a boot has been lifted off their necks. But as long as the weapons are not confiscated, there is still tremendous tension."
At the government radio station, the fear has meant only a skeleton staff to run things since American troops wrested control from the military. Television service will take longer to restart.
Parliament, too, is faltering between two forces. When Mr. Fignole went there this week for an emotional reunion with other legislators who support the exiled Government, he traveled with an American military escort. The situation, everyone says, is still tenuous. Many other exiles and members of the "maronage" have yet to reappear.
"None of us go through this without tears and hardship," Mr. Madistin said. "To have lived for three years of fear and brutality is not nothing. It is hard for many people to go back home and get to work, because they know exactly what's waiting for them if democracy is not back."
"Thursday, they threw a grenade," he said of an attack on demonstrators calling for Father Aristide's return. "It was a reminder. We fight. But we also die."
In this odd time between hope and history, many in hiding simply wait and watch. History has not been kind here. And hope is thin gruel to a country where the natural response to the question, "How are you?" is the bleak Creole utterance, "Papi mal" -- "Not worse."
Mayor Paul, who is thought to harbor dreams of the presidency, deflects a pointed question about his own future with a simple segue as though not to tempt the fates.
"What is important to me," he said, "is the right to conduct my life, the right to live in my house, the right to invite a friend to a restaurant and the right to go to a meeting or go jogging if I want to."
But even with thousands of American troops on Haitian soil, the Mayor still looks over his shoulder as he drives through town. And he has yet to go home.

GRAPHIC: Chart: "PROFILE: Haiti's Civilian Leaders"
 
ROBERT MALVAL, prominent businessman and staunch supporter of Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide ... named Prime Minister by Aristide after June 1993 Governors Island accord that was to restore Aristide ... seen as one of the few elite Haitians who could work effectively as a bridge between upper classes and growing populist movement ... remained in Haiti after coup, working in political underground and acting as liason between the elite, the army and Aristide supporters ... resigned as Prime Minister last December, after it was clear that Aristide's return had been indefinitely delayed ... has indicated several times that he hopes only to be a figure in the transition, not a force in a new administration.
 
GERARD JEAN-JUSTE, Catholic priest and militant opponent of the Duvalier dictatorship ... educated in Boston and Canada and holds engineering degree ... directed Haitian Refugee Center in Miami, 1980-1991, then returned to Haiti to work in Aristide Government ... because of work with refugees, was named director of "10th department," recognizing for the first time that many Haitians had fled outside the country, as opposed to the nine regions, or departments, within Haiti ... remained in Haiti under junta Government of Lieut. Gen. Raoul Cedras, as a central figure organizing demonstrations and other opposition activities, but rarely appearing in public ... continued active role in Haitian Catholic conference, but gave no sermons during his three years in hiding ... has family in New York and Miami.
 
FIRMIN JEAN-LOUIS, President Haitian Senate since July 1993, but prevented from functioning effectively since last spring, when senators supporting military took the building by force with help of soldiers ... studied in United States and Canada ... taught political science while in exile for 15 years during the Duvalier regime ... elected to Senate in 1990 representing northern region ... prevented from showing himself in Parliament during reign of Cedras junta, he spent time meeting with international community and coordinating efforts of Aristide supporters and political parties seeking his return.
 
EVANS PAUL, militant reformer and strong Aristide supporter ... elected Mayor of Port-au-Prince in 1990 ... actor and journalist during Duvalier regime ... arrested during the Cedras coup and beaten and shuttled between two prisons before release ... remained in Haiti and has worked underground since, occasionally appearing in public to speak or attend political meetings ... has worked on resistance efforts and tried to build support for his political party, the National Front for the Advancement of Democracy ... also works for group called Fondem, a fledgling human rights organization ... most political activities conducted in secrecy until last week, when returned to City Hall with protection of American troops.

HEADLINE: THE 1994 CAMPAIGN: CUOMO AND TAXES;
Governor Delays Plan For Cuts

BYLINE: By IAN FISHER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Oct. 4

 BODY:
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo delayed releasing his tax-cut proposal, saying today that he wants to hear more details of how his Republican challenger, State Senator George E. Pataki, will pay for his own plan to slash the top personal income tax rate by 25 percent.
"First, I want to hear from him," Mr. Cuomo said in a news conference after a state police cadet graduation here. "I don't want to set up a fog that allows him to escape. Let's hear their answers first. Why should we get to my plan?" 
 And in a day devoted to sniping over economic issues -- both campaigns see their credibility on tax cuts as a key to the election -- Mr. Pataki charged that business has been stifled because of 6,000 new regulations adopted during Mr. Cuomo's tenure. Mr. Pataki pointedly declined, though asked at least three times, to name any specific regulation he considered onerous.
"We could give you a list after list of regulations we think are onerous," he said at at news conference in Manhattan. "But it wouldn't serve a point. The point is that there are 6,000 new regulations that have been adopted since Mario Cuomo took office."
Last week, Mr. Cuomo's aides said he would release the final details of an estimated $1.5 billion tax cut in Buffalo on Wednesday. But today the Governor said he would delay, charging again that Mr. Pataki's plan, which would cost $5.6 billion a year by 1998, would raise local property taxes substantially.
Mr. Cuomo appears to be gambling that he can keep the focus on Mr. Pataki's proposal, which the Governor says is unworkable, and that the voters will, on closer inspection, agree with him. But he may risk looking petty or to be playing the same game -- of refusing to be specific -- that he accuses Mr. Pataki of playing.
Mr. Pataki blasted Mr. Cuomo for his decision. "Let me say that I'm not surprised that the Governor is having confusion putting together a tax-cut package because it's something from his record he's not been very good at," he said.
Surrounded by green books titled "Official Compilation: Codes, Rules and Regulations of the State of New York," Mr. Pataki said he would take several steps to ease regulations on businesses. Among those steps would be requiring state agencies to analyze any regulation's effect on the economy and ordering a review of all state regulations to reduce "as much as possible the burden that the people of this state suffer under."
But Mr. Pataki conceded that not every state regulation has a direct effect on businesses.
For his part, Mr. Cuomo defended his record of cutting regulations. "Everybody overregulates," he said. "We're probably doing more to cut that back than most states."
Although Mr. Cuomo linked his decision to delay his tax plan to a further explanation from Mr. Pataki, a Cuomo spokesman said later that the Governor's plan had not been completed. But Thomas Conroy, the spokesman, said Mr. Cuomo still planned to travel to Buffalo to deliver a speech on his overall agenda for economic development.

The Governor delayed releasing his tax-cut proposal, saying he wants to hear more details of how his Republican challenger, State Senator George E. Pataki, will pay for his own plan to slash taxes. (David Jennings for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Auto Sales Rose 7.4% Last Month

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Oct. 4

 BODY:
Sales of cars and light trucks rose 7.4 percent in September, as the Big Three auto makers gained market share from foreign producers by virtue of the surging popularity of pickup trucks, mini-vans and four-wheel-drive vehicles.
The strong gain in sales, reported today by the auto makers, came despite concerns that higher interest rates could choke off consumer confidence and the ability of consumers to make monthly payments. The report briefly unnerved the bond market, which saw it as a sign that higher rates were failing to moderate growth, and Treasury prices fell. [Page D15.] Stock prices were also lower yesterday. [Page D8.] 
 For the month, total sales reached 1,208,691 cars and light trucks, compared with 1,125,456 in the comparable period a year ago. The results did not include sales of the Mitsubishi Motor Corporation, which said it would not report results today because of internal reporting problems with its dealers.
The seasonally adjusted annual rate of sales of domestically built vehicles was 7.1 million cars and 5.6 million light trucks, according to the Commerce Department. The year's brisk pace of sales showed few signs of letting up.
Joel Pitcoff, sales analyst for the Ford Motor Company, said, "We've been saying we're on track for selling 15.5 million cars and trucks by year's end, and I see no reason to change that." If the industry reached that total, it would be the best auto sales year since 1988.
Some analysts, however, were expecting even stronger results. Tom Webb, chief economist for the National Automobile Dealers Association, said, "total sales were a little less than expected." Mr. Webb said he was concerned that household incomes had not grown fast enough to support the current sales pace, and consumer debt was rising.
But Ron Nippe, general sales manager of Ira Oldsmobile-Toyota-Lexus-Mazda in Danvers, Mass., north of Boston, said he saw no signs of slowing sales. "There's pent-up frustration in the buying public," he said. "They have been keeping cars longer and they need to buy new cars."
Mr. Nippe said the Toyota brand was "especially hot," and Oldsmobile's new Aurora model was "selling faster than we can get them."
Encouraged by robust consumer demand, North American auto makers have planned the most aggressive fourth-quarter production in a decade. Ward's Automotive Reports, an industry newsletter, said auto makers would build about 4.1 million cars and trucks through the end of 1994, up 9 percent from 1993.
The General Motors Corporation, the No. 1 auto maker, posted monthly car and light-truck sales of 396,216, an increase of about 15 percent from a year ago and well ahead of G.M's pace for the first nine months of the year. Car sales rose 22.3 percent, and light-truck sales were up 4.7 percent.
William E. Hoglund, executive vice president of G.M., said sales might have been higher but for tight availability of light trucks and two assembly plants -- in Lordstown, Ohio, and Fairfax, Kan. -- that have just begun to produce new models.
"We're feeling pretty good," Mr. Hoglund said. He noted that G.M. had sold an unusually large number of vehicles to rental fleets in the month. That did not represent a change in the auto maker's policy of reducing its reliance on sales to rental fleets, Mr. Hoglund said. "It was just a timing issue," he said.
The Ford Motor Company's car and light-truck sales in September were 321,153, or about 8 percent ahead of last year. Car sales were 4.1 percent higher and light-truck sales were 12.2 percent higher.
"Our trucks were impressive across the board, but two areas of strength stood out in particular -- mini-vans and pickups," said Robert L. Rewey, group vice president of marketing and sales for Ford. He said sales of Ford's three mini-van models -- Aerostar, Windstar and Mercury Villager -- were up 37 percent.
The Chrysler Corporation's total vehicle sales rose more modestly, compared with those of its rivals. Chrysler, the No. 3 auto maker, said its car and light-truck sales rose only 2 percent for the month, to 168,074, because of a drop of about 17 percent in car sales.
The auto maker said the slip was caused in part by the lack of availability and the discontinuation of some models. Sales of light trucks, including mini-vans, rose 17 percent for the month.
Two of the larger Japanese producers posted lower September sales. The Honda Motor Company reported a drop of 12 percent in car sales, compared with the comparable month last year. Honda said last year's results were unusually strong because of a special clearance of 1993 models.
Noting that the sales for the 1994 model year were 6.6 percent ahead of the previous model year, Tom Elliott, executive vice president of Honda's United States sales organization, said, "We expect '94 calendar year sales to be even stronger." The 1994 model year ended on Sept. 30.
The Toyota Motor Corporation reported sales of 83,953 cars and light trucks for the month, down 11.1 percent from last year.
The Nissan Motor Corporation posted sales of 69,822, up 10.7 percent from last year. Earl J. Hesterberg, vice president of the auto maker's Nissan division, said, "Nissan's momentum continues to accelerate." Sales of the Altima compact sedan rose 6.9 percent in September, to 15,297, making it Nissan's best-selling model.
The Mazda Motor Corporation reported monthly sales of 30,735, up 6.3 percent. Mazda's subcompact Protege outsold all other models.

HEADLINE: Man in the News;
New SUNY Chancellor: Thomas Alva Bartlett

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE VAN GELDER 

 BODY:
As Thomas A. Bartlett recalls it, "it was a complete bolt out of the blue."
There he was, one afternoon early in June, sitting contentedly in the Portland office of the University of Oregon. At 63, retiring after five years as Chancellor of the Oregon state university system, he was looking forward to assuming the mantle of chancellor emeritus, and leading a different sort of life. There was his cattle farm in the foothills of the Cascade Mountains, and some projects connected with international education. Maybe even a book. 
 Then, the telephone rang.
Now, as a result of that bolt-out-of-the-blue call from an executive search company, Dr. Bartlett plans to sell his 130 head of cattle and take office on Dec. 1 as the fifth Chancellor of the State University of New York in the 30 years since Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller created the post and led an expansion of the system.
As a successor to D. Bruce Johnstone, who stepped down in March because of cancer, Dr. Bartlett is to receive $172,500 a year to head the largest state university system in the United States. SUNY has 400,000 students, 64 campuses and a budget of just over $5 billion a year.
"It's a little bit like getting married," he said of his decision to accept the SUNY post after much reflection and evaluation and many discussions. "It isn't just a job. It's not a contract. It's a relationship."
But it is clear that he sees the relationship as one that extends far beyond ivy-covered walls.
"I think of the chancellor's role as strategy, structure, leadership," he said.
With a background in foreign affairs that includes nearly eight years with the United States Mission to the United Nations, he sees the impact of world economy and the state's politics on education. "Is the public going to decide it wants to invest less in higher education?" he said.
He knows that people educated in the university will ultimately play a role in the research and public policy that shape decisions on issues like health care and the environment.
"Public higher education exists to serve individual needs and social needs, and much of the trick of leadership is to keep those two in the right balance," Dr. Bartlett said. "Our fundamental challenge is to combine access and quality, or quantity and quality, if you like."
Dr. Bartlett, who has also been Chancellor of the University of Alabama and the president of Colgate University, assessed his role in New York this way:
"I think it is the job of the chancellor to help the board of trustees -- and through the board of trustees, the political processes of the state -- to understand the choices, make sure those choices are clear, get the best possible professional advice on how to get the most results from our money, to make the best educational choices and to make sure that we've got able people at the right places in the organization."
David B. Frohnmayer, the president of the University of Oregon, who worked with Dr. Bartlett for nearly a dozen years in various capacities, called him "a very intelligent, very intense and extremely experienced higher education administrator" whose background in diplomacy will serve him well.
Yetta G. Samford Jr., an Opelika, Ala., lawyer who was a trustee when Dr. Bartlett headed the Alabama system, described him as "a person of superior intellect. He demands academic excellence."
Discussing Dr. Bartlett's managerial style, he said, "He lets his people have free rein as long as they keep within the mission that they've agreed on."
Even as a teen-ager, Thomas Alva Bartlett thought of a career in education. The youngest of the three sons of Cleave Bartlett, a auditor-bookkeeper and real estate broker, and the former Alma Hanson, a housewife, Dr. Bartlett was born in Salem, Ore., on Aug. 20, 1930.
At Salem High, he was student body president, a member of the football team, a champion debater and, he says with apparent modesty, "a pretty good student." He considered a future in politics or education.
"It seemed to me that it was a great big world out there that I didn't know nearly enough about, and I wanted to see it and experience it and find out as much as I could about it," he said. "In my opinion, that -- at that point in my life -- said education."
After graduation from Salem High in 1947, he spent two years on a Rotary scholarship at Willamette University and two years at Stanford University on a Newhouse Foundation scholarship before receiving a bachelor of arts degree, Phi Beta Kappa, in political science with an emphasis on international relations.
Next stop was Oxford University as a Rhodes Scholar, studying philosophy, politics and economics. He was granted a master's degree in 1953.
While working toward a doctorate in political science that he received from Stanford in 1959, he was recruited as an adviser to the United States Permanent Mission to the United Nations and remained there until 1963, when his work on Arab-Israel relations led to a proposal to become the president of the American University in Cairo.
He then was the president of Colgate and of the Association of American Universities, before assuming chancellorships in Alabama and Oregon.
Since 1954, he has been married to the former Mary Bixby, known as Molly, whom he met at Stanford.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Once just months from retirement to an Oregon farm, Dr. Thomas A. Bartlett is instead contemplating preparations for a new job, as the next Chancellor of the State University of New York. He begins on Dec. 1. (Marilynn K. Yee/The New York Times)
 
Chart: "OVER TIME: Bartlett's Predecessors" shows SUNY Chancellors since 1964.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Issues Fall Moderately

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities were moderately lower in fairly subdued trading yesterday, as a sales report by the Ford Motor Company showed continued strength in that sector.
According to some analysts, the market had been expecting the monthly sales data to dip slightly after the strong showing for August, but the first September figures out, those of Ford, were much stronger than expected. 
 Gerald A. Guild, a senior vice president and manager of the taxable fixed-income department at Advest Inc. said a malaise of pessimisism had infected the market, and as a result a decisive negative bias continued to be built into trading. "And the next test of that will be on Friday when the employment number comes out and in the week following when the inflation producer price and consumer price numbers are released," he said.
The reaction to the Ford sales numbers may have been exaggerated because of the recent strike settlement with General Motors, Mr. Guild noted. "The market may have seen that settlement as a victory for labor and saw the specter of higher labor costs and the negative prices pressures generated that could lead to higher inflation," he said.
Mr. Guild added, "But I see nothing magical about 8 percent on the long bond, and bet that rates have to come down."
Others are not so sure. George Mateyo, chairman of Carnegie Capital Management in Cleveland, which has assets totaling about $3 billion, sees the Fed moving to raise rates again within the next 60 days. So in the meantime he says, "You try to structure yourself to take advantage of it."
Many traders and investors yesterday avoided making any large commitment amid concern that any one report -- notably this Friday's employment numbers -- showing economic growth is too brisk might prompt the Fed to raise short-term rates sooner, rather than later.
The 30-year bond fell 10/32 , to 9521/32 for a yield of 7.88 percent, up from 7.85 percent on Monday and the highest since June 10, 1992, when it was 7.89 percent. Shorter bill rates on the other hand were mixed, with the three-month issue up 3 basis points, to 4.94 percent, and the six-month bill down one basis point, to 5.37 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
Earlier in the day Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen, in opening remarks at the International Monetary Fund's annual meeting in Spain, said he was concerned about the worldwide rise in interest rates, but that long-term rates in the United States were still lower than was typical for this stage of the expansion. His statement did nothing to soothe the market's frail nerves.
Traders said that yesterday's report on the index of leading indicators for August had little impact on the market, since most of the data that made up the index were already known.
The index was in line with market expectations, posting a six-tenths of1 percent increase, the highest reading since March. Nine of the 11 components registered increases in August.
In the corporate bond market, traders said, Eastman Kodak's plan to buy back up to $4.8 billion in outstanding debt could eventually give a lift to Treasury securities, particularly the short end, if and when those bondholders reinvest that cash.
Dean Witter, Discover, a former unit of Sears, Roebuck, sold $895 million of floating-rate and fixed-rate debt backed by Discover credit card receipts at a price of par to yield 35 basis points more than the one-month London interbank offered rate, which international banks charge one another for loans. Late in the day yesterday, the one-month rate was at 5.125 percent.
In another financing as rates rose yesterday, Sears sold $522.6 million of fixed-rate securities backed by credit card receipts in two parts through Goldman, Sachs. An issue of $500 million of the fixed-rate securities with an average life of 2.88 years was priced at $999.51 per $1,000 of bonds to yield 7.38 percent. The remaining subordinated securities with an average life of 3.4 years were priced at $999.41 per $1,000 of bonds to yield 7.74 percent.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Mostly Trades Lower But Is Steady Against Yen

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar fell against most leading European currencies yesterday, following American bonds lower. But optimism about last weekend's trade accord between the United States and Japan kept the dollar steady against the yen. .
Prices of Treasury bonds fell yesterday after the Ford Motor Company reported a strong surge in vehicle sales in September. Such signs of a vigorous economy often disturb bond investors because rapid economic growth can produce inflation, which erodes the value of the fixed interest payments that bondholders receive. Currency traders, in turn, watch the American stock and bond markets to gauge foreign investors' appetite for assets priced in dollars. 
 "Lack of interest in U.S. assets will continue to hurt the dollar," said Peter Gloyne, manager of institutional foreign exchange trading at First National Bank of Chicago.
In late New York trading yesterday, the dollar fell to 1.5465 German marks from 1.5543 marks on Monday. The dollar dropped to 5.2815 French francs, from 5.3020 on Monday, and to 1.2845 Swiss francs from 1.2927.
The dollar held its ground against the yen amid optimism that a partial trade agreement signed on Saturday would prevent a trade war between the United States and Japan. The agreement is considered the first step toward curbing Japan's $60 billion annual trade surplus with the United States, a gap that many currency traders consider the source of the yen's strength. The surplus means that Japanese exporters have a constant supply of dollars to sell for yen when they send profits home.
Negotiators from Japan agreed Saturday to increase Japanese Government purchases of American telecommunications and medical equipment and to reduce barriers to American insurance and glass products. The agreement, coming after 15 months of difficult talks, narrowly averted an imposition of American trade sanctions on Japan.
"A partial deal is better than no deal, and it's certainly better than a trade war," said Karl Halligan, a trader at CF-CIC Bank New York. "The dollar looks a lot more stable now than it did a month ago, that's for sure."
The dollar edged up to 99.65 yen in New York trading yesterday from 99.57 yen on Monday.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Hog and Cattle Prices Fall As Supplies Remain Strong

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Hog futures prices fell to 14-year lows yesterday on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, as record supplies continued to flood the market. Beef futures prices also collapsed.
On other commodity markets, copper continued higher and coffee futures jumped, while lumber sank and energy prices finished lower. Grain and soybean prices were mixed. 
 The Commodity Research Bureau's index of 21 commodity prices fell 0.74 point, to 230.30.
October live hogs fell 1.05 cents, to 35.20 cents a pound, the lowest prices for a nearby contract since 1980, Charles Leavitt, a livestock analyst with the Alaron Trading Corporation in Chicago, said. However, February frozen pork bellies rose 0.45 cent, to 39.27 cents a pound.
October cattle fell 0.57 cent, to 67.95 cents a pound, and October feeder cattle fell 0.25 cent, to 72.70 cents a pound. Beef and pork prices are slipping in the face of record total supplies. Demand has been high this year but not enough to keep up with increasing supplies.
"We've got a situation where productivity is going bananas," Mr. Leavitt said. "Cows and pork are getting heavier, thanks to farmers trying to get rid of record supplies of corn and soybeans and nowhere to put all this meat."
Lumber futures prices plunged on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Figures this week pointing to a robust economy are prompting fears that the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates to prevent inflation. Higher interest rates would slow home building and sales, which leads to fewer lumber sales.
December copper on the Commodity Exchange in New York rose 0.85 cent, to $1.15 cents a pound, as industrial demand remained high.
December coffee on the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange in New York rose 4.55 cents, to $2.14 a pound, on continued dry weather in Brazilian growing regions.
Energy futures prices ended lower on the New York Mercantile Exchange, mainly on technical factors. November light sweet crude retreated 11 cents, to $18.08 a barrel. November home heating oil fell 0.49 cent, to 49.75 cents a gallon. November unleaded gasoline fell 0.32 cent, to 46.34 cents a gallon, and November natural gas rose 0.9 cent, to $1.69 for 1,000 cubic feet.
