HEADLINE: HOCKEY;
N.H.L. Revises Its Proposal To Players

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
Eleven days before Opening Night II, the National Hockey League presented its players with a revised proposal yesterday. Neither side offered details of the proposal, but a person familiar with the offer said it contained nothing the union could be expected to embrace as a way of ending the dispute.
Commissioner Gary Bettman made the revised offer in an effort to inject some impetus into the stalled talks and get the two sides moving toward an agreement that would enable the league to open the season on Oct. 15. That's the date Bettman set last Friday when he announced he was postponing the scheduled Oct. 1 start. 
 The person familiar with the alterations in the plan that would tax payrolls above the league average would say only that it gave the players a couple of points to check out. Another person said the league added a tax on gate receipts, borrowing from the players' proposal.
However, the first person said the proposal retained the maximum tax rate of 125 percent on payrolls that the union found offensive when the original proposal was made last week.
With the players essentially locked out of what they thought would be the first week of the season, when they would begin earning their salaries, they have chosen to stop working out. The urgency to forge an agreement thus becomes even greater because the longer it takes, the more time the players will need to brush up on their conditioning for league play.
Nearly seven hours after the negotiators resumed the talks that had broken off a week earlier, Bob Goodenow, the players' labor leader, held a short news briefing at the New York Hilton and said, "The league gave us a revised proposal to what they gave us last week."
Goodenow said the union would "analyze matters" last night and resume meeting with Bettman and his aides this morning.
"The best thing is we're going to be meeting again tomorrow," said John McMullen, owner of the Devils, who was one of four club representatives at the session.
Ronald Corey, owner of the Montreal Canadiens, said he liked the amount of time the two sides spent in discussing the revised proposal.
"They showed flexibility," Corey said.
How could he tell, since it was the owners who made the proposal?
"We discussed it a long time."
Unlike negotiations in previous years, owners and team executives had not attended bargaining sessions this year. But yesterday Bettman was joined by McMullen, Corey, Howard Baldwin, owner of the Pittsburgh Penguins, and Harry Sinden, president of the Boston Bruins.
"Having their presence is obviously a plus," Bettman said at his news conference. "It was important to me that to the extent they would be in a position to answer questions the players might have, they would be there. I had said previously we always would be happy to bring owners in. All they had to do was request it. This wasn't requested, but I figured what the heck, let's do it."
Goodenow said the owners' presence had "changed some of the communications, but I'm not going to get into that."
Bettman said the four men would attend today's session as well.
Goodenow and Bettman declined to characterize the talks or the proposal or the way in which it was revised. They said they agreed not to discuss it publicly.
Last week Bettman said the league had not made its best proposal. Asked if this was it, he said: "It's not realistic to respond to that in the course of collective bargaining. We made a proposal, the players are considering it. If this takes us down the road to a deal, it would be great."
When the negotiators met in Toronto last week, the league presented a new proposal, coming off a plan that would have levied two levels of taxes on team payrolls that rose above the league average. The first 10 percent of the amount over the average would have cost a team an equal amount, 100 percent, or a dollar for a dollar. Everything over that level would have cost a 200 percent tax, $2 for every $1.
The new plan also was a luxury tax but not as steep.
Under that plan, a team would be taxed 5 percent for every $250,000 over the average payroll, up to a maximum of 125 percent. Based on last year's payrolls, six teams would have been hit the heaviest under that tax structure.
The Detroit Red Wings and the Rangers would have paid the most, each contributing a sum equal to 20 percent of its payroll. The Red Wings would have paid $4 million on a $20.2 million payroll, the Rangers $3.965 million on a payroll of $20,172. The deductible would have been $14 million, the average payroll.
The money collected under any tax plan would be divided among the low-revenue teams. The league says it is imperative that these teams, such as Winnipeg, Edmonton and Quebec, be bolstered financially so that they can compete with the high-revenue teams.
"We need a system that will enable all of our teams to be competitive," Bettman said yesterday.
Nevertheless, it is not all that clear that all of the owners agree with that quest. Some owners have said their primary interest is in seeing to it that players' salaries are reduced. They say the escalation of salaries has inflicted the most economic damage on teams generally.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Bob Goodenow, the players' chief, arriving for talks in New York yesterday. He later had no comment on the new N.H.L. offer. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: ON PRO HOCKEY;
Help Us, Oh Help Us, We've Got Buildings

BYLINE: By Joe Lapointe 

 BODY:
One of the big issues in hockey's labor hassle is the suggestion that team owners share revenue. The players want the owners to redistribute some gate receipts so that wealthy clubs from big cities can help their less-fortunate partners in smaller markets.
The owners, represented by Commissioner Gary Bettman, have rejected the proposal, so far. Although they speak in generalities and provide few details, they insist they are losing money as a group, so why spread red ink? 
 Operators of two large-market clubs, the Philadelphia Flyers and the Montreal Canadiens, spoke recently of one major reason for keeping their cash to themselves. Both Ed Snider of Philadelphia and Ronald Corey of Montreal are building big new arenas with some 20,000 seats, trimmed with luxury boxes like frosting on cake. They say they need to pay for the buildings.
"I don't have any money to share," said Snider, adding that the Flyers lost "$3 million in cash" last season on revenues of $30 million.
"What do I have to share?" he said.
A skeptic might wonder about the $15 million Snider sent to Quebec in the 1992 Eric Lindros deal or about the $40 million a bank is paying him to put its name on Snider's new building.
When the National Hockey League Players Association looked at his financial statement two years ago, Snider said the union accused him of "hiding the money in the arena and the hot dogs and everything else."
He is offended at the thought.
"We're spending over $200 million to build a new arena," he said. "What's going to pay for it? The hot dogs! Not the players."
One reason for what Snider describes as his stretched financial state is that the Flyers haven't qualified for the playoffs for the last five seasons. Roughly two-thirds of N.H.L. teams make the tournament, where the biggest profits are made.
A business student might suggest that smart management succeeds and makes money while less-enlightened management enjoys less success, that there are always winners and losers in business, and that people who are failing should sell their business at a profit instead of investing in a new infrastructure.
Corey's Canadiens are considered among the shrewdest operations in hockey, and Corey has admitted "I made $8 million" in the last fiscal year. But he said the league already shares enough revenue from television and souvenir sales.
"We are making an investment of $200 million," he said, referring to the new Forum being raised in downtown Montreal. "My first objective is to pay for the building."
Moreover, he said, "you have to understand that not everybody has the same fixed costs," and that it costs more money to do business in places like Montreal and New York.
"We cannot see sharing gate revenue," he said. "Nobody's paying for my new building. We have no subsidies from anybody."
And what a fine new building it will be. It will have 135 luxury boxes, which sell for a minimum of $100,000 a year. All have been leased, and the leases will last 11 years.
Back in Philadelphia, Snider said the ones who suffer most are the fans.
"Every ticket in the lower level of the Spectrum is $50," Snider said. "I will not raise those tickets another dollar. We are pricing our great fans out of the game. My dream is when we open up that new building, to reduce ticket prices. Hopefully, the corporate revenues will give us enough revenue to do that for the average Joe out there."

 
 A student of elementary economics might suggest that most prices in a market economy are set by supply and demand. It might be suggested that if people keep paying $50 to see Snider's team not make the playoffs, the ticket prices will stay the same or go up, assuming that capitalism is working as it should. It will be interesting to see whether Snider makes good on his dream for the average Joe.
"This is about the fans," Snider concluded. "And it is about the players' meeting the owners halfway and solving the problems of this game."
Sounds fair enough. And it might help the fans and the players and the news media understand the problems of the owners if they would make public a little more financial data. Some sample questions:
What was your gross ticket revenue last season? What did you take in for luxury boxes? For advertising on signboards? For concessions? For parking? What were your operating costs, including salaries paid to members of the front office and to owners? How much did you take in from television and radio?
Are you including money from expansion teams as part of your financial statements? What is the line by line breakdown of your operating costs? What was your share of licensing revenue for N.H.L. products? What was your team worth when you bought it and what is it worth now?
Given enough data, the average Joe can add up the numbers.

HEADLINE: Quel Shock! The Italianization Of French Cuisine

BYLINE: By MOLLY O'NEILL 

 BODY:
FOR more than three centuries, France has set the international gold standard for fine restaurants. From lobster thermidor to beef Wellington, the nature of dishes was as immutable as the order in which each course was served, the arrangement of flatware as unyielding as the presence of sweet butter on the well-laid table.
So there is, understandably, much consternation at the growing Italian influence in haute bastions like Le Louis XV, Alain Ducasse's three-star restaurant in Monte Carlo. Increasingly, the menu offers more and more pasta, risotto and Italian-style vegetables. And last summer, the chef took the butter off the tables and set them with five different varieties of olive oil -- Italian olive oil. Quelle horreur! 
 "There are no borders anymore," said a retired inspector for the Michelin guide in Paris, who commented only on condition of anonymity. For a country that wears its epicurean superiority as proudly as some citizens wear their Legion of Honor pins, the blurring of national culinary borders is as inconceivable as the establishment of a single standard European currency.
Prominent chefs like Mr. Ducasse, Roger Verge and Paul Bocuse, who all admit a fascination with Italian cooking, are trend setters, crucibles in the continuing evolution of French cuisine. They acknowledge that the emergence of the casual Italian style in three-star restaurants may be due in part to its greater ease of preparation and lower cost.
But the consequences could be grave, the inspector said: it could eventually allow an erosion of the exacting French cooking techniques that are the bedrock of traditional cuisine.
Such fear wasn't fed by the last trend that rattled the haute table. With its Japanese influence, the nouvelle cuisine of the 1970's bred even more precision in the mighty galleys of France. Traditionalists bemoaned the style's wacky flavor combinations, and they chafed beneath the lightened sauces and unpredictable, idiosyncratic menus. But none feared for the future of French cuisine.
The Italian invasion is different. The increased use of olive oil and decreased deployment of butter in top French restaurants represents a change in cooking medium that strikingly affects the character of the dishes. The increased use of basil and tomatoes, of flat-leaf Italian parsley rather than the more delicate chervil, of garlic rather than shallots, transforms the flavor of dishes.
But traditionalists fear a change of mind-set more that a change of menu. The simple, direct Italian approach to cooking is antithetical to the precise, cerebral approach of classically trained French chefs.
"Italians are constitutionally incapable of complicating food, said Sirio Maccioni, the Tuscan-born owner of Le Cirque restaurant in New York. "It is against their mentality."
For the last decade, Mr. Maccioni has led dozens of notable French chefs, including Mr. Bocuse, Mr. Verge and Mr. Ducasse, on epicurean tours of Italy. "Tasting the wine, the Parmesan, the white truffles, the olive oil changed them," he said. "They began to appreciate simplicity." Gradually, Italian wines and white truffles crept into three-star restaurants.
Now, Mr. Ducasse said, "the Italian trend in French cuisine is spreading like an oil slick, an olive oil slick, of course."
He is proud to be in the vanguard of French chefs looking beyond geographic (and psychic) borders. "France has been too pretentious," he said. "Its refusal to listen to what's going on in the rest of the world is killing French cuisine. I am influencing a trend that is revitalizing cuisine."
But he is quick to add, "I am not an Italian restaurant!"
But of course. French chefs under the Italian influence remain, first and foremost, French chefs.
"We are still French, but now we are also European," said Mr. Verge, the owner of Moulin de Mougins and a consulting chef at the French pavilion at Epcot Center in Florida.
In his restaurant, as well as in his book "Roger Verge's Vegetables in the French Style" (Artisan Press), Mr. Verge's cooking has clearly crossed the Italian border. But along with other Francophiles who are enthusiastic about the growing Italian influence in French restaurants, he seeks to place this influence in a wider and less revolutionary-sounding context.
While some historians dispute the claim, it is popularly held by most French people that Catherine de' Medici brought the table fork as well as cooks and ingredients from Italy to France in 1533, when she married the man who would eventually become King Henry II, and that she introduced a seminal form of fine dining.
Even the historians who argue that the development of French cuisine wasn't instigated only by the culinary dowry of Catherine de' Medici acknowledge that her Florentine chefs brought superior ways with pastry -- a harbinger of culinary finesse -- to the French court. They also credit the Medici family with bringing artichokes, broccoli and savoy cabbages to the French table.
The historic exchange may account for the similarity between some French and Italian dishes -- as well as centuries-old disputes as to the origins of certain dishes. "Ravioli was originally from Nice," Mr. Verge said. "So was gnocchi."
Italian food historians like Faith Willinger, a cookbook author and owner of Cucina Toscana, a company in Florence that arranges custom food tours, point out that until the last century, Nice was a part of Italy. Nevertheless, French chefs under the Italian influence today employ such claims to emphasize their fundamental Frenchness.
Mr. Verge, for instance, doesn't deny that olive oil, vegetables and pasta have been given a new prominence on the French table. He merely hints that perhaps this is a renewal of a historic French tradition.
When Patricia Wells was gathering recipes for her Italian cookbook, "Trattoria!" (William Morrow & Company, 1993), she was struck by how closely many recipes echoed ones she had collected for "The Food Lover's Guide to France" (Workman, 1988). Ms. Wells said the similarities were strong, particularly in food from the south of France, which shares Italy's Mediterranean climate.
But the Italian influence is no longer limited to dishes served in modest bistros in the south of France. Mr. Ducasse said he could not think of one three-star restaurant in France today that did not offer a pasta dish and at least one dish prepared with olive oil. Moreover, a spate of Italian restaurants has opened in Paris, two of which, Paolo Petrini and Le Carpaccio, have become favorites of French chefs.
Ms. Wells, who is also the restaurant critic in Paris for The International Herald Tribune, calls these developments "a drop in the bucket." The French, she said "are never going to allow a major invasion of cuisine."
Jean-Yves Bonhommet, the editor of Saveurs, France's sleek and highly respected food magazine, agrees that "influence" should not be misconstrued as "invasion." In fact, he is uncomfortable with using the word "influence."
"I prefer to speak of 'co-existence of Mediterranean and French cuisine,' " he said. "How could one possibly cook a cassoulet with olive oil or serve Alsatian choucroute with olives? Some have tried, but with no great success."
He admitted that it was difficult to find a chef in France today who was not influenced by the Mediterranean but said that "one may think it Italian, but that is only because Italian cuisine has, more than any other, integrated the characteristics of Mediterranean cuisine."
In fact, dishes like Mr. Ducasse's ravioli made from bitter greens and even the vegetable compositions at Joel Robuchon in Paris are painstakingly precise, labor intensive French pronunciations of dishes from the Italian cooking vocabulary.
And noting this characteristic, Mr. Bonhommet said: "I am not at all worried about the future of French cuisine. On the contrary, it has blossomed in recent years."
Nevertheless, it is not clear that such French modulations will satisfy the growing appetite for Italian food in France or anyplace else in the world where "French cuisine" has until lately been synonymous with "the best." Part of that appetite, Ms. Willinger said, is the international impatience with the French "high-minded food for people who wear high heels" and the growing appeal of cooking that "is easily appreciated and best eaten in loafers."
Since tourists are significant supporters of top French restaurants, shifts in taste preferences are significant to three-star French chefs. And tourists and French nationals alike are less willing to pay dinner prices mandated by the enormous labor costs inherent in elaborate cuisine, the chefs interviewed said.
"There is a perception that Italian cooking is easier and more profitable," Mr. Verge said. He added that the shift to Italian techniques and ingredients began when the economics of restaurants began to tighten about 10 years ago.
While Mr. Verge maintains that cooking fine Italian food is as demanding as cooking fine French cuisine, strict traditionalists don't see today's Italian influence as the cosmopolitan touch to French cooking. They see it as the "dumbing" of cuisine.
"Anybody can make a plate of pasta," Julia Child, the American-born French cooking impresario, said in an interview last year. "You have to have some talent and training to make a fine French meal."
Even Mr. Maccioni has trepidations about the long-term effect of the trend toward Italian cooking in France today. The Italians, via Catherine de' Medici, may or may not have pushed the French to begin refining their cooking. But the French indisputably established the professionalism and technical expertise that, over the last 300 years, transformed fodder into cuisine. "If you create chefs who can make only pasta, pizza or a veal chop, eventually you lose an art," he said.
The international appetite for Italian food, he said, was in no small part nurtured in Manhattan, where over the last 20 years "Italian" has come to mean "elegant and hip and possibly healthy."
But he doesn't believe that Italian influence on French cuisine is economically determined. No, the fate of cuisine lies in the hands and palates of the cooks who train for about 20 years before presuming to call themselves "chef."
"The problem is that all they want to eat is Italian food," Mr. Maccioni said with the mixture of pride and remorse one would expect from an Italian native who owns a stylish French restaurant in Manhattan. "Oh, what have I done?"

LENGTH: 392 words

HEADLINE: Quit Stalling on Trade Accord

 BODY:
The symbolism was apt. In the front row at a White House rally this week for GATT -- the international trade accord that the House leadership will try to bring to a vote today -- sat Lawrence Eagleburger, Secretary of State in the Bush Administration, and Brent Scowcroft, its national security adviser. Free trade is a bipartisan policy and, after the cold war, the country's foremost foreign policy. Trade binds disparate nations and creates wealth; the GATT accord is expected to raise world income by $500 billion, and American income alone by $100 billion.
That is why it is important for the House to stop stalling and approve the GATT accord today. The Senate -- because of the unconscionable opposition of a single textile-belt Senator, Ernest Hollings of South Carolina -- must wait until after elections to vote. Once the U.S. ratifies the treaty, more than 100 other nations are likely to follow soon. But delay plays into the hands of protectionists abroad.
Besides die-hard protectionists, some environmental and consumer groups also oppose the accord. These opponents worry that international dispute panels, which oversee enforcement of GATT rules, might undermine U.S. health, safety and environmental laws. But the threat is mostly fictitious -- as a ruling this week by such a dispute panel convincingly proves. 
 The European Union challenged U.S. laws that penalize manufacturers of cars with low average fuel efficiency (known as CAFE standards), tax such cars and tax high-priced cars. These laws, the Europeans claimed, target sales of their cars.
The dispute panel rejected the European claims because trade laws permit tough environmental standards if they do not unjustifiably discriminate against imports. Environmental protection, then, is O.K. but protectionism disguised as environmental regulation is not. Indeed, the panel proved the point by rejecting one provision of CAFE that separately treated foreign-built cars in order to block imports.
Beyond this single ruling, U.S. laws are well protected. Few countries, if any, are likely to challenge American laws and risk a trade war with the U.S. The gargantuan size of the U.S. economy provides a protection no trade accord or dispute panel can ever strip away -- guaranteeing that the GATT accord will generate huge benefits and no important threat.

HEADLINE: Mourning in Sitcomville

 BODY:
It is a sad day in Sitcomville. To say this is not to belittle the human loss that her real-life family is experiencing at the death of Harriet Nelson in California this week. For Mrs. Nelson, her husband, Ozzie, and their sons, David and Ricky, were also inhabitants of a mythic electronic community.
It seemed vaguely Californian. People wore sweaters at all seasons, and the hedges were always healthy. Inside the house the geographic location seemed less important than its commercial orientation. The kitchen looked like the kind of place where Betty Furness would feel comfortable touting the appliances. The cabinets seemed to be hiding food products that deserved to be praised in the golden tones of Ed Herlihy. 
 The economic base of Sitcomville was hard to figure out for folks who lived in industrial towns with round-the-clock shift work. Except for William Bendix on "The Life of Riley," there did not appear to be many clock punchers in Sitcomville. There were no strikes and lots of time off. There was a feeling that Mr. Nelson and Ward Cleaver, the father of the newcomer family in "Leave It to Beaver," worked in the same vague, clean commercial enterprise. They made a fair amount of money and came home early to ask their wives about snacks for the fellas who were coming over to play cards that night.
As far as the nation was concerned, Ozzie and Harriet's main role was not economic but psychological. They made the world less dangerous. The night that Ricky was allowed to imitate Elvis did more than launch Ricky's recording career. It also assured all the parents who took cultural signals from the Nelson living room that the hip-shaking menace from Memphis was a safe product to bring into their own homes.
That turned out to be less than totally true, but Ozzie and Harriet can hardly be blamed for that. By the time the neighborhood got raucous ("All in the Family," "Maude" and the grandiose dysfunctions of "Roseanne"), their boys were grown and the Nelsons themselves were retired.
There were some attempts to bring back the old days in Sitcomville with the retro sunniness of "Happy Days" and "The Wonder Years." It was not quite the same. For one thing, the world would not stay as safely at bay as it did in the pioneer days in the video suburbs. In real life, Harriet Nelson lost Ozzie in 1975 and Ricky in 1985. She died in Laguna Beach, Calif., a nice enough place, but not nearly as comfortable as the town she and her husband invented for themselves and for America. It is an abandoned place now, its once proud bungalows, its shining kitchens, its flawless children and prattling couples exiled in the weedy back lots of Cableland.

HEADLINE: German Train Isn't the Fastest

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Germany's experimental magnetic levitation train is by no means the world's fastest at only 240 miles per hour, as you erroneously report Sept. 25. The French high-speed train, T.G.V. (train a grande vitesse), has bettered that speed on a number of occasions and attained 320.2 miles per hour during a test run in May 1990. Long sections of the new T.G.V. line south of Lyon were built for commercial service of 200 miles an hour at less than half the per-mile cost of the German Transrapid. 
 Since T.G.V. can also run on standard railways at lower speeds, the trains are not restricted to specialized, expensive rights of way as are all forms of magnetic levitation. The T.G.V. can enter urban areas on existing infrastructure and have access to many cities and towns served by rail lines.
One way to illustrate this would be to look at plans that have been developed for a Los Angeles-to-San Francisco, T.G.V.-style route, on which through service from off-line cities is contemplated.
True, the Germans have discovered how to lower the formerly very high energy consumption levels of magnetic levitation, but service to the many more areas that T.G.V. makes possible would lower total energy use for all transport modes, since travelers have deserted their automobiles and parallel airlines in great numbers wherever this service has been initiated.
This is one of the many reasons those Germans who are environmentally sensitive are fighting the use of $6 billion to build a single 170-mile Transrapid, when the same funds could easily pay for 500 miles of high-speed lines that are compatible with existing rail systems.
The already operational German high-speed ICE (intercity express) train does not go as fast as T.G.V. and is not as profitable; perhaps this has helped promote German enthusiasm for a shiny new attention-getter, whatever the cost to the environment. As in this country, the problems may be more psychological and political than technological.
In the United States, enormous Government subsidies to aviation and highway transport have long obscured the economy and efficiency of modern railways, which can easily outperform the other two inherently wasteful modes on a level financial playing field.
No wonder Southwest Airlines panicked when plans for a Texas T.G.V. were announced and used expensive lobbyists to defeat it.
One can only hope that recent news of worldwide climate shift because of carbon emissions will bring our "fly and drive" leaders to their senses.
 
JOHN LILLY
Washington, Sept. 30, 1994

HEADLINE: No Reaganomics Redux

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The return to Reaganomics espoused by most Republican candidates for Congress (editorial, Sept. 28) would saddle the Federal Government with huge debt increases and would jeopardize our economy. A balanced budget amendment is useless if combined with policies that add to the deficits. 
 Adam Smith warned in "The Wealth of Nations" that public debt endangers private wealth. The Republican core constituencies -- the wealthy and business executives -- would have the most to lose from the program that is advocated by those who would represent them in Congress.
 
ERNEST J. OPPENHEIMER
New York, Oct. 1, 1994

HEADLINE: Evolution of the Workplace Alters Office Relationships

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: RYE, N.Y.

 BODY:
The Giffnock Corporation, a small company just off Interstate 95 in Rye, N.Y., that rents office suites to itinerant business executives, is the kind of place that would give an organization man fits: it's a thoroughly modern office.
Most of the people working there are barely connected with one another. They work for large and small companies elsewhere or for themselves -- merely leasing their offices for a monthly fee. There's a foreign-currency trader for a big Wall Street brokerage house telecommuting in one office, just down the hall from a former I.B.M. executive trying to make it on his own. Freelance headhunters stalk the halls. 
 Giffnock's six employees exist in a new realm as well. They work at Giffnock (named for a small town in Scotland where the president's father was born), but all, including the president, George Russell, are employed by another company, which provides their benefits and signs their paychecks. They are leased employees.
"All the relationships that we've grown up with, they're all changed," Mr. Russell said.
Relationships are at the center of any workplace, and for decades the white-collar empires of the New York metropolitan area conferred stability and a certain predictable order on the universe of work. People made careers inside single companies, developed their internal networks and treated office mates as extended family.
But much of that universe is gone, management experts and psychologists say. Downsizing and layoffs have released tens of thousands of highly trained and educated executives onto the landscape, some of whom have alighted at places like Giffnock. Increasing reliance on temporary employment contracts, employee leasing and outsourcing -- where a whole department might be suddenly taken over by a specialized contractor -- have further fractured relationships, forcing people to reorganize their lives, make friends and relate to one another in subtle but fundamentally different ways.
"What's happening now is that people are feeling their way toward a new workplace and a new definition of what the corporation is," said Philip Anderson, an associate professor of business administration at Dartmouth University. "Whether you're downsized or outsourced, whether you're fired or continue to work, it'll be under a completely different relationship -- the idea of large numbers of white-collar people working in one corporation, moving up and getting a pension is a phenomenon of the 1950's that is drawing to an end."
Statistics support the view that businesses are becoming smaller, jobs more fleeting. In Manhattan, where large corporations still dominate the employment landscape more than just about any place in the nation, nearly 38 percent of the work force of 1.9 million in 1988 worked at a company that had 500 or more employees, according to State Labor Department figures. By 1993, that percentage had slipped to 33.9 percent.
At the same time, even as hundreds of thousands of jobs were being lost in the region, the numbers of temporary corporate cadres and leased employees were climbing. Between 1990 and 1993, 20,000 people joined the ranks of leased workers in New York and New Jersey -- a 17 percent increase in three years, according to the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics. The number of companies in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut that specialize in placing white-collar executives in temporary contract jobs has nearly tripled since 1990, to 45 from 16.
At Drake Beam Morin Inc., a Manhattan-based concern that specializes in "individual and organizational transition," displaced white-collar workers are told up front that any job they get, in any company, should not be expected to last longer than three to five years -- if they are lucky and they stay on their toes.
"People have got to look at employment as a temporary assignment," said Barbara Collins, a senior vice president and managing director at the company. "If not, they'll get sucked right back into the old paradigm. With companies changing so fast, the person who is going to survive in all this is the one who can change in a heartbeat."
Stories of survival and adaptation abound.
Take Steven Bitterman. A former employee of Chase Manhattan Bank, he still sits at his same desk at the bank's downtown Brooklyn operations center, surrounded by many of the same co-workers, doing the same work he did before as a controller for the telecommunications department. But now he works for the AT&T Corporation. Over a weekend this spring, Mr. Bitterman's department was outsourced to AT&T, which now handles the bank's communications operations.
"On the Friday we went home Chase people, and on Monday we came in AT&T people," he said. "Some people actually changed mid-shift, at midnight."
Mr. Bitterman, who is 50, said that after 16 years inside one company, quickly adapting to another company's culture was stressful but eminently preferable to unemployment. "There was a little bit of joshing," Mr. Bitterman said. "They said, 'Now you're one of them.' "
The transient nature of work in the new office environment has disrupted the way people make and keep friends. On the other hand, if people no longer envision working together for decades, they do not have the same incentives for cutthroat office politics, since a once-coveted job like a manager's is probably the most tentative now.
Rhonda L. Miller, a human resources consultant who lives in the Carroll Gardens section of Brooklyn, has been a migrant corporate executive since taking a voluntary severance package from the State Power Authority last year. Her network -- for friendship, support and business contacts -- is alive and well, but now it is mostly in her head and her Rolodex, friends who have stayed in touch and helped each other since leaving their jobs at the power authority.
The idea of long-term allegiance to any particular employer, she said, is obsolete. In the new world, informal associations of like-minded colleagues are everything.
"Where people used to be loyal to a company, now they're loyal to a profession," she said.
Another former power authority employee, Sandy Wells, a consultant in Austin, Tex., said the key to surviving in the fragmented office was to make friends in every job, because chances are you will meet somewhere else.
"It's not really a question of coming up through the ranks anymore," she said. "In a flattened organization, you jump."
Sometimes, the new order results in confusion. At Giffnock, a typist once complained that she was being sexually harassed on the job.
The accused harasser was not employed by Giffnock -- he was simply renting an office suite. And the typist, like all Giffnock staff members, also worked under the hybrid management -- Mr. Russell was her boss, but she was paid by International Charter, an employee-leasing operation, which also rents a suite at Giffnock.
Mr. Russell said he negotiated this jurisdictional jungle mainly through bluster. He and International Charter's president, Cleve Lynn, confronted the offender, who was apparently chastened.
Some companies take over the work of others while shipping out some of their own. Xerox, based in Stamford, Conn., has developed a niche by taking over other companies' mail rooms and print shops: sign the contract, and all your shipping, receiving and internal document production becomes a unit of Xerox. At the same time, the company has eliminated its telecommunications operation, outsourcing the operation to Electronic Data Systems, a unit of General Motors.
Freeport-McMoRan, a natural resources company in New Orleans, created a new company to handle its communications department and gave all the former department's 21 employees shares of stock in the company that now employs them.
"The boss, for all intents and purposes, who sits behind a 200-pound steel desk with a sledge hammer is dead -- and if he's not dead, we're all in trouble," said the new company's president, Garland Robinette.
Those experiencing these changes in the workplace voice a mixture of nostalgia, optimism, melancholy and ambition.
"It used to be that if you were with I.B.M., you'd bank with I.B.M. and have parties with I.B.M. -- I don't think that world exists anymore," said Douglas Shanks, who works on Long Island for I.B.M., which has been one of the region's most aggressive companies at trimming its staff and embracing new management and employment forms.
The price of those changes, Mr. Shanks said, is greater insecurity and probably some loss of company loyalty. The bittersweet reward is self-knowledge, he said.
"You immediately understand whether you have the right skills for the marketplace," he said.
Alan J. Klavans, a former senior vice president at Simon & Schuster, who rents an office at Giffnock for his one-man consulting and investment banking company, speaks fondly of the old days as well.
"I loved it at the time," he said. "I loved the Concord trips to England -- it's heady stuff."
And sometimes he feels that not so much has changed. He still works too hard.
"I told my wife I hadn't read a book in a while, and I didn't like it," he said. "I'm getting to be as busy as I was when I was with a big company."
 He was Steven Bitterman, a former employee of Chase Manhattan Bank, who still serves as a controller for Chase's telecommunications department but works for AT & T; he was not George Russell, president of the Giffnock Corporation.

HEADLINE: THE 1994 CAMPAIGN;
In Oklahoma's Senate Race, Both Candidates Are Running Against Clinton

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: OOLOGAH, Okla., Oct. 4

 BODY:
President Clinton is probably more unpopular in this state than in any other, says one of its Senators, David L. Boren, a Democrat who is retiring this year.
"When Bill Clinton ran for President, people here hoped he was one of them," Mr. Boren explained in an interview. "Our guy next door, they thought, New Democrat, a lot less liberal than Dukakis or Mondale or Carter. So he carried the state. Now they've decided he ran under false colors, and that has infuriated them." 
Which is why Representative Dave McCurdy, the Democrat who is running for Mr. Boren's seat, is so frustrated. The more he tries to suggest that he is a real New Democrat, unlike Mr. Clinton, the more his Republican opponent, Representative James M. Inhofe, portrays him as a Clinton clone.
If the President has a champion in Oklahoma this midterm election season, his voice is faint and his sword is dull.
Mr. McCurdy has not invited Mr. Clinton to come to Oklahoma to campaign for him. When he is asked whether he intends to, he replies that he has asked Garth Brooks, the country singer, instead.
A survey taken last weekend by Kielhorn & Associates, a Democratic consulting firm, put Mr. McCurdy six percentage points up; a poll completed only a few days earlier by Cole Hargrave Snodgrass & Associates, a Republican firm, gave Mr. Inhofe a five-point edge.
Gary Copeland, a political scientist and associate director of the Carl Albert Center at the University of Oklahoma, said he was "as confounded as anybody by the disparity." But he said he considered an Inhofe victory improbable because of the huge Democratic registration edge in the state and Mr. McCurdy's greater prominence.
The race here, one of a handful that will help decide which party controls the Senate for the last two years of the President's term, is like many this year, only more so. Few Democratic candidates are eager to embrace a President down on his political luck, and voters everywhere speak of their disillusionment with Mr. Clinton on questions like family values and personal responsibility.
"Every time the President has needed a vote," said Mr. Inhofe on Monday amid the heat and the din of the Liberty Glass Company factory in Sapulpa, near Tulsa, "Dave McCurdy has been right there with him -- on the budget, for example, and gun control."
Mr. McCurdy, a leader on Capitol Hill who succeeded Mr. Clinton as chairman of the centrist Democratic Leadership Council, said he had been disappointed by what he termed the President's "screwed-up priorities."
"I've been critical of him from Day 1 on foreign policy," Mr. McCurdy said. "He should have been concentrating on Russia, China, Korea, the Middle East, but instead he's been messing around in Bosnia and Somalia and Haiti. I wanted more spending cuts, and I sponsored alternative health care and welfare reform bills."
Oklahoma is a deeply conservative state, especially on what voters term "the morality issue," a heading under which they group questions about the President's private life and topics like abortion, homosexuals in the military and prayer in public schools.
Mr. McCurdy's longtime friend, Representative Mike Synar, whom he has known since their undergraduate days at the University of Oklahoma, was defeated in the Democratic primary last month, in part because he stood with Mr. Clinton on the unpopular side of several of the big social issues.
Now Mr. McCurdy faces a similar threat. He has to "make sure," he conceded, "that the voters understand that Mike is more liberal than I am, exactly as Clinton has turned out to be."
When Mr. Inhofe visited an immense power station owned by the Public Service Company of Oklahoma today, he encountered a parking-lot full of pickup trucks with bumper stickers like "Sayonara Synar" and "Ban McCurdy and Not Guns."
Inside the plant, in Oologah (pronounced OO-luh-gaw), a small town about 25 miles northeast of Tulsa and the birthplace of Will Rogers, Mr. Inhofe found plenty of support. Marcus Dennis, a technician who was wearing a black electrical workers' union T-shirt, said he would back Mr. Inhofe because of his opposition to abortion and to gun control as well as his support of prayer in public schools.
Wayne Watts, a maintenance mechanic who conceded that he knew little about either candidate, said he would vote for Mr. Inhofe. Why? "Clinton supports homosexuals, that makes me sick, and McCurdy's for Clinton," he said. "I can't stand Clinton's wife, either."
But a third member of their crew, Darrell Mitchell, pressed Mr. Inhofe on his opposition to the President's health care plan, asking again and again what the candidate would do "for the guy who makes seven, eight dollars an hour and doesn't get insurance." He said later he would vote for Mr. McCurdy "on economic issues."
Such issues are one of Mr. McCurdy's best weapons. He noted in a recent speech that only 4 of Oklahoma's 77 counties were at or above the national average in income, and while he makes a bow to social concerns by talking about the importance of families as building blocks for society, he also emphasizes the need for better technological education as a step toward economic growth.
Mr. McCurdy, a Pentagon stalwart on the House Armed Services Committee and a captain in the Air Force Reserve who served in the Persian Gulf war, sells himself as the best hope of retaining the jet engine repair center at Tinker Air Force Base. Threatened with closing, it is the state's largest employer with 13,000 workers.
In talking to voters and in his television commercials, Mr. McCurdy has also gone on the attack surprisingly early against his opponent's personal probity and record as a businessman.
One topic is a life insurance company inherited by Mr. Inhofe that failed in the 1980's -- because of the recession, Mr. Inhofe says; because it was run into the ground by dubious investments, Mr. McCurdy asserts.Another is a lawsuit that Mr. Inhofe brought against his brother over the family business, and a third is the $588,000 a Federal court ordered him to pay the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation in a dispute over a loan.
The character questions about Mr. Inhofe have been intensified by the recent disclosure that he received his degree from the University of Tulsa, not as he maintained in his published biographies, in 1959, but in 1973, when he was already in the State Senate.
Mr. Inhofe's somewhat uneven business experience has been echoed in his political experience. Before being elected to the House in 1986, he had failed in campaigns for governor, for mayor of Tulsa and for the House, and had been elected mayor three times.
Still, the Clinton problem haunts Mr. McCurdy. He said on Monday night that "without it, this thing wouldn't be close."
Picturing himself as a conservative Democrat like Mr. Boren, who has a reputation for independence of Mr. Clinton, Mr. McCurdy denounces Mr. Inhofe as a captive of the religious right. Mr. Inhofe has put up billboards asserting that Mr. McCurdy has voted with the President more often than Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts, another Democrat in jeopardy this fall.
Mr. McCurdy can cite his role in helping to kill the President's proposed B.T.U. tax, hated in this oil- and gas-producing state, which is chronicled at length in Bob Woodward's book, "The Agenda." He can cite his early opposition to an invasion of Haiti.
But his votes for gun control and for federally financed abortions remain liabilities, as does his prominent role in helping to make Mr. Clinton President.
It is widely remembered here that when Mr. Clinton was in trouble early in 1992, beset by Gennifer Flowers's accusations and by the story of his draft avoidance, Mr. McCurdy took his military credentials and his clean-cut aura to New Hampshire and stumped for Mr. Clinton. Eventually, Mr. McCurdy campaigned for Mr. Clinton in 37 states and delivered a seconding speech at the Democratic National Convention.
Mr. McCurdy sought a major job in the Administration, preferably Secretary of Defense, but he was passed over, and the Clinton staff spread the word that he had tried too hard. Soon, Mr. McCurdy was openly criticizing Clinton policies, declaring as early as May 1993 that the Administration was proposing too many taxes and too few spending cuts.
Since then he has been seen in Washington political circles as a maverick. His chances for the Senate depend largely on whether he can sell that picture of himself to the voters of Oklahoma.

CORRECTION-DATE: October 13, 1994, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Oct. 5 about the Oklahoma Senate election referred incorrectly to the state's vote in the 1992 Presidential election. George Bush, not Bill Clinton, carried the state.

HEADLINE: Utilities See Costly Time Warp In '78 Law

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS 

 BODY:
The 1978 law that shook the utility industry seemed like a good idea to Congress. Aimed at reducing the nation's use of imported oil by spurring the development of alternative energy sources, it requires utilities to buy power from independent generators.
Now the industry is saying that the prices set for that electricity more than a decade ago are so high that utilities are paying hundreds of millions of dollars extra for power they no longer need, hurting stockholders and raising bills to consumers. 
 Utilities around the country are petitioning their state regulatory commissions, which Congress left to carry out the Public Utility Regulatory Policies Act, to lower these costs or allow them to renegotiate contracts with the independents. Under the law, utilities are required to buy most of the power generated by the independent plants.
The impact is most acute in New York and California, states that had wanted to cut their dependence on oil and provide incentives for a new industry to compete with regulated utilities. In New York, utilities signed hundreds of long-term contracts with the independents at state-mandated rates of about 6 cents a kilowatt-hour.
The Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation, an upstate utility that serves 1.5 million customers, signed more contracts than any other utility in the state, but now says it generates all the power it needs and can buy more from other utilities at a rate of about 2.5 cents a kilowatt- hour. It has asked the State Public Service Commission for help in modifying the old contracts.
 "This is being watched by everyone in the industry," said Raymond E. Moore, the utility analyst for Dillon, Read & Company. "It could show whether regulators will provide a means for utilities to be able to adapt to competition."
The New York commission estimated this year that in 1997, seven of the state's utilities will pay $1 billion more because of the old contracts than if they were allowed to buy the power in the open market.
The independents counter that they risked capital to build the plants, in some cases enabling utilities to avoid spending billions of dollars to build plants themselves.
Lawrence J. Kostrzewa, senior vice president at Indeck Energy Services, which built a number of plants under the Federal law, including several with Niagara Mohawk, called the strategy similar to what many industries do -- enter into long-term contracts to buy commodities to guard against future price increases.
"They signed contracts that were a hedge against $40-a-barrel oil," he said. "Now they don't want to pay for the hedge."
When many of the early contracts were signed, oil prices were between $30 and $40 a barrel, with forecasts of big increases. And even as oil prices fell in the late 1980's, many analysts kept predicting an upturn. Instead, oil prices gradually declined further, hitting a low of $14 a barrel last year before recovering to about $18 this year.
State regulators around the country are trying to deal with the fallout from the policy. They must decide whether to grant relief to the utilities or continue to provide incentives to the independents, which have been responsible for 53 percent of the nation's new generating capacity in the last four years. About 7 percent of the electricity produced nationally comes from independents.
In 1978, the policy was seen as a logical response to the energy crisis earlier in the decade. Congress, trying to cut dependence on foreign oil, promised entrepreneurs who built generating stations that they could sell power to utilities.
The law required utilities to buy the power at a rate equal to what the utilities would otherwise have spent to generate it themselves. Many states set rates based in part on estimates of future oil and natural gas prices.
In 1979, before most states had established programs, the accident at the nuclear power plant at Three Mile Island, near Harrisburg, Pa., cast the future of nuclear power into doubt. Many utilities began to cancel plans to build nuclear plants.
As a result, the law also had the effect of giving these utilities a cushion of extra power to meet growing demand.
Then, as Eugene R. McGrath, the chairman of the Consolidated Edison Company, said recently, "The world changed."
Oil prices began to drop, and demand was much lower than expected. The long-term contracts that had set rates based on future fuel costs, with some projections of oil hitting $100 a barrel, no longer made sense to utilities. And with the recession in the early 1990's, utilities found themselves generating more electricity than they could sell.
"The projected demand and oil price contracts turned out to be much too high," Peter Bradford, chairman of the New York commission, said in a recent interview. He said the state was looking at ways to provide relief for utilities, such as reducing their state and local taxes or taking over the ownership of their high-cost nuclear plants.
In 1981, New York State had guaranteed independents a floor rate of 6 cents a kilowatt-hour. But in 1992, the state, then trying to reduce the program's impact, eliminated the floor rate for new contracts. No major new deals have been negotiated since then, but hundreds of old long-term contracts are still in effect.
But utilities fear that the high price they pay for power under those contracts will make them less competitive if the industry is eventually deregulated and customers can shop around for cheaper electricity. California is considering a move toward deregulation and other states may follow.
 In California, regulators are still pressing the major utilities to enter into new independent contracts, even as the state's utilities have excess capacity and can buy cheap power from other utilities out of state.
The struggle with these contracts is considerable at Niagara Mohawk Power. It receives electricity from about 150 independent generators, which supply about 29 percent of the utility's power.
Niagara Mohawk estimates that this power costs it an extra $350 million a year. That $350 million has been passed on to customers as higher rates, and the company estimates that as a result, its customers pay about 12 percent more for electricity.
A few weeks ago, however, the staff of the New York commission recommended that such pass-throughs be limited and that Niagara Mohawk begin absorbing some of the contract costs.
"Taking such an action would devastate the financial viability of the company," William E. Davis, the chairman of Niagara Mohawk, said in an interview. "These costs were largely imposed on us by the state government."
Wall Street, however, does not care whose fault it was. Its reaction was quick. Within a week of the staff's recommendation, Niagara Mohawk's stock price had dropped more than 20 percent, from $15.50 a share to $12. The Standard & Poor's Corporation and Moody's Investor Service put the company's bonds on credit watch. The stock closed yesterday at $13.125, down 25 cents.
What riles Mr. Davis is that the same commission promoted the use of the contracts in the 1980's, brushing aside warnings from management at the time.
William J. Donlon, a former Niagara Mohawk chairman, sent a letter in 1987 to Mr. Bradford, the commission's chairman, warning that the utility was getting locked into more contracts with such plants while it could buy power elsewhere at about half the cost.
Typical of such projects was a plant that Indeck Energy proposed in 1988, which would burn natural gas and provide steam for an International Paper Company plant in Oswego, N.Y. Indeck's excess power was sold to Niagara Mohawk under the state program for about $20 million a year.
Ralph Leidy, the manager of the Indeck plant, said that it ran at capacity most of the time because Niagara Mohawk had to take all the power the plant generated.
"The more efficiently we run, the better the profits for the company," he said.
The utility estimates that unless it can renegotiate contracts with Indeck and others, its customers will pay about $3 billion more for power between now and the year 2008.
Consolidated Edison is in a similar bind. The company decided about three years ago to buy out some of its contracts, paying independents about $170 million not to build six plants that would have provided it with 580 megawatts of power. Mr. McGrath, Con Ed's chairman, estimated it would have cost $150 million more annually for the next 20 years had the utility bought the power.
But such contract buyouts cause much debate because regulators must decide whether the costs should be passed on to customers or shouldered by shareholders.
Abraham Glezerman, chief executive of Inter-Power, an independent power producer in Colonie, N.Y., said that instead of trying to kill new plants and long-term contracts, utilities should close their old, polluting coal plants and nuclear plants that produce high-cost power.
"We can produce electricity better, cheaper and with less pollution," he said.
 Niagara Mohawk Power, 11.4 cents; Consolidated Edison, 14.5 cents; New York State Electric and Gas Corporation, 11.8 cents; Long Island Lighting, 16.8 cents; Orange and Rockland Utilities, 14.3 cents; Rochester Gas and Electric. 11.4 cents; Central Hudson Gas and Electric, 11.3 cents.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
The U.S. and Japan are happy, but the trade truce is fragile.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
DETERMINED American trade negotiators bargained into the wee hours with their equally determined Japanese counterparts and, miracle of miracles, both sides went to bed happy. For what Gary Saxonhouse, an economist at the University of Michigan, calls "an artful compromise" allowed both to claim victory at a moment neither could afford defeat.
The catch is that the agreement does nothing to dispel the myth that Japan and America are engaged in a Darwinian economic struggle one or the other must lose. And that virtually guarantees continuing friction over trade. 
 The agreement marks a timeout in the bitter trade confrontation between the Clinton Administration and a series of weak Japanese governments. It began with a demand by the White House that Japan set numerical targets for growth in imports -- a demand justified as the only way to get the wily Japanese to keep their promises, and resisted as a step toward carving world markets into government-directed cartels. It was settled with some practical moves to assure foreigners a better shot at the Japanese markets for medical and telecommunications equipment, insurance and plate glass.
What makes the agreement artful is that it also gave American advocates of managed trade a symbolic victory without guaranteeing market shares or rates of import growth. In insurance, for example, the Japanese agreed to speed approval of new sorts of policies and allow independent brokers to serve as go-betweens -- measures that should increase American sales because American insurers lead the world in marketing savvy. Medical equipment, largely purchased by the Japanese Government, is to be judged by quality as well as price, a move seen as giving American makers of super-expensive, high-tech gadgetry a leg up on Japanese competitors.
The big concession to the managed traders is to consider the pact successful only if imports rise. But that is well short of the infamous deal that divided the Japanese market for computer chips in the 1980's. For one thing, it does not require more regulation of private enterprise. For another, the growth of Japanese imports is nearly a sure thing anyway because the overvalued yen buys so much more abroad than it does at home.
Not surprisingly, spin masters on both sides are working overtime to extract earthshaking news from modest events. Prime Minister Tomiichi Murayama's unwieldy coalition, facing increasingly organized opposition from reformers, needed to prove their leader could stand up to Washington. President Clinton, bloodied in the health care battle, needed a victory to stave off a Republican sweep in the November elections and to keep alive prospects for ratifying the GATT pact.
Spin, however, can only go so far to obscure some unpleasant realities. Japan's rejection of imported auto parts on the ground of consumer safety plays into the worst fears of Japan-bashers: very, very few auto injuries in America are related to mechanical failure.
By the same token, notes Robert Z. Lawrence, an economist at Harvard's Kennedy School of Government, America's reluctance to take the case to the new World Trade Organization advertises a lack of commitment to rules-bound dispute resolution. Indeed, the day America announced the investigation of Japan's unfair trade practices in auto parts, a GATT panel ruled in favor of Washington in its dispute with Europe over mileage standards for imported cars.
In Mr. Lawrence's view, there is an almost tragic tendency for America and Japan to talk past each other on trade matters. Just as Japanese policy makers seemed to accept the idea that it was in Japan's long-term interest to deregulate markets, he notes, America embraced managed trade as the trade cure of last resort.
Most disturbing is the apparent decision by the White House to minimize the impact of the only Japanese action likely to reduce the trade imbalance noticeably: a delay of a sales tax increase that had been proposed to offset scheduled income tax cuts. That delay will stimulate domestic purchasing power, diverting Japanese goods from export markets and sucking in imports.
Japan would probably have postponed the tax increase, with or without American pressure: higher consumer taxes are anathema to the left wing of Mr. Murayama's ruling coalition. Still, the American silence is evidence of how few movers and shakers in the Clinton Administration understand the overriding importance of fiscal and monetary measures in balancing trade -- and how those who do have given up trying to explain the point to Congress or the public.
All this augers poorly for relations with Japan. Exhausted negotiators have retired to toast their accomplishments in defending domestic interests. But the truce is fragile, and bound to be shattered before long if Americans persist in blaming Japanese perfidy for their economic ills.

HEADLINE: THE 1994 CAMPAIGN: PATAKI;
Pataki's Tax-Cut Plan: How to Pay for It?

BYLINE: By TOM REDBURN 

 BODY:
How much can New York afford to cut state taxes?
With just a little more than a month before the election, that question encompasses the central debate between the two major candidates for governor. And at the heart of that debate is the question of how the Republican candidate, State Senator George E. Pataki, can pay for his plan to slash personal income taxes, saving taxpayers at least $5.6 billion a year by 1998. 
 Mr. Pataki says it can be done by curbing the growth of state spending. But his own campaign promises would make that difficult, if not impossible, many experts say. The only places left to find the money he needs, they say, are in government support programs for the poor and economic development subsidies for big business.
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo agrees that taxes should be reduced but has delayed releasing all the details of his own, much more modest, $1.5 billion tax-cut proposal in an effort to keep the focus on Mr. Pataki's plan.
Mr. Cuomo, who yesterday termed the Pataki plan "a con job," insists that it would inevitably push local taxes higher to make up for lost state revenues. Of his own tax plan, the Democratic Governor said yesterday that he would reduce the top income tax rate for most people, but he declined to say how he would pay for it. [Page B13.]
To independent analysts, significant tax cuts may be within reach, but only if Albany is prepared to reduce spending across a wide array of popular government services that in the past have proved largely immune to attack. The job is made much more difficult because the state itself only spends directly about a quarter of the money it raises; most of the state's money goes for local school aid and to localities and nonprofit organizations for social services, including Medicaid.
"How many state troopers can you cut?" said Michael Brooks, a former state budget analyst who said he is a Democrat but who worked for a Republican state comptroller. To reduce state income taxes by as much as Mr. Pataki wants, said Mr. Brooks, now a municipal bond specialist at Sanford C. Bernstein & Company, a Wall Street investment house, "the only place you're going to be able to achieve savings of that magnitude is by cutting state aid to education. And if he's not prepared to cut there, where is he prepared to cut?"
Indeed, on the campaign trail, Mr. Pataki seems to be finding it a lot easier to add than subtract. He has vowed to increase state support for schools, avoid cutting aid to local governments, provide property tax relief, bolster law enforcement, even restore some previously lost funds for day care. Yet, to fulfill his promise to cut New Yorkers' top income tax rate of 7.875 percent to 5.9 percent over the next four years, Mr. Pataki says he must prevent government spending from growing faster than the rate of inflation.
How is all that possible? Other than suggesting a few relatively painless cuts in state patronage jobs and a crackdown on waste, fraud and abuse in Medicaid and welfare, Mr. Pataki is not yet saying.
The unacknowledged prime target, Republican supporters of Mr. Pataki say, must be billions of dollars to be squeezed from the costly Medicaid program that provides health care for poor people, nursing homes for many not-so-poor people and a host of other medical services for the mentally ill and disabled. "There is no good reason," Mr. Pataki said last week, "why Medicaid should cost three times as much per patient in New York as it does in California."
Edwin S. Rubenstein, an economic columnist for National Review who is close to those who are running the Republican campaign for governor, said that reining in Medicaid spending -- while long overdue -- would not come without pain.
"New York has the most generous eligibility rules and provides more optional services than any other state," Mr. Rubenstein said. "So cutting back does not mean you have to bash the poor. But it would affect the medical establishment and the more affluent. The income rules on nursing homes, for instance, have become so easy to get around that Medicaid has become an unacknowledged entitlement for the middle class. That's not just unneccessary, it's immoral."
So far, however, in decrying Medicaid's excesses, Mr. Pataki has carefully avoided specifics. Instead of saying which services now provided by Medicaid would be eliminated, or whose benefits should be reduced, he has proposed administrative reforms that his staff says would save perhaps $300 million. But the program currently costs the state $6 billion, and that cost is increasing at least 10 percent a year. (Albany and local governments, which now pay more than $4 billion a year, share the expense of half of the cost of Medicaid that is not paid by the Federal Government.)
"Something has to give," said Steven Gold, director of the Center for the Study of States in Albany. "On the spending side, I don't see how you get from here to there."
To meet his vow to keep the growth in state spending under the rate of inflation -- expected to average about 3 percent a year -- Mr. Pataki would have to put Albany in a fiscal straitjacket. He said that is exactly what he intends to do.
"I will put in place a real cap on state spending," he said. "We are no longer going to add up all of the spending demands of every special interest in Albany and then raise taxes on the hard-working people of this state to pay the tab."
But a look at the state budget shows the difficulty of keeping spending in check. In the fiscal year that runs through March, the state plans to spend $43.3 billion of what it collects in taxes and fees. To keep spending from outpacing the expected inflation rate, next year's budget could not exceed $44.6 billion, giving the state as much as $1.3 billion extra to spend.
That may sound generous, but all of it and more would quickly be chewed up by commitments that the state cannot easily escape and promises that Mr. Pataki has already made.
To begin with, $10 billion comes from special assessments dedicated to particular purposes like road building and mass transit, making it practically impossible to cut the spending without also cutting the revenue that supports it.
Beyond that, the state is already obligated to start paying back pension funds, at a cost of almost $170 million next year; to provide an extra $169 million for preschool children of the handicapped, and to increase school aid by an additional $166 million.
Mr. Pataki's campaign promises are also adding up fast. At a stop in Manhattan on Monday, for example, he told Republican legislators that he wanted state support for local schools to keep rising as it has over the last decade, or roughly double the inflation rate. "I would like to see education aid increase," he said. "I want to see us do everything we can to remove the burden from the property taxpayer, particularly for the funding of education."
To increase the $9 billion Albany now funnels to schools by 6 percent would add more than $500 million to the state budget next year. That alone would eat up 38 percent of what Mr. Pataki would allow spending to grow by.
Adding it all up, the state faces a potential budget gap of at least $2 billion next year and more than $3.5 billion by the fiscal year that starts in April 1996.
"Unless the economy booms in an unprecedented way," said Frank Mauro, executive director of the labor-supported Fiscal Policy Institute, which traditionally has opposed tax cuts, "the next several years will bring more of the same: a structural deficit that undercuts both the programs that allow the state's neediest residents to keep their heads above water and the services essential to the quality of life for all, while putting unwarranted pressure on the regressive property and sales taxes upon which local governments must rely."

HEADLINE: Cuomo Unveils a Few New Tax-Cut Details

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BUFFALO, Oct. 5

 BODY:
With a trickle rather than a splash, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo continued to disclose some details about his tax-cutting plans today, proposing a cut in the top personal income-tax rate that he said would benefit almost all the New Yorkers who pay that rate now.
The Governor proposed lowering the top tax rate to 7 percent from its current level of 7.875 percent for middle- and upper-middle-income earners, a reduction that eventually would be worth $600 million. But he would not say how long it would take to phase in the cut or what spending he would eliminate to pay for it. 
 The cut would bring the top tax rate to the level promised in a 1987 law signed by Mr. Cuomo. The last phase of that three-year reduction has been deferred by Mr. Cuomo and the Legislature for five consecutive years because of the recession.
Mr. Cuomo also said today that he wanted to lower the state's tax on utility revenues from 4.25 percent to 2 percent and to insure through state laws that the gains would be passed along to ratepayers.
At the same time, Mr. Cuomo unleashed a blistering attack on State Senator George E. Pataki's more ambitious tax-cutting plan, calling his Republican rival's proposal "a con job" that would devastate local governments and schools.
Mr. Cuomo argued that Mr. Pataki's assumption that New York's revenues would grow at 6 percent next year is transparently faulty and suggested that the Republican is promising tax cuts he knows he will not be able to deliver.
"I will not cheapen our government and insult your intelligence by trying to fool you with empty promises so I can win the right to disappoint you next year," he said.
Mr. Pataki, who spent the day campaigning in Staten Island, the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn and Maspeth, Queens, responded: "Mario Cuomo has no credibility on the tax issue, coming up with a plan four and a half weeks before the election. It's a plan that sounds like he just made it up in response to ours."
Also today, Democratic officials said that former Mayor David N. Dinkins would endorse Mr. Cuomo in Manhattan on Thursday. Mr. Dinkins has said for months that he planned to endorse the Governor, but the enthusiasm of the former Mayor's embrace -- or the lack thereof -- may send an important signal to black voters and other Dinkins loyalists in New York City.
Mr. Cuomo spoke today to several hundred people in an auditorium at the Roswell Park Cancer Institute, a state facility where the state Dormitory Authority is financing $241 million in renovations and new construction. Mr. Cuomo has showcased the hospital and research center in a campaign advertisement.
The Governor had originally planned to fully outline his tax-cut plan in today's speech. But in a strategic decision, he drew back in an effort to keep attention focused on the plan that Mr. Pataki unveiled last week. The Cuomo campaign has depicted that plan, which promises tax cuts worth $5.6 billion a year by 1998 in a general-fund budget that is currently $32 billion, as an irresponsible and cynical play for votes.
Mr. Pataki has said that some top taxpayers would see their taxes drop by 25 percent. But he has provided only the vaguest information about how the state would afford such a massive reduction in revenues.
Mr. Cuomo told reporters after his speech that he preferred to let the news media continue to explore that question, rather than engaging in a tax-cutting duel.
"It hasn't really been fully explicated," he said of Mr. Pataki's plan. "I want to give him plenty of room. I don't want to get you all busy with my detail before seeing his, you know."
And yet, Mr. Cuomo made incremental progress in outlining his own plans. His speech marked the fourth time since August that the Governor has revealed pieces of his plan without fully explaining it.
He first disclosed that he would cut taxes up to $1.5 billion over an unspecified period. Then he announced that one of the taxes he would cut would be the gross-receipts tax on utilities. Then he announced that his other two tax cuts would be a reduction in the personal income tax for some payers and an increase in the income-tax credit for those with high property taxes. He still has not provided any detail about that element of his plan.
Under the income-tax cut Mr. Cuomo proposed today, the top income-tax rate would drop to 7 percent for married taxpayers with taxable incomes above $26,000 but below $100,000, and for single taxpayers with incomes above $13,000 but below $50,000. Currently, all married taxpayers who earn more than $26,000 and all single taxpayers who make more than $13,000 pay the top rate of 7.875 percent on income above those levels. Under Mr. Pataki's plan, the top rate would drop to 5.9 percent by 1998, and the top tax bracket for a married couple would rise from $26,000 to $50,000.
