HEADLINE: Mayor Moves To Cut Role Of Legal Aid

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

 BODY:
Striking Legal Aid lawyers returned to work yesterday, but Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani insisted that he would not restore the nonprofit Legal Aid Society to its position as the primary defender of the poor in the city's packed courts.
Contending that the city should not be subject to lawyers' strikes, Mr. Giuliani said he would be looking for alternative arrangements to the Legal Aid Society in some city courts, suggesting that new options could be tried in Queens and Staten Island. 
 "We will not be having a primary, singular service deliverer for accused criminals who want representation or even indigents," the Mayor said.
Several leaders of the city's municipal unions, who had watched the tug of war, expressed relief that the strike had ended without broadening into a long, polarizing labor confrontation. But one union leader conceded that the Mayor had won a victory that would make bargaining more difficult next year when all municipal contracts come up for renegotiation.
"It makes our fight tougher," said Arthur Cheliotes, the head of Local 1180 of the Communications Workers of America, which represents about 10,000 city administrators.
Although Legal Aid lawyers work for the Society and are not city employees, the Society gets $79 million a year from the city, and the Mayor had said he would not accept wage increases during a time of fiscal hardship. Instead, he said he would cut off the city's 28-year contract with the Legal Aid Society.
Disillusioned and grim Legal Aid lawyers spent much of their day back at work yesterday arguing among themselves, many admitting that their strike had boomeranged to the advantage of the Mayor. [Page B7.]
The Mayor declined to endorse the tentative contract agreement hammered out Tuesday night between the lawyers' union and the Legal Aid Society, under which the lawyers would receive bonuses of 2 percent in each of the next two years.
"If there's room for a raise then that would mean there's probably room for a reduction in the amount of money that we supply for the Legal Aid Society," Mr. Giuliani said, "unless it can be demonstrated to us that's going to be done through productivity, with the productivity first demonstrated and produced rather than paid for up front."
At a union meeting last night, the lawyers voted 544 to 150 to accept the agreement. Participants said there had been emotional speeches both to accept the contract and to return to the strike.
"We're the best lawyers in this city," said Michael Z. Letwin, the president of the lawyers union. "We take pride in the fact that these lawyers represent poor people not for the money but because we believe in it."
The lawyers, seeking a 4.5 percent wage increase over two years, walked off the job Saturday after their contract expired. But confronted with an ultimatum by the Mayor to return to work or be replaced, union leaders agreed to a deal Tuesday night that was close to the offer they had originally rejected.
The average salary of the lawyers is $45,000 a year.
The bonuses in the new contract are similar to what the Legal Aid Society had previously offered. But while the management had sought higher payments by union members for health care, medical payments would remain at about current levels in the first year and then be submitted for arbitration the following year.
"I think this is a much better package than the original," said Mr. Letwin, the union president. He said his members also won some non-economic concessions such as a union management committee to examine workloads in some areas.
Still, it was far from clear whether Mr. Giuliani would approve the new terms, and whether Legal Aid would end up with anything near the city financing it had before the strike caused the Mayor to terminate the city's contract. Last year, the society received $79 million from the city for criminal work alone and provided the lawyers to represent about 60 percent of indigent defendants.
The Mayor said yesterday that the city might not provide enough money to Legal Aid to pay for the bonuses it had negotiated with the lawyers and the raises planned for its managers. "It may very well be that the city can save money by not funding all that," he said, adding, "It leaves a lot of options open."
The Mayor did not explain further how he would find other lawyers for the poor, and Katherine N. Lapp, his criminal justice coordinator, said it was "premature" to say what options would be considered. On Monday, the Mayor had said the city could consider setting up a public defenders office or contracting for lawyers with the city bar association.
Paul S. Goldstein, the president of the Queens County Bar Association, said that he had had no inquiries from the Giuliani administration. "We have an active private bar which may distinguish us from other counties," he said. "But to contract with us on a fee basis, I don't know, because we'd have to see what they're prepared to spend."
Many indigent defendants are already represented by private lawyers who charge the city by the hour under what is called the Assigned Counsel Plan. Their bills were expected to reach $50 million this year. But several months ago, the Giuliani administration had proposed giving the bulk of that criminal caseload to the Legal Aid Society in a cost-saving effort.
In a letter sent to the Legal Aid Society last night and released publicly by the Mayor, Ms. Lapp said the administration would also require that any new agreement with the Legal Aid Society include a provision granting the city the right to impose penalties if lawyers strike and a clause requiring "that lawyers who breach their ethical obligations to clients be terminated." Mr. Giuliani had called the strike a breach of ethics.
Ms. Lapp has said that the lawyers who return to work will be paid at the rate of the existing contract while the administration negotiates with the Legal Aid Society. She said, "This payment arrangement can continue only until such time as either new contracts are negotiated or we are unable to amicably agree upon future contractual relationships."
Pat Bath, a spokeswoman for the Legal Aid Society, said that if the city substantially reduced the size of its contract with the society, it might have to dismiss many of its 1,131 lawyers. "He would be telling us we won't have as much work and then we wouldn't need as many people to do as much," she said.
But Mr. Letwin, the union leader, expressed confidence that Legal Aid would still prove the best alternative for representing indigent clients. "We think it's clear that the society's the most cost-effective and best quality in the city," he said, "and I think we have a lot of allies on that."
The showdown between the Mayor and the Legal Aid lawyers came at a time when the city faces a $1 billion budget gap this year and multi-billion-dollar annual deficits for the foreseeable future. Mr. Giuliani used the strike to emphasize that he would be granting no wage hikes for several years, unless paid for through increased worker productivity.
Ruth W. Messinger, the Manhattan Borough President who had rallied to the side of the striking lawyers, yesterday accused the Mayor of using the lawyers' dispute to distract the public. "There are major budget problems afoot and perhaps the Mayor's looking for a way to keep his and everyone's mind off of them," said Ms. Messinger, a Democrat who is considered a potential challenger to the Mayor in 1997.

HEADLINE: G.S.A. Chief Undergoes Inquiry Into Use of Staff

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5

 BODY:
One of the highest-ranking Republicans in the Clinton Administration, Roger W. Johnson, is being investigated after he was accused of using top aides for personal errands.
Mr. Johnson, who heads the General Services Administration, the Government's chief landlord, is under investigation by his agency's Inspector General. He has been accused of using subordinates to carry out personal tasks for him, like taking his Mercedes to the car wash. 
 In a statement released today, the agency officials described Mr. Johnson's troubles as "inadvertent actions occurring during his transition from 35 years as a private sector executive to public service."
The statement said, "As Mr. Johnson became aware of any actions which were inappropriate, he took full responsibility for the infractions and insured that similar actions did not recur."
Mr. Johnson became the agency's administrator in July 1993 after spending a decade as president and chairman of the Western Digital Corporation in Irvine, Calif. He had been a regular contributor to Republican candidates but broke with the party in 1992 over its economic policies.
Besides the taking of his car to be washed, the investigation is looking into accusations that Mr. Johnson used agency employees to wait at his home for deliveries and repairmen, and to handle his personal correspondence.
Agency officials declined to comment further because of the investigation. For now, the White House is taking a similar approach to the matter.

HEADLINE: Markets Plunge, but Dow Loses Only 13.79

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
American and European financial markets shuddered yesterday, with United States stock and bond markets plummeting so far and so fast as trading in New York opened that their counterparts in London, Paris and Frankfurt, nearing the end of their sessions, suddenly buckled.
After falling as much as 53 points, the Dow Jones industrial average recovered late in the day and closed at 3,787.34, down 13.79 points, for only an 0.36 percent drop. But the damage was already done. British stocks fell 1.5 percent, German stocks, including after-hours trading, dropped 2.16 percent, and French stocks plunged 2.26 percent. 
 Bond prices fell and yields rose sharply to smoke out buyers, who nonetheless continued to refuse to buy bonds in volume. The benchmark 30-year Treasury bond came perilously close to an 8 percent yield, finishing at the end of the day in New York at 7.95 percent, up from 7.88 percent.
Bond yields across Europe soared, with French yields reaching a 22-month high and German yields a 25-month high.
The worsening market performance in the United States is coming ahead of what is normally market-moving economic data, like the monthly unemployment figures due tomorrow, the Producer Price Index due Oct. 13 and the Consumer Price Index Oct. 14.
And the American outlook -- characterized by a weak dollar, rising yields for bonds and sharply declining stock prices in heavy trading -- has spread to Europe at a time when local factors, like German political uncertainty, were already driving stock and bond prices down there.
The nub of traders' anxiety on both sides of the Atlantic, some anlaysts say, is the Federal Reserve's decision last week to forgo raising interest rates, contrary to what many traders had come to expect.
Traders are thus anticipating the next rate increase by bidding down the prices of stocks and bonds to cushion the blow of the expected interest-rate action. But the most pessimistic of traders seem to be imagining ever-darkening worst-case scenarios and thus refusing to buy either stocks or bonds.
The source of the market pessimism is clear. With a steadily lengthening list of Government and private-sector reports indicating a quickening rather than a slowing economy, traders are wondering whether the Fed is "behind the curve" and too slow to act against inflation. The more pessimistic traders now see two Fed rate increases by year's end, rather than one, as expected only two weeks ago.
Tomorrow will be an especially nerve-jangling day for the financial markets because the Labor Department releases data on job creation. A number close to or above 300,000 new nonfarm payroll jobs in September could indicate enough economic strength that the Fed may have to raise rates immediately, said Neal M. Soss, co-founder of Soss & Cotton Enterprises, a market research and private investment firm. While stock and bond prices are sure to plummet, traders may find themselves feeling better because the Fed had finally acted.
"The market will want a number that is cathartic," Mr. Soss said. "If it isn't cathartic, if it's ambiguous, then it will just fill the market with dread and foreboding."
The Dow fell so far and so fast that the New York Stock Exchange's "circuit breaker" rules, designed to slow high-speed computer-guided trading, kicked in at 12:29 P.M. But the Dow, as well as the Standard & Poor's 500 and the Nasdaq composite index, spent the rest of the day recovering lost ground.
By the end of the day, the S.& P. 500 fell only 1.07 points, to 453.52, and the smaller-company Nasdaq fell 1.02 points, to 746.28.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was above normal, with 360.3 million shares changing hands.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index fell 1.10 points, to 250.36, with advancing stocks lagging declining stocks by 543 to 1,761. The American Stock Exchange market value index fell 2.70 points, to 451.11.
Of the 30 component stocks that make up the Dow industrials, 19 fell, led by Alcoa, which dropped 1 3/4, to 82 3/4. Of the 500 component stocks that make up the S.& P. 500, 302 fell, led by AT&T, which lost 3/8, to 52 1/4.

HEADLINE: New Study On Jobs: Good News To Whitman

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 5

 BODY:
A quickening pace of job growth is helping New Jersey lead the region out of the recession, but the job recovery lags behind the national growth rate. That's what two Rutgers University economists told an audience of New Jersey business people here today.
The figures compiled by James W. Hughes and Joseph J. Seneca for the State Data Center's annual economic conference are good news for Gov. Christine Todd Whitman. If current trends hold, the two predict, the state will have recovered all of the 262,000 jobs lost in the 1989-92 recession by early 1997, the year Mrs. Whitman could be expected to run for re-election. 
 The economic update, which attracts business people from around New Jersey, is an annual event of the state's economic statistics service, which is part of the State Department of Labor. Those who attended the conference also heard presentations today from the state's business development agencies and from Governor Whitman's special panel to improve New Jersey's business climate. Today's event therefore had the quality of an economics seminar with a distinct whiff of business boosterism.
From May 1993 to May of this year, New Jersey ranked 35th among the states in job growth with an annual rate of 1.6 percent, while New York ranked 46th with 0.8 percent growth and Connecticut, beset by defense industry cutbacks, ranked 48th with 0.4 percent growth. The national average for the same period, however, was 2 percent, and it was that robust level of job creation, at better than three million new jobs a year nationally, that helped pull New Jersey along, Mr. Hughes said.
New Jersey's recession bottomed out before New York's did, Mr. Hughes said. And the Garden State has also profited from the diversity of its economy in pharmaceuticals and financial services, while also developing a lead in specialized services like architecture and engineering, he said.
This year has been the second year of recovery from the recession, which lasted from early 1989 through March 1992 in New Jersey, longer than for the nation as a whole. The latest figures, Mr. Hughes said, show an acceleration of job growth in construction and services, and an end, for now at least, to the decline in manufacturing jobs that has been a feature of the state's economy since the 1950's.
"This is the year a boomlet threatens to become a full-scale boom," Mr. Hughes said. "We're being swept along by a potent level of national job creation, and we've been helped by a housing recovery that is an area where we benefit from suburbanization."
The state's highest growth in employment came in the suburban fringe counties of Somerset and Ocean, while New Jersey's urban counties continued to lag.
Because of the overall improvement in the state's employment health, Mr. Hughes said New Jersey had entered "a post-nightmare economy." Since the end of the recession two and a half years, the state has made back about 47 percent of the jobs lost.
Mr. Hughes spelled out just how bad the nightmare was: the 262,000 jobs lost in the recession amounted to about 7 percent of New Jersey's total employment between 1989 and 1992. The losses were 10 times the number lost during the previous recession, in 1981 and 1982, and the recovery, in turn, took far longer.
But Mr. Seneca noted that New Jersey had managed to keep its relatively high level of personal income despite the recession. The state's per capita personal income, which stood at 31 percent above the national average in 1989, was still at 29 percent above at the end of last year.

HEADLINE: Opponents Successfully Challenge Hoboken Rent-Control Limits

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: HOBOKEN, N.J., Oct. 5

 BODY:
An effort to relax rent control on vacant apartments in small buildings in Hoboken has been stymied by tenant advocates, very likely forcing the issue onto the ballot for voters to decide.
Invoking a New Jersey law allowing citizens to challenge local ordinances, opponents of the measure last week filed a petition blocking an amendment to the city's Rent Control Ordinance that would have let landlords charge market value for some regulated apartments that become vacant. Now the measure goes back to the City Council, which can repeal it or set a referendum. 
 Cathy Cardillo, a member of the Campaign for Housing Justice, a tenant advocacy group, said, "The Council has not shown, by statistics or any other way, any harm to homeowners" under the 21-year-old rent-control law .
Mayor Anthony Russo, however, defended the decontrol, which was approved by the City Council early last month. "I thought we should give small homeowners an opportunity to get market value for their property," he said. Mr. Russo attributed the challenge to "a very small group of people," adding, "It's the democratic process at work."
The measure would cover owner-occupied buildings with up to four units in Hoboken, a city of 30,000. While landlords are now limited to a small annual cost-of-living increase they could increase rents to market value for the affected apartments.
Opponents claim the measure would give landlords economic incentive to evict rent-controlled tenants and that it is the first salvo in an effort to completely eliminate Hoboken's 1973 Rent Control Ordinance.
Supporters of decontrol, however, said it was intended to provide economic relief to small landlords, many of whom have been suffering under the impact of property-tax increases and other rising costs.
"Homeowners need some relief, and not at the cost of existing tenants," said Michael Buoncristiano, the president of the Hoboken Homeowner's Alliance. "That's what this amendment does."
Apartments in small, owner-occupied buildings account for one-fourth to one-half of the city's nearly 12,000 nonsubsidized rental units, depending on who is asked.
The Mayor said that based on his own observations and on census figures, he thought the new measure would affect only higher-income residents who he believed could easily afford market-value rents.
Between 1980 and 1990, median rents in Hoboken increased by about 230 percent, according to the Census Bureau.
"This is in part due to landlords' skirting the rent-control law altogether," Ms. Cardillo asserted. "Most people in Hoboken don't even know they are rent controlled."
Apartments rented to households with income of more than $20,000 increased to 7,601 in 1990 from 2,786 in 1980, the Census Bureau said.
"It's for small homeowners who stuck out the years of blight before the economy and the quality of life here improved," the Mayor said of the decontrol measure.
But tenant advocates say the current law allows rent increases for legitimate expenses like higher property taxes or renovation. "If there's a problem with the rent-control law, fix it," said Dan Tumpson, a principal behind the challenging petition. "Don't destroy the law."
Tenant advocates said the Council ignored their input on decontrol. City officials denied this, saying they amended the measure before passage to add language preventing landlords from gaining higher rents by arbitrarily evicting rent-controlled tenants. But Ms. Cardillo contended that loopholes remained.
If the Council schedules a referendum, it would probably be in December or January.
Citizen challenges of local actions have occurred several times in recent years in Hoboken. In 1988, the City Council repealed a vacancy-decontrol measure after tenants' groups filed a similar petition. In 1990 and 1992, voters rejected a city-sponsored project for development of the waterfront after a similar citizen petition opposing the plan.
The citizens acted under a section of the state's Municipal Government Law under which opponents of new local ordinances can submit petitions to challenge the law.

HEADLINE: U.S. Pledges Over $1 Billion in Aid Projects for South Africa

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5

 BODY:
Answering Nelson Mandela's pleas to help South Africa's fractured economy, the Clinton Administration announced today that it would provide loan guarantees to build housing, begin sending Peace Corps volunteers and set up investment funds to generate more than $1 billion in projects.
As part of President Clinton's efforts to support Mr. Mandela's cause, O.P.I.C., the Overseas Private Investment Corporation, unveiled two new equity funds, totaling $150 million, which aim to produce $1.3 billion in investment. 
 The Agency for International Development announced $150 million in loan guarantees to build housing and electrification projects as well as a $100 million enterprise fund to help South Africa and neighboring countries. Andrew Young, the former mayor of Atlanta, will oversee that fund, which will provide money for small and medium-sized companies to expand.
At a joint news conference on the South Lawn of the White House, President Clinton said, "President Mandela, you can be certain that the United States will continue to do everything in our power to support the new nation you and your South African people have created and now seek so strongly to build."
With all the new aid programs announced today, several Administration officials estimated that aid to South Africa would climb above $700 million over the next three years. Mr. Mandela's two-day state visit here is part of a weeklong trip to the United States.
During the visit, President Clinton repeatedly hailed Mr. Mandela's remarkable journey from prison to the presidency and pledged stepped-up support to South Africa. For his part, Mr. Mandela repeatedly extolled Mr. Clinton's qualities as a leader.
At a White House luncheon given for Mr. Mandela and the Congressional Black Caucus, the South African lavished so much praise on President Clinton that the American leader appeared to choke up for a few seconds.
"I must say that to have a strong leader, highly competent but with a common touch, who worries himself about the needs of the people, is a species that is very rare in the world today," Mr. Mandela said, gesturing to his American counterpart. "In our President here, we have a man who is endowed with such virtues, with such qualities. And the world is rich as long as he remains the President of this country."
This morning, Mr. Mandela met with Vice President Al Gore to complete details for a new cooperative commission on which Mr. Gore will serve as co-chairman along with Thabo Mbeki, the South African Deputy President. The commission will bring together Cabinet members of both countries to give a high-level boost to projects involving energy, education and economic development.
The United States has set up such a commission with only one other country, Russia.
Encouraged by Administration officials, President Mandela announced today that he would meet on Thursday in Washington with Haiti's exiled President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide.
The Clinton Administration has quietly urged the South African leader to meet Father Aristide in the hope that Mr. Mandela's singular success at promoting reconciliation in his bitterly divided country could serve as a model for Haiti and could reassure President Aristide's opponents.

HEADLINE: Inquiry on Rental Car Sales

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Oct. 5

 BODY:
Detroit's Big Three auto makers said today that they were cooperating with a Justice Department investigation of their sales to rental car agencies, but denied any wrongdoing.
The General Motors Corporation, the Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Corporation were first notified of the probe in July. 
 Executives of the auto makers said the inquiry centered on whether they had cut back on repurchase incentives to independent car rental companies.
Gina Talamona, a Justice Department spokeswoman in Washington, said the department was investigating certain auto sales practices, but declined to elaborate.
Ford controls the Hertz Corporation and has a financing arrangement with Budget Rent-a-Car Inc. G.M. has an equity stake in Avis, and owns National Car Rental System, which it recently agreed to sell to an investor group. Chrysler owns the Dollar and Thrifty rental chains and recently sold Snappy Rent-a-Car.
Some rental agencies have asserted that auto makers will no longer buy back vehicles -- an incentive used during the recession to sell off car inventories.
"Some of the smaller rental operations are complaining that we are not repurchasing enough vehicles from them," a Ford spokesman, Bill Carroll, said. "Our contention is that we do provide a lot of vehicles to them. Some we repurchase and some we don't." He said Ford required a minimum purchase of 100 cars for a repurchase agreement.

HEADLINE: New Orders At Factories Climb 4.4%

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5

 BODY:
Factory orders and shipments surged at the fastest rate in more than a year during August, the Commerce Department said today, fanning fears that a strong economy may soon force interest rates higher.
The value of orders received by manufacturers jumped 4.4 percent, to a seasonally adjusted $286.5 billion, after falling a revised 2 percent in July. 
 Not only was it the strongest monthly gain in orders in more than a year and a half, but the report said finished goods were also shipped at the fastest rate in 15 years, especially popular new cars.
"It adds to the impression accrued over the past couple of weeks that the economy is on pretty firm ground," said Dick Berner, an economist at the Mellon Bank in Pittsburgh. "The notion that it is slowing down is being deflated rapidly."
Although the central bank did not raise rates when its policy makers last met on Sept. 27, a string of strong economic data leading up to the September employment report, scheduled for Friday, has set financial markets on edge.
Every recent indicator, including September new-car sales, August new-home sales and personal consumption expenditures have shown strong rises that suggest credit-tightening so far has not been enough to deter consumers.
A Federal Reserve governor, Lawrence B. Lindsey, told a bankers group in Atlanta today that policy makers were determined that inflation "is never going to get in the headlines" before it applies another dose of preventive medicine.
The rise in August factory orders was the strongest since December 1992, when they gained 5.6 percent, the department said. Orders have been up in 11 of the last 13 months.
Shipments of manufactured goods, which reflect more immediate demand than orders, increased 4.5 percent in August -- the largest for any month since May 1979, when they were up 4.7 percent -- after a decline of 1.1 percent in July.
Previously, the Commerce Department said July factory orders had fallen by 2.3 percent.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
A Declaration of Chip Independence

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 5

 BODY:
Seven years ago, when the United States semiconductor industry was reeling in the face of a Japanese invasion, American chip makers persuaded the Government to establish a groundbreaking federally financed manufacturing consortium intended to resurrect their industry.
The argument was that by investing in manufacturing technology, it was possible to reverse declining United States market share for the fingernail-sized circuits that were increasingly being viewed as the crude oil of the information age. 
 Today, with American chip companies not only leading the world again but also expecting to control about half the $77.3 billion global semiconductor market by the end of the year, the consortium, Sematech, declared its national mission accomplished. At a news conference in Washington, leaders of the consortium politely thanked the Government and said they would wean themselves off Federal financing -- now $90 million a year -- by 1997.
The group, to be financed solely by industry money, intends to concentrate not on "national industrial policy," but on the nuts and bolts, and microscopic circuits, of the chip maker's art.
Does Sematech prove the case for a national industrial policy -- the practice of using taxpayers' money to revitalize American industries under threat from foreign competitors? Not necessarily, because there were other, arguably larger, economic and market forces contributing to the United States semiconductor resurgence.
But the Sematech example indicates that when the Government allows -- indeed, encourages -- industry leaders to collaborate, the national economy can benefit.
"My hope is that the model of government, industry and university cooperation will have proved so effective that more government programs in the future will want to follow our example," William J. Spencer, Sematech's president and chief executive, said in a telephone interview today.
Sematech's members are 11 of the nation's biggest chip makers, including Intel, I.B.M., Motorola, National Semiconductor and Texas Instruments. Since the founding of the consortium, the Government has invested $690 million, while the members together have matched that amount, with companies' contributions based on their annual revenues.
On the face of it, the group has overseen an astounding industry comeback. In 1988, Japanese companies controlled 46 percent of the market, compared with 43 percent for United States concerns. Currently, American companies supply 48 percent of the world's semiconductors, while Japanese companies provide 36 percent.
While Sematech can rightly claim some credit for this reversal, the chip industry has received a great deal of help from larger technological and international trends.
Continued American control of the personal-computer industry has helped United States chip makers act as standard-setters. Meanwhile, the slowness of the Japanese semiconductor giants like NEC and Toshiba to move beyond commodity memory chips and excel at making more lucrative "brain" microprocessor chips, has been a drag on Japan's world market share. At the same time, South Korean memory chip makers like Samsung have put new pressure on the Japanese. And the rising value of the Japanese yen has benefited chip makers in the United States and Europe.
Still, most American semiconductor industry executives now seem willing to call Sematech a success -- something that might not have been predicted in the late 1980's, when the consortium stood at the middle of a fierce debate about whether the Government should be in the business of picking winners and losers. Even some formerly bitter enemies of Sematech now seem prepared to wish it well.
"My last major objection to Sematech was that they were on the Government dole," said T. J. Rodgers, president and chief executive of Cypress Semiconductor, a chip maker in Santa Clara, Calif. "So I now say more power to them."
Because his mid-sized company chose not to pay the $1 million minimum membership fee to join Sematech, Mr. Rodgers said he was originally angered because Sematech seemed to be locking up American-made chip-making equipment only for its 11 members. Thus, Mr. Rodgers saw his company as under attack from the very Federal money that had been designated for saving American semiconductor companies. But that policy changed, he said, in 1991, after Mr. Spencer, the former vice president for research at the Xerox Corporation, took over as head of Sematech.
Other chip makers that are not part of Sematech say the Government's money has been well spent. "We've wasted a lot more money more fruitlessly than on efforts like Sematech," said Bernard Vonderschmitt, president of Xilinx, a small Silicon Valley chip company. But, Mr. Vonderschmitt cautioned, "it's dangerous to extrapolate that we are better off now simply because of the investment."
Indeed, there were some glaring errors made in Sematech's effort to save chip makers and producers of chip-making equipment.
A notable and costly failure was the 1993 collapse of GCA. The company, based in Andover, Mass., was a leading maker of a multimillion-dollar tool called a stepper -- one of the most critical elements in chip making. Three years earlier, GCA had been one of only two American stepper makers left in a market that was dominated by two Japanese companies, Nikon and Canon.
Using $60 million of Sematech's money, GCA developed a new line of steppers that would have catapulted the company into the forefront of the technology wars. But the project was a year late and GCA did not have Nikon's reputation for good service. Even Sematech members preferred to continue using Japanese steppers.
The project failed and GCA's parent, the General Signal Corporation, shut the operation last year.
"It was a perfect example of how Sematech failed to understand the political and business issues," said G. Dan Hutcheson, president of VLSI Research Inc., a Silicon Valley firm that tracks the chip industry. "They approached GCA as a technology problem and not as a market or a business problem."
Sematech officials say they are doing better with the remaining American stepper company, Silicon Valley Group Lithography of Wilton, Conn.
One point on which there seems to be little debate is that by focusing on manufacturing, Sematech created a new kind of esprit de corps and pride within the American chip industry. And the results paid off in better efficiency and higher quality.
For Mr. Hutcheson, the most striking proof is the fact that even Japanese companies now point to the quality of American factories. One of NEC's most productive chip factories, for example, is in Roseville, Calif. It surpasses all the company's Japanese manufacturing sites in terms of productivity and is second by that measure only to an NEC plant in Scotland.
During the period when Sematech was devising ways to beat Japan, "the Japanese were sitting on their laurels, praising themselves for the strength of Japanese manufacturing techniques," Mr. Hutcheson said. "They made the same mistakes we made during the 1980's."

HEADLINE: Javits Center Inquiry Says Workers Have Mob Ties

BYLINE: By JAMES BARRON 

 BODY:
Despite repeated efforts to curb corruption at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center, a court-appointed investigator charged yesterday that 100 carpenters who put up and take down most of the displays there are hired by union officials with connections to organized crime.
The investigator, Kenneth Conboy, said in a report that "an alarming number" of the 100 carpenters also appear to have connections to the Genovese crime family. In addition, the report said, about a third of them have been arrested or convicted of crimes ranging from arson to drug trafficking to murder. 
 The union's employment practices mean higher costs for exhibitors, who have complained about labor expenses and frequent shakedowns since the glass-enclosed Javits Center opened eight years ago.
In 1990, Federal prosecutors described the Javits Center as a hiring hall for mobsters and former convicts, who earn more than $60 an hour. They are often assigned, at time-and-a-half rates, to work at night, on weekends and on holidays, assembling or disassembling displays under tight deadlines.
Some 125 to 400 people -- carpenters, electricians, teamsters and laborers -- work at the center daily, depending on the size of the shows and meetings scheduled. Mr. Conboy's report charged that because the Javits Center regularly hires only the 100 carpenters on a "pool list," the union's 30,000 members are effectively locked out of jobs that are considered virtually recession-proof.
Unlike construction jobs, which all but disappeared in the recession, most convention centers boomed. In part because of high labor costs, however, the Javits Center lost business.
Mr. Conboy's report said that the way the carpenters are hired violates a consent decree that Judge Charles S. Haight Jr. approved in Federal District Court in Manhattan in March.
That agreement settled a civil racketeering suit filed by the Government in 1990 against the union, the District Council of New York City and Vicinity of the United Brotherhood of Carpenters and Joiners. At the time, prosecutors said that the accord would limit the power of union officials to assign members to jobs.
But Mr. Conboy's report said that the tainted system at the Javits Center persisted even after the consent decree was signed. The report said that the 100 carpenters on the pool list for the Javits Center are hired "before any jobs there are referred to rank and file members of any of the local unions."
The day-to-day hiring decisions are made by two union stewards with little experience as carpenters but extensive mob connections, the report charged. It said that one, Anthony D. Fiorino, is the brother-in-law of Barney Bellomo, who is believed to be the acting boss of the Genovese crime family.
The other, Lenard J. Simon, is the brother-in-law of Ralph Coppola, a convicted arsonist with mob ties, the report said. Mr. Simon, an unemployed taxi driver, told Mr. Conboy's staff that he had joined the carpenters' union at Mr. Coppola's urging, falsely declaring that he had extensive construction trade experience.
Mr. Coppola handled the work referrals at the Javits Center until August 1991, when Frederick W. Devine, the district council president, dismissed him as the Javits Center steward, quoting the racketeering suit about his connections to organized crime.
Since then, Mr. Conboy said in the report, "President Devine has sought to avoid responsibility for the procedures governing the allocation of work at the Javits Center by testifying that he is largely unaware of matters involving the center, has been on the premises only a few times, and did not even know Messrs. Simon and Fiorino (except by their first names) when he made them the District Council's handpicked representatives" there.
The report also said that Mr. Devine testified under oath that he had selected the two men "without any knowledge of their relationship to Coppola and Bellomo," despite the fact that the ties were mentioned in newspaper articles and in the racketeering suit. Mr. Devine was himself a defendant.
"According to President Devine," the report said, "he did not see the newspaper articles, only read very selective portions of the complaint and selected Messrs. Simon and Fiorino because Fabian Palomino, the president of the Javits Center, brought these men to his attention."
Mr. Palomino did not return calls for comment yesterday.
Mr. Conboy's report said that Mr. Fiorino and Mr. Simon had invoked their Constitutional privilege against self-incrimination when interrogated by Mr. Conboy's investigators. They refused to answer any questions about contacts or conversations with organized crime figures, including Mr. Bellomo and Mr. Coppola, or the employment of organized crime associates at the Javits Center.
Bernard Cohen, the general counsel for the district council, said that he had not read Mr. Conboy's report. But he attacked Mr. Conboy, a former Federal judge in Manhattan whom Judge Haight appointed when the consent decree was signed.
"He'd be far better off trying to work on what he's supposed to be doing, which is to root out corruption," Mr. Cohen said of Mr. Conboy, "as opposed to looking to battle windmills where there are no crimes committed."
Mr. Cohen said that Mr. Devine had repeatedly asked Mr. Conboy for proof of allegations that Mr. Fiorino and Mr. Simon were organized-crime figures, not just relatives of organized-crime figures by marriage.
As for the list of carpenters who are hired regularly at the Javits Center, Mr. Cohen said it has 800 names, not 100, and will be expanded by the end of the month to include everyone in the union.
But the report said that the expansion was a bogus reform, because the union is imposing new requirements that could exclude all but the 100 workers now on the job. Carpenters hired for the Javits Center must now have at least three years' experience in handling large trade-show displays.

HEADLINE: Banks Give Russia Time On Loans

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Oct. 5

 BODY:
Russia agreed with its foreign bank creditors today on a deal to postpone repayment of $26 billion in loans, relieving a little of the pressure on the nation as it struggles toward a market economy.
The agreement followed a year of negotiations that came down to whether Russia should be treated as a developing country or accorded first-world status. The logjam was broken only after the banks dropped a demand that they be free to seize Russian Government funds and property around the world if Moscow defaulted on the loans. 
 Russia argued strenuously, and ultimately successfully, that it deserved the same "sovereign immunity" from such actions enjoyed by the world's richest nations.
Deputy Prime Minister Aleksandr N. Shokhin, Russia's chief debt negotiator, called the agreement "an important vote of confidence from the international financial community."
The deal, which must be ratified by Russia's 600 lenders around the world, requires a $500 million payment to the banks by the end of this year. After that, Russia will have a five-year grace period during which it will not be required to pay either interest or principal on the loans, which were made before the Soviet Union broke up at the end of 1991.
After the grace period, Russia will have to pay off the loans in twice-yearly installments over 10 years. Unlike most other nations involved in debt-restructuring deals, Russia neither sought nor was granted any reduction in the loan principal.
The main creditor banks are German, including Deutsche Bank and Dresdner Bank. Today's announcement affects American banks only marginally because whatever loans they made to Moscow were tied to trade deals, and not made directly to the Government.
"The agreement reached today indicates considerable progress toward reaching a final agreement, but the impact on U.S. banks will be minimal," said James H. Mitchell, a spokesman for the Bank of America.
Before the agreement, Russia was reported to have fallen $2 billion behind in interest payments to the banks. In delaying repayment, the accord gives the cash-pressed Russian Government a little more leeway at a time when it is struggling to hold on to the considerable economic gains it has made over the last year.
Inflation, which fell to 4 percent in August from 22 percent in January, bounced up in September to a range between 6 and 8 percent, depending on the calculation. The ruble, which seemed to have stabilized earlier in the year, has been plunging in value the last several weeks, and traded today at 2,808 to the dollar, down 36 percent in a little over a month.
Russian budget planners, hoping to bring their huge deficit under control, are seeking big cuts in subsidies to ailing industries and farms, but business lobbies and unions are exerting tremendous pressure to retain or increase the subsidies.
The agreement should also remove an element of uncertainty about Russia from the calculations of foreign banks that are considering making new loans to rapidly expanding Russian private businesses.
The deal with the banks is part of a broader debt-restructuring effort undertaken by the post-Soviet Government. It agreed to assume the Soviet debts, but argued that it should be given some leeway in repayment by Western governments and banks as it dismantles the central economy and tries to establish democracy and capitalism.
In addition to the $26 billion in bank debt, Russia owes foreign governments and other creditors nearly $60 billion. The governments have agreed several times in recent years to postpone interest payments, including $7 billion due this year.
Although the Russian Government could not immediately provide details, Russia by some estimates faced interest and principal payments this year of nearly $30 billion in the absence of any restructuring agreements, but was able to budget only $4.5 billion for debt service.
Western economists said it was far from certain that Russia would ultimately be able to repay all its debts, as much would depend on the course of the economy and on President Boris N. Yeltsin's ability to keep the nation on a reformist track.
The breakthrough on bank debt came after two days of meetings in Madrid between the creditors' group, led by Deutsche Bank, and Mr. Shokhin. Many leading bankers and government finance officials are in Madrid for the annual meeting of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund.

HEADLINE: METRO MATTERS;
If Ars Is Really Longa, Is New Money Brevis?

BYLINE: By Joyce Purnick 

 BODY:
IT sounded like a great idea in its first incarnation. It still sounds, for those who value the arts, like a great idea. But it is no longer as advertised. Little in government ever is, actually. Reality has a funny way of getting in the way.
The original suggestion came in February when the cultural world, starved for government money, proposed a way of loosening up public dollars: give us $10 million in matching money if we raise our own $10 million in private donations. This proved to be an irresistible proposition to elected officials. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yes, so did the City Council and the State Legislature, and the Cultural Challenge Initiative was born. 
 There is only one hitch.
Though there was never any question that the cultural institutions were supposed to match the public money with new money -- an increase over 1993 -- few now say they have succeeded in doing so, and apparently they do not have to.
The application for a challenge grant does not specifically ask if the money represents new or higher contributions, and officials of both the City Department of Cultural Affairs and the State Council on the Arts indicate that they are prepared to be flexible. Which means that a number of New York's cultural institutions could share $10 million from the government, money that might have gone to other needs absent the compelling prospect of aggressive, private fund-raising.
"THE whole initiative is to encourage additional and/or new activities," said Schuyler G. Chapin, City Commissioner of Cultural Affairs. "Because it is essentially a new initiative, we are encouraging new money. But it is not a program that requires new money in every sense of that word."
John Dyson, Deputy Mayor for Finance and Economic Development, said he'd wait to see the grant applications later this month before passing judgment. "The Mayor is unequivocal that we are providing new money for new money," he said. And if arts groups do not provide new funds? "To the extent I can find it out, the city won't fund them. But money is fungible, and that's the problem."
Defining "new," suggested Nathan Leventhal, president of Lincoln Center, "is not as simple as it seemed." Apparently not. For instance, if a group got $1,000 from a foundation last year, and $1,000 this year but is applying that money to the matching grant, is that "new" money or an accounting device? "I think what one could say is, even if it is the same old money, as long as it's really there, it's in a sense new," said Rochelle Slovin, director of the American Museum of the Moving Image. "For those of us in the trenches, every time we get a grant from a corporation or foundation, for us, it's new."
AVAILABLE money, she and others suggest, is limited. "We deal with finite resources," said Robert Crane, vice president for programs at the Joyce Mertz-Gilmore Foundation. "We will make $2 million in grants next year. We don't have a way to say, 'God, this is wonderful, let's increase the grants to $4 million.' It doesn't work that way with most foundations, because grants are based on endowments."
With that in mind, leaders of some cultural groups, convinced that the new-money pledge was unrealistic, even talked to one another about trading contributors to prove they had "new" money. "It was, 'I'll trade you my 1993 donor for your 1994 donor, and that way we'll both have new money,' " said an executive with one city cultural institution, quickly adding that the trades never took place.
Of course, as Mr. Dyson notes, absent an army of auditors, the city and state will have to take a lot on faith, and arts groups say they are trying. But will the Challenge Initiative ultimately expand cultural programs, draw larger audiences and spur economic development, as originally intended? Or will it amount to an increase in government grants dressed up as something more ambitious?
Not that the city's cultural institutions or their benefactors are all that concerned about the fine print. "The good news is that there is some new money from the city and state," Mr. Crane said. "That's the 'new money.' And it's good news because the arts community needs every penny it can get."

HEADLINE: House Vote on Trade Accord Is Postponed

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5

 BODY:
Stymied by election-year politics, leaders from both parties in the House of Representatives decided tonight to postpone until after the elections a House vote on legislation to allow the United States to participate in a new worldwide trade agreement.
The Senate decided last week to hold a lame-duck session after Thanksgiving to vote on the measure. 
 The Speaker of the House, Thomas S. Foley, said the delay did not mean the measure would not ultimately be enacted. "It is going to become law," he said at a news conference this morning. "And anybody who doesn't think that is right is betting a very bad bet in my view."
The Republican leader, Robert H. Michel, agreed with that assessment.
But Mr. Foley and the other Democratic leaders who set the schedule for the House were forced to postpone the final vote because all but a handful of Republicans planned to vote against a procedural resolution, called a rule, that would have allowed a vote on the trade legislation this week.
Congress hopes to recess at the end of the week to begin the final stretch of campaigning before the Nov. 8 elections.
Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, the Republican whip, said his party needed more time to examine the fine print of the bill. But there was no doubt that many Republicans who support free trade wanted to delay a final vote until after the elections to deny President Clinton what has become his top remaining legislative priority this year. Enough Democrats oppose the measure that it cannot be passed without Republican support.
The top House leaders from both parties wrote President Clinton tonight that the Senate's decision to postpone a vote on the trade measure had "frankly undermined our ability to guarantee strong bipartisan support for this effort in the House at this time."
They said that the House would vote on Nov. 29 and that they would work to see that the legislation was enacted.
Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, said the White House was satisfied with the arrangement. "I think we are assured we will move forward," he said.
The bill would change the United States laws to conform with the trade pact, under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, that negotiators from the United States and 122 other countries have signed.
The trade accord would reduce tariffs, which are taxes on imported goods, by an average of 40 percent during the next 10 years and include a few services like accounting under international trade rules for the first time. Especially important to the United States, it would require all countries to guard against the abuse of patents, copyrights and trademarks and the illegal copying of computer programs.
The agreement would be supervised by a new international organization called the World Trade Organization.
At a hearing this morning, Mr. Kantor said the expanded trade under the accord would create as many as 700,000 new jobs in the United States during the next decade. He said the agreement would force other countries to abide by trade rules that the United States considers fair.
"Like it or not, change is inevitable," Mr. Kantor told the Senate commerce committee. "We can't stop the globalization. We've got to make it our friend."
At a news conference, President Clinton called the trade agreement "the biggest world tax cut in history," and said it would be "a huge job gainer for America."
But opponents of the bill said it would put American products at a disadvantage, because this country's markets would be opened to goods manufactured in low-wage countries. The result, the opponents say, would be the loss of thousands of American manufacturing jobs.
In the debate on the House floor tonight, many representatives expressed opposition to the trade agreement. For example, Representative David E. Bonior, a Democrat from Michigan, argued that the United States would "run the risk of seeing more companies pack up and move overseas."
But there seemed to be little doubt that the large majority of representatives supported the accord. "We should not turn our back on this opportunity for our children and their children," said Representative Bill Archer, Republican of Texas.
In the main, the broad middle of the ideological spectrum of economists and politicians from both parties support the trade pact. But it is opposed by people like Ralph Nader on the left and Patrick J. Buchanan on the right.
It is also opposed by most of organized labor. The jobs that would be lost in manufacturing are of the kind that are often unionized, and the jobs that would be gained would tend to be in service industries and others where workers are less likely to be union members.
In the Senate, Ernest F. Hollings, the South Carolina Democrat who is chairman of the commerce committee, has exercised his authority to delay a vote on the legislation for 45 days. As a consequence, the Senate plans to return to Washington for a lame-duck session and to vote on Dec. 1. Leaders from both parties say the measure will be approved then.
Some representatives would also find it easier to vote for the pact after the election. They are generally Democrats with large labor constituencies and Republicans who are trying to appeal to supporters of Mr. Buchanan and Ross Perot, who also opposes the trade pact.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
30-Year Bond Nears 8% As Prices Fall 3d Day

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Bond prices tumbled yesterday for the third consecutive day, as investors, fearing inflation, pushed up the yield on the Treasury's long bond to 7.95 percent, its highest point in 28 months.
After opening quietly, Treasury securities turned down after the release of the August factory orders data, which showed exceptional strength in the economy and at the same time increased investors' uneasiness that the Federal Reserve could move soon to increase short-term interest rates for the sixth time this year. 
 The 30-year bond fell 23/32 , to 9429/32 , for a yield of 7.95 percent, up from 7.88 percent on Tuesday, which means bondholders lost about $7.10 for each $1,000 of bonds. The yield yesterday was the highest since May 7, 1992, when it was 7.96 percent, the same week investors saw the yield drop below 8 percent.
Rates on shorter-maturity bills gained only slightly, benefiting as investors moved away from the volatility of the long end to the relative safety of the short end.
Traders said the large number of Fed officials making comments about the economy yesterday might have added to the nervousness. For example, Robert P. Forrestal, president of the Federal Reserve Bank in Atlanta, said in Gadsden, Ala., that the Fed, while honoring a strong commitment to curb inflation, must avoid harming the economic expansion by raising rates too rapidly.
Thomas M. Hoenig, president of the Federal Reserve Bank in Kansas City, Mo., told an audience in Colorado that the economy was generally sound, and the outlook generally favorable. A Fed governor, Lawrence B. Lindsey, addressing a bankers group in Atlanta, said that policy makers were determined not to let inflation become a problem. "In the long run we will be better off acting sooner than if we had waited," he said.
And in El Paso on Tuesday night, Robert D. McTeer Jr., president of the Federal Reserve Bank in Dallas, was reported to have said that the central bank was not concerned that healthy economic growth would cause an acceleration in inflation.
Analysts at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette said that a 4.4 percent rise in August factory orders reported by the Commerce Department yesterday indicated even more momentum in the manufacturing sector than was implied by last week's statistics on durable goods orders.
Durable goods orders rose 6.1 percent, while nondurable orders rose 2.5 percent. The strength of the data added to the bearish tone in Treasuries and heightened speculation of a near-term tightening.
Peter McTeague, MCM Money Watch-Boston, saw the fundamentals of the economy still strong, as the factory orders helped confirm yesterday. "With the pace stronger than expected, the market is preparing for a 300,000-type jobs number," he said, referring to the scheduled release on Friday of September employment figures.
Mr. McTeague said market participants, especially the large hedge funds and dealers that had been positioned to take advantage of the spread between the short end of the market and long end, have been cashing in during the market's recent narrowing of that spread. "We saw some of it on Tuesday," he said. "Today they were unwinding positions and all rushing for the same exit at the same time. The market just can't handle that."
He said that some of that money came out of the market on Tuesday, and more came out yesterday. By today, all of it may be out of the market, he added.
Traders and analysts said they thought the short end of the market might already be priced to reflect a near-term 50-basis-point rise in interest rates that is expected from the Fed. As a result, some see limited scope for additional losses in the shorter maturities. But not so in the long bond, which is approaching 8 percent. These analysts say that the longer the Fed waits to raise rates, the longer the long end of the market will suffer.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Cotton Recovers on Hints Of Strong Demand for Crop

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Cotton prices recovered from a nine-month low yesterday on indications of strong demand for a huge American crop.
In other commodity movements, wheat futures retreated from a two-and-a-half-year high and hog futures fell to a fresh 14-year low. Lower crude oil and gold prices helped push the Commodity Research Bureau's index of 21 commodities down 0.44 point, to 229.86. 
 On the New York Cotton Exchange, the cotton contract for October delivery rose 0.58 cent, to 66.75 cents a pound. Its session low of 65.90 was the lowest price for near-term deliveries since Jan. 4. American mills bought futures as insurance against rising prices, while speculation of an impending large purchase by China stirred speculative buying, analysts said.
"The expectation for the U.S. crop is now close to 19.5 million," Judy Ganes, an analyst at Merrill Lynch, said. "Having China as a buyer is going to be a must. We certainly need that buying to help absorb some of the large supplies from the U.S. crop."
She said China's crop, currently estimated by the Agriculture Department at 20 million bales, may be reduced by a million by pest damage.
Cotton has tumbled from an early September high of nearly 73 cents a pound on expectations that this year's crop in the United States will exceed 19 million 480-pound bales, compared with last year's 16.1 million -- an 18 percent increase. But demand for cotton clothing, bedding and furniture upholstery is also rising, and the trend should strengthen as the economy improves.
On the Chicago Board of Trade, wheat for December delivery settled at $4.075 a bushel, down 1.25 cents, after trading at a two-and-a-half-year high of $4.13 3/4. Prices dipped on sentiment that the market could not sustain such high prices without stronger export demand.
"Despite the fact we've had a lot of export business, total sales are still trailing year-ago levels," said Joel Karlin, research analyst with Kemper Securities Inc. in Chicago.
Hog futures plunged 0.95 cent, to a 14-year low of 34.25 cents a pound, on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange as abundant supplies of livestock continued to put pressure on prices.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Continues to Falter After Decline in U.S. Bonds

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar fell against other leading currencies yesterday, dragged down for a second day by a decline in the American bond market.
Prices of United States Treasury securities dropped after a strong factory orders report contributed to inflation fears. While higher interest rates tend to bolster a currency, foreign-exchange traders have been tracking American asset markets to gauge demand by foreign investors for dollars. Yesterday, the dollar fell sharply against the British pound and dipped against the Japanese yen and German mark as investors fled dollar-denominated assets. 
 "People are looking at where the capital is really flowing, and the U.S. market is not that attractive," said Chris Iggo, a currency strategist with Chase Manhattan Bank. "The dollar bears the brunt of that."
The pound advanced amid signs that the British economy was improving since the Bank of England raised a key interest rate on Sept. 12, currency dealers said. In late New York trading yesterday, the pound was quoted at $1.5860, a 17-month high, up from $1.5810 on Tuesday.
The dollar traded in narrow ranges against the German mark and Japanese yen as market participants, awaiting tomorrow's release of the United States employment report for September, stuck with their positions. The dollar also continued to be buoyed against the yen by the trade agreement announced on Saturday between the United States and Japan.
The dollar slipped yesterday to 1.5435 marks from 1.5465 marks on Tuesday. The dollar settled unchanged against the yen at 99.65 yen.
But the dollar gained against the Italian lira, rising to 1,570 lire, from 1,559 on Tuesday, after Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi's Government was thrown into political turmoil.
Many traders and analysts expect the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates for the sixth time this year. The jobs report should give a clearer picture of when a tightening may come.
"Some people think it will happen in October, others think the Fed will wait till November," Dorit Ronnen, a currency trader at Bank Leumi Trust in New York, said.
The dollar remains under pressure until the Fed moves, she said, because inflation fears will continue to roil the bond market, which weighs down the dollar.

HEADLINE: PRO BASKETBALL;
N.B.A. and Stern Take the Road Less Traveled

BYLINE: By RICHARD SANDOMIR 

 BODY:
On a day when locked out hockey players rebuffed two management plans, and striking baseball players mulled an owners' proposal to freeze free agency rules, the National Basketball Association yesterday traveled the labor road not taken: it declined to set a date to lock out players and said it expects to start the season on time.
"We want to separate ourselves from other sports," said Larry Miller, the Utah Jazz owner. "Setting a lockout date would inflame discussions." 
 Not setting a lockout date, he said, was a reaction to harsh, pre-emptive moves by Gary Bettman, the National Hockey League commissioner. Unhappy with his negotiations with the hockey players' union over a new collective-bargaining agreement, Bettman first set a deadline for postponing the start of the season, then did postpone it, deferring the start until at least Oct. 15.
"He felt desperate," Miller said. "We have time and we want to keep this in a nonhostile environment."
The N.B.A. season begins Nov. 4. David Stern, the N.B.A. commissioner, said: "I plan to be in Houston on Nov. 4 to give the Rockets their rings."
Charles Grantham, executive director of the players' union, said before the N.B.A. Board of Governors met yesterday that he expected a lockout date to be set. But after the announcement he said: "It was definitely an effort to show optimism and not get pushed into an arena of confrontation. It sounds like the hawks are at bay for a while. This gives us optimism that the league wants to talk."
If events do not force a change, the league's stance, combined with the cheerfulness expressed by Stern, stood in sharp, almost comic, relief to the grimness of the baseball and hockey negotiations.
"I not only love this game, but I am in love with our players," Stern said jovially, in the day's guise as the roundball Mr. Rogers, standing downstage from a red and blue chart that depicted the rise of N.B.A. revenues and player salaries since revenue-sharing and the salary cap came into being a decade ago.
Stern's demeanor was in keeping with his desire to extend the era of good feeling in the N.B.A. that began in the early 1980's with the agreement to share 53 percent of defined gross revenues with players via the salary cap. But that period of amity has eroded as the union became persuaded that the cap has outlived its usefulness by restricting free-agent mobility and salaries. The collective bargaining agreement between the N.B.A. and its players expired June 24, and the players now want to eliminate the salary cap, as well as the college draft and restrictions on free agency.
Stern's rhetoric yesterday stressed that the league believes all problems can be resolved and extreme measures are unneeded. He said the season could start without a labor agreement, a different tack from the one taken by Bettman, who wants a deal before starting the season because, he said, more than half the teams are losing money and the league's economics must be overhauled.
The N.B.A. is different. Unlike Bettman or Bud Selig, baseball's acting commissioner, Stern is not pleading poverty. "I'm not here saying the owners are doing poorly," he said. "We'd like a deal before the season. But there are no ultimata here. There's no gauntlet being thrown down."
Not only that, but Stern also said the league would make its financial documents available to the players.
Miller acknowledged that the owners had discussed the lockout option for about 10 minutes during the N.B.A. meeting yesterday at the Plaza Hotel. But Stern said the league was wary of its ability, and the players' ability, to shut down the game.
"We have mutually assured destructive capacity," Stern said. "But we've never called these actions. We haven't used them and don't plan to."
David Falk, a player agent whose clients include Patrick Ewing, said: "I'm not sure what you'd accomplish by locking out the players. This is a sport that's growing, and gains nothing with a lockout. Basketball has been in the lead in labor negotiations and a lockout is simply counterproductive."
Underlying Stern's percolating confidence that an agreement with the players' union can be negotiated without harming the season is a belief that the players will lose their Federal Court challenge to the N.B.A.
That challenge currently is in the United States Court of Appeals in Manhattan, where the union is appealing a lower-court ruling on the N.B.A.'s salary cap, draft and right-of-first-refusal signings, saying they violate antitrust law. A Federal District Court judge ruled in favor of the league last July, saying that the dispute should be decided under labor law, not antitrust statutes.
Miller said one goal of the league's labor-relations committee was to initiate settlement discussions of the union's court appeal.
Grantham said the union will not engage in formal talks with the league until the Court of Appeals issues a ruling, which may come within days of the start of the season. The union wants to maintain the upper hand it would gain by winning the lawsuit; if it loses, it would probably have to accept an agreement that looks much like the one that recently expired.
"It sounds like we're both moving in the same direction," Grantham said. "It's not unusual that we start the season without a collective-bargaining agreement. We can play while we resolve the issues."
Stern expressed an openness to renegotiate how much revenue is shared, and how to restructure the salary cap, which owners would like to strip of its loopholes, turning it from a "soft" to a "hard" cap. A "soft" cap is one with provisions that enable teams to exceed the payroll limit.
But Stern is unlikely to want to radically alter the status quo that has so greatly enriched the N.B.A.
'There is no line in the sand," he said.
He said owners would explore increasing the percentage of defined gross revenues shared, but not at levels that would hurt team profitability or discourage owners from signing players in order to be competitive. He said going as high as the 64 percent of revenues shared by National Football League teams with its players "would wipe out a number of franchises and our profitability."
He also said monies not shared with players are now "on the table." The revenues include more from domestic licensing, and a first crack at cash from sponsorships, arena concessions, international TV and luxury-suite rentals.
Stern estimated that the newly negotiable revenues are worth $100 million, beyond the $925 million that was shared with players during the 1992-93 season. But Grantham said they were worth closer to $175 million.
"Whatever numbers they're putting out don't represent the potential for change in the future," Grantham said. "And it doesn't reflect the eight or nine new arenas being built with three times more luxury boxes than in the past."

 CORRECTION:
An article yesterday about disputes in the Haitian Parliament over legislation to grant amnesty to leaders of the September 1991 coup, which overthrew President Jean-Bertrand Aristide, misstated the circumstances of the death of Silvio Claude, leader of the country's Christian Democratic Party. He was killed during that coup, not at the time of Father Aristide's taking office in February 1991.
