HEADLINE: THE 1994 CAMPAIGN: THE REPUBLICANS;
More Black Candidates Find Places on Republican Ballots

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: NORMAN, Okla., Oct. 4

 BODY:
J. C. Watts Jr., who is running for Congress, is still remembered here as the quarterback who directed the Oklahoma Sooners down the field for a dramatic victory over Florida State in the waning seconds of the 1981 Orange Bowl.
But what really makes Mr. Watts stand out is that he is a black politician in a state that is overwhelmingly white, and a Republican amid a national black population that is overwhelmingly Democratic. Mr. Watts was the first black person elected to statewide office in Oklahoma when he won a spot on the utility-regulating Corporation Commission four years ago, and he is widely regarded as the favorite to win on Nov. 8 in the Fourth District in southwestern Oklahoma. 
 Since the New Deal, the term "black Republican" has been a virtual oxymoron, and even now, national polls suggest that barely one-tenth of all blacks consider themselves Republican. But though the numbers are still small, there is clear evidence this fall of a growing number of black candidates running under the Republican banner at both the Federal and state levels.
Of this year's Republican nominees for Congress, 25 are black, nearly double the number in 1992 and by far the most of any year in the nation's history, including Reconstruction.
The few black Republican candidates given any reasonable shot at winning are running in districts that are largely white. They include Mr. Watts, candidates in Missouri and Texas and incumbent Gary A. Franks of Connecticut, who in 1990 became the first black Republican elected to the House since the Depression. And Republicans are far more likely than Democrats to nominate blacks in such districts.
Of this year's 38 black Democratic nominees for the House, only one is running in a district that has a majority of white voters, while 8 of the 25 Republican nominees are running in such districts, according to research compiled by David A. Bositis, senior analyst at the Joint Center for Political and Economic Studies, a Washington research group specializing in issues affecting black people.
Republican leaders and black candidates suggest that the increase points to the party's growing appeal to blacks, who may feel that Democratic solutions to poverty and racism have failed. Even a minor surge in black allegiance to the Republican Party could profoundly affect the balance of power between the two parties, especially in the South.
But Mr. Bositis said that although such a shift could occur in the future, it was not necessarily heralded by the growing number of black Republican candidates.
"If they're elected, they'll be sent to office by white voters, not black voters," he said. "There will be no real shift until you can look at a black Republican who is elected with black votes."
That appears unlikely to happen this fall. Indeed, several black Republicans running in districts with large black populations are considered little more than sacrificial candidates, running against veteran black Democrats like Representatives Maxine Waters of Los Angeles or Ronald V. Dellums of Oakland.
Many black Democrats are scornful of or even hostile toward black conservatives like Mr. Watts, who advocates an overhaul of the country's "sick, pathetic" welfare system and preaches the benefits of a cut in the capital gains tax for inner-city blacks.
Ed Coles, a black member of the Democratic State Committee in Mississippi, speaking generically of black conservative candidates, said: "I mean, come on. For a black man to be talking about no food stamps or no public housing, or some Draconian welfare reform, that's just ridiculous."
But many of the Republican candidates say that such dismissals are based on an exaggeration of their political views and a misreading by black Democrats of a fundamental conservatism among many blacks.
"One Democrat on public radio took it upon himself to accuse me of being a Tom or whatever, and the Republican Party was basically using us," said Dorothy LeGrand, a black lawyer who is the Republican candidate in the Fifth Congressional District in Minnesota.
"I'm not running on Jesse Helms's platform," she added. "I'm not running on Willie Horton. I will say he's a thug and a hoodlum and should be locked up. The Willie Hortons of this world are a threat to African-Americans."
Mr. Horton, a black convicted murderer who raped a white woman while on parole, was the subject of a Republican-produced commercial in the 1988 Presidential campaign that many blacks said was racist in tone.
Michael Murphy, a black man who spent 18 years as director of consumer affairs for Dunkin Donuts and is now running for Congress in Massachusetts, said that the welfare state had failed and that Republican policies would offer black people greater chances of advancement. "The system will be more of a trampoline than a swamp," he said.
In Houston the other day, at a national conference of hundreds of black conservatives, Senator Phil Gramm, Republican of Texas, drew steady refrains of "Amen" and "Tell it" as he called for an overhaul of the country's welfare system.
Some black Republicans even use images of slavery to suggest that some Democratic-inspired programs have done little more than entrap blacks in poverty. "Now we're returning to the party of our liberation," said Marvin B. Scott, a Republican candidate for Congress in Indiana's 10th District.
Others said that they had put up with no end of grief from fellow black Democrats when they switched to the Republican Party.
"Most of them thought I was brain-dead," said Bill Jordan, a lawyer and minister who is the Republican nominee in a black-majority district in Mississippi. "But that's part of the problem that blacks have in this country. We so blindly support Democrats. Democrats know that no matter how ineffective programs might be, if they have the right name on them, blacks will support them."
The Republicans also have several black candidates at the statewide level this year. In Texas, for instance, the Republican nominee for state comptroller is Teresa Doggett, whose husband, John, gained brief prominence at the 1991 Senate Judiciary hearings on the Supreme Court nomination of Clarence Thomas when he testified that Anita F. Hill had acted disturbed after he had rejected her overtures for a date.
It is impossible to characterize these candidates as a group. Some said they hoped to act as a moderating influence on the party in the mold of Edward W. Brooke, the black Republican who represented Massachusetts in the United States Senate from 1967 to 1979.
Others, however, are unabashed conservatives, including Mr. Watts. He campaigns on a platform of staunch opposition to homosexuals in the military and to abortion in all cases except when a pregnant woman's life is endangered. Abortion is "a scriptural issue, not a political issue," he said.
Of public-assistance programs, he said, "Congress for too long has defined compassion in America by how many people are on food stamps and in public housing. I think we should measure compassion by how few people are on food stamps and in public housing."
And, taking a page from the playbook of Jack Kemp, a former Republican Congressman, Housing Secretary and football star who has come here to campaign for him, Mr. Watts said: "We've got to go into the black communities, and we've got to talk about capital formation. We've got to talk capital gains."
Mr. Watts, with 92 percent name recognition in one poll and known almost universally here as just J. C. (which stands for Julius Caesar), has shown a wide lead in some early polls in his race against the Democratic nominee, David Perryman, a white lawyer from Chickasha. Many people expect the race to tighten considerably and predict that some white voters who told pollsters they would vote for Mr. Watts would not.
But Frosty Troy, editor of the Oklahoma Observer, a bimonthly political newspaper, said that Mr. Watts's conservative, Christian image was so firmly established that it could overcome the reluctance of many white conservatives to vote for a black man.
Perhaps even more tellingly, Mr. Troy added, Oklahomans seem to like their football stars this fall. Mr. Watts was a Sooners quarterback in his day, but so was the Democratic nominee for Governor, Lieut. Gov. Jack Mildren. A Republican nominee for Congress in Tulsa, Steve Largent, a former Seattle Seahawk, holds the National Football League record for career receptions. "Oklahoma," Mr. Troy said, "seems to be a jockocracy this year."

HEADLINE: Census Sees Falling Income and More Poor

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6

 BODY:
Despite the growth of the overall economy, the typical American household saw its income decline in 1993, and more than a million Americans fell into poverty, according to figures made public today by the Census Bureau.
The numbers show the persistence, and perhaps even the quickening, of one of the most worrisome trends in the American economy, the long-term growth in inequality. 
 The numbers may help explain the voter discontent that threatens to turn next month's elections into a nationwide rebellion, despite an expanding economy and relative international peace. While voters have voiced concern about everything from declining moral values to rising immigration, at least some of their anger may have its origins in a familiar place: the pinched pocket.
"Even though the economy looks good on the surface, most Americans are not yet seeing a substantial change in their fortunes," said Robert B. Reich, the Labor Secretary. "There's a lot of resentfulness out there, a lot of frustration, and a great deal of anxiety."
Mr. Reich stressed that the trend toward inequality had been apparent for the better part of two decades and defended the Administration's long-term strategy for fighting it. But he made no effort to hide his alarm. "America is in danger of splitting into a two-tiered society," he said. "This is not anyone's idea of progress."
From 1992 to 1993, median household income declined by about $300, when adjusted for inflation, to $31,241. While this 1 percent decline was small, most economists had expected an increase, because the economy bounced back from the recession that ended in 1991.
The decline in household income looks much larger when measured against 1989, the peak of economic expansion in the 1980's. From 1989 to 1993, the typical American household lost $2,344 in annual income, a fall of 7 percent.
There is a similar pattern in the percentage of Americans who fell below the poverty line. The 1993 figure of 15.1 percent was not significantly different from the previous year's, but was sharply higher than the 1989 figure of 13.1 percent. A family of four was considered poor in 1993 if it had an income of less than $14,763.
The stagnation that bedeviled the broad middle class came despite what seemed to be encouraging numbers on the overall economy. The economy grew by 3 percent in 1993, and the unemployment rate fell, to 6.8 percent from 7.4 percent the previous year.
The numbers even surprised economists who make a career of studying such trends. "It's quite rare to have median income fall in a year where there's aggregate growth overall," said Rebecca Blank, an economist at Northwestern University. "It's not a good sign."
While average per capita income was up, by 1.8 percent, most of the benefits flowed to the wealthiest Americans. The Census report showed record levels of inequality, with the top fifth of American households earning 48.2 percent of the nation's income, while the bottom fifth earned just 3.6 percent.
The trend toward greater inequality has a number of causes, many of them working to depress wages. Economists disagree over which factors are most responsible for wage stagnation or erosion, but the list of suspects includes increased international competition; the shift from a manufacturing to a service economy; the decline of unionization; and the erosion of the minimum wage.
While the decline of wages has been most pronounced for those with the least education, the wages of college-educated workers has also stagnated since 1987, said Isaac Shapiro, acting director of the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, a Washington advocacy group.
President Clinton made promises to meliorate these trends a major part of his 1992 campaign, and the voter anger may reflect disappointment that change has been slow to arrive. Mr. Clinton promised, for instance, a middle-class tax cut, but dropped it after taking office to fight budget deficits that he said were even worse than previously reported.
Gene Sperling, a White House economics adviser, said the President had put in place other strategies for helping average Americans, but that it was too soon to feel their effect. He cited, for instance, an expansion of tax credits for low-wage workers that will amount to more than $20 billion over the next five years.
He also cited a variety of programs aimed at raising the skills of average Americans to boost their wages. These include new training opportunities for dislocated workers and a change in student loan programs that allow borrowers up to 25 years to repay the Government.
"We are moving in the right direction, but we'd be the first to say there's still a long way to go," he said.
Mr. Reich made similar points, but with a tone of greater alarm, saying the nation's broad economic anxiety set the stage of demagogy on both the political right and left. "America has the most unequal distribution of income of any industrialized nation in the world," he said. "We cannot have a prosperous or stable society if these trends continue."
In issuing this year's poverty numbers, the Census Bureau adopted a system of statistical weighting that is different from previous years. While last year's official poverty rate was 14.5 percent, for instance, under the new system it would have been 14.8 percent. The increase to this year's figure of 15.1 percent does not meet tests of statistical significance.

HEADLINE: Revised Tax on Domestic Help Passes House and Goes to Senate

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6

 BODY:
The House today easily approved a loosening of the requirement that household employers pay Social Security for domestic workers, a levy that gained attention last year in confirmation hearings for top jobs in the Clinton Administration.
The vote was 423 to 0. Passage by the Senate would send the measure to President Clinton, who is expected to sign it. 
 The bill would require household employers to pay Social Security and Medicare taxes on any worker earning at least $1,000 a year, up from the current threshold of $50 a quarter. Teen-age baby sitters would be exempt.
The issue of the "nanny tax" has been a recurrent problem for the Administration, starting with Zoe Baird, President Clinton's first choice for Attorney General. Several other candidates for top positions were also embarrassed by revelations they had not paid Social Security taxes on their domestic help.
The Internal Revenue Service estimates that only about one-fourth of household employers pay taxes on their baby sitters, housekeepers and gardeners.
By raising the threshold and requiring employers to file taxes once a year, instead of quarterly, lawmakers believe that more people will pay taxes on their employees, allowing them to qualify for benefits from Social Security when they retire or become disabled.
The bill lets employers file both Social Security and unemployment taxes annually, and on their own 1040 Federal tax returns. Many states collect state unemployment taxes quarterly, however, and the bill addresses that by letting the Treasury Secretary enter into agreements with states to collect those unemployment taxes annually as well.
Under the bill, the $1,000 threshold would rise with future growth in wages, with increases occurring in $100 increments.

HEADLINE: World News Briefs;
Syrian Foreign Minister Meets American Jews

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6

 BODY:
The Foreign Minister of Syria has held the first formal meeting with leaders of American Jewish organizations, members of Congress and Jewish spokesmen said.
Mr. Shara met eight Jewish spokesmen in Washington Wednesday for a 45-minute session after an initial discussion with six members of the House Foreign Affairs Committee. The committee organized the meeting at the request of the Syrian Embassy, people attending the meeting said. 
 Mr. Shara told the American Jews that President Hafez al-Assad of Syria had made a strategic commitment to peace with Israel and there was no time to waste in getting a peace agreement signed.
Mr. Shara said that Syria would absolutely not take part in a high level conference to be held in Casablanca, Morocco, on the regional economic development of the Middle East, said Malcolm Hoenlein, executive vice chairman of the Conference of Presidents of Major Jewish Organizations.
"But he said Syria's first priority was to change the region from war to peace," Mr. Hoenlein said, adding that Mr. Shara and the American Jews pledged to have further talks in the future.

HEADLINE: MISSION TO HAITI: POLICE;
U.S. Scrambles for Recruits to Bring Order To the Streets of Haiti's Two Largest Cities

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6

 BODY:
With the interim police force it had hoped to install in Haiti now in disarray, the United States is scrambling to cobble together another force for Haiti's two largest cities and may soon hire "auxiliaries," basically any at least marginally trustworthy Haitian they can put in a uniform, senior Administration officials said today.
The military's plan to use members of the existing police and Haitian military for a new police force -- allowing American troops to hand off policing duties they accepted only reluctantly -- has faltered as many of the uniformed Haitians have either fled or refused to cooperate. 
 American commanders are now rushing to put together a credible force for both Cap-Haitien and Port-au-Prince, the capital, before the planned return of Haiti's exiled president, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, in another week or so. But the effort is by no means assured and may leave the United States military stuck with policing duties for months to come.
"The plan hasn't been developed as far as we'd like," a senior Pentagon official acknowledged today. "In fact, we don't quite have a plan yet. We don't have the timing, the structure or the components down."
Although they have received only scant training, about 25 of the 900 recruits from refugee camps at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, will be sent to Cap-Haitien soon to take part in a police force as "public safety trainees." Out of desperation, the military is now discussing hiring other recruits from among ordinary Haitian working people. "That would be a total joke," said one senior American officer involved in Haiti planning, rolling his eyes.
The first group of some 840 international police monitors, some of whom have already arrived in Haiti under the direction of Raymond W. Kelly, the former New York City police commissioner, is ready to supervise a new Haitian force. But the monitors, carrying sidearms, will not perform police duties themselves.
A senior State Department official disagreed with the Pentagon's bleak assessment and said an interim police force in Cap-Haitien would be "up and running by Monday." The State Department official also said the Administration would not likely resort to using the auxiliaries.
Administration officials insist that an interim force will be in place within days, even if at first it is only an inexperienced constabulary that directs traffic. A symbolic force like this, composed of unarmed clerks taught how to march, would leave United States Army soldiers responsible for the more dangerous job of maintaining order until a permanent Haitian police force can be trained.
"Our mission is very clear: to maintain essential civic order," said the senior Pentagon official, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. "But we're also conscious of avoiding mission creep. That's why we're working so hard to put together an interim public security force."
Under the last-minute diplomatic agreement brokered by former President Jimmy Carter, the Haitian police and military agreed to be responsible for internal policing duties. But American and Haitian forces clashed almost immediately, culminating in the death of 10 Haitian police in a shootout with marines in Cap-Haitien on Sept. 24.
Since then, many Haitian security forces in Cap-Haitien and Port-au-Prince have stripped off their uniforms and fled, or refused to cooperate with American troops, forcing Army soldiers and Special Forces troops to fill the vacuum. "It is our feeling that the existing police and their effectiveness in many areas has almost totally disappeared, and in others degraded," Gen. John M. Shalikashvili, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, told reporters this week.
American commanders express confidence that they can eventually lure Haitian security forces out of hiding or their obstinacy with salaried jobs in an interim force, coveted treasures in Haiti's devastated economy. Indeed, a senior aide to Mr. Kelly said that uniformed Haitians and police monitors from Argentina, Jordan and St. Vincent started patrolling parts of Port-au-Prince together on Wednesday.
But the experience in Cap-Haitien, Haiti's second-largest city, raises doubts. The United States plans to establish an interim force first in Cap-Haitien and then phase in a similar force in Port-au-Prince precinct by precinct.
With no effective civilian police force in Cap-Haitien now, the American high command asked Lieut. Gen. Raoul Cedras, the head of the military, to send Haitian forces from elsewhere in the country. "General Cedras gave the order to deploy other people, but it was either not transmitted or it's been stalled in some way," said the senior Pentagon official, who said the incident illustrated how the authority of General Cedras and other senior military leaders is "coming unraveled."
The senior State Department official said the American commander in Haiti, Lieut. Gen. Hugh Shelton, had been ordered to find a Haitian military or police unit to go to Cap-Haitien. International monitors would accompany these forces.
Haitian refugees recruited at Guantanamo Bay would serve as clerks or traffic police. Members of President Aristide's Government and State Department officials chose the recruits based on a literacy test and a personal interview.
The recruits received three days of training in ethics, Haitian criminal law, and basic skills like traffic control, said Michael Berkow, the Haiti police project manager for International Criminal Investigative Training Assistance Program, a Justice Department agency.

HEADLINE: Mandela Says U.S. Must Aid World's Poor

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6

 BODY:
President Nelson Mandela of South Africa told a joint meeting of Congress today that the United States and other wealthy nations must resist the lure of isolationism and dedicate themselves to improving the lot of all the world's people.
After spending the last two days asking the Clinton Administration to help his country, President Mandela had a broader message: As nations grow closer together, rich lands need to do more to aid poor ones because that will serve the cause of peace, prosperity and democracy. 
 Mr. Mandela said that if "the world is one stage and the actions of its inhabitants part of the same drama," then "each one of us as nations, including yourselves, should begin to define the national interest to include the genuine happiness of others, however distant in time and space their domicile might be."
In an appearance that was equal parts celebration and sermon, Mr. Mandela used the forum to serve not as a national spokesman, but as a global statesmen and visionary outlining his prescription for the post cold-war world. It was a vision in which the masses of Africa and elsewhere in the third world would not be marginalized, but central to a cooperative international effort to increase prosperity and freedom.
The "new world order that is in the making must focus on the creation of a world of democracy, peace and prosperity for all," Mr. Mandela told the lawmakers.
With the speech, Mr. Mandela became just the third foreign leader, after Winston Churchill and Israel's Prime Minister, Yitzhak Rabin, to address a joint meeting of Congress more than once. Mr. Mandela spoke to a joint meeting of Congress in June 1990, shortly after he was released from 27 years in prison.
In a 33-minute speech that was interrupted more than a dozen times with applause, Mr. Mandela said that with the cold war over, it was time to move "to the positive," to "the global creation of the conditions which will make it possible for all peoples to enjoy the right to full human dignity."
He thanked the United States for its political and economic aid and expressed his gratitude to Congress in particular for leading the nation's efforts to fight apartheid. In 1986, Congress overrode a veto by President Ronald Reagan to impose economic sanctions against South Africa.
After explaining how interconnected Africa, America and the rest of the world have become, Mr. Mandela said: "I come out of a continent with whose travails and suffering you are very familiar. You will therefore understand it easily why I stand up to say that for such a powerful country such as yours, democracy, peace and prosperity in Africa are as much in your national interest as ours."
He saw 21st-century telecommunications creating a problem for fledgling democracies like South Africa.
"The new age will surely demand that democracy must also mean a life of plenty," he said. "As the images of life lived anywhere on our globe become available to all, so will the contrast between the rich and the poor" become a "force impelling the deprived to demand a better life from the powers that be."
On Wednesday night, the Hunger Project, an organization that fights malnutrition, awarded Mr. Mandela a $100,000 prize for his role in fighting hunger throughout Africa.
In a speech Wednesday night to 1,400 guests at a Washington hotel, Mr. Mandela said that Africa faced "a terrible food crisis." He estimated that 34 million people in the sub-Saharan region face daily shortages of food, adding that this was "the worst humanitarian crisis in modern times."
For most of Mr. Mandela's weeklong visit to the United States, he has focused on persuading the Clinton Administration and American businesses to assist his nation's economic revival. On Wednesday, the Clinton Administration announced plans for a $100 million enterprise fund to help small- and medium-size business in southern Africa as well as $150 million in loan guarantees to build housing and electrification projects in South Africa.
Mr. Mandela was originally scheduled to hold a long meeting today with Haiti's exiled President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, but they met for only a few minutes and agreed to schedule a longer session for Friday.
The Clinton Administration has urged such a meeting in the hope that Mr. Mandela's success at promoting reconciliation in South Africa can serve as an ideal for Haiti to follow.
"The most important thing South Africa can do for Haiti has been accomplished by President Mandela coming to the United States at this historic moment, and then on top of that agreeing to meet with President Aristide," President Clinton said at a news conference. "The Haitian people will see that you can bring a country where there have been deep, even bloody divisions together and work together in a spirit of freedom, reconciliation, democracy and mutual respect."

Foreign Minister Alfred Nzo of South Africa is at right. Mr. Mandela, in an address at Congress, urged the United States to aid the world's poor nations. (Paul Hosefros/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: U.N. Study Finds a Free Eastern Europe Poorer and Less Healthy

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Oct. 6

 BODY:
The unsettling years of transition from Communism to free-market democracies have left the most vulnerable people of Eastern and Central Europe significantly poorer, less healthy or fed and more prone to accidental death and homicide, according to a report published today by Unicef, the United Nations Children's Fund.
Economic changes have "provoked a deterioration of unparalleled proportions in human welfare throughout most of the region," the Unicef study says. Rising incidence of infectious diseases, stress, malnutrition and alcoholism, already documented in Russia, affect a much wider area, the report shows. 
 "This health crisis is unprecendented in the peacetime history of Europe in this century," James P. Grant, the director of Unicef, said at a news conference today. He added that the crisis "is obviously contributing to eroding political support for the reforms that are under way.
The study covers developments from 1989 into early 1994 in Albania, Bulgaria, the Czech Republic, Slovakia, Hungary, Poland, Romania, Russia and Ukraine.
Giovanni Andrea Cornia, director of social and economic policy research at Unicef's International Child Development Center in Florence and the author of the report, told the news conference that low tax revenues and inflation buoyed by more spending on social programs was a major cause of the crisis.
He said that a shortage of drugs and vaccines, one result of reduced government spending, was having "a massive health impact."
Mr. Grant said that statistics from Russia continue to be the most discouraging, with a 10-fold increase in families living below the poverty line and a mortality rate up by 35 percent compared with the pre-1989 rate. The homicide rate in Russia had reached twice that of the United States by 1992, and is still rising. In Romania, the number of homicides had increased 60 percent since 1990.
While Unicef began its studies with a focus on women and children, Mr. Grant said, it soon became apparent that the group most at risk were young adult men, where cardiovascular disease, alcoholism and violent death are on the increase.
Unicef surveys not included in the report show that public satisfaction with living conditions is highest in the Czech Republic, with 54 percent of the people satisfied, Mr. Grant said. "But when you get to European Russia, 79 percent say they are dissatisfied with their living standards," he said. "When you get to the Ukraine, it's 88 percent.
Mr. Cornia said that as of early 1994, conditions were still declining in Russia and the Ukraine, but had begun to register some improvement in eastern Europe.
Among other findings of the report, titled "Crisis in Mortality, Health and Nutrition," are indications that school enrollments have begun to decline, often with kindergarten and higher education first to be eliminated by families who cannot afford to pay for services that were once heavily subsidized. Many children are also experiencing more instability in their families with increased poverty and violence.
Iodine deficiency disorders are endemic in all countries studied except parts of Hungary, the Czech Republic and Slovakia. In Bulgaria the situation is as bad as in central Africa. Such deficiencies lead to goiter, nervous system damage, growth retardation and cretinism.
Protein and calorie intakes have been declining with shortages or rising costs of the most nutritious foods. The sharpest drops in consumption were in milk, fruit and vegetables, the report found.

HEADLINE: ART REVIEW;
From Postwar Italy, With Style

BYLINE: By MICHAEL KIMMELMAN 

 BODY:
YOU needn't have cruised down the Via Veneto on a Vespa in the 1960's to know what is meant by la dolce vita. It means Ferrari, Ferragamo and Fellini, Pucci and paparazzi: Italy during its years of postwar prosperity epitomized glamour. Beginning in the late 50's, the country enjoyed what Italians considered to be a miracle of economic and industrial expansion after the degradation of the Fascist years. But the biggest miracle was the number of talented people who came to maturity after World War II and gave to resurging Italy a culture and style that reached a peak by the mid-60's.
"The Italian Metamorphosis, 1943-1968," which fills the Guggenheim Museum, is a gigantic survey of what they accomplished in painting and sculpture, film and photography, fashion, architecture and design between the fall of Mussolini and the rise of a generation opposed to Italy's new opulence. 
 The subject is a great one. The exhibition is good, not great. It could have been better selected and more creatively organized to make relationships across the arts clearer. Still, it gives a sense of the range of achievements, and it includes, among more than 1,000 objects, classics like the sleek modernist Olivetti typewriter that Ettore Sottsass designed in the late 60's, and the teensy Isetta automobile that Ermenegildo Preti created in the early 50's, a two-seater with gills, a door through the front and bumpers about the size of your shins.
There are ornate and fabulously creative pieces of jewelry, some by artists whose work looks better on a small and decorative scale, where elegance counts, than on the scale of their paintings and sculptures. And there are works by artists who deserve to be better known in America, among them Mimmo Rotella, whose collages like "The Tiger" from the early 60's, made of ripped posters, brought a distinctive brand of Pop to Italy at the same time that they playfully referred back, in their all-over compositions, to Action Painting. The story of postwar Italian art is partly the story of a trans-Atlantic dialogue with America, but not -- as chauvinistic Americans tend to assume -- one in which we did all the talking and they did all the listening. Rotella is an example of an Italian original.
Francesco Lo Savio is another. He was doing Minimalism before the Minimalists, hanging monochrome canvases and bent black metal sheets on walls as early as 1959. Fausto Melotti is yet another, a sculptor of delicate, twittering forms.
Besides Lo Savio, Melotti and Rotella, far more important figures, like Alberto Burri, Lucio Fontana, Piero Manzoni and some members of the Arte Povera movement who came to prominence in the mid-60's using materials as unorthodox as ice and lettuce, prove that Italian postwar painting and sculpture, at its best, was vital, experimental, original.
At its best. At its worst, it was dreary, and the show provides evidence of this, too. Modernism was not altogether quashed under Mussolini as it was under Hitler; geometric abstractions continued to be painted. But after the war, it became necessary to redefine abstraction in Italy, and artists like Giuseppe Capogrossi, Afro Balsadella, Giulio Turcato and Piero Dorazio helped to do so by making it something that represented liberalism, freedom and change. Symbolically significant though their works may be, however, they are ignored in America for a reason.
Their paintings set this show off to a shaky start. You get the sense that paintings and sculptures in the exhibition, on the whole, could have been more meticulously selected. A bold artist like Emilio Vedova is represented by good and bad examples. So is Fontana. Luciano Fabro, Tano Festa and Jannis Kounellis look entirely uninteresting.
A couple of themes emerge from the exhibition. One has to do with the baroque. Germano Celant, who headed the team of nine curators that put the show together, writes in the catalogue that Italian postwar art was largely ignored by the rest of Europe and by Americans because it was "too much in line with 'leftist' thought, to which the West demonstrated an absolute aversion." But, he adds, its rejection "may also have been caused by its sensual and 'baroque extremism.' " Just look at Fontana's colored-glass and stone-encrusted canvases or his ceramic "Crucifixion," not to mention Salvatore Ferragamo's shoes and Arnaldo Pomodoro's jewelry, to see what Mr. Celant is referring to. There's even a baroque quality to certain of the Arte Povera sculptures.
Another theme has to do with materials. Italian artists and designers were exceptionally resourceful. When Roberto Mango echoed a 1950 design by Don Knorr for his own 1952 chair, he nonetheless gave it a new twist by using string for the seat and back. Carla Accardi made tubular sculptures out of rolled Sicofoil decorated with yellow, orange and black stripes.
Burri was more remarkable. His abstractions at first looked very loosely like Mondrians, then evolved into something closer to Abstract Expressionist paintings. But his materials included scraps of burlap, which he sewed together, creating Robert Rauschenbergs before the fact. He used rusted iron, as Richard Serra would do. And he took sheets of plastic and burned and twisted them, to create a strangely elegant and visceral music that struck its most gothic note in the blood-red cobwebs and burn holes of "Red Plastic" (1964).
Manzoni's materials, too, were unusual. His works from 1958-59 are white-on-white canvases creased in the middle, as if squeezed by corsets. He used straw, rabbit skin and burned wood to concoct sculptures in the manner of Meret Oppenheim, in one case at least, and pictures that were readymade Action Paintings, with flying fur in place of flying paint. Eventually he canned his own feces.
Then, of course, came Arte Povera figures like Alighiero Boetti, who froze sculptures, and Michelangelo Pistoletto, who bent and spray-painted burned corrugated cardboard into the shape of a rose, and Mario Merz, who used sacks of earth, neon tubing and even a raincoat.
Arte Povera is a movement Mr. Celant defined in 1967, so it's not surprising that he presents the whole postwar period as culminating in it. The exhibition's painting and sculpture section takes up the Guggenheim ramp, with the Arte Povera artists at the top. Everything else is in side galleries. But the scale of the show isn't a problem, as you might think. Design, glassware, jewelry and ceramic sections could have been bigger, if anything. There should have been one for textiles, too.
It's important that different media be brought together. An artist like Fontana, for example, painted and did sculptures, ceramics and jewelry. Too bad there is none of his work in neon here, just a photograph of a neon he did for the 1951 Milan Triennale. (A Fontana neon would have looked better in the Guggenheim's rotunda than Gae Aulenti's pointless installation of giant triangles does.) In postwar Italy, as Fontana illustrates, art connoted more than painting and sculpture. It included everything from shoes to vacuum cleaners to the lighting of a room. It was a way of life.
"The Italian Metamorphosis, 1943-1968" remains at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, Fifth Avenue at 88th Street, through Jan. 22. The show is sponsored by the Italian Trade Commission, Centro di Firenze per la Moda Italiana and Telecom Italia. The show travels to Milan in February and to Wolfsburg, Germany, in May.

HEADLINE: China Energy Stock Listed on Big Board

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
China's booming energy sector received a cash infusion yesterday with the listing of a second company on the New York Stock Exchange.
The company, Huaneng Power International, China's largest independent power producer, issued 31.25 million American depository receipts at $20 each. 
 "Investors like the company very much," said Michael Bugel, an analyst with James Capel Asia in New York. "It has very strong government contacts."
Huaneng Power's stock was the sixth-most active on the exchange, with a volume of 2.64 million shares. It closed unchanged from its offering price of $20.
The listing came a day after the chief underwriter of the issue, Lehman Brothers, announced that it would lower the offering share price to $20, from the $27.50 noted in the company's preliminary prospectus.
An American depository receipt, or A.D.R., represents stock in a foreign company that is held in trust by a United States bank. A.D.R.'s are traded like stocks of American companies.
Half of Huaneng Power's A.D.R.'s are designated for sale in the United States and Canada, while a quarter will be offered to Asian investors and the rest to other investors outside China.
China's appetite for energy has outstripped supply in recent years, with the economy growing at double-digit rates. The country's total power generating capacity was 181,000 megawatts at the end of 1993. Official estimates call for an additional 17,000 megawatts in each of the next six years to meet demand.
Huaneng Power owns and operates five coal-fired power stations in various Chinese provinces and plans to acquire several more plants to expand its generating capacity to 7,500 megawatts by the end of the decade.
Huangeng Power is a subsidiary of a Chinese state company that was formed in 1985 to construct and operate power stations at a profit using imported power-generating equipment.
An unrelated company, the Shandong Huaneng Power Development Company (Hua neng means China power), became the first Chinese utility to list on the Big Board on Aug. 4. It reached a high of $14.375 on Aug. 12 and has since declined more than 10 percent. It closed yesterday at $11.625.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bond Prices Mixed Ahead Of Jobs Data

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Bond prices were mixed yesterday as investors and traders waited to see if today's employment report for September would confirm that the economy is expanding and thus heighten fears about the possibility of accelerating inflation.
The price of the 30-year bond was unchanged at 9429/32 to yield 7.95 percent, with rates for shorter-maturity bills also holding the line. 
 With inflation fears come new market expectations of another increase in interest rates by the Federal Reserve. For the market to rally, traders said, it must have confidence that the central bank is doing its job, while the bank has to show it is staying ahead of inflation.
A sharp rise in jobs today could prompt the Federal Reserve to raise short-term interest rates for the sixth time this year, analysts said. Market estimates of how many jobs were added to the economy last month range from 250,000 to 300,000, up from 179,000 in August.
An increase of more than 300,000 is likely to spur some move in the Federal funds rate or discount rate or both, analysts said. Since February, the central bank has lifted the Federal funds target to 4.75 percent from 3 percent and the discount rate to 4 percent from 3 percent.
David Cohen, an economist with MMS International in San Francisco, a market research and analysis firm, noted yesterday that only a month ago a report showing nonfarm payroll growth moderating to 179,000 in August was widely seen as corroborating the expansion's slowdown. Now the market awaits the September data worrying that a potential strong bounce in payrolls would confirm a new round of explosive growth.
Mr. Cohen said that a "moderate" payroll increase of 210,000 in September would suggest that "while the flow of data in the past month has reflected considerably more vitality than anticipated, it did not alter the likelihood that gross domestic product growth indeed slowed during the third quarter from the unsustainably strong pace of the previous three quarters."
Similarly, he said, that payroll growth -- averaging a robust 270,000 through the first eight months of 1994 -- is unlikely to be sustained.
An increase of 210,000, Mr. Cohen said, "would nevertheless be most respectable, reflecting a healthy labor market, consistent with the recent easing in initial unemployment claims to their lowest sustained level since 1989."
As far as wage pressures building, Mr. Cohen said that employers were holding the line, and expects that the average hourly wage in September will continue at a growth rate of two-tenths of 1 percent that had been the trend for the last three years.
"However, an uptick here or in nonfarm payrolls will raise the likelihood of a Fed tightening by mid-month," he said. "We see little chance of an immediate move on Friday."
His bet is for a rate increase of 50 basis points after the Fed's policy-making panel, the Federal Open Market Committee, meets next month. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
For most of the trading session yesterday, bonds bounced in a narrow range, with the Conference Board's help wanted index spurring short-covering early in the day.
The index for August fell 4 points, to 118, suggesting hiring had moderated after sustaining a rather torrid pace through much of the year.
Also yesterday, the initial jobless claims report for the week ended last Saturday released by the Labor Department rebounded 7,000, to 317,000, in line with market expectations but somewhat higher than anticipated by MMS International analysts. Despite the week's rise, the four-week moving average fell further to 319,000, its lowest level since May 1989.

HEADLINE: Waiting Out Japan's Trade Surplus

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Oct. 6

 BODY:
Even as the United States struggles to reach new market-opening agreements with Japan, some foreign and Japanese economists believe that natural forces could eliminate Japan's huge trade surplus within the next decade or two.
"The trade surplus will disappear toward the end of the decade," Robert Alan Feldman, the chief of economic research for Salomon Brothers in Tokyo, predicted. Edward J. Lincoln, an economic adviser to the United States Embassy in Tokyo, said, "Certainly in the first decade of the 21st century it will disappear." 
 According to some economic theories, what will make the trade surplus disappear is the aging of Japan's population, which will bring about an economic and social transformation of the nation that could liquidate its current account surplus -- essentially the trade surplus adjusted for some other flows, such as foreign aid, gifts to relatives in foreign countries and earnings from foreign investments. This surplus measured $131.4 billion last year.
By the year 2020, about one in four Japanese is expected to be at least 65 years old, compared with about one in seven now, in large part because of a low birth rate. That could give Japan, which celebrates a national holiday every September called Respect-for-the-Aged Day, the oldest population in the world.
Older people tend to draw down their savings to support themselves. So as Japan's population ages, the nation's currently high private savings rate should decline.
Economists say that Japan's current account surplus is a byproduct of the fact that Japan saves more than it invests at home. That difference is what it invests overseas -- and by definition it equals the current account surplus. So if saving is replaced by consumption, and if there is not an equal drop in investment within Japan, the inevitable result will be a drop in the current account surplus.
Japanese households save about 14 percent of their disposable income compared with about 4 percent for Americans. This is partly because many Japanese remember the deprivation after World War II. They must also save for a long time for home down payments, which are extraordinarily large compared with those in America, both because housing is expensive and because mortgage lenders demand large equity cushions.
But Charles Horioka, a professor at Osaka University, predicts that Japan's savings rate will "decline very sharply, possibly approaching zero or even negative by 2010 or 2020." The rate has already dropped from a peak of 23 percent in 1974.
The Japanese Government has been citing such an argument to its trading partners out of self-interest. Tokyo has urged other countries to take a long-term view of its perennial trade surplus, because the problem will go away as Japan's working- age population shrinks. In the short term, some Japanese say, the trade surplus is needed so the nation must keep saving to prepare for the burden of caring for more and more elderly citizens.
"There is an aspect of preparing for the aging society in Japan's current account surplus," Motoshige Itoh, a professor at the University of Tokyo, wrote in "Misunderstandings about the Trade Surplus," a book published this year by the research institute of Japan's Ministry of International Trade and Industry.
Washington ran into this argument recently when it urged Tokyo to cut taxes to stimulate its economy, which would in turn increase imports. When the Japanese Government recently cut income taxes, it also decided to offset this by raising the sales tax, partly on the ground that it was worried about affording care for the aging population.
Even if Japan's trade surplus with the rest of the world falls away, it might not mean better trade relations with the United States, since the surplus with America could continue.
While the trade imbalance between the United States and Japan of roughly $60 billion a year has come to symbolize the larger trade problems between the two nations, pressure to correct it comes from American companies that have trouble selling in Japan.
"It's not just an issue of macroeconomics, it's also an issue of fairness," Ambassador Walter F. Mondale of the United States said at a news conference last week.
Even if Japan's trade surplus were to disappear, Western economic analysts say, there could still be complaints that Japanese markets are closed, just as there are complaints from other countries about trading practices of the United States, which runs a large trade deficit.
In fact, relying on theories alone is chancy, because Japan's trade surplus has defied other predictions and proved remarkably resilient. In the last two years, the surplus has soared to new records, partly because Japan's recession reduced domestic demand for imported goods.
Kenneth Courtis, an economic strategist at the Deutsche Bank in Tokyo, points out, moreover, that in the future Japan will have a huge stream of income from the investments it is now making overseas with its surplus savings. That income, he argued, will largely offset the decline in the current account surplus caused by an aging population.
Even those who expect the surplus to diminish say it may not take place soon. Yukio Noguchi, a professor of economics at Hitotsubashi University, has analyzed this question, and thinks the surplus will turn negative for Japan, but not until the year 2025 or so.
Clinton Administration officials agree that the recent agreements opening Japan's insurance, government procurement and flat glass markets will not shrink Japan's trade surplus very much by themselves. An agreement on automobiles and auto parts, which accounts for the largest part of the American trade deficit with Japan, could have far more effect, but over the long run.
Far more effective in reducing Japan's surplus, some economists say, has been the increase by roughly 25 percent of the yen against the dollar in the last two years. That makes Japan's exports less competitive abroad and the country's imports more attractive at home.
The rising yen, coupled with a resumption of economic growth in Japan, should reduce the nation's current account surplus to below 2 percent of economic output in a few years. This is one of the goals of the trade framework agreement signed by the United States and Japan last year. The International Monetary Fund predicted last week that Japan's surplus would fall to 2.9 percent of gross domestic product this year and 2.6 percent next year, compared with 3.1 percent last year.
But complete elimination of the deficit might have to wait until Japan grows older. The nation has the world's highest average life expectancy, with women likely to live for 82.51 years and men for 76.25 years. The Government reported last month that 5,593 Japanese were now at least 100 years old in a population of 125 million, up by 791 from last year.
Kazumasa Iwata, a professor of social and international relations at the University of Tokyo, said that a reduction in savings by the Government would go far toward eliminating the trade imbalance.
Japan has slipped into a national budget deficit, although it still has a surplus in its social security account. But as people get old and start drawing their social security payments, that surplus, too, will turn into a deficit.
The effect of demographic change on investment in the domestic economy remains unclear. With the labor force shrinking, some economists say, investment in new factories might decline. Or it might rise, as more automation is stimulated by the scarcity of labor.
"We do not know what will happen to investment," Professor Noguchi said.

HEADLINE: Dow Off 11.78 as Market Awaits Report on Jobs

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE 

 BODY:
The stock market declined again yesterday as traders nervously awaited a closely watched economic indicator today: the announcement by the Labor Department about monthly job creation.
"It was the least interesting day in the last two weeks," said Bernard Spilko, senior vice president of Bank Julius Baer, about yesterday's market. "But the holding pattern will end when the employment numbers are reported." 
 If these numbers demonstrate that the economy is growing too fast, it could be a sign of accelerating inflation, and the Federal Reserve may move quickly to raise interest rates for the sixth time this year. "Otherwise, the increase could come after Election Day," Mr. Spilko added.
All three major market indicators fell, with the benchmark Dow Jones industrial average down 11.78 points, to 3,775.56. The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks dropped 1.16 points, to 452.36, while the Nasdaq composite index declined 2.09 points, to 744.19.
In addition, declines on the New York Stock Exchange outnumbered advances by 1,124 to 988. Volume was 271.4 million shares, slightly under the yearly average and well below Wednesday's turnover of 360.3 million shares.
Cyclical issues, which are sensitive to swings in the economy, led the downturn, just as they did the previous day. An example was the auto stocks; General Motors declined 1 5/8, to 44; Ford Motor fell 3/8, to 27 1/4, and Chrysler dropped 7/8, to 44 1/4.
Biotech stocks, which had been moving up in the last two weeks, were hard hit by profit taking. Included were Biogen, off 2 1/8, to 49 1/4, and Chiron, off 2 3/8, to 61 3/8.
On the other hand, many mining companies moved against the trend and wound up on higher ground. Cyprus Amax rose 5/8, to 30; Battle Mountain Gold advanced 1/2, to 12 3/4, and American Barrick increased 5/8, to 25 5/8.
Among the special situations, Union Pacific dropped 1 7/8, to 50, after its hostile offer on Wednesday to acquire Santa Fe Pacific for stock it valued at $18 a share. Santa Fe Pacific, the most active stock on the Big Board and currently in a merger deal with Burlington Northern, gained 7/8 to close at 13 1/2.
Also on the down side, Apple Computer declined 1 5/8, to 36 1/4, a day after it jumped 4 1/8. There have been widespread rumors that the computer company will be acquired by Motorola, and both companies refused to comment.
With hot weather in September discouraging customers from buying fall and winter merchandise, TJX, a leading retailer, announced a decline of 4 percent in same-store sales, and its stock fell 2 3/8, to 17 7/8. International Paper, an important component of the Dow Jones industrials, dropped 1 1/8, to 76 3/8.
Printonix, which makes microcomputer printers, rose 2 3/8, to 22 1/4, after reporting sharply higher second-quarter earnings this week. First Alert, a producer of a new carbon monoxide detector for residential use, advanced 3 1/2, to 38 3/4, after an American Stock Exchange statement that option trading in the company's stock would begin on Tuesday.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
The Dollar Is Little Changed As Traders Await Jobs Data

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar was little changed against most other leading currencies yesterday as dealers awaited a report on United States employment in September.
The jobs data could give the Federal Reserve persuasive evidence that inflation in the United States is accelerating. That , in turn, could prompt the central bank to raise short-term interest rates. 
 "All the markets -- bonds, stocks and currencies -- are waiting for the nonfarm payroll data," Tom Benfer, director of foreign exchange at the Bank of Montreal in New York, said. "The market is bracing for a strong number" in the increase in payrolls for the month, he said.
The Fed has increased interest rates five times this year. Bond prices tumbled after the previous rate increases, dragging down the value of the dollar. Currency dealers have been taking their cue from the American bond market to gauge demand among foreign investors for the dollar.
"There is no demand for dollar assets," Earl Johnson, a vice president at the Harris Trust and Savings Bank in Chicago, said. "U.S. stocks and bonds are weak, so foreign investors have little need for dollars."
While higher rates should, in theory, bolster the currency by attracting money into short-term dollar deposits and assets such as Treasury bills, that has been more than offset this year by weakness and volatility in American stock and bond markets.
"Although rates here are now higher relative to Europe, foreign investors suffer losses if they buy into U.S. bonds and interest rates go higher," Mr. Benfer said. "They will flock back to U.S. assets when they're convinced that the Fed is done" raising rates, he said.
In late New York trading yesterday, the dollar was virtually unchanged against the German mark, at 1.5436 marks from 1.5435 marks on Wednesday. The dollar rose slightly to 1.2795 Swiss francs, from 1.2785 Swiss francs on Wednesday. The dollar also edged up against the yen, rising to 99.88 yen, from 99.65 yen on Wednesday
But the dollar continued to weaken against the British pound, which has gained from higher interest rates. The pound was quoted at $1.5905 in New York trading, up from $1.5860 on Wednesday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with Wednesday, were: 5.2760 French francs, up from 5.2745; 1,567 Italian lire, down from 1,570, and 1.3468 Canadian dollars, up from 1.3453.

HEADLINE: THE 1994 CAMPAIGN: POLL;
Giuliani's Approval Rating Rises to 61%

BYLINE: By DAVID FIRESTONE 

 BODY:
Bolstered by his maverick support of a Democratic Federal crime bill, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani now has the approval of a majority New York City residents, according to a New York Times/WCBS-TV News Poll.
The poll, taken between Sept. 29 and Oct. 2 with 495 city residents participating, shows that the Mayor's approval rating has shot upward in the last three months, increasing to 61 percent from 49 percent in June. His rating is roughly tied with the first rating of Mayor David N. Dinkins four years ago; but Mr. Dinkins's popularity quickly began to decline, while Mr. Giuliani's seems to be on the rise. 
 In another finding, the poll showed that among registered voters across New York State, the state comptroller's race is a dead heat, with H. Carl McCall, the Democratic incumbent, tied with the Republican challenger, Herbert London.
The poll also showed that Karen S. Burstein, the Democratic candidate for state attorney general, has a comfortable lead over Dennis C. Vacco, the Republican, although neither candidate commanded a majority of those polled.
The poll had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus 4 percentage points among city residents and 3 percentage points among registered voters statewide.
The increasing popularity of Mr. Giuliani, who is a Republican, comes at a time of municipal retrenchment, with the Mayor ordering deep cuts in city spending and services to balance the budget. But few of his new supporters mentioned his belt-tightening in follow-up interviews. Rather, they cited his support for President Clinton's crime bill and his refusal to endorse automatically the Republican gubernatorial candidate, two positions that have annoyed many Republican Party leaders.
"He doesn't show partiality to any party," said Abraham R. Cutler, a retired city administrator who lives in the Pelham Parkway section of the Bronx. He now approves of the Mayor, after being undecided three months ago: "If he thinks something is good for the city, like the crime bill, he supports it, just like he's doing with Cuomo and Pataki. He's got an open mind on things."
The Mayor has so far withheld his endorsement in the gubernatorial race between Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and his Republican opponent, State Senator George E. Pataki.
But the poll showed that despite the Mayor's popularity, his endorsement makes no difference to 69 percent of the New York City residents polled. Seventeen percent said it would make them more likely to vote for his choice, and 11 percent said it would make them less likely.
Mr. Giuliani's approval rating is lower than that of former Mayor Edward I. Koch at his peak in 1981, when 71 percent of New Yorkers approved of his performance. Mr. Koch's rating eventually declined to 33 percent in 1989. Mr. Dinkins's rating began at 56 percent in 1990, and quickly declined to 29 percent by the next year. It was at 45 percent at the end of his term.
In an indication that even municipal layoffs cause jitters in a troubled economy, 46 percent of the city residents polled said they would rather have local taxes raised than see the city lay off workers to balance the budget. Twenty-eight percent said they would prefer the layoffs.
The results in the comptroller's race indicate that Mr. McCall is having difficulty generating name recognition and support from his incumbency. Though he is the only black candidate running for statewide office on a major ticket, Mr. McCall has even failed to make significant headway among black voters. The poll showed that he is supported by 57 percent of black voters, and that 30 percent of the respondents who are black are undecided.
In another statewide race, the poll showed Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the incumbent, with a wide lead over Bernadette Castro, the Republican candidate. If the election were held today, 65 percent of those polled said they would vote for Mr. Moynihan, and 18 percent said they would support Ms. Castro.
The poll asked several questions about Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, a leading supporter and organizer of Mr. Pataki's run for governor. As they did in a similar poll two years ago, only a quarter of respondents expressed a favorable opinion of Mr. D'Amato, while a plurality -- 35 percent -- had an unfavorable opinion, and 45 percent said they believe he does not have the honesty and integrity they would like to see in a senator. Thirty-one percent said they believe he does.
Fifty-two percent of those polled, however, said it made no difference to them whether Mr. D'Amato would exert influence over Mr. Pataki if he were elected. The Cuomo campaign has repeatedly tried to stress the close ties between the two Republicans, hoping some of Mr. D'Amato's tarnish will rub off on Mr. Pataki.
Another poll, released yesterday by the Quinnipiac College Polling Institute in Hamden, Conn., found a 3 percentage point lead for Mr. Pataki among likely voters. The poll, conducted among 691 people who said they would definitely vote on Nov. 8, had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus 4 percentage points.
The results were similar to those of the Times/WCBS-TV News poll, released Tuesday, which also showed the Republican gubernatorial candidate leading by 3 points. Because his lead was within the margin of error of the two polls, Mr. Pataki and Mr. Cuomo are considered statistically tied.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Companies
 General Electric took a big step toward letting Kidder, Peabody go. G.E. announced a broad revamping of its troubled brokerage unit that includes staff cuts of 10 percent and cost reductions totaling $100 million. Kidder also plans to sell $30 billion of its assets, including huge holdings in Government bonds. [Page D1.] 
 Salomon lost $100 million in the quarter, largely from losses on trading the Salomon Brothers unit did for its own account. [D1.]
 The nation's big retail chains reported disappointing sales for September. Some chains lowered third-quarter earnings forecasts as a result. The slowdown was attributed to the weather. [D1.]
 Santa Fe Pacific rejected Union Pacific's takeover offer. Analysts said the $3.4 billion offer would raise antitrust concerns. [D4.]
 Thirty-two insurers agreed pay $36 million to settle an antitrust lawsuit. The companies had been accused of conspiring to restrict the availability of liability coverage to towns in the 80's. [D4.]
 Coors will end a brewery tradition and restrict employees' on-site beer consumption. Coors said it would be the last of the nation's largest breweries to ban on-the-job drinking. [D4.]
 The F.C.C. is cautiously moving toward changing a rule that limits the networks to filling just three hours of prime time. [D15.]
 
International
 Japan's huge trade surplus could disappear because of natural forces, some economists believe. The surplus, which the United States points to as a symbol of the larger trade problems between the two nations, will shrink as the Japanese population ages, these economists say. Older Japanese draw more on savings, and this would bring about an economic and social transformation that could liquidate the nation's current account surplus. [D1.]
 
The Economy
 Congressional inaction on the S.E.C. budget has benefited companies that are registering bond issues. Registration fees have been cut almost in half because the fee rate must be renewed through legislation, something being blocked by a succession of objections being raised by Republican senators running for re-election. [D2.]
 The typical American household saw its income decline in 1993, despite a growing economy, Census Bureau data show. [A16.]
 
Markets
 The New York Stock Exchange unanimously elected Richard A. Grasso to succeed William H. Donaldson as its chairman and chief executive. Mr. Grasso is the first exchange staff member to rise to the top job in its 202-year history. [D2.]
 Treasury prices were steady as investors awaited today's employment report for signs of inflationary pressures. [D5.]
 Stocks were lower in cautious trading ahead of the September jobs report. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 11.78 points. [D6.]
 The dollar was little changed against other leading currencies. But the British pound continued to advance. [D13.]
 Corn prices fell sharply after a firm forecast a record crop. Coffee prices dropped after a report of rain in Brazil. [D13.]
 
Today's Columns
 Some films are naturals for licensing merchandise; and then there's "Forrest Gump." The film has unexpectedly become a big generator of merchandise licensed to bear its name and logos. Its success underscores the mercurial nature of licensed merchandise as a marketing tool. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D1.]
 This was going to be the year airline stocks would get a lift from a growing economy. But earnings have been hurt by some fare cuts and economies in corporate travel budgets. Market Place. [D6.]

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
Congress, Haiti and Ravens

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL 

 BODY:
Often, listening to some of the American journalists and politicians who opposed the U.S. intervention in Haiti, you can hear clearly what they do not say. They want the mission to fail and Haiti to explode into violence and chaos.
They do not want American troops to be killed. But if casualties do come, they are poised, mouth and computer at the ready, to scream havoc. 
 They think of themselves as in favor of democracy. But they are so committed to the idea that Haitians are incapable of achieving or maintaining it that they await the first stumbles with chilling eagerness.
They are so full of angers at President Clinton that they get hives at the thought that his decision to move against the Haitian dictators will burnish his name internationally and maybe even do a little something for him in 1996.
These ravens are a minority compared with Americans who opposed military involvement in Haiti but hope it will work. The reason to take account of them now is that at the first sign of trouble they will demand the one step guaranteed to wreck the American mission: the immediate military and economic desertion of Haiti.
Nothing, I think, can raise the raven people from the dyspeptic ditch into which they have thrown themselves. But for Americans with open eyes, hearts and mind, the operation has been a great teacher of the nature of dictatorship. Many Americans, blessed with freedom, might not have understood.
Even with American troops present, the dictatorship beat their people with clubs, or shot them dead in the street.
We could understand then that the dictatorship was destined to do this, although the world watched. The police had no other choice because the dictatorship could conceive of no other way of dealing with the people.
We learned that unless American troops had landed, the generals would never have agreed to leave power. Only when they knew that American troop planes were in the air did the generals acknowledge that their reign was over. All the negotiations, for the three years they were in power, were a fraud. By definition honorable dictators do not exist.
And when we saw Haitians run to greet the Americans we knew at once that the joy grew out of the hate they bore for those who beat them and shot them. In the streets, it was election day in Haiti -- under the guns of the tyranny but poignantly clear in choice.
President Clinton and U.S. forces still have work to do in Haiti and enemies to take on. But they have done much of what they can do by themselves. Now it is up to President Aristide and Congress. Either can make and destroy the mission.
President Aristide, although elected by his people and overthrown by killers, is not liked in America, very not liked. "Loony Communist" is the most affectionate term of the ravens. But large numbers of non-ravens also resent him.
He has given them plenty of reason. The Heritage Foundation has compiled a list of bone-mean Aristide insults and inanities about the U.S., incitements to kill, Socialist blather and capitalist-baiting. He admires Che Guevara and thinks Christopher Columbus was nothing but "a big white man, a colonial" who stole and exploited America. Columbus was not at all big.
But the mission was not simply to restore Mr. Aristide but to prepare the way for an elected successor next year. American officials urge amnesty for Haitian murderers. If Mr. Aristide works toward a free election, Americans and Haitians will find it in them to give him amnesty for leftish nastiness.
Congress can do more to help or hurt Haitians than Mr. Aristide can. The good news is that right now it is helping, by resisting pressure to set a specific date for withdrawal of U.S. troops. Republican and Democratic senators understood that would be a gift to the followers of the dictatorship.
But when the troops withdraw, Congress could nullify their work and the whole mission unless it appropriates some money to help Haitians get the small-business credits they need so desperately, build roads and communications destroyed by the decades of tyrannies.
To help a neighbor out of a burning house and then walk away leaving him naked and hungry -- it does not seem sensible, compassionate or the American way, if raven-friends will forgive the sentimentality.

HEADLINE: New Jersey Gets Warning On Auto Emissions Rules

BYLINE: By JOSEPH F. SULLIVAN 

DATELINE: TRENTON, Oct. 6

 BODY:
New Jersey legislators were told today by Federal officials that they must enact tough new auto emissions standards by February or face sanctions that could virtually shut down road-building and business expansion in the state by next summer.
Officials of the United States Environmental Protection Agency told the lawmakers at a hearing here that the state had exhausted its discretion under the Federal Clean Air Act of 1990 to obtain additional time to lower pollution from automobiles. They said that Federal sanctions would be triggered automatically if the February deadline passed without tough new state standards. 
 Members of Governor Christine Todd Whitman's cabinet also urged passage of the required legislation. But the legislators, many of whom face re-election next year, said they were worried about the reaction of motorists to a program that some say is too expensive and unworkable. Some lawmakers said they doubted there were enough votes to approve the new standards.
The Environmental Protection Agency, under the 1990 Federal law, is requiring New Jersey to create an enhanced system of inspection and maintenance to cut down on auto emissions. Senator Robert E. Littel, the chairman of the Senate Appropriations Committee, said that it could cost as much as $700 million to create the new system.
"The E.P.A. has a failed system on its hands and instead of admitting it and returning to the drawing board, they attempt to punish the states that refuse to implement their system," he said.
The new testing system would be a significant technical advance over the current tailpipe test, which measures hydrocarbons and carbon monoxide, two of the three major pollutants from auto exhaust. In the new test, computers connected to a dynamometer -- a treadmill device that causes a car to replicate its highway performance at various speeds -- measure those two pollutants as well as nitrogen oxide, which creates ground-level ozone.
Several states in the Northeast have either suspended their new auto emission testing programs or refused to create them. But Richard Wilson, Deputy Assistant E.P.A. Commissioner for air and radiation, said most of the 23 states under Federal orders to adopt enhanced emissions tests in their urban areas were complying. He said that the few holdouts were expected eventually to come around.
Maine, for example, has suspended its mandatory testing program, but is expected to resume it in March. Vermont has refused to adopt legislation and faces Federal sanctions. Delaware put its program on hold while it looked for less expensive ways of meeting the Federal guidelines. And Virginia is discussing the program with the E.P.A.
"It's a new program and there is always some controversy when you introduce something that affects all the public," Mr. Wilson said.
Because it is the most densely populated state in the country, New Jersey is the only state required to conduct the new tests in all parts of the state. Other states must introduce the tests only in urban centers. To meet the Federal guidelines, New Jersey must reduce auto emissions of organic compounds including hydrocarbons and carbon monoxide by 25 percent and nitrogen oxide by 75 percent by the year 2005 in southern New Jersey and 2007 in the northern half of the state.
Motorists would pay a fee of $28 for the new test. But if their cars fail, they might be required to pay at least $450 for repairs to fix the emission problem, according to Federal officials.
But Mr. Wilson said that only 3 percent of the cars are expected to need major repairs. He said most problems could be fixed for less than $100. He said that the new system, far from being expensive, represents "the best and cheapest way to provide clean air for New Jersey."
Several senior members of the Whitman administration -- Frank Wilson, the Transportation Commissioner, Deborah T. Poritz, the Attorney General, and Robert C. Shinn Jr., the Environmental Protection Commissioner -- warned the legislators that the state faces serious consequences if new regulations are not adopted on time.
Mr. Wilson said his department "could be effectively out of business after Feb. 2, 1995." He said New Jersey could lose $500 million in Federal highway funds and 20,000 construction jobs, as well as money for mass transportation. Other witnesses said the sanctions would impose tough new pollution-control requirements on businesses seeking to expand or move into the state.
Senator Joseph M. Kyrillos Jr., chairman of the Senate Natural Resources, Trade and Economic Committee, which conducted the hearing along with the Assembly Environment and Energy Committee, said he was frustrated by the inflexibility of the program and what he characterized as the apparent indifference of Federal officials to the consequences of the threatened sanctions. "If imposed, these sanctions would essentially bring the economy of this state to a standstill," he said.

CORRECTION-DATE: October 8, 1994, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
A picture caption in some editions yesterday about the New Jersey Legislature and new automobile emission rules misidentified the man second from the right. He is Kevil Duhon, an aide to the State Senate Committee on Natural Resources, Trade and Economic Development, not Frank Wilson, the Transportation Commissioner.
