HEADLINE: U.S. SENDS FORCE AS IRAQI SOLDIERS THREATEN KUWAIT

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7

 BODY:
Iraqi troops took up positions near Kuwait today, prompting President Clinton to dispatch Navy and Marine forces to the region and to warn that Washington would defend its Persian Gulf allies.
Pentagon officials said that Iraq had moved 10,000 troops, including forces from its elite Hammurabi division, to the area near Basra, about 30 miles from the Kuwait border, bringing the total number of Iraqi troops in the area to between 40,000 and 50,000. 
 The division, part of Iraq's Republican Guard, escaped destruction in the Persian Gulf war three and a half years ago and is among the country's most potent and highly trained forces.
Another division, the Nida, was also reported to be heading south. Pentagon officials said they did not know if this division intended to take up positions near Kuwait.
American officials said the troop deployments, the most threatening moves Iraq has taken since the gulf war, were probably a bluff intended to encourage the United Nations Security Council to lift economic sanctions imposed after Iraq invaded Kuwait in August 1990.
But chastened by the failure to anticipate the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait three years ago, officials said that they could not be sure of President Saddam Hussein's intentions and that Washington was making a commanding show of force to warn Baghdad not to attack. Despite its defeat, Iraq has never acknowledged Kuwait's autonomy.
At a White House press conference, Mr. Clinton said he had ordered "precautionary steps" and would not permit Baghdad to intimidate the United Nations into lifting sanctions. "It would be a grave mistake for Saddam Hussein to believe for any reason that the United States would have weakened its resolve on the same issues that involved us in that conflict just a few years ago," President Clinton said.
Pentagon officials said that the next two days could be critical in determining whether to send ground troops or take other military steps.
The state-run Iraqi News Agency denied any intention by Baghdad to invade Kuwait, saying "peace-loving Iraq has no aggressive intentions."
But at the United Nations, Iraq's Deputy Prime Minister, Tariq Aziz, delivered a scathing speech demanding that the Security Council end trade and oil embargoes that have devastated the Iraqi economy.
Madeleine K. Albright, the United States delegate to the United Nations, countered that Mr. Aziz was ignoring Iraq's failure to abide by several United Nations demands.
To strengthen its forces, President Clinton ordered the American aircraft carrier George Washington from the Adriatic to the Red Sea, which would put its planes within striking distance of Iraq. An Aegis cruiser, which is equipped with Tomahawk cruise missiles, is also being deployed to the Red Sea. Pentagon officials said it would take four or five days for the ships to get there.
The Pentagon also ordered a Marine amphibious group to leave the United Arab Emirates and steam to the northern Gulf. An Aegis cruiser and a destroyer, each equipped with cruise missiles, are already on routine patrol in the Persian Gulf.
One of the most important steps the Pentagon took was to order maritime prepositioning ships, huge floating warehouses based at Diego Garcia in the Indian Ocean, to set sail for the Gulf. The ships contain tanks, vehicles and war materiel for a force of 16,500 Marines, including 5,000 fighting men.
In addition, the Pentagon is sending ships with Army equipment from Diego Garcia, perhaps enough to equip a brigade of 6,000 troops. The Army has already stored enough equipment in Kuwait for a brigade.
A senior Pentagon official said that American troops, whose number he put at less than 20,000, had been alerted for possible deployment to the gulf. They would be flown in to link up with the equipment now en route.
The United States has also stepped up reconnaissance flights. Washington still has about 70 planes on the Arabian peninsula, which have been enforcing the no-flight zone in southern Iraq.
Ms. Albright told a closed meeting of the Security Council, that if Iraqi forces continued to stream south, Iraq would have a total force of 60,000 to strike Kuwait. The force would be equipped with 700 tanks and 900 armored personnel carriers.
The American force being sent is substantial, but still a far cry from the allied force of more than 500,000 that defeated Iraq in the Persian Gulf war in 1991.
The swiftness of Washington's response reflects the Clinton Administration's belief that Iraq remains a menace to the region. The Bush Administration sought to destroy Iraq's ability to threaten its neighbors during the Persian Gulf war, but fell short. According to the Central Intelligence Agency, half of the Iraqi Republican Guard, including about 365 T-72 tanks, got away.
One of the divisions, the Hammurabi, was the unit that was spared destruction when President Bush ordered an end to the ground war after only 100 hours. Officials said that the two Iraqi divisions heading south have about 350 tanks.
All told, Iraq has about 28 divisions, including 7 Republican Guard divisions. According to estimates, Iraq's army numbers about 350,000, about 100,000 of which are reservists. That is far short of its one-million-man military during the gulf war. But it is enough to intimidate and invade tiny Kuwait.
Administration officials said the Iraqi deployments are probably saber-rattling intended to underscore Baghdad's demands for the lifting of the economic sanctions. The Security Council is scheduled to take up the issue of the sanctions next week. The United States wants to keep the sanctions, but Turkey, Russia and France want to lift them.
Iraq may be trying to show that it will stir up trouble if the sanctions are not lifted. Baghdad may also be calculating that the United States has been distracted by its intervention in Haiti and the fighting in Bosnia. On Oct. 4, President Saddam Hussein condemned the American-led effort to maintain the sanctions, saying that "the Iraqi people will render helpless those harboring ill intentions."
But American officials said that the Iraqi actions would strengthen Washington's argument that the sanctions should not be lifted. Defense Secretary William J. Perry said the troop movements "are not routine and are not typical of what we've seen in the past and therefore cause us concern."
The Saudi Foreign Minister, Saud al-Faisal, met briefly with President Clinton this afternoon. Mr. Clinton assured the Saudis that Washington has an ironclad commitment to Saudi security, and the Saudis were reported to have said they would cooperate with American efforts to defend the Gulf.


GRAPHIC: With members of the elite Iraqi Republican Guards heading toward the border with Kuwait, the United States called a limited troop alert and sent an aircraft carrier to the Red Sea. It is also sending 2,000 marines to the Gulf and dispatching huge floating warehouses of weapons in case troops are flown in. (Sources: Department of Defense Associated Press) (pg. 6)

IRAQI THREAT TO KUWAIT
Iraqi troops moved toward the border with Kuwait, prompting President Clinton to send American forces to the region and to warn that the United States would defend its Persian Gulf allies. 1

Kuwait lives with a strong sense of insecurity, more than three years after the end of the Persian Gulf war, with many young Kuwaitis feeling hopelessness about the future of their country. 1
 
C.I.A. TIES TO HAITIAN GUNMEN
The head of Haiti's most infamous paramilitary group was on the C.I.A. payroll for two years, even after his group helped chase away American troops preparing for the exiled leader's return. 1
 
NARROW AMNESTY IN HAITI
The Haitian Senate approved a narrow amnesty proposal that would excuse leaders only from political offenses, not criminal ones, increasing the pressure on them to leave the country. 4
 
SOUTH AFRICA A HARD SELL

HEADLINE: CONGRESS WINDS DOWN: THE PRESIDENT;
Clinton Assails G.O.P. for Effort To 'Kill It or Just Talk It to Death'

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7

 BODY:
After months of watching Congress shoot huge holes in his legislative agenda, President Clinton fought back today, saying the Republicans had pursued a strategy to "stop it, slow it, kill it or just talk it to death."
Mr. Clinton's accusation of obstructionism, issued as Congress prepared to leave town without a crowning achievement and with the midterm elections now little more than four weeks away, was meant to transfer blame to Republicans for inaction that polls indicate has left many voters disillusioned with Congress and with Washington in general. 
 Today the Senate dealt a final blow to legislation that would have restricted lobbying and gift-giving in the capital and then, with the House, resumed an agonizing crawl toward adjournment that left what remains of their business in limbo. [Page 9.]
But the White House had already begun to switch gears for a daunting political campaign, scheduling the formal afternoon news conference at which the President made his case.
Mr. Clinton not only complained about the way the Republicans, led by Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, the House minority whip, had blocked a whole string of measures in the final weeks of Congress, but he also tried to make the case for why Americans should vote for Democratic candidates, particularly the party's endangered incumbents.
He mocked the national "contract" of promises that Republicans presented in Washington last week, calling it a throwback to failures of the past. While he acknowledged that the achievements of the 103d Congress had been modest, he said it had taken substantial strides in important directions.
"It was only a beginning, and more could have been done," Mr. Clinton said of the successes and failures of his first 20 months in office, which have left him burdened by low public approval ratings. He said he feared that his economic achievements had too often been overlooked.
But on health care, campaign finance reform and a welter of other areas in which he had promised that his Presidency would make a difference, he declared that the void that remained was the fault of Republicans intent on turning back the clock.
"What is the direction you want?" Mr. Clinton said, rehearsing the question he plans to pose across the country between now and the elections on Nov. 8. He said the Democrats were committed to "fighting for the future, not going back to the past," and echoed the plea that President Ronald Reagan made to voters as midterm elections neared 12 years ago, at a time of recession-driven political distress.
"Staying the course," Mr. Clinton said, "is good for the country."
An election held today could result in Democratic losses so heavy as to leave the Senate and even the House under Republican control, some polls show. That would almost certainly leave Mr. Clinton unable to deliver on his many unredeemed campaign promises, and his aides said he planned to travel to a dozen states in the next 25 days alone in trying to fend off that politically catastrophic prospect.
With his own popularity sagging, aides to Mr. Clinton recognize that the effect of his appeals may be limited. But they said his remarks today served as the opening volley of an effort to convince voters angry at gridlock that the way out lies not in repudiating incumbents but in punishing the Republicans, whom the President portrayed as standing in the way of progress.
In denouncing the "contract" that 300 Republican Congressional candidates offered last week on the steps of the Capitol, Mr. Clinton renewed Democratic efforts to apply an unsavory appearance to a potentially appealing package that includes calls for a balanced-budget amendment, tax breaks and a military buildup.
"Do they really want this contract," the President said of American voters, "which is a trillion dollars of unfunded promises, a contract which will certainly lead to higher deficits, cuts in Medicare and throwing us back to the years of the 80's, when we lost jobs and weakened our country?
"Or do we want to face up to the challenges which were not met in this Congress and use the next Congress to keep the economic growth going, to pass health care reform, to pass welfare reform, to pass political reform and to deal with these environmental issues?"
Mr. Clinton looked and sounded somewhat tense throughout the 45-minute news conference, in the chandelier-adorned East Room of the White House. The political message he offered had been developed in weeks of meetings involving him and top advisers, but some aides said he recognized the risk in arguing, as he did today, that the country is moving in the right direction when polls show that nearly 6 in 10 Americans believe it is on the the wrong track.
The President began the session by reading a statement intended to underscore his accomplishments in creating jobs and building a healthier economy. But he had to contend with questions that lurched from his political plight to military moves by Iraq to accusations of impropriety leveled against Henry G. Cisneros, the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development.
On the subject of Mr. Cisneros, the President voiced strong support for the Housing Secretary, saying a controversy over his payments to a former mistress should not disqualify him from continuing to serve in the Cabinet. Mr. Clinton was not asked about what his aides regard as the more sensitive question: whether Mr. Cisneros lied to the Federal Bureau of Investigation about the payments when the bureau was conducting its pre-appointment background check on him.
Mr. Clinton attributed his own lack of popularity to "a period of drag" that has plagued nearly all modern Presidents in midterm election years. He noted that Republicans suffered heavy losses even in 1982, only two years before President Reagan rebounded to win a landslide re-election victory.
Mr. Clinton said part of his problem was that too few Americans knew of his accomplishments, including a four-year low in unemployment announced by the Labor Department today. "The record is a good one," he said, "and there is ample evidence that if people knew the record, they would respond to it."

GRAPHIC: Photo: With elections a month off, the President went on the attack yesterday. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Recycled Material Is Finding A New and Lucrative Market

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
Recycling is being transformed from a gesture to help the environment into a solid business. Used paper, cardboard and newspaper that had recently languished in warehouses are now hot commodities. The reasons: an economic recovery that has increased demand for raw materials, and a commitment by manufacturers to build the mills that can process recycled products.
The surge in demand has sent prices soaring, and has made it more likely that what is rescued from the trash at home and in the office will find a valuable use somewhere else in this country. In the past, much of the trash collected for recycling was exported because of low domestic prices. 
 Bales of old corrugated boxes that sold for as much as $35 a ton in September 1993 shot up to as much as $110 a ton in the Midwest by last month. Waste paper collected from offices went from less than $15 a ton to more than $85 in the same period. Newspapers jumped from less than $30 a ton to more than $55. There have been similar increases in most other regions.
Prices for steel cans, which are melted and used to make new steel, have increased to a range of $70 to $110 a ton east of the Mississippi, from $30 to $70 a ton two years ago.
Even some plastics, typically the weak sisters among recyclable materials, are in greater demand. A poor cotton harvest in China in recent months has had brokers in Western states scurrying to gather old soda bottles to be transformed into synthetic fibers for the textile industry there.
"The last year represents the beginning of the maturing of the recycling industry," said Ralph Earle, an environmental strategist with Arthur D. Little Inc., the consulting firm. He said investments over the last six to eight years in equipment to collect, transport and process recycled material have created momentum for the industry.
Indeed, recycling is becoming a significant line of business for some other companies, as well. Browning- Ferris Industries, the nation's second-largest trash hauler, expects recycling revenue to approach $400 million this year, or about 10 percent of its total. As recently as 1989, recycling amounted to less than 1 percent of the company's revenue.
"This is the fastest-growing business we have," said Philip Angell, an aide to William D. Ruckelshaus, Browning-Ferris's chairman. "And the margins are in the mid-teens, which produces respectable profits." The company can thus sell the recycled paper for about 15 percent more than it costs to collect and process it.
"Recycling has become a big business," said J. Winston Porter, an environmental consultant who was assistant administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency from 1985 to 1989. "Something like one-quarter of the nation's garbage is being handled" this way, he said.
The current situation is in contrast with that in the late 1980's, when very limited capacity spurred fear of a landfill crisis, particularly in the Northeast. This led some cities and states to adopt laws encouraging or requiring families and businesses to separate cans, bottles and paper from other trash so they could be recycled. Such recycling continues in a number of these places.
However, collection is only part of the recycling process. Once collected, the material must go through a factory or mill where it can be processed into a product some one wants to buy.
From 70 to 80 percent, by weight, of all material collected for recycling consists of paper products of some kind, according to people in the industry. But most mills were equipped only to make products using virgin fiber from trees and were not prepared to handle the new flood of used paper.
The result was a sharp drop in prices for the growing supply of waste paper collected. Just a few years ago, the markets were so bad that many paper brokers charged customers a fee to take the paper off their hands.
But there have been other forces at work to halt that trend and turn it around. Recycling programs are popular with voters, and states and cities ratcheted up recycling goals. Big trash-hauling companies like Browning-Ferris and WMX Technologies added recycling programs to their bids for collection contracts, although industry executives grumble that it is hard to make money with curb-side programs because of the costs of collection and sorting.
A year ago, President Clinton issued an executive order requiring Federal agencies and the military to buy printing and writing paper with a minimum of 20 percent recycled fiber.
In addition to household paper, collection companies focused on office buildings and large institutions, where large loads of relatively clean paper could be picked up at one stop. Company officials say the commercial, rather than residential, part of the recycling business is where the money is to be made.
Recycled paper has long been used in products requiring lower grades of paper, like facial tissues, toilet paper and cereal boxes. The makers of higher grades, for use in printing and writing paper, generally insisted on virgin fiber to control the quality of their products. But today, even makers of the highest-grade papers are finding ways to incorporate recycled fiber because of the public demand.
With their customers pressed into demanding recycled paper, paper companies began installing equipment capable of removing ink and preparing the paper fibers for reuse on big paper-forming machines. Unlike aluminum and steel, which can be recycled endlessly, recycling weakens paper fibers, so that only 80 to 85 percent can be used again.
When paper mills install recycling equipment, they want to run it continuously, the way they do their other machinery. That requires an assured supply.
An expanding economy increases demand for most commodities, so demand for aluminum and steel cans is higher than a year ago, as is demand for the polyethylene ter-ephthalate plastic used in big soda bottles and the high-density polyethylene used in milk jugs.
Chinese manufacturers appear to be heavy buyers of the former for use as an alternate fiber in textiles -- the plastic can be manufactured into thread -- and the high-density polyethylene appears to be going into the chemical industry as a raw material, said Chaz Miller, manager of recycling for the Environmental Industries Association, which represents the waste-management industry.
A lot of plant additions capable of processing waste paper, cardboard and newspaper are expected to come on line in the next two years. For example, plant capacity for recycled office paper is expected to rise by nearly four million tons in 1995 and 1996, up from an increase of less than 700,000 tons in 1993 an 1994.
The increases are so great that they raise questions about whether the current collection system will be able to supply them all.
"The question is where we can get new sources of fiber," said John Ruston, an analyst with the Environmental Defense Fund. "The B.F.I.'s of this world," he said of Browning-Ferris, "have pretty much tapped out the big office buildings, so they are going to have to look at new sources like shopping malls and stores. They are also going to have to figure out how to get paper out of smaller cities."
The competition for fiber, he said, will force producers of lower-grade paper products, like tissues, to look at alternatives that until now have not been widely recycled.
"They are going to have to dig deeper into the waste stream and look at things like junk mail," Mr. Ruston said. "A lot of new products will be coming to market."

That Has Prices Soaring" shows prices paid by mills for each ton of recyclable material in the Midwest. (Source: "Recycling Times," published by Environmental Industries Association) (pg. 41)

HEADLINE: CONGRESS WINDS DOWN: THE CONGRESS;
At the Capitol, Much Talk But Hardly Any Action

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7

 BODY:
Congress praised itself today, denounced itself and complained that the public misunderstood it, while crawling toward adjournment with hardly any votes on anything.
The most decisive action was a Republican victory. The Senate voted not to vote on legislation requiring lobbyists to register and report who pays them and prohibiting members of Congress from accepting gifts and golf junkets. The measure died after the Senate fell 10 votes short of the 66 needed to break a Republican-led filibuster against the bill, which the House passed last week. 
 Then the Senate moved on, wallowing in four more Republican filibusters, one against a bill to protect the California desert and three against Air Force promotions bitterly opposed by Senator Charles E. Grassley, Republican of Iowa. He accused two of the candidates of mismanagement on military projects and the third of illegally interfering with a promotion board.
Another bill that was dying in the Senate would apply all Federal workplace laws, like those involving discrimination, overtime and occupational safety, to Congress. The House passed it on Aug. 10 but tonight gave up on the Senate. Instead, by a 348-to-3 vote, the House amended its rules to apply most aspects of those laws to itself alone.
All day long, more energy and imagination went into analyzing the results of the 103d Congress than legislating. Indeed, the analyzing began at midday even though no one knew whether the legislative record for this Congress (except for the scheduled post-election session on trade legislation) would be completed tonight, Saturday or even Sunday. The House adjourned a few minutes after midnight, but senators said they would work into the weekend.
Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, the majority leader, said, "We believe the record of the 103d Congress will be one of significant accomplishment, particularly in four areas: economic growth, trade, education and crime." He stressed economic growth, saying the record of Congress and the Administration was "nothing short of spectacular."
Like most Democrats who sounded off today, he accused Republicans of "total obstruction."
Republican leaders in the House also claimed success, but from a very different perspective. "We can be proud of this session," said Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, the deputy leader. "We were able to stop the big spending last spring. We were able to stop the worst parts of the crime bill.
"It is not obstructionist," Mr. Gingrich said. "It is interpreting the will of the American people."
Speaker Thomas S. Foley of Washington also claimed great, though misunderstood, accomplishment. "In area after area, this Congress has done extraordinary, even historic work," he said. Asked why the public did not appear to share that perception, he lashed out at the press, saying Congress had been "poorly reported."
"We pass record, historic education bills, they go on page 8" Mr. Foley said. "On the other hand, if something is blocked in the Senate, again, it goes on page 1. And then when a bill is mugged, the mugger is half the time praised for his proficiency in mugging the legislation, and the victim is condemned for having been mugged."
Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican leader, was one of the very few to offer a mixed report card. He recalled bipartisan cooperation with Mr. Clinton, from the North American Free Trade Agreement "to the Russian reconstruction program to approving all the appropriations bills before the new fiscal year to rapid approval of the President's Cabinet and Supreme Court nominees -- there were many areas of bipartisan cooperation."
He continued: "It goes without saying that there were also issues of disagreement. The so-called stimulus package. The budget. Health care reform. The crime bill. Campaign finance reform. Republicans make no apologies for trying to protect the American taxpayer from bad legislation in each of these areas."
Senator William S. Cohen of Maine, one of the nine Republicans who voted to bring the lobbying bill to a vote, offered a more general explanation of public doubts about Congress. He said they came from the belief that "laws are being shaped by high-paid lobbyists who don't really reflect the views or needs of the people."
He said the filibuster was thwarting the public's wishes. "People want to know who is being paid how much to lobby whom on what issues," Mr. Cohen said.
Senator Carl M. Levin of Michigan, a Democrat who with Mr. Cohen led the effort for the bill, said current lobbying laws are "permeated with holes, loopholes, promoting disrespect for laws."
On Thursday, a first effort to break the filibuster failed when Republicans contended that the measure would inhibit grass-roots lobbying. So today the bill's sponsors, who said the fears were groundless, offered to take out all sections that dealt with grass-roots lobbying -- lobbying like the campaign that deluged the Capitol with telephone calls against this bill.
But opponents would not accept that change. Senator Don Nickles, Republican of Oklahoma, said he might want to amend the changes. Senator Mitch McConnell, Republican of Kentucky, said the bill would impose unfair burdens on nonprofit organizations.
Senator Malcolm Wallop of Wyoming, a Republican who voted against the earlier versions of the bill when 95 senators voted for it, then objected and blocked efforts to change the bill.
So when the second vote on ending debate was taken, it changed little from Thursday's 52-to-46 outcome. The effort now drew 56 votes, from 47 Democrats and 9 Republicans, while 7 Democrats and 34 Republicans voted to continue the filibuster. Because the gifts ban involved Senate rules, ending debate required a two-thirds vote of those present.
A few hours later, Senator John B. Breaux of Louisiana, a Democrat who once asserted that although his vote could not be bought, it could be rented, asked the Senate if it could be changed. Since changing his vote would not alter the outcome, the Senate agreed and made him the 42d vote to keep the filibuster going, at least in the Congressional Record, which will also say that only 55 senators voted to halt debate.
Senator Wallop was also the central figure in the filibuster against the California desert measure. His insistence on delaying a vote led Mr. Mitchell to warn that he would keep the Senate in session all weekend if necessary, but late tonight Senator Mitchell said a vote would be taken at 10 A.M. on Saturday, indicating an agreement had been reached.
The bill would designate about 7.5 million acres as wilderness and expand two national parks. If enacted, it would be the biggest measure involving public lands since the 1980 Alaska Lands Act.
The bill is a major project of Senator Dianne M. Feinstein of California, a Democrat in a tough battle for re-election, and Republicans have acknowledged that denying her the accomplishment is an element of their opposition to the bill.
But most of the day was spent on talk, and most of the talk concerned Democratic complaints, and Republican boasts, about obstructionism.
Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the majority leader, said: "Republicans have tried to derail any and every bill that has come along." And Senator Joseph R. Biden of Delaware, a Democrat who commutes by railroad daily from Wilmington, said people at the train station who used to ask him, "Why don't the Democrats have their act together?" were now asking, "Why don't the Republicans want anything to happen?"
Senator Phil Gramm, Republican of Texas, had an answer. He criticized Mr. Clinton and the Democrats on health care, the gasoline tax, the 1993 stimulus package and Haiti, and said, "I think, when the American people look at that list of items, that their answer is remarkably similar to the answer that the President accuses Republicans of giving, and that answer is no, no, no, no."

GRAPHIC: Photo: As the 103d Congress, the one that some critics said could not get anything done, moved toward adjournment, Representative Newt Gingrich, the deputy Republican leader, right, declared that Republicans had enjoyed a good session. "It is not obstructionist," he said of his party's tactics, contending that his forces had blocked bad legislation. Behind him was Representative Dick Armey, Republican of Texas. (Vince Ricardel for The New York Times)
 
Chart: "COUNTDOWN: Congress Winds to a Close"
 The 103d Congress crawled toward adjournment yesterday with few votes. Shortly after midnight today, the House adjourned, but the Senate was to keep working. Republican leaders said they had succeeded in killing many bills, but Speaker of the House Thomas S. Foley said, "Congress has done extraordinary, even historic work."
 
LOBBYING: The most decisive action of the day was a vote not to vote on legislation that would have required lobbyists to register and report who pays them and would also have prohibited members of Congress from accepting gifts and golf junkets. The measure died after the Senate fell short of the votes needed to break a Republican-led filibuster against the bill, which the House had already passed.
 
ENVIRONMENT: The House approved a compromise version of a bill to protect millions of acres of desert in California, creating the largest wilderness area outside Alaska. The Senate began to debate the measure, but opponents immediately began to delay a vote using procedural rules, including requiring the Senate's clerk to read the entire 61-page bill aloud. Late last night, the Senate majority leader, George J. Mitchell, said a vote would be taken at 10 A.M. today.
 
DRINKING WATER: A bill that would have revised the Federal standards for the purity of municipal water supplies died when negotiators from the House and Senate failed to agree on a compromise. One difference was over how and when the Environmental Protection Agency should weigh the costs and benefits of its regulations. The House bill would have relaxed the standards for testing water and would have exempted smaller towns from some regulations. The Senate bill contained provisions that the House and environmental groups would not accept. The bill's death means that $1.3 billion in Federal aid to cities and states for water purification will not be available in the coming year.
 
BANKRUPTCY: The Senate approved the first comprehensive overhaul of the nation's bankruptcy laws in 16 years, setting rules that would make it easier for individuals to repay their debts on installment plans and harder for big corporate debtors to avoid their creditors. The House passed the same bill on Wednesday night, so the Senate vote sends the bill to President Clinton. Administration officials said he planned to sign it. The bill was welcomed by banks, savings and loans and other creditors. The new legislation imposes many time limits on various steps in the bankruptcy process to hasten the flow of cases through courts and prevent the dissipation of debtors' assets to legal fees.
 
CONGRESSIONAL EMPLOYEES: The House voted, 348 to 3, to apply Federal workplace laws, like those on discrimination and occupational safety, to itself. The Senate failed to act on a similar proposal.
 
DIETARY SUPPLEMENTS: The House passed a compromise bill that would limit but not forbid health claims on the labels and in the advertising of vitamins and supplements, which are taken by tens of millions of people daily. Early today, the Senate approved the bill as well. The legislation is a compromise that would require a strict standard of proof if the labels or advertisements made disease-prevention or cure claims, but would still permit claims about how vitamins and supplements might help promote good health.
 
OTHER MEASURES: Late Thursday and early yesterday, Congress approved and sent to the President the following legislation:
*A bill that would raise the threshold for the "nanny tax." Household employers, starting this tax year, would have to pay Social Security and Medicare taxes on any worker earning at least $1,000 a year, up from $50 a quarter. Teen-aged baby sitters would be exempt.
*A bill that would give schools flexibility in how they meet new requirements to cut fat in school lunches, rather than forcing them to follow a nutrition analysis system mandated by the Agriculture Department.

HEADLINE: South Korea President Lashes Out at U.S.

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, Oct. 7

 BODY:
After weeks of watching in silent frustration as the United States tries to negotiate a halt to North Korea's nuclear program, President Kim Young Sam of South Korea lashed out at the Clinton Administration today in an interview for what he characterized as a lack of knowledge and an overeagerness to compromise.
Mr. Kim said that he supported the Administration's efforts and that ties between Seoul and Washington were strong. But Mr. Kim directly attacked Washington's basic stance in the discussions with North Korea as naive and overly flexible. He said that the North Korean Government was on the verge of an economic and political crisis that could sweep it from power, and that Washington should therefore stiffen its position in pressing Pyongyang to abandon its suspected nuclear weapons program. 
 Diplomats and senior officials in the Administration have maintained that such pressure might drive North Korea's Communist Government into a corner and bring the two Koreas dangerously close to a war, not a deal. Those fears have grown in the past week, with the talks in Geneva reportedly at an impasse.
But Mr. Kim expressed deep doubts about whether the North Koreans could be trusted to live up to any agreements and whether the American negotiators understood that possibility.
"We should resolve the issue through dialogue," he said. "There is nothing wrong with that. The problem is we think we know North Korea better than anyone. We have spoken with North Korea more than 400 times. It didn't get us anywhere. They are not sincere." He added, "The important thing is that the United States should not be led on by the manipulations of North Korea."
In an hourlong interview, Mr. Kim was clearly unhappy that South Korea had been denied any position in the negotiations in Geneva and yet has been criticized for counseling toughness. This marks the latest turn in South Korea's policy toward the nuclear issue. Earlier this year, some South Korean officials were warning that the United States was taking too hard a line, but since the death of the North's longtime ruler, Kim Il Sung, Seoul is taking an increasingly tough position.
Mr. Kim explained that compromises might prolong the life of the North Korean Government and would send the wrong signal to its leaders. "We should not make more concessions in the future," he declared. "Time is on our side."
He painted a bleak picture of the economic situation in North Korea and questioned whether the negotiations could really achieve anything. More important, he placed his own views in stark contrast to those of the American delegation in Geneva, a rare occasion when discord received more emphasis than the common ground.
"If the United States wants to settle with a half-baked compromise and the media wants to describe it as a good agreement, they can," he said. "But I think it would bring more danger and peril."
Mr. Kim also expressed bitterness over the Administration's failure to raise the issue of human rights with Pyongyang, and its treatment of the Government as a suitable dialogue partner rather than a ruthless and deeply isolated dictatorship.
"Despite the fact that the United States is making an issue of human rights in Haiti and Cuba and China, it is not in North Korea, where the situation is worse," he said. "I can't really understand the logic."
In a separate interview, Lee Hong Koo, the Minister of National Unification, complained about the Administration and its lead negotiator in Geneva, Robert L. Gallucci, an Assistant Secretary of State.
Mr. Lee praised Mr. Gallucci for changing his views recently and becoming tougher, but he argued that the United States was weakening its position by relying not on Korea experts, but experts in nuclear nonproliferation.
He was also critical of Secretary of State Warren Christopher for not having visited South Korea or focused much publicly on the crisis on the Korean peninsula.
Perhaps the sharpest difference between the United States and South Korean Governments, evident in the interviews today, is their view on war, something Washington has sought to avoid at all costs.
"We don't want war," Mr. Lee said. "Nevertheless, the North Koreans must realize war doesn't mean the end of history, not for us anyway. But it does for their system."
The tough comments underscored the extremely sensitive position in which the United States finds itself after months of uncertain nuclear diplomacy. After the countries marched toward a confrontation earlier this year, former President Jimmy Carter went to Pyongyang in June and brokered a deal that led tothe current negotiations.
Kim Il Sung, North Korea's absolute ruler for the last four decades, died suddenly on July 8 after the agreement was reached, but the negotiations took place anyway. In August, a framework for a broader deal was hammered out. Washington agreed to provide modern light-water reactors for generating electricity if North Korea would abandon its existing nuclear facilities, which produce large amounts of weapon-grade plutonium.
The United States also insisted that North Korea agree to open its nuclear sites to international inspections, a means of certifying whether it had already extracted enough plutonium to build one or more bombs.
The deal quickly looked less promising when the North Koreans demanded an interim supply of electrical power, the right to choose the light-water reactor and a payment of some $2 billion in cash. They also rejected the idea of the inspections, bringing the talks to their latest impasse.

HEADLINE: Three Years After Gulf War, Sense of Siege Grips Kuwait

BYLINE: By CHRIS HEDGES, Special to The New York Times; The writer of this article left Kuwait before Iraq began moving troops toward the Iraqi-Kuwaiti border yesterday.

DATELINE: KUWAIT CITY, Oct. 5

 BODY:
With its gleaming high-rises, lavish shopping malls and well-groomed beltways, Kuwait looks as if it has lifted itself out of the destruction and morass of war. But the glitter and affluence mask a country that has lost faith in itself, lives in fear of a resurgent Iraq and sees a future darkened by forces beyond its control.
"There is a scramble to get another passport, to teach children other languages besides Arabic and to keep our money outside the country," a leading businessman, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said in Kuwait City this week. "There is a feeling that if Iraq to the north does not get us, the fundamentalists, backed by a growing movement in Saudi Arabia, will." 
 Three and a half years after the Persian Gulf war, the sense of insecurity was palpable on a recent visit to the country. It has driven many Kuwaitis into the arms of Islamic fundamentalists, who preach that the country has been punished for its moral laxity and loss of faith. It has also fueled a sense of hopelessness among other young Kuwaitis, who see no future in their country, look to the West and revel in American popular culture and habits.
"The war acted like a volcano," said Dr. Haya al-Mughni, a sociologist. "It spread out and exaggerated extremes that already existed within the society before occupation."
The United Nations sanctions against Iraq, still in place, have done little to change Baghdad's behavior.
Iraq refuses to acknowledge Kuwait's sovereignty, as demanded by the United Nations, and still refers to the emirate as the 19th province. The Kuwait-Iraq border, newly demarcated by the United Nations after the war, has not been recognized by Baghdad. And Iraqi officials deny all knowledge of some 600 missing Kuwaitis, many of whom were arrested by Iraqi security forces during Iraq's seven-month occupation of Kuwait.
Senior Iraqi officials warned the United Nations this week that they would "retaliate" if the Security Council, as expected, decides on Monday to maintain economic sanctions. Their meaning was unclear.
"There has been no change in the Iraqi stance toward Kuwait since the war," said Abbas Habib Mounar al-Mussein, chairman of the Kuwaiti Parliament's Defense and Interior Committee. "As long as Saddam Hussein is in power we are concerned."
Kuwait has budgeted $11 billion for arms over the next decade. The United States has large stockpiles of military equipment in the country and will soon have 100 military advisers training the Kuwaiti Army.
But many diplomats worry that equipment and training may not be enough to either hold off any invading forces for even a few days or restore public confidence.
"Without combat experience and the will to fight," said a Western diplomat who works with the military, "it will all fall apart. All we can do is equip and train. The rest is up to them."
The siege mentality is illustrated along the desert border with Iraq. A huge trench running the 120-mile length of the border separates the countries. The trench, which must be constantly maintained because of blowing sand, is 9 feet deep and 15 feet wide. It is topped on the Kuwaiti side with a 12-foot-high sand hill that is frequently sprayed with tar to show footprints. Kuwaiti police officers in trucks with tinted windows race back and forth on an asphalt road along the hill, watching for infiltrators.
"The Iraqis have tried to send over many assassination teams to carry out missions such as the one designed to murder President Bush during his visit last year," said an Interior Ministry official as he stood looking toward an Iraqi police post. "Nothing has changed."
But Iraq is only one of many troubles besetting Kuwait. The ruling al-Sabah family, discredited in the eyes of many Kuwaitis when some members fled the invading Iraqis, promised to liberalize the political system and the press. Parliament was revived in 1992 elections and political reforms were debated.
"It was the new democratic leadership that many hoped would be able to restore Kuwaitis' faith in the Government and self-confidence," a Western diplomat said, "but the ruling family has only been stalling for time."
Members of Parliament have mounted a fierce campaign to prosecute officials, many from the ruling family, suspected of skimming billions of dollars from the Government or losing it through mismanagement.
The press carries reports on official corruption and ineffective leadership that would be unthinkable in neighboring Saudi Arabia. But power remains in the hands of the ruling family, which failed to prepare the country's defenses. Parliament's inquiries into the behavior of senior officials have so far yielded little. And the political reforms, which would have given women the vote and allowed political parties to form, have sputtered out.
The most powerful political figure is Prime Minister Sheik Saad Abdullah al-Sabah, who is also the Crown Prince. The Prime Minister can only be appointed or removed by the Emir, Sheik Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah.
"As long as the al-Sabah family is able to handle the public finances," said Mubarak al-Adwani, a political analyst, "it will keep tremendous power within its hands."
The frustration with the slow pace of reform has seen many Kuwaitis, and especially those under 21, who make up 60 percent of the population, give up on the political system. An increasing number embrace Islamic fundamentalists, who have the largest single bloc in Parliament. Mosques that were empty before the war are now overflowing during Friday prayers, and the movement has contacts with other militant groups in the region.
"The fundamentalists promise their followers that they are part of a movement that is destined by history to succeed," Dr. Mughni said.
In contrast, many young, Westernized Kuwaitis see their future in the United States and embrace American pop culture with gusto. One recent night dozens of young Kuwaitis, dressed as if for an audition on MTV, crammed into a luxury penthouse overlooking the coast. Rap music pulsated from a powerful stereo system that could be heard blocks away. Couples danced or threw back shot glasses of tequila, although alcohol is banned.
"Kuwait is like West Berlin during the cold war," shouted a young man, who did not want to be identified. "We know at any moment we could be finished off, so we drink and party until they come to get us."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
 
The nation's unemployment rate fell to a four-year low in September. But the report did not alarm financial markets because the job growth was not strong enough to force the Federal Reserve to move immediately on interest rates. [Page 39.] While job growth was seen in all regions of the country, the unemployment rate in New Jersey rose to 6.7 percent, from 6 percent. In New York State, the rate fell to 6.2 percent, from 6.9 percent. [47.]
An overhaul of the nation's bankruptcy laws was approved by the Senate. The measure would set new rules making it easier for individuals to repay their debts on installment plans and harder for big corporate debtors to avoid their creditors. [39.]
Recycling is becoming a big business as economic recovery and greater mill capacity increase demand for raw material. Old corrugated boxes, waste paper, plastics and steel cans have been finding new and lucrative markets. [1.]
The F.C.C. may let cable operators charge what they want for new channels or services as long as they do not dilute programming protected under current price restrictions. [39.]
 
International
 
U.S. executives remain wary about investing in South Africa, despite their applause for President Nelson Mandela earlier this week. Currency exchange controls, trade barriers and a militant labor force are seen as the chief obstacles. [39.]
 
Companies
 
Shares of Broderbund Software jumped after the company reported higher-than-expected earnings and a stock split . [39.]
The stocks of Kemper and Conseco tumbled after Conseco said it was changing the financing for its acquisition of Kemper. [41.]
A Tenneco subsidiary signed agreements to develop two natural-gas-fired power plants in central Chile. [41.]
Thirteen bidders for F.C.C. licenses defaulted. The licenses for interactive video services will be re-auctioned. [41.]
 
Markets
 
Stocks rallied. Buyers were encouraged by the employment report, which lessened expectations of an immediate increase in interest rates. The Nasdaq composite index rose 5.77 points. [40.]
Treasury prices rose after the Government reported a rise in payrolls that was below market expectations. [47.]
The dollar strengthened, rising above 100 Japanese yen. The dollar was bolstered by gains in stocks and bonds and by a report showing a reduction in Japan's trade surplus. [48.]
Crude oil prices jumped before falling back. Traders bet a move by Iraqi forces toward Kuwait would not lead to an invasion. [48.]
 
Your Money
 
Peter Lynch has kept his investment approach startingly simple. Mr. Lynch, who produced huge gains as manager of Fidelity's Magellan Fund before going into semiretirement four years ago, has made some changes in his own investment portfolio. Now, the renowned stock picker even buys bonds. [37.]
Olde Discount is offering trades without commissions. But there is a catch: the transactions must be in stocks recommended by analysts at the deep discount brokerage firm. [37.]
Citibank customers can buy and sell stocks on cash machines. Citibank, which began offering the service this week, is the first bank in the country to let customers make such trades. [37.]
B'nai B'rith is sending members an offering this month for a group of mutual funds created for them. [38.]

HEADLINE: Denver Celebrates Opening of Its Light Rail Transit System

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: DENVER, Oct. 7

 BODY:
With no particular destination in mind, Helen Jackson got on board the train, stepped off 15 blocks later and got right in line for a train going the other way.
"I just came for the ride -- it's just so much fun," said Mrs. Jackson, a retired Government worker, adding with a conspiratorial whisper, "Of course, it helps that it's free." 
 The new light rail system opened in downtown Denver today, a city that has had its share of transportation woes with a still-delayed new airport. Today was given over to civic celebration, as the streets downtown were filled with bands, balloons and clowns, and anyone who cared to stand in line for the train could ride without charge.
Starting Monday, passengers will pay 50 cents or $1, depending on the time of day, to board a train that winds along a 5.3-mile route in downtown Denver and some nearby residential neighborhoods. The cars, powered by electricity, run on street-level tracks.
The $116 million project, financed with bonds, has been promoted as a test to determine whether sufficient demand exists here for a more elaborate light rail system, one that would reach into the suburbs.
Some skeptics of the new transit system say light rail is more aesthetic than practical, an expensive way to prettify the usual screech and grind of workaday downtown Denver.
But besides lending a dash of charm, the light rail system is intended to reduce bus and automobile traffic in Denver, a place that lives with a cover of smog, known here as "the brown cloud."
The system opens at a time when downtown Denver is enjoying a renaissance. The new ball park, Coors Field, which will be home for the Colorado Rockies, is near completion. Old warehouses are being converted to condominiums, and a host of new restaurants and taverns have opened in an area called Lower Downtown. And the venerable Tattered Cover bookstore is opening a new branch downtown.
The city's transit officials predict that 14,000 passengers will ride the trains daily, which will depart every five minutes during rush hour and every 10 minutes at other times.
Given the embarrassment with the troubled airport, light rail officials delighted in crowing a bit today, as the project opened on time and on budget.
Motorists and pedestrians were still getting adjusted to the trains. In the last few weeks, as the rail cars ran tests through the city, there have been nine crashes.
In one accident, a driver was injured when a rail car slammed into the passenger side of an automobile, then dragged it across Speer Boulevard and onto a sidewalk.
Transit officials have embarked on a campaign to remind people not to pull out in front of moving trains. The cars reach speeds of 55 miles an hour. Each rail car weighs about 40 tons, and a car going 25 miles an hour needs about 115 feet to stop.
"If you see one coming toward you," a transit district tip sheet warns, "get out of the way!"
Each rail car is equipped with surveillance cameras to deter graffiti and other crime, and wheelchair ramps are located at each stop.
The transit district plans an 8.7 mile extension that could be ready in 1999. Officials are exploring several other light rail corridors, including a possible link to the new Denver International Airport.
No advertising is allowed on the rail cars, inside or out. To speed the transit, passengers will not be able to buy tickets on board. Each station will be equipped with a ticket vending machine.
For today, most people were riding the trains simply for fun, with transportation as a secondary concern.
"I'm taking this as far south as it goes, and then coming right back," said Ray Stevens, a 36-year-old unemployed computer technician. "It sure beats taking the bus."

HEADLINE: Unemployment Falls to 5.9%, Lowest in 4 Years

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7

 BODY:
The economy generated solid job growth in September as the unemployment rate fell to 5.9 percent, the lowest level in four years, the Labor Department reported today.
Hiring was substantial enough to swell payrolls by 239,000 and to indicate that the economy was expanding only a bit less briskly than during the unsustainably robust first half of the year. Payroll gains were revised upward for July and August. 
 Nonetheless, the strong employment report did not spook financial markets because the job growth was not vigorous enough, analysts said, to force the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates again immediately.
In its effort to slow growth and keep inflation in check, the Fed has raised its target for short-term interest rates five times this year. Inflation now is hovering around 3 percent annually.
In trading today, bond prices initially fell enough to push the interest rate on 30-year bonds up to 8 percent but a rally then began and the yield declined, ending at 7.90 percent, down from 7.95 percent on Thursday. Stock prices also rose. [Pages 40 and 47.]
Susan M. Phillips, a Fed governor, seemed to find little reason in today's report to change policy.
"It seemed to me to be about the same pace on average we've seen recently, so I didn't take much news out of it," she said, referring to the growth in payroll jobs.
The Clinton Administration welcomed the monthly job report, which is considered the most important single gauge of economic performance. Laura D'Andrea Tyson, head of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, called the report "additional evidence that the economy remains on a path of healthy expansion with modest inflation."
She expressed little concern that unemployment had dipped to a level that many economists consider low enough to cause accelerated pressure for higher wages. In August, the Congressional Budget Office estimated that that level would be 6 percent unemployment.
Ms. Tyson's own estimate is 5.9 percent to 6.3 percent, but she said in a briefing today that it would be silly to believe "the world has radically changed" at some precise rate regardless of other economic forces or circumstances.
Indeed, analysts have been particularly cautious in interpreting movements in the unemployment rate this year because a change in methodology that took effect in January has made it difficult to compare current rates with those of the past. Still, regarding today's number, the department said that a simulation using the old methodology produced the same rate, 5.9 percent, for September. The last time the rate was this low was in October 1990.
There was no doubt, however, that the job market continued to strengthen last month in all regions of the country. September also saw a decline in unemployment among black workers, to about the lowest rate since the mid-1970's.
Moreover, many more people in the thinning ranks of the unemployed had voluntarily left their last job, indicating confidence about finding a new one, while the number of people who lost their jobs or completed temporary ones fell sharply.
"The economy is still very much in full swing," said Alan M. Gayle, a Richmond-based analyst who currently heads the economic advisory committee of the American Bankers Association.
The department's survey of households, which is separate from the payroll survey that economists watch closely, showed a hefty gain of 462,000 jobs on top of August's 714,000 jump, reflecting what one official said seemed to be a catching up of this series after it had lagged behind earlier in the year. This growth was the main factor pushing the unemployment rate down in September.
The rate for adult men fell three-tenths of a point, to 5.1 percent, while the jobless rate for blacks tumbled eight-tenths of a point, to 10.7 percent, approaching the rate for Hispanic workers, which was unchanged last month at 10.2 percent.
Geographically, the West, where joblessness fell to 7 percent from 7.5 percent, showed the biggest such change, but unemployment also declined in the Northeast, to 6.2 percent from 6.4 percent; in the South, to 5.7 from 5.8, and in the Midwest, to 5 from 5.1 percent.
Among the largest industrial states for which figures were published today, the only change of clear statistical significance was in Florida, where the unemployment rate rose to 6.7 percent from 5.6. The rate for New Jersey rose seven-tenths of a point, to 6.7 percent, while the rate for New York fell by that amount, to 6.2 percent.
The California unemployment rate dropped to 8.3 percent last month, compared with 8.9 percent in August. Still, it remains among the highest nationwide.
Job gains as posted by the payroll survey were once again dominated by business and social services, though construction jobs rebounded 19,000 after holding steady in August and government jobs spurted 65,000, mostly temporary election workers and additions to the staff of state universities.
Higher interest rates, however, contributed to further job declines in mortgage banking, and real estate jobs were flat, after a big gain in August.
Factories shed 3,000 jobs, a trivial loss but a suggestion of a slowdown from the substantial advance of 39,000 in August. The length of the factory workweek and factory overtime were both unchanged, though at historically high levels.
The job gain at temporary-help agencies was 28,000, but for the second consecutive month that rise was less than the monthly average during the previous 12 months, the department noted.
"The economy's still growing, but at a more sustainable 2.5 percent rate," said Ben K. Han, an economist at Corestates Financial in Philadelphia.
Average hourly earnings rose three-tenths of 1 percent, to $11.16, today's report showed, while average weekly earnings rose six-tenths of 1 percent, to $386.14. Neither of these seemed unsettling, analysts said.
The number of so-called discouraged workers -- people who say they want jobs but have given up looking because they think it is futile -- was 521,000 last month compared with 489,000 in August. Unlike most other figures in the report, this is not adjusted for recurring seasonal variations.

HEADLINE: Investors Wary, Despite Mandela

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON 

 BODY:
South Africa's President, Nelson Mandela, seemed to cast a spell over more than 800 business executives at a dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel early this week, winning repeated standing ovations. Yet his main goal -- attracting more American investment to South Africa -- may be harder than wowing the crowd.
Although a growing number of United States companies are tentatively entering South Africa, many executives who listened to Mr. Mandela's appeal for investment say caution is likely to outweigh their initial excitement when it comes to plunking down enough money to open a factory that creates jobs. 
 Currency exchange controls, trade barriers, and a militant labor force are considered hindrances. Perhaps Mr. Mandela's biggest obstacle is competition for foreign capital from vibrant emerging markets in Southeast Asia and Latin America.
"The world is not breathless to invest anywhere," said Anthony J. F. O'Reilly, chief executive of the H. J. Heinz Company, who was host at a breakfast for Mr. Mandela and 30 executives on Tuesday in New York. "There are no magic wands around. South Africa is going to have to fight to make its case."
As a place to invest, South Africa is a hybrid: a first-world financial system with antiquated habits from years of isolation, paired with a population of almost 40 million, many of whom live in third-world conditions. As one economist said, South Africa's economy -- at about $100 billion -- is roughly the size of Maryland's.
In several meetings with executives this week, Mr. Mandela spoke knowledgeably about bringing down inflation, lifting currency controls and abandoning the idea of nationalizing industry -- a major plank in the African National Congress charter until 1991. All that was reassuring to his American listeners.
"There is no longer any basis for reticence," he said at the Waldorf. "South Africans have demonstrated with distinction their ability to manage political and economic change."
By last month, 169 United States companies had employees or direct investment in South Africa, up from 119 only a year ago but shy of the nearly 300 that were there in 1984, according to the Investor Responsibility Research Center.
For each company that is investing, several more are asking questions and visiting South Africa, said Daniel O'Flaherty, executive director of the United States-South Africa Business Council.
Yet executives at large American companies, from Xerox to Eastman Kodak, all in the process of expanding in South Africa, are tentative about making significant investments. Many voice interest in ventures that require only a small down payment, like selling or distributing an American product, rather than manufacturing it there.
"A token investment will be profitable," said Brian C. Henderson, senior vice president of Merrill Lynch & Company, one of several securities firms advising clients, but yet to open an office itself. "But the sizable investment will not really happen until the dual currency system and other problems are solved."
South Africa uses one exchange rate for ordinary commercial transactions and another for foreign financial investments. Many foreign businessmen are uncomfortable with this complex dual system. So far, though, fear of capital flight has deterred the Government from eliminating it.
Political stability is another unavoidable concern, even if the outlook is far brighter than a year ago or five years ago. Mr. Mandela is 76, and although business executives are encouraged by his choice of deputies, the potential for political unrest remains.
If many South Africans expected a quick embrace by American businesses in the euphoria that followed Mr. Mandela's remarkable political transition last spring, others point out that investment does not come in a day or a week or a month. It usually follows trade, sales and small experiments that grow.
"Anybody who expected the floodgates to open was not in touch with reality," said Secretary of Commerce Ronald H. Brown, who took a group of senior executives to South Africa last November and set up a business development committee to encourage investment and trade.
"I'm a real optimist about South Africa's future," Mr. Brown said, ticking off the nation's advantages to potential investors. "There's a commitment to a free market, good infrastructure, a stock market and a functioning economy."
Black American executives may be among those who move into the South African market most swiftly.
Chris Morris, president of an investment firm called the Savant Group of Santa Monica, Calif., helped arrange a $20 million partnership of a dozen black American investors with Pepsi-Cola for a bottling plant in South Africa run by black South Africans.
"We believe that the hesitation of others may be an advantage for us," said Mr. Morris, who wants to aim Pepsi sales in South Africa at the township population that has been under-served. "Whoever figures out how to effectively tap into that sector of the market is going to have a great opportunity."
Black South African consumers are likely to respond better to products sold by companies that are owned and run by blacks, Mr. Morris predicts. Echoing an idea voiced by many executives, Mr. Morris said he hoped Pepsi's operations in South Africa would also be used for business in neighboring countries.
"If you're going to make a play in the African continent, this is the place," he said.
Mr. O'Reilly of Heinz, who earlier this year bought a controlling stake in a newspaper group that owns The Star of Johannesburg, is optimistic about South Africa's prospects. Heinz is negotiating with local producers and is expected to begin producing food products next year.
"It won't be easy, and it won't be cheap, but we're determined to do it," Mr. O'Reilly said. "There is long-term opportunity and we want to be there."
Asked about the role of Mr. Mandela's visit in encouraging investment, Mr. O'Reilly said it would bring investors to the table.
"It's a Gandhi-like experience," he said of meeting the South African leader. "People will take a look at South Africa with a special commitment because of Mandela."
Ruth Harkin, president of the Overseas Private Investment Corporation, which this week announced programs of loan guarantees and other incentives aimed at producing corporate investment in South Africa, said about a dozen executives approached her after Mr. Mandela's speech at the Waldorf. "He spoke to them in their language, in their tone," she said. "Mandela touched them with his directness, his genuineness. I think they're going to be very responsive."
Not everyone was as optimistic. "No company will make an investment based on their enthusiasm for Nelson Mandela," said Mr. O'Flaherty of the business council. "I don't think sentiment is going to drive investment in South Africa."

GRAPHIC: Photo: President Nelson Mandela of South Africa, President Clinton and former Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar of the United Nations at a dinner in Washington this week. Mr. Clinton announced a $100 million fund to help business and a panel on South African energy, education and development. (Associated Press)
